Now so much did this new matter take up all [her]108-birdalone mind , that [she]108-birdalone thought no more of going up into the wood ; but though [she]108-birdalone had fain abided there long to see whatever might be seen , [she]108-birdalone deemed it would go ill with [her]108-birdalone did [the witch]394-the witch happen on [her]108-birdalone [there]215-there ; wherefore [she]108-birdalone turned about , and went back the way [she]108-birdalone had come , going very slowly and pondering the tidings . And ever [she]108-birdalone called to mind what [Habundia]97-habundia had said to [her]108-birdalone , that it was by [water]687-water [she]108-birdalone must flee , and wondered if [she]97-habundia had sent [her]108-birdalone this thing that [she]108-birdalone might escape therein ; so different as [her]108-birdalone going would be thereby to swimming [the lake]355-the lake with [her]108-birdalone wet body . Then again [she]108-birdalone thought , that before [she]108-birdalone might let [herself]108-birdalone hope this , it were best , if [she]108-birdalone might , to find out from [the witch]394-the witch what was the thing , and if [she]108-birdalone knew thereof . Yet at last [she]108-birdalone called to mind how [little patient of questions]690-little patient of questions was [[her]108-birdalone mistress]407-her mistress , and that if [she]108-birdalone were unheedful [she]108-birdalone might come to raise an evil storm about [her]108-birdalone . Wherefore [she]108-birdalone took this rede at the last , that [she]108-birdalone would keep all hidden in [her]108-birdalone own breast till [she]108-birdalone should see [Habundia]97-habundia again ; and meanwhile [she]108-birdalone might steal down thither from time to time to see if the thing still abode [there]215-there ; which [she]108-birdalone might the easier do by swimming if [she]108-birdalone chose [her]108-birdalone time heedfully , and go thither from [Rock Eyot]7-rock eyot , which now and again [she]108-birdalone visited . Chapter XI ~ Of [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s Guilt and the Chastisement Thereof By this [she]108-birdalone was come back to [the sandy bight]693-the sandy bight , and the sun was westering ; and [she]108-birdalone looked up toward [the house]311-the house and saw that it was the time of [their]695-their evening meal , for the blue smoke of the cooking fire was going up into the air . So [she]108-birdalone went thither speedily , and entered gay of seeming . [The witch]394-the witch looked on [her]108-birdalone doubtfully , but presently fell to speaking with [her]108-birdalone graciously as yesterday , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone was glad and easy of mind , and went about the serving of [her]108-birdalone ; for always [she]108-birdalone ate after [the dame]403-the dame ; and [the mistress]698-the mistress asked [her]108-birdalone of many matters concerning [the house]311-the house , and the gathering of stuff . So came the talk on the fishing of [the brook]700-the brook that ran before [their]695-their door , and how the trouts therein were but little , and not seldom none at all ; and even therewith came these words into [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s mouth , [she]108-birdalone scarce knew how : [[My]0-i lady]603-my lady , why do [we]695-their not fish [the lake]355-the lake , whereas there be shoal places betwixt [us]695-their and the eyots where lie many and great fish , as [I]0-i have seen when [I]0-i have been swimming thereover ? And now in [that same creek]703-that same creek whereas the serpent used to lurk when [I]0-i was little , [we]695-their have a thing come , which is made to swim on [the water]347-the water ; and [I]0-i , could [I]0-i have a long pole to shove withal . But no time [she]108-birdalone had to make an end , ere [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife sprang up and turned on [her]108-birdalone with a snarl as of an evil dog , and [her]108-birdalone face changed horribly : [her]108-birdalone teeth showed grinning , [her]108-birdalone eyes goggled in [her]108-birdalone head , [her]108-birdalone brow was all to - furrowed , and [her]108-birdalone hands clenched like iron springs . [Birdalone]108-birdalone shuddered back from [her]336-the witch - wife and cringed in mere terror , but had no might to cry out . [The witch]394-the witch hauled [her]108-birdalone up by the hair , and dragged [her]108-birdalone head back so that [her]108-birdalone throat lay bare before [her]108-birdalone all along . Then drew [the witch]394-the witch a sharp knife from [her]394-the witch girdle , and raised [her]394-the witch hand over [her]108-birdalone , growling and snarling like a wolf . But suddenly [she]394-the witch dropped the knife , [her]394-the witch hand fell to [her]394-the witch side , and [she]394-the witch fell in a heap on the floor and lay there hushed . [Birdalone]108-birdalone stood gazing on [her]108-birdalone , and trembling in every limb ; too confused was [she]108-birdalone to think or do aught , though some image off light through the open door passed before [her]108-birdalone : but [her]108-birdalone feet seemed of lead , and , as in an evil dream , [she]108-birdalone had no might to move [her]108-birdalone limbs , and the minutes went by as [she]108-birdalone stood there half dead with fear . At last , ( and belike it was no long while ) [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife came to [herself]336-the witch - wife again , and sat up on the floor , and looked all about [the chamber]292-the chamber , and when [her]336-the witch - wife eyes fell upon [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [she]336-the witch - wife said in a weak voice , yet joyfully ; Hah ! [thou]710-thou art there still , [[my]0-i good servant]711-my good servant ! Then [she]336-the witch - wife said : A sickness fell upon [me]0-i suddenly , as whiles it is wo nt ; but now am [I]0-i [myself]0-i again ; and presently [I]0-i have a word for [thee]108-birdalone . Therewith [she]336-the witch - wife rose up slowly , [Birdalone]108-birdalone helping [her]336-the witch - wife , and sat in [her]336-the witch - wife big chair silent awhile , and then [she]336-the witch - wife spake : [[My]0-i servant]577-my servant , [thou]710-thou hast for the more part served [me]0-i well : but this time [thou]710-thou hast done ill , whereas [thou]710-thou hast been spying on [my]0-i ways ; whereof may come heavy trouble but if [we]713-we look to it . Well is it for [thee]710-thou that [thou]710-thou hast none unto whom [thou]710-thou mightest babble ; for then must [I]0-i needs have slain [thee]710-thou here and now . But for this first time [I]0-i pardon [thee]710-thou , and [thou]710-thou hast escaped the wrath . [Her]336-the witch - wife voice was soft and wheedling ; but for [Birdalone]108-birdalone the terror had entered into [her]336-the witch - wife soul , and yet abode with [her]336-the witch - wife . [The witch - wife]336-the witch - wife sat a while , and then arose and went about [the chamber]292-the chamber , and came to a certain aumbry and opened it , and drew forth a little flasket of lead and a golden cup scored over with strange signs , and laid them on the board beside [her]336-the witch - wife chair , wherein [she]336-the witch - wife now sat down again , and spake once more , still in the same soft and wheedling voice : Yet , [[my]0-i servant]577-my servant , [thy]710-thou guilt would be required of [me]0-i , if [I]0-i let this pass as if today were the same as yesterday ; yea , and of [thee]710-thou also would it be required ; therefore it is a part of the pardon that [thou]710-thou be corrected : and the correction must be terrible to [thee]710-thou , that [thou]710-thou mayst remember never again to thrust [thyself]717-thyself into the jaws of death . And what may [I]0-i do to correct [thee]710-thou ? It shall be in a strange way , such as [thou]710-thou hast never dreamed of . Yet the anguish thereof shall go to thine heart â€™s root ; but this must [thou]710-thou needs bear , for [my]0-i good and thine , so that both [we]718-we may live and be merry hereafter . Go now , fill this cup with water from the spring and come back with it . [Birdalone]108-birdalone took the cup with a sinking heart , and filled it , and brought it back , and stood before [the witch more dead than alive]719-the witch more dead than alive . Then [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife took up the flasket and pulled out the stopple and betook it to [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and said : Drink of this now , a little sip , no more . And [the maiden]393-the maiden did so , and the liquor was no sooner down [her]393-the maiden gullet than [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife and [the chamber]292-the chamber , and all things about [her]393-the maiden , became somewhat dim to [her]393-the maiden ; but yet not so much so as that [she]393-the maiden could not see them . But when [she]393-the maiden stretched out [her]393-the maiden arm [she]393-the maiden could see it not at all , nor [her]393-the maiden limbs nor any other part of [her]393-the maiden which [her]393-the maiden eyes might fall upon . Then would [she]393-the maiden have uttered a lamentable wail , but the voice was sealed up in [her]393-the maiden and no sound came from [her]393-the maiden voice . Then [she]393-the maiden heard [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife how [she]336-the witch - wife said ( and yet [she]336-the witch - wife heard it as if [her]336-the witch - wife voice came from afar ) , Nay , [thou]725-thee canst not speak , and [thou]725-thee canst not see [thyself]726-thyself , nor may any other , save [me]0-i , and [I]0-i but dimly . But this is but part of what [I]0-i must lay upon [thee]725-thee ; for next [I]0-i must give [thee]725-thee a new shape , and that both [thyself]726-thyself and all other may see . But , before [I]0-i do that , [I]0-i must speak a word to [thee]725-thee , which [thy]725-thee new shape would not suffer the sense thereof to reach to thine heart . Hearken ! Chapter XII ~ The Words of [the Witch - Wife]100-the witch - wife to [Birdalone]108-birdalone Said [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife : When [thou]725-thee comest to [thyself]726-thyself ( for it is not [my]0-i will that [thou]725-thee shouldest never have thine own shape again ) , doubtless the first thing which [thou]725-thee shalt do with [thy]725-thee new - gained voice and [thy]725-thee new - gained wit shall be to curse [me]0-i , and curse [me]0-i again . Do as [thou]725-thee wilt herein ; but [I]0-i charge [thee]725-thee , disobey [me]0-i not , for that shall bring [thee]725-thee to [thy]725-thee bane . For if [thou]725-thee do not [my]0-i bidding , and if [thou]725-thee pry into [my]0-i matters , and lay bare that which [I]0-i will have hidden , then will it be imputed unto [thee]725-thee for guilt , and will [I]0-i , will [I]0-i not , [I]0-i must be avenged on [thee]725-thee even to slaying : and then is undone all the toil and pain [I]0-i have had in rearing [thee]725-thee into [a deft and lovely maiden]728-a deft and lovely maiden . Deem [thou]725-thee , then , this present anguish kind to [thee]725-thee , to keep [thee]725-thee that [thou]725-thee come not to nought . Now since [I]0-i have begun speaking , [I]0-i will go on ; for little heretofore have [I]0-i spoken to [thee]725-thee what was in [mine]0-i heart . Well [I]0-i wot that [thou]725-thee thinkest of [me]0-i but as of an evil dream , whereof none can aught but long to awake from it . Yet [I]0-i would have [thee]725-thee look to this at least ; that [I]0-i took [thee]725-thee from poverty and pinching , and have reared [thee]725-thee as faithfully as ever [mother]729-mother did to [child]283-child ; clemming [thee]725-thee never , smiting [thee]725-thee not so oft , and but seldom cruelly . Moreover , [I]0-i have suffered [thee]725-thee to go whereso [thou]725-thee wouldest , and have compelled [thee]725-thee to toil for nought but what was needful for [our]731-our two livelihoods . And [I]0-i have not stayed [thy]725-thee swimmings in [the lake]355-the lake , nor [thy]725-thee wanderings in [the wood]335-the wood , and [thou]725-thee hast learned bowshot there , till [thou]725-thee art now [a past - master in the craft]734-a past - master in the craft : and , moreover , [thou]725-thee art swift - foot as the best of the deer , and mayest over - run any one of [them]735-them whom [thou]725-thee wilt . Soothly a merry life hast [thou]725-thee had as [a child]229-a child , and merry now would be [thy]725-thee life , save for thine hatred of [me]0-i . Into a lovely lily - lass hast [thou]725-thee grown . That [I]0-i tell [thee]725-thee now , though [my]0-i wo nt has been to gird at [thee]725-thee for the fashion of [thy]725-thee body ; that was but the word of [the mistress]698-the mistress to the thrall . And now what awaiteth [thee]725-thee ? For [thou]725-thee mayst say : [I]0-i am lonely here , and there is [no man]534-no man to look on [me]0-i . Of what avail , therefore , is [my]0-i goodliness and shapeliness ? [Child]101-child , [I]0-i answer [thee]725-thee that the time is coming when [thou]725-thee shalt see here [a many of the fairest of [men]204-men]739-a many of the fairest of men , and then shalt [thou]725-thee be rather rose than lily , and fully come to womanhood ; and all those shall love and worship [thee]725-thee , and [thou]725-thee mayst gladden whom [thou]725-thee wilt , and whom [thou]725-thee wilt mayst sadden ; and no lack soever shalt [thou]725-thee have of the sweetness of love , or the glory of dominion . Think of it then ! All this is for [thee]725-thee if [thou]725-thee dwell here quietly with [me]0-i , doing [my]0-i will till [thy]725-thee womanhood hath blossomed . Wherefore [I]0-i beseech and pray [thee]725-thee put out of [thy]725-thee mind the thought of fleeing from [me]0-i . For if [thou]725-thee try it , one of two things shall be : either [I]0-i shall bring [thee]725-thee back and slay [thee]725-thee , or make [thee]725-thee live in misery of torment ; or else [thou]725-thee wilt escape , and then what will it be ? Dost [thou]725-thee know how it shall go with [thee]725-thee , coming poor and nameless , [an outcast]741-an outcast , into the world of [men]204-men ? Lust shalt [thou]725-thee draw unto [thee]725-thee , but scarce love . [I]0-i say [an outcast]741-an outcast shalt [thou]725-thee be , without worship or dominion ; [thy]725-thee body shall be a prey to ribalds , and when the fine flower thereof hath faded , [thou]725-thee shalt find that the words of [[thy]725-thee lovers]744-thy lovers were but mockery . That [no man]534-no man shall love [thee]725-thee , and [no woman]746-no woman aid [thee]725-thee . Then shall Eld come to [thee]725-thee and find [thee]725-thee at [home]373-home with Hell ; and Death shall come and mock [thee]725-thee for [thy]725-thee life cast away for nought , for nought . This is [my]0-i word to [thee]725-thee : and now [I]0-i have nought to do to [thee]725-thee save to change [thee]725-thee [thy]725-thee skin , and therein must [thou]725-thee do as [thou]725-thee canst , but it shall be no ugly or evil shape at least . But another time maybe [I]0-i shall not be so kind as to give [thee]725-thee a new shape , but shall let [thee]725-thee wander about seen by none but [me]0-i . Then [she]0-i took the cup and took water in the hollow of [her]0-i hand and cast it into [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s face , and muttered words withal ; and presently [she]0-i saw [herself]0-i indeed , that [she]0-i was become [a milk - white hind]748-a milk - white hind ; and [she]0-i heard and saw again , but not as [she]0-i , [the maiden]393-the maiden , was wo nt to hear and see ; for both [her]0-i hearing and seeing and [her]0-i thought was of a beast and [not of a maiden]750-not of a maiden . Said [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife : It is done now , till [I]0-i give [thee]725-thee grace again ; and now be off into [the field]752-the field ; but if [thou]725-thee stray more than half a bowshot from [the brook]700-the brook , it shall be the worse for [thee]725-thee . And now the day was done and night was come . Chapter XIII ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone Meeteth [the Wood - Woman]520-the wood - woman Again It was fifteen days thereafter that [Birdalone]108-birdalone awoke lying in [her]108-birdalone bed on a bright morning , as if all this had been but a dream . But [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife was standing over [her]108-birdalone and crying out : [Thou]725-thee art late , slug - a - bed , this fair - weather day , and the grass all spoiling for lack of the scythe . Off ! and down to [the meadow]499-the meadow with [thee]725-thee . [Birdalone]108-birdalone waited not for more words , but sprang out of bed , and had [her]108-birdalone work - a - day raiment on in a twinkling , and stayed but to wash [her]108-birdalone in [a pool of [the brook]700-the brook]757-a pool of the brook , and then was amidst the tall grass with the swathe falling before [her]108-birdalone . As [she]108-birdalone worked [she]108-birdalone thought , and could scarce tell whether joy at [her]108-birdalone present deliverance , or terror of [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife , were the greatest . Sore was [her]108-birdalone longing to go see [[her]108-birdalone friend]433-her friend in [the wood]335-the wood , but the haysel lasted more than a week , and when that was done , whether it were of set purpose or no , [the dame]403-the dame forgat [her]403-the dame other promise , to give [Birdalone]108-birdalone more holiday , and kept [her]108-birdalone close to [her]108-birdalone work about meadow and [acre]763-acre . Otherwise [[her]108-birdalone mistress]407-her mistress nowise mishandled or threatened [her]108-birdalone , though [she]108-birdalone had gone back to the surliness and railing which was [her]108-birdalone wo nt . At last , on a morning when [the dame]403-the dame had bidden [her]108-birdalone to nought of work , [Birdalone]108-birdalone took [her]108-birdalone bow in [her]108-birdalone hand and cast [her]108-birdalone quiver on [her]108-birdalone back , and went [her]108-birdalone ways into [the wood]335-the wood , and forgat not the tress of [Habundia]97-habundia â€™s hair ; but [she]108-birdalone had no need to use it , for when [she]108-birdalone was come to [the Oak of Tryst]767-the oak of tryst , straightway came [Habundia]97-habundia forth from the thicket , and now so like to [Birdalone]108-birdalone that it was a wonder , for as [[her]108-birdalone friend]433-her friend [she]108-birdalone bare bow and quiver , and green gown trussed up till [her]433-her friend knees were naked . So [they]769-they kissed and embraced , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone wept upon [[her]108-birdalone friend]433-her friend â€™s bosom , but was ashamed of the words which would have told [her]108-birdalone of [her]108-birdalone case . Then [Habundia]97-habundia set [her]433-her friend down upon the greensward , and sat down beside [her]433-her friend , and caressed [her]433-her friend and soothed [her]433-her friend ; then [she]97-habundia smiled on [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and said : [Thy]108-birdalone tale is partly told without words , and [I]0-i would weep for [thee]108-birdalone if [I]0-i might shed tears . But [thou]108-birdalone mayest tell [me]0-i wherefore [thou]108-birdalone didst suffer this ; though forsooth [I]0-i have an inkling thereof . Hast [thou]108-birdalone happened on [[the witch]394-the witch â€™s ferry]772-the witch â€™s ferry ? Even so it was , [sister]773-sister , quoth [Birdalone]108-birdalone . And therewith [she]97-habundia plucked up heart , and told [her]433-her friend all the tale of the vanishing of [her]97-habundia body and the skin - changing . And [Habundia]97-habundia answered : Well then , there is this to be said , that sooner or later this must have happened , for thereby lieth [thy]108-birdalone road of escape ; wherefore it is better sooner than later . But tell [me]0-i again : was [she]97-habundia fierce and rough in words with [thee]108-birdalone ? for what [she]97-habundia said to [thee]108-birdalone [thou]108-birdalone hast not yet told [me]0-i . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : In [her]97-habundia first fury , when [she]97-habundia was like to have slain [me]0-i , [she]97-habundia had no words , nought but wolfish cries . But thereafter [she]97-habundia spake unto [me]0-i strangely , yet neither fiercely nor roughly ; nay , it seemed to [me]0-i as if almost [she]97-habundia loved [me]0-i . And more than almost [she]97-habundia besought [me]0-i rather than commanded [me]0-i not to flee from [her]97-habundia . And [wert]774-wert [thou]108-birdalone beguiled by [her]97-habundia soft speech ? said [Habundia]97-habundia . Nowise to cast aside [my]0-i hope of escape , nay , not even in that hour , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; but amidst all the confusion and terror somewhat was [I]0-i moved to compassion on [her]97-habundia . Spake [Habundia]97-habundia , looking anxiously on [her]97-habundia : Dost [thou]108-birdalone deem that [thou]108-birdalone art somewhat cowed by what [she]97-habundia hath done to [thee]108-birdalone ? Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and flushed very red : Oh no , no ! Nought save death or bonds shall come betwixt [me]0-i and [my]0-i utmost striving for escape . That is better than well , said [Habundia]97-habundia ; but again , canst [thou]108-birdalone have patience a little , and be wary and wise the while ? So meseemeth , said [the maiden]393-the maiden . Said [Habundia]97-habundia : Again it is well . Now is the summer beginning to wane , and by [my]0-i rede [thou]108-birdalone shalt not try the flight until May is come again and well - nigh worn into June ; for [thou]108-birdalone wilt be bigger then , [little sister]776-little sister , and tidings are waxing that shall get matters ready for [thy]108-birdalone departure : moreover , [thou]108-birdalone must yet learn what [thou]108-birdalone hast to do meanwhile , and thereof shall [I]0-i tell [thee]108-birdalone somewhat as now . For [that boat]777-that boat , the thing which [thou]108-birdalone didst find , and for which [thou]108-birdalone didst suffer , is called the Sending Boat , and therein [[thy]108-birdalone mistress]553-thy mistress fareth time and again , [I]0-i deem to seek to some other of [her]553-thy mistress kind , but [I]0-i know not unto whom , or whereto . Hast [thou]108-birdalone noted of [her]553-thy mistress that whiles [she]553-thy mistress goeth away privily by night and cloud ? Yea , verily , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and this is one of the things which heretofore hath made [me]0-i most afraid . Said [Habundia]97-habundia : Well now , that [she]553-thy mistress wendeth somewhither in this ferry [I]0-i wot ; but as [I]0-i wot not whither , so also [I]0-i know not what [she]553-thy mistress doth with the Sending Boat to make it obey [her]553-thy mistress ; whereas , though [I]0-i know all things of [the wood]335-the wood , [I]0-i know but little of [the lake]355-the lake . Wherefore , though there be peril to [thee]781-thee therein , follow [her]553-thy mistress twice or thrice when [she]553-thy mistress riseth up for this faring , and note closely what is [her]553-thy mistress manner of dealing with the said Sending Boat , so that [thou]108-birdalone mayst do in like wise . Wilt [thou]108-birdalone risk the smart and the skin - changing , or even if it were the stroke of the knife , to gather this wisdom ? And thereafter [thou]108-birdalone shalt come hither and tell [me]0-i how [thou]108-birdalone hast sped . With a good heart will [I]0-i , [dear sister]782-dear sister , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone . Then [Habundia]97-habundia kissed [her]782-dear sister and said : It is a joy to [me]0-i to see [thee]782-dear sister so valiant , but herein may [I]0-i help [thee]782-dear sister somewhat ; here is a gold finger - ring , see [thou]108-birdalone ! fashioned as a serpent holding [his]783-his tail in [his]783-his mouth ; whenso [thou]108-birdalone goest on this quest , set [thou]108-birdalone this same ring on the middle finger of [thy]108-birdalone left hand , and say [thou]108-birdalone above [thy]108-birdalone breath at least : To left and right , Before , behind , Of [me]0-i be sight As of the wind ! And nought then shall be seen of [thee]108-birdalone even by [one who standeth close beside]784-one who standeth close beside . But wear not the ring openly save at such times , or let [the witch]394-the witch have sight thereof ever , or [she]394-the witch will know that [thou]108-birdalone hast met [me]0-i . Dost [thou]108-birdalone understand , and canst [thou]108-birdalone remember ? Laughed [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and took the ring and set it on [her]108-birdalone finger , and spake aloud even as [Habundia]97-habundia had given [her]108-birdalone the words . Then quoth [Habundia]97-habundia , laughing : Now have [I]0-i lost [[my]0-i friend]304-my friend and [sister]773-sister , for [thou]108-birdalone art gone , [Birdalone]108-birdalone . Take off the ring , sweetling , and get [thee]108-birdalone to thine hunting , for if [thou]108-birdalone come [home]373-home empty - handed there will be flyting awaiting [thee]108-birdalone , or worse . So [Birdalone]108-birdalone took off the ring and came back to sight again laughing ; then [the wood - woman]520-the wood - woman kissed [her]108-birdalone and turned [her]520-the wood - woman heels to [her]108-birdalone , and was gone ; but [Birdalone]108-birdalone strung [her]108-birdalone bow , and got to [her]108-birdalone woodcraft , and presently had a brace of hares , wherewith [she]108-birdalone went back [home]373-home to [the dame]403-the dame ; who indeed girded at [her]108-birdalone for [her]108-birdalone sloth , and [her]108-birdalone little catch in so long a while ; but there it ended . Chapter XIV ~ Of [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s Fishing Now were the days wearing toward wheat - harvest , and nought befel to tell of , save that on a morn [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife called [Birdalone]108-birdalone to [her]336-the witch - wife , and said : Now is little to be done till the wheat is ready for the hook , and [thy]108-birdalone days are idle ; or what is that word that fell from [thee]108-birdalone that other day , that there be good swims for fish about the eyots ? Canst [thou]108-birdalone swim across bearing thine angle , and back again therewith , and [thy]108-birdalone catch withal ? Yea , certes , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone gaily ; with one hand [I]0-i may swim gallantly , or with [my]0-i legs alone , if [I]0-i stir [mine]0-i arms ever so little . [I]0-i will go straightway if [thou]108-birdalone wilt , [lady]493-lady ; but give [me]0-i a length of twine so that [I]0-i may tie [my]0-i catch about [my]0-i middle when [I]0-i swim back again . Therewith [she]336-the witch - wife went forth lightly to fetch [her]336-the witch - wife angle , which was in [a shed without]794-a shed without ; but just as [she]336-the witch - wife took it in [her]336-the witch - wife hand , a sudden thought came to [her]336-the witch - wife , so wary as [she]336-the witch - wife was grown . [She]336-the witch - wife undid the bosom of [her]336-the witch - wife gown , and took forth [her]336-the witch - wife serpent - ring ; for [she]336-the witch - wife bore it next to [her]336-the witch - wife skin , made fast to the bosom of [her]336-the witch - wife smock ; but now [she]336-the witch - wife hid it carefully in the thickest of [her]336-the witch - wife brow - hair , which was very thick and soft . Withal the tress of [Habundia]97-habundia â€™s hair [she]336-the witch - wife bore ever mingled with [her]336-the witch - wife own . No sooner had [she]336-the witch - wife done it , but [she]336-the witch - wife was glad ; for [she]336-the witch - wife heard [the dame]403-the dame calling [her]336-the witch - wife , who , when [she]336-the witch - wife came to [the house]311-the house - door , spake and said : Now shall [I]0-i fare with [thee]336-the witch - wife down to [the water]347-the water , and look to [thy]336-the witch - wife garments lest they be fouled by some straying beast . And therewith [she]336-the witch - wife looked curiously on [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and knit [her]336-the witch - wife brows when [she]336-the witch - wife saw that [the maiden]393-the maiden changed countenance in nowise . Down to [the water]347-the water went [they]800-they , and [the witch]394-the witch sat down close to where [Birdalone]108-birdalone should take [the water]347-the water , and watched [her]393-the maiden do off [her]393-the maiden raiment , and eyed [her]393-the maiden keenly when [she]393-the maiden was bare , but said nought . [Birdalone]108-birdalone turned [her]108-birdalone head as [she]108-birdalone stood knee - deep , and said : How long shall [I]0-i abide , [lady]493-lady , if [I]0-i have luck ? As long as [thou]804-thou wilt , said [the dame]403-the dame : most like [I]0-i shall be gone by then [thou]804-thou comest back , even if [thou]804-thou be away no long while . Fell [Birdalone]108-birdalone to swimming then , and when [she]108-birdalone was more than half over , [the witch , stirring no more than need was]806-the witch , stirring no more than need was , got hold of [her]108-birdalone raiment , which was but the old grey coat over a smock , and ransacked it , but found nought , as well [ye]807-ye may wot . And when [she]806-the witch , stirring no more than need was had done , [she]806-the witch , stirring no more than need was sat down again in heavy mood as it seemed , and watched [Birdalone]108-birdalone swimming , and when [she]806-the witch , stirring no more than need was beheld [her]108-birdalone body come forth out of the water , and pass out of sight amongst the flowers of [the eyot]633-the eyot , [she]806-the witch , stirring no more than need was arose and went [her]806-the witch , stirring no more than need was ways [home]373-home . [Birdalone]108-birdalone looked through the willow - boughs , and saw [her]108-birdalone turn away ; then [she]108-birdalone fared to [her]108-birdalone fishing with a smile , and soon had plenteous catch from under the willow - boughs . Then , whereas the day was very calm and fair , and [the dame]403-the dame had given [her]108-birdalone holiday , [she]108-birdalone wandered about [the eyot]633-the eyot , and most in a little wood of berry - trees , as quicken and whitebeam and dog - wood , and sported with the birds , who feared [her]108-birdalone not , but came and sat on [her]108-birdalone shoulders , and crept about [her]108-birdalone feet . [She]108-birdalone went also and stood a while on [the southern shore]812-the southern shore , and looked on the wide water dim in the offing under the hot - weather haze , and longed to be gone beyond it . Then [she]108-birdalone turned away , and to [the other shore]813-the other shore , and gat [her]108-birdalone fish and strung them on the string , and made them fast to [her]108-birdalone middle , and so took the water back again to [the yellow strand]814-the yellow strand , where now was [no one]815-no one awaiting [her]108-birdalone . But before [she]108-birdalone did on [her]108-birdalone garments , [she]108-birdalone looked on them , and saw that they lay not as [she]108-birdalone had left them , whereby [she]108-birdalone knew well that [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife had handled them . Amidst all this the day was wearing to an end , and again [she]108-birdalone saw the smoke of the cooking - fire going up into the air from the chimney of [the house]311-the house ; and [she]108-birdalone smiled ruefully , thinking that [the witch]394-the witch might yet find an occasion for ransacking [her]108-birdalone raiment . But [she]108-birdalone plucked up heart , and came [home]373-home with [her]108-birdalone catch , and [the dame]403-the dame met [her]108-birdalone with a glum face , and neither praised [her]108-birdalone nor blamed [her]108-birdalone , but took the fish silently . Such ending had that day . Chapter XV ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone Weareth [Her]108-birdalone Serpent - Ring After this [she]108-birdalone went once and again fishing on to [Green Eyot]6-green eyot by the bidding of [the dame]403-the dame , who went not again to [the shore]344-the shore with [her]108-birdalone . These times [she]108-birdalone had half a mind to go see [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat , but durst not , lest the thing itself might have life enough to tell of [her]108-birdalone . And now was come the time of wheat - harvest , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone must wear [her]108-birdalone days swinking in [the acre - land]454-the acre - land , clad but in smock and shoes ; and the toil was hard , and browned [her]108-birdalone skin and hardened [her]108-birdalone hands , but it irked [her]108-birdalone not , for [the witch]394-the witch let [her]108-birdalone work all alone , and it was holiday unto [the maiden]393-the maiden if [[her]108-birdalone mistress]407-her mistress were not anigh , despite those words which had somewhat touched [her]108-birdalone heart that other day . But when wheat - getting was done , there was again rest for [her]108-birdalone body , and swimming withal and fishing from the eyot by [the witch]394-the witch â€™s leave . And again by [her]108-birdalone own leave [she]108-birdalone went to seek [Habundia]97-habundia in [the wood]335-the wood , and spent a happy hour with [her]97-habundia , and came back with a fawn which [she]108-birdalone had shot , and so but barely saved [her]108-birdalone skin from the twig - shower . Then yet again [she]108-birdalone went into [the wood]335-the wood on [the witch]394-the witch â€™s errand as well as [her]108-birdalone own , and was paid by [[her]108-birdalone friend]433-her friend â€™s sweet converse , and by nought else save the grudging girding of [[her]108-birdalone mistress]407-her mistress . But on a night when September was well in , and the sky was moonless and overcast , somewhat before midnight [the dame]403-the dame came and hung over [Birdalone]108-birdalone as [she]108-birdalone lay abed , and watched to see if [she]108-birdalone waked ; forsooth [the witch]394-the witch â€™s coming had waked [her]108-birdalone ; but even so [she]108-birdalone was wary , and lay still , nor changed [her]108-birdalone breathing . So [the witch]394-the witch turned away , but even therewith [Birdalone]108-birdalone made a shift to get a glimpse of [her]394-the witch , and this [she]108-birdalone saw thereby , that the semblance of [her]394-the witch was changed , and that [she]394-the witch bore the self - same skin wherewith [she]394-the witch had come to [Utterhay]1-utterhay , and which [she]394-the witch had worn twice or thrice afterwards when [she]394-the witch had an errand thither . [The witch]394-the witch now glided swiftly to the door , and out into the night . [Birdalone]108-birdalone lay still a little , lest [she]108-birdalone should fall into a trap , and then arose very quietly and did on [her]108-birdalone smock , which lay ever under [her]108-birdalone pillow with the ring sewn thereto again , and so went out adoors also , and deemed [she]108-birdalone saw [the witch]394-the witch some way on ahead ; but it was nothing for [her]108-birdalone light feet to overtake [her]108-birdalone . So [she]108-birdalone stayed to take the ring from [her]108-birdalone smock , and set it on [her]108-birdalone finger ; then in a low voice [she]108-birdalone said : To left and right , Before , behind , Of [me]0-i be sight As of the wind ! Then boldly [she]108-birdalone sped on , and was soon close on the heels of [the witch]394-the witch , who made [her]394-the witch way to [the edge of [the lake]355-the lake]840-the edge of the lake , and then turned east , and went even as [Birdalone]108-birdalone had gone when [she]108-birdalone came across [the Sending Boat]9-the sending boat . So fared [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife straight to [the creek - side]843-the creek - side , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone must needs stick close to [her]336-the witch - wife , or [she]336-the witch - wife had known nought , so black was the night amongst the alder - boughs . But [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife fumbled about a while when [she]336-the witch - wife was stayed by [the creek]675-the creek , and presently drew somewhat from under [her]336-the witch - wife cloak , and [the maiden]393-the maiden saw that [she]336-the witch - wife was about striking flint upon steel , and quaked somewhat , lest [her]336-the witch - wife charm had played [her]336-the witch - wife false . Presently the tinder quickened , and [the dame]403-the dame had lighted a lantern , which [she]403-the dame held up , peering all about ; and full [she]403-the dame looked on the place whereas was [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and made no show of seeing [her]403-the dame , though well - nigh [the maiden]393-the maiden looked for it to see [her]403-the dame drop the lantern and spring on [her]403-the dame . Now [the witch , holding the lantern aloft]849-the witch , holding the lantern aloft , steps over the gunwale of [the boat]850-the boat , and sits down on the thwart ; and it was a near thing but that [Birdalone]108-birdalone followed [her]849-the witch , holding the lantern aloft into [the boat]850-the boat , but [she]108-birdalone feared the getting forth again , so [she]108-birdalone but hung over it as close as [she]108-birdalone might . Then [she]108-birdalone saw [the witch]394-the witch draw out of [her]394-the witch girdle that sharp little knife which [Birdalone]108-birdalone had seen raised against [her]108-birdalone own throat ; and then [the witch]394-the witch bared [her]394-the witch arm , and pricked it till the blood sprang from that barren white skin ; thereat [she]394-the witch stood up , and went to the bows of [the craft]682-the craft and hung over them , and drew [her]394-the witch arm to and fro over the stem to bloody it ; and went thereafter to the stern , and took blood into [her]394-the witch right hand and passed it over the place of [the steerage]855-the steerage ( for there was no rudder ) and came back and sat down on the thwart again ; and , so far as [Birdalone]108-birdalone might see , busied [herself]108-birdalone in staunching the little wound on [her]108-birdalone arm . Then deemed [Birdalone]108-birdalone that [she]108-birdalone knew what manner of paint was that which had made the rusty smears which [she]108-birdalone had seen on [the boat]850-the boat by daylight . But now as [the witch]394-the witch sat there , a harsh voice began to stir in [her]394-the witch throat , and then words came out of [her]394-the witch , and [she]394-the witch sang in a crow â€™s croak : The red raven - wine now Hast [thou]858-thou drunk , stern and bow ; Then wake and awake And the wonted way take ! The way of the Wender forth over the flood , For the will of [the Sender]859-the sender is blent with the blood . Therewithal began [the boat]850-the boat to stir , and anon it glided forth out of [the creek]675-the creek into [the waters of [the lake]355-the lake]862-the waters of the lake , and the light of the lantern died , and it was but a minute ere [Birdalone]108-birdalone lost all sight of it . [She]108-birdalone abode a little longer , lest perchance boat and [witch]864-witch might come back on [her]108-birdalone hands , and then turned and went swiftly back again . [She]108-birdalone would have drawn off [her]108-birdalone ring straightway , but the thought came on [her]108-birdalone , that [she]108-birdalone had seen [the witch]394-the witch depart in [her]394-the witch second semblance ; how if [she]394-the witch were abiding [her]394-the witch at [home]373-home in [her]394-the witch wonted skin ? So [she]108-birdalone came to [the house]311-the house even as [she]108-birdalone was , and opened the door , and looked in , quaking ; but there was no image of [a child of Adam therein]868-a child of adam therein , and no living thing , save the cat drowsing before the fire ; wherefore [Birdalone]108-birdalone took the ring from [her]108-birdalone finger and went to the hearth , and stirred up the cat with [her]108-birdalone foot till [he]869-he arose and fell to rubbing [himself]869-he against [her]108-birdalone legs , and [she]108-birdalone was fain of [him]869-he . Thereafter [she]108-birdalone made [her]108-birdalone ring fast to [her]108-birdalone smock again , and set the smock under [her]108-birdalone pillow as [her]108-birdalone wo nt was , and betook [herself]108-birdalone to bed , and fell asleep sweetly , leaving all troublous thoughts for the morrow ; and that the more as [she]108-birdalone was free of [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife for that night at least . Chapter XVI ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone Meeteth [Habundia]97-habundia Again ; and Learneth [Her]108-birdalone First Wisdom of [Her]108-birdalone When morning was , [Birdalone]108-birdalone arose , and longed sore to go into [the wood]335-the wood to seek [Habundia]97-habundia again , but durst not , lest [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife should come to hand again earlier than might be looked for . So [she]108-birdalone abode quiet and did what was toward near about [the house]311-the house . All that day [the witch]394-the witch came not back , nor the next ; but the morrow thereafter , when [Birdalone]108-birdalone arose , [she]108-birdalone found the wonted aspect of [[her]108-birdalone mistress]407-her mistress in [the wonted place]876-the wonted place , who , when [she]108-birdalone saw [the maiden]393-the maiden , greeted [her]108-birdalone , and was somewhat blithe with [her]108-birdalone ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone would have asked [her]108-birdalone leave to go to [the wood]335-the wood , but [she]108-birdalone trusted little in [her]108-birdalone unwonted soft mood ; which yet lasted so long that on the third day [she]108-birdalone [herself]108-birdalone bade [Birdalone]108-birdalone go take [her]108-birdalone pleasure in [the wood]335-the wood , and bear back with [her]108-birdalone what of venison [she]108-birdalone might . Forthwith went [Birdalone]108-birdalone as glad as might be , and met [[her]108-birdalone friend]433-her friend at [the Oak of Tryst]11-the oak of tryst , and told [her]433-her friend closely how [all]881-all had betid ; and [Habundia]97-habundia said : Here , then , [thou]882-thee hast learned how to sail [the lake]355-the lake . But hast [thou]882-thee learned enough to try the adventure and not to fail ? Even so [I]0-i deem , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; but this [I]0-i would say , that [meseemeth]884-meseemeth it better that [I]0-i follow [the witch]394-the witch down to [the boat]850-the boat one more time at least ; for this first time it was dark ; and moreover shall [I]0-i not be surer of the spell if [I]0-i hear it said oftener , lest it be not ever the same words ? What sayest [thou]882-thee ? [She]108-birdalone said : [Thou]882-thee art right herein , and , since the adventure may not be tried till next [June]92-june is at hand , there is time enough and to spare . And now for this hour that is [we]887-we need talk no more of it . Only , [my]0-i sweet , [I]0-i beseech [thee]882-thee be wary ; and above all suffer not [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife to set eye or hand on the ring . Truly [mine]0-i heart oft aches sorely for [thy]882-thee peril ; for therein the image of [thee]882-thee abideth rather as of [[my]0-i daughter]889-my daughter than [[my]0-i friend]304-my friend . Yea , now [thou]882-thee laughest , but kindly , so that the sound of [thy]882-thee laughter is as sweet music . But know that though [thou]882-thee art but [a young maiden]891-a young maiden , and [I]0-i in all wise like unto [thee]882-thee of aspect , yet have [I]0-i dwelt many and many a year upon [the earth]432-the earth , and much wisdom have learned . Trowest [thou]882-thee [me]0-i ? [Yea]893-yea , [yea]893-yea , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , with all [my]0-i heart . Then [she]108-birdalone hung [her]108-birdalone head a while and kept silence , and thereafter looked up and spake : [I]0-i would ask [thee]882-thee a thing and crave somewhat of [thee]882-thee , as if [thou]882-thee wert verily [[my]0-i mother]894-my mother ; wilt [thou]882-thee grant it [me]0-i ? Yea , surely , [child]283-child , said [Habundia]97-habundia . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : This it is then , that [thou]882-thee wilt learn [me]0-i of [thy]882-thee wisdom . [Habundia]97-habundia smiled full kindly on [her]108-birdalone , and said : This of all things [I]0-i would have had [thee]882-thee ask ; and this day and now shall [we]896-we begin to open the book of [the earth]432-the earth before [thee]882-thee . For therein is [mine]0-i heritage and [my]0-i dominion . Sit by [me]0-i , [child]283-child , and hearken ! So [the maiden]393-the maiden sat down by [her]393-the maiden likeness under the oak , and began to learn [her]393-the maiden lesson . Forsooth forgotten is the wisdom , though the tale of its learning abideth , wherefore nought may [we]896-we tell thereof . When it was done , [Birdalone]108-birdalone kissed [[her]108-birdalone wood - mother]900-her wood - mother and said : This is now the best day of [my]0-i life , this and the day when first [I]0-i saw [thee]882-thee . [I]0-i will come hither now many times before the day of [my]0-i departure . [Yea]901-yea , but , [sweet child]902-sweet child , said [Habundia]97-habundia , beware of [the witch]394-the witch and [her]394-the witch cruelty ; [I]0-i fear [me]0-i [she]394-the witch shall yet be grim toward [thee]882-thee . So will [I]0-i be wary , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , but [I]0-i will venture some little peril of pain but if [thou]904-thou forbid [me]0-i , [mother]729-mother . And [I]0-i pray [thee]882-thee by [thy]882-thee love to forbid [me]0-i not . And this [I]0-i pray [thee]882-thee the more , because after one of these grim times then mostly doth [she]394-the witch meddle the less with [me]0-i for a while , wherefore [I]0-i shall be the freer to come hither . [Habundia]97-habundia kissed [her]882-thee and embraced [her]882-thee , and said : Valiant art [thou]904-thou for [a young maiden]891-a young maiden , [[my]0-i child]907-my child , and [I]0-i would not refrain [thee]891-a young maiden more than [a father]908-a father would refrain [[his]908-a father young son]909-his young son from the strokes of [the tilt - yard]910-the tilt - yard . But [I]0-i pray [thee]891-a young maiden to forget not [my]0-i love , and [my]0-i sorrow for [thy]891-a young maiden grief . Therewith [they]911-they sundered , and it was drawing toward evening . [Birdalone]108-birdalone sought catch , and brought [home]373-home venison to [the dame]403-the dame , who was yet blithe with [her]108-birdalone , and spake that evening as [she]108-birdalone eyed [her]108-birdalone : [I]0-i can not tell how it is , but [thou]891-a young maiden seemest changed unto [me]0-i , and lookest more towards [thy]891-a young maiden womanhood than even yesterday . [I]0-i mean the face of [thee]891-a young maiden , for [wert]914-wert [thou]891-a young maiden stripped , lean enough [I]0-i should see [thee]891-a young maiden , doubtless . But now look to it , [I]0-i beseech [thee]891-a young maiden , to be both deft and obedient , so that [I]0-i may be as kind to [thee]891-a young maiden as [I]0-i would be , and kinder than [I]0-i have been heretofore . Chapter XVII ~ The Passing of the Year Into Winter Wore the days now , till on a night of October , toward the end thereof , [the witch]394-the witch went a - night - tide to [the Sending Boat]9-the sending boat , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone followed [her]394-the witch as erst . This time the night was wild and windy , but the moon was high aloft and big , and all cloud save a few flecks was blown from off the heavens ; so that the night was as light as could be ; and even at [the tree - hung creek]916-the tree - hung creek it was easy to see all that was done . And so it was that [the witch]394-the witch did and spake in all wise as [she]394-the witch did before . Another time , when November was well - nigh out , [the dame]403-the dame arose for [her]403-the dame lake - faring ; but this night the snow lay deep betwixt [house]919-house and [water]687-water , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone thought that it would scarce do to follow . Forsooth [she]108-birdalone knew not whether [her]108-birdalone feet would the less leave their print in the snow because they were not to be seen . When [she]108-birdalone asked [Habundia]97-habundia thereof , [she]108-birdalone laughed and said : Once more [thou]921-thou hast been wise , [[my]0-i child]907-my child , for though it had been no harder to put this might into [thy]921-thou ring , that whoso wore it should not touch the ground , yet it hath not been done . It must be told , that in this while [Birdalone]108-birdalone went oft to [the Trysting Tree]12-the trysting tree , and called on [[her]108-birdalone mother]318-her mother ( as now [she]108-birdalone called [her]318-her mother ) to come to [her]108-birdalone , and ever more and more of wisdom [she]108-birdalone won thereby . Though [the witch]394-the witch was oft surly with [her]318-her mother , and spared not [her]318-her mother girding , yet , the needful work done , [she]318-her mother meddled little with [her]318-her mother . But on a day [she]108-birdalone straightly banned [her]318-her mother the wood , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone went notwithstanding , and when [she]108-birdalone was there with [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother nought [she]108-birdalone told [her]108-birdalone thereof , but was blithe and merry beyond [her]108-birdalone wo nt . [She]108-birdalone came back [home]373-home thereafter empty handed , and stepped into [the chamber]292-the chamber proudly and with bright eyes and flushed cheeks , though [she]108-birdalone looked for nought save chastisement ; yea , it might be even the skin - changing . Forsooth [the witch]394-the witch was sitting crouched in [her]394-the witch chair with [her]394-the witch hands on the elbows and [her]394-the witch head thrust forward , like a wild beast at point to spring ; but when [her]394-the witch eye fell on [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [she]394-the witch faltered and drew back into [herself]394-the witch again , and muttered somewhat unheard ; but to [Birdalone]108-birdalone spake nought of good or bad . Now was winter - tide upon [them]929-them , when there was nought to do in [field and acre]930-field and acre , and but a little in the byre . In years bygone , and even in the last one , [the witch]394-the witch had not spared [Birdalone]108-birdalone toil any the more , but had made errands for [her]108-birdalone amidst the snow and biting winds , or over [the lake]355-the lake when it was laid with ice . But now [she]394-the witch bade [her]108-birdalone to nought save what [she]108-birdalone had a will to ; whereby [she]108-birdalone lost but little , whereas [Birdalone]108-birdalone was well willing to strive against wind and weather and the roughness of [the winter earth]933-the winter earth , and overcome if [she]108-birdalone might , so that all were well done that had to be done about the stead . Still did [the witch]394-the witch give [her]394-the witch hard words and rail at [her]108-birdalone for the most part , but from the teeth outward only , and because [she]108-birdalone was wo nt thereto . Inwardly indeed [she]394-the witch began to fear [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and deemed that [she]394-the witch would one day have the mastery ; and this led [her]394-the witch into fierce and restless moods ; so that [she]394-the witch would sit staring at [the maiden]393-the maiden â€™s beauty handling [her]394-the witch knife withal , and scarce able to forbear [her]108-birdalone . And in such a mood [she]394-the witch once made occasion to chastise [her]108-birdalone as [her]394-the witch wo nt had been erst , and looked to see [Birdalone]108-birdalone rebel against [her]394-the witch ; but it fell out otherwise , for [Birdalone]108-birdalone submitted [herself]108-birdalone to [her]108-birdalone meekly and with a cheerful countenance . And this also was a terror to [the witch , who deemed , as indeed it was , that the purpose]936-the witch , who deemed , as indeed it was , that the purpose was growing in [her]394-the witch thrall . So from that time [she]394-the witch meddled with [her]108-birdalone no more . All this while , as may be thought , [Birdalone]108-birdalone went yet oftener to [the Oak of Tryst]11-the oak of tryst , despite frost and snow and wind , and gat much lore of [[her]108-birdalone wood - mother]900-her wood - mother , and learned wisdom abundantly . And [her]108-birdalone days were happy . Chapter XVIII ~ Of Spring - Tide and the Mind of [Birdalone]108-birdalone Now was the winter gone and the spring - tide come again , and with the blossoming of the earth blossomed [Birdalone]108-birdalone also . Nought sweeter of flesh might [she]108-birdalone be than erst , but there was now a new majesty grown into [her]108-birdalone beauty ; [her]108-birdalone limbs were rounded , [her]108-birdalone body fulfilled , [her]108-birdalone skin sleeked and whitened ; and if [[any mother]938-any mother â€™s son]939-any mother â€™s son had beheld [her]108-birdalone feet as [they]940-they trod [the meadow]499-the meadow besprinkled with saffron and daffodil , ill had it gone with [him]939-any mother â€™s son were [he]939-any mother â€™s son gainsaid the kisses of [them]942-them , though for the kissing had [he]939-any mother â€™s son fared the worse belike . That spring - tide , amidst of [April]102-april , [she]108-birdalone followed [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife down to [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat for the third time ; and there went everything as erst , and [she]108-birdalone deemed now that the lesson was well learned , and that [she]108-birdalone was well - nigh as wise as [the witch]394-the witch [herself]336-the witch - wife therein . But the day after [she]108-birdalone went about somewhat pensive , as though a troublous thought were on [her]108-birdalone ; and when , three days thereafter , [she]108-birdalone met [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother , [she]108-birdalone spake to [her]925-the wood - mother even as [they]947-they parted , and said : [Mother]729-mother , much wisdom hast [thou]949-thou learned [me]0-i , and now this at the last withal , that hitherto there has been shame in [my]0-i life ; and now fain were [I]0-i to be done with it . [Fair child]950-fair child , said [Habundia]97-habundia , little is the shame though [this woman]412-this woman hath had the upper hand of [thee]950-fair child and hath used [thee]950-fair child cruelly : how mightest [thou]950-fair child , [a child]229-a child , strive with [her]412-this woman ? But now [I]0-i see and know that there is an end of that ; that [she]412-this woman feareth [thee]950-fair child now , and will never again raise a hand against [thee]950-fair child save [thou]950-fair child fall wholly into [her]412-this woman power ; as [thou]950-fair child shalt not , [[my]0-i child]907-my child . Be comforted then for what is gone by ! Nay , [mother]729-mother , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , it is not that which troubleth [me]0-i ; for , as [thou]950-fair child sayest , what else might [I]0-i do ? But [thy]950-fair child wisdom which [thou]950-fair child hast set in [my]0-i heart hath learned [me]0-i that for these last months [I]0-i have been meeting guile with guile and lies with lies . And now will [I]0-i do so no more , lest [I]0-i become [a guileful woman]955-a guileful woman , with nought good in [me]0-i save the fairness of [my]0-i body . Wherefore hearken , [sweet mother]956-sweet mother ! What is done , is done ; but when it cometh to the day , which is speedily drawing nigh , that [I]0-i must part from [thee]729-mother , it may be for a long while , then will [I]0-i not fare to the Sending Boat by night and cloud and with hidden head , but will walk thither in broad day , and let that befall which must befall . Changed then [Habundia]97-habundia â€™s face and became haggard and woeful , and [she]97-habundia cried out : O if [I]0-i could but weep , as [[ye]957-ye children of [Adam]96-adam]958-ye children of adam ! O [my]0-i grief and sorrow ! [Child]283-child , [child]283-child ! then will betide that falling into [her]97-habundia hands which [I]0-i spake of eâ€™en now ; and then shall [this wretch]961-this wretch , [this servant of evil]962-this servant of evil , assuredly slay [thee]283-child there and then , or will keep [thee]961-this wretch to torment [thee]283-child till [thy]283-child life be but a slow death . Nay , nay , do as [I]0-i should do , and fare with hidden head , and [my]0-i ring on [thy]283-child finger . Or else , O [child]283-child , how wilt [thou]283-child hurt [me]0-i ! [Birdalone]108-birdalone wept ; but presently [she]108-birdalone fell to caressing [the mother]252-the mother â€™s hand , and said : This is [thy]283-child doing , wherein [thou]283-child hast made [me]0-i wise . Yet fear not : for [I]0-i deem that [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife will not slay [me]0-i , whereas [she]336-the witch - wife looketh to have some gain of [me]0-i ; moreover , in the evil of [her]336-the witch - wife heart is mingled some love toward [me]0-i , whereof , as erst [I]0-i told [thee]252-the mother , [I]0-i have a morsel of compassion . [Mother]729-mother , [she]336-the witch - wife will not slay [me]0-i ; and [I]0-i say that [she]336-the witch - wife shall not torment [me]0-i , for [I]0-i will compel [her]336-the witch - wife to slay [me]0-i else . It is [my]0-i mind that [she]336-the witch - wife will let [me]0-i go . Said [the mother]252-the mother : [Yea]968-yea , mayhappen , yet but as a bird with a string to its leg . If it be so , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , then let [my]0-i luck prevail over [her]336-the witch - wife guile ; as well it may be , since [I]0-i have known [thee]252-the mother , [O wise mother]969-o wise mother ! [The wood - wife]559-the wood - wife hung [her]559-the wood - wife head and spake nought for a while ; then [she]559-the wood - wife said : [I]0-i see that [thou]971-thou wilt have it so , and that there is something in thine heart which [we]972-we , who are [not children of [Adam]96-adam]973-not children of adam , may not understand ; yet once [wert]972-we [thou]971-thou more like unto [us]972-we . Now all [I]0-i may say is , that [thou]971-thou must rule in this matter , and that [I]0-i am sad . Then [she]559-the wood - wife looked down again and presently raised a brighter face , and said : Belike all shall be better than [I]0-i thought . Then [she]559-the wood - wife kissed [Birdalone]108-birdalone and [they]974-they parted for that time . Chapter XIX ~ [They]974-they Bid Farewell , [Birdalone]108-birdalone and [the Wood - Mother]925-the wood - mother Now [April]102-april was gone , and [May]103-may was come with the thorn a - blossoming , and there was [Birdalone]108-birdalone waxing still in loveliness . And now [the witch]394-the witch had left all girding at [her]394-the witch even , and spake to [her]394-the witch but little , save when [she]394-the witch needs must . But to [Birdalone]108-birdalone it seemed that [she]925-the wood - mother watched [her]394-the witch exceeding closely . [Birdalone]108-birdalone went oft to [the wood]335-the wood , and learned yet more of lore : but of the matter of the Departure , how it was to be gone about [they]974-they spake no more , and great was the love betwixt [them]974-they . At last when [May]103-may was worn nigh to [June]92-june came [Birdalone]108-birdalone to [the Oak of Tryst]11-the oak of tryst , and found [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother there ; and when [they]974-they had talked a while , but ever from the teeth out , spake [Habundia]97-habundia : Though [thou]979-thou be now the wiser of [us]974-they two maybe , yet have [I]0-i wisdom to wot that this is the hour of [our]974-they sundering , and that tomorrow [thou]979-thou wilt try the adventure of [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat : is it not so ? [Yea]981-yea , [mother]729-mother , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; [I]0-i bid [thee]729-mother farewell now : woe is [me]0-i therefor ! Said [Habundia]97-habundia : And [thou]979-thou wilt deliver [thyself]983-thyself into the hands of [the witch]394-the witch , wilt [thou]979-thou , as [thou]979-thou saidst that other day ? Quoth [Birdalone]108-birdalone : Is it not wisdom , [dear mother]985-dear mother , if [I]0-i trust in [my]0-i goodhap ? Alas , said [the mother]252-the mother , it may be so when all is said . But O [my]0-i sad heart ! and how [I]0-i fear for [thee]729-mother ! [[My]0-i mother]894-my mother , [[my]0-i mother]894-my mother ! said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , that [I]0-i should make the days grievous unto [thee]729-mother ! and [thou]979-thou who hast made [my]0-i days so joyous ! But now canst [thou]979-thou not say of [thy]979-thou wisdom that [we]989-we shall meet again ? [The wood - woman]520-the wood - woman sat down , and let [her]520-the wood - woman head fall over [her]520-the wood - woman knees , and was silent a long while ; then [she]520-the wood - woman rose up and stood before [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and said : Yea , [we]989-we shall meet again , howsoever it may be . Let [us]989-we depart with that sweet word in the air between [us]989-we . Yet first [thou]979-thou shalt give [me]0-i a tress of thine hair , as [I]0-i did to [thee]729-mother when first [we]989-we met ; for by means of it may [I]0-i know tomorrow how [thou]979-thou hast sped . Even so did [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and this was the end of [their]989-we talk , save broken words of lamentation as [they]989-we said farewell . And therewith for that while [they]989-we sundered . Chapter XX ~ Of [Birdalone]108-birdalone and [the Sending Boat Birdalone]108-birdalone woke up in the morning , and arose and clad [herself]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone saw not [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife in [the chamber]292-the chamber , though [her]108-birdalone bed looked as if it had been slept in . [Birdalone]108-birdalone accounted little thereof , whereas [the dame]403-the dame would oft go on one errand or another much betimes in the morning . Yet was [she]108-birdalone somewhat glad , for [she]108-birdalone was nowise wishful for a wrangle with [her]108-birdalone . Withal , despite [her]108-birdalone valiancy , as may well be thought , [she]108-birdalone was all a - flutter with hopes and fears , and must needs refrain [her]108-birdalone body from overmuch quaking and restlessness if [she]108-birdalone might . Now [she]108-birdalone mingled the tress of [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother â€™s hair with [her]108-birdalone own hair , but deemed it nought perilous to leave the ring yet sewn to [her]108-birdalone smock : [she]108-birdalone set some deal of bread and flesh in [her]108-birdalone scrip , lest [her]108-birdalone voyage should be long , and then all simply stepped over the threshold of [the House of [[her]108-birdalone Captivity]996-her captivity]995-the house of her captivity . [She]108-birdalone went straight to [the strand aforesaid]997-the strand aforesaid , seeing nought of [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife by the way ; and when [she]108-birdalone came [there]215-there , was about to turn straightway to [her]108-birdalone left hand down to [the creek]675-the creek , when it came into [her]108-birdalone mind that [she]108-birdalone would first swim over to [Green Eyot]6-green eyot for this last of times . For the eyot indeed [she]108-birdalone loved , and deemed it [her]108-birdalone own , since never had [her]108-birdalone evil dream , [the witch]394-the witch , set foot thereon . Moreover , [she]108-birdalone said to [herself]108-birdalone that [the cool lake]1002-the cool lake would allay the fever of [her]108-birdalone blood , and make [her]108-birdalone flesh firmer and less timorous for the adventure . And again , that if [the witch]394-the witch should see [her]108-birdalone from afar , as [she]108-birdalone could scarce fail to do , [she]108-birdalone would deem [the maiden]393-the maiden was about [her]108-birdalone wonted morning swimming , and would be the less like to spy on [her]108-birdalone . So now , when [she]108-birdalone had let [her]108-birdalone garments slip from off [her]108-birdalone on to the sand close to [the water]347-the water â€™s edge , [she]108-birdalone stood a while , with [her]108-birdalone feet scarce covered by the little ripple of [the bight]1006-the bight , to be a token of safety to [[her]108-birdalone mistress]407-her mistress . To say sooth , now it was come so nigh to the deed , [she]108-birdalone shrank aback a little , and was fain to dally with the time , and , if it might be , thrust something of no import betwixt [her]108-birdalone and the terror of the last moment . Now [she]108-birdalone took [the water]347-the water , and rowed strongly with [her]108-birdalone lovely limbs till [she]108-birdalone came to the eyot , and there [she]108-birdalone went aland , and visited [every place which had been kind to [her]108-birdalone]1009-every place which had been kind to her ; and kissed the trees and flowers that had solaced [her]108-birdalone , and once more drew the birds and rabbits to sport with [her]108-birdalone ; till suddenly it came into [her]108-birdalone head that the time was wearing overfast . Then [she]108-birdalone ran down to [the water]347-the water and plunged in , and swam over to [the strand]648-the strand as fast as [she]108-birdalone might , and came aland there , thinking of nothing less than what had befallen . For lo ! when [she]108-birdalone looked around for [her]108-birdalone raiment and [her]108-birdalone scrip , it was nowhere to be seen ; straightway then it came into [her]108-birdalone mind , as in one flash , that this was [the witch]394-the witch â€™s work ; that [she]394-the witch had divined this deed of the flight , and had watched [her]108-birdalone , and taken the occasion of [her]108-birdalone nakedness and absence that [she]394-the witch might draw [her]108-birdalone back to [the House of Captivity]1013-the house of captivity . And this the more as the precious ring was sewn to [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s smock , and [the witch]394-the witch would have found it there when [she]394-the witch handled the raiment . [Birdalone]108-birdalone wasted no time in seeking for the lost ; [she]108-birdalone looked down on to the smooth sand , and saw there footprints which were not [her]108-birdalone own , and all those went straight back [home]373-home to [the house]311-the house . Then [she]108-birdalone turned , and for one moment of time looked up toward [the house]311-the house , and saw plainly [the witch]394-the witch come out adoors , and the sun flashed from something bright in [her]108-birdalone hand . Then indeed [she]108-birdalone made no stay , but set off running at [her]108-birdalone swiftest along the water - side toward [the creek]675-the creek and [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat . As is aforesaid [she]108-birdalone was as fleet - foot as a deer , so but in a little space of time [she]108-birdalone had come to [the creek]675-the creek , and leapt into [the boat]850-the boat , panting and breathless . [She]108-birdalone turned and looked hastily along the path [her]108-birdalone feet had just worn , and deemed [she]108-birdalone saw a fluttering and flashing coming along it , but some way off ; yet was not sure , for [her]108-birdalone eyes were dizzy with the swiftness of [her]108-birdalone flight and the hot sun and the hurry of [her]108-birdalone heart . Then [she]108-birdalone looked about a moment confusedly , for [she]108-birdalone called to mind that in [her]108-birdalone nakedness [she]108-birdalone had neither knife , nor scissors , nor bodkin to let [her]108-birdalone blood withal . But even therewith close to hand [she]108-birdalone saw hanging down a stem of half - dead briar - rose with big thorns upon it ; [she]108-birdalone hastily tore off a length thereof and scratched [her]108-birdalone left arm till the blood flowed , and stepped lightly first to stem and then to stern , and besmeared them therewith . Then [she]108-birdalone sat down on the thwart and cried aloud : The red raven - wine now Hast [thou]1023-thou drunk , stern and bow ; Then wake and awake And the wonted way take ! The way of [the Wender]1024-the wender forth over [the flood]1025-the flood , For the will of [the Sender]859-the sender is blent with the blood . [Scarce]105-scarce had [she]108-birdalone time to wonder if [the boat]850-the boat would obey [her]108-birdalone spell ere it began to stir beneath [her]108-birdalone , and then glided out into [the lake]355-the lake and took its way over [the summer ripple]1029-the summer ripple , going betwixt [Green Eyot]6-green eyot and [the mainland]1030-the mainland , as if to weather [the western ness of the eyot]1031-the western ness of the eyot : and it went not a stonecast from [the shore of [the said mainland]1033-the said mainland]1032-the shore of the said mainland . Hither to meet it now cometh [the witch]394-the witch , running along [the bank]1035-the bank , [her]394-the witch skirts flying wild about [her]394-the witch , and a heavy short - sword gleaming in [her]394-the witch hand . [Her]394-the witch furious running [she]108-birdalone stayed over against [the boat]850-the boat , and cried out in a voice broken for lack of breath : Back over the flood To [the house]311-the house by [the wood]335-the wood ! Back unto [thy]108-birdalone rest In [the alder nest]1039-the alder nest ! For the blood of [the Sender]859-the sender lies warm on [thy]108-birdalone bow , And [the heart of [the Wender]1024-the wender]1041-the heart of the wender is weary as now . But [she]108-birdalone saw that [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat heeded [her]108-birdalone words nothing , whereas it was not [her]108-birdalone blood that had awakened it , but [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s . Then cried out [the witch]394-the witch : [O child]1045-o child , [child]283-child ! say the spell and come back to [me]0-i ! to [me]0-i , who have reared [thee]283-child and loved [thee]283-child and hoped in [thee]283-child ! O come back ! But how should [Birdalone]108-birdalone heed [her]108-birdalone prayer ? [She]108-birdalone saw the sax ; and withal had [her]108-birdalone heart forgotten , [her]108-birdalone flesh might well remember . [She]108-birdalone sat still , nor so much as turned [her]108-birdalone head toward [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife . Then came wild yelling words from [the witch]394-the witch â€™s mouth , and [she]108-birdalone cried : Go then , naked and outcast ! Go then , [naked fool]1049-naked fool ! and come back hither after [thou]1050-thee hast been under the hands of the pitiless ! Ah , it had been better for [thee]1050-thee had [I]0-i slain [thee]1050-thee ! And therewith [she]108-birdalone whirled the sax over [her]108-birdalone head and cast it at [Birdalone]108-birdalone . But now had [the boat]850-the boat turned its head toward [the ness of [Green Eyot]6-green eyot]1052-the ness of green eyot and was swiftly departing , so that [Birdalone]108-birdalone but half heard the last words of [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife , and the sax fell flashing into the water far astern . There [the witch]394-the witch stood tossing [her]394-the witch arms and screaming , wordless ; but no more of [her]394-the witch saw [Birdalone]108-birdalone , for [the boat]850-the boat came round about [the ness of [Green Eyot]6-green eyot]1052-the ness of green eyot , and there lay [the Great Water]13-the great water under the summer heavens all wide and landless before [her]108-birdalone . And it was now noon of day . So glided [Birdalone]108-birdalone over [the lake]355-the lake and was come forth from [the House of Captivity]1013-the house of captivity ; it might well be that [she]108-birdalone was but swimming unto death ; naked as [she]108-birdalone was , fireless , foodless , and helpless , at the mercy of mere sorcery . Yet [she]108-birdalone called to mind the word of [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother that [they]1060-they should meet again , and took heart thereby ; and [she]108-birdalone was glad in that [she]108-birdalone had had [her]108-birdalone will , and shaken off the guile and thraldom of [the witch]394-the witch . Much [she]108-birdalone thought of [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother , and loved [her]925-the wood - mother , and wondered had [she]925-the wood - mother yet sought into and seen [her]925-the wood - mother welfare by the burning of a hair of that tress of [hers]925-the wood - mother ; and therewith [she]108-birdalone looked on that tress of [Habundia]97-habundia â€™s hair and kissed it . All day [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat sped on , and [she]108-birdalone saw [no land]1064-no land and nought to tell of . It was but wave and sky and the familiar fowl of [the lake]355-the lake , as coot , and mallard , and heron , and now and then a swift wood - dove going [her]108-birdalone ways from [shore]1066-shore to [shore]1066-shore ; two gerfalcons [she]108-birdalone saw also , an osprey , and a great ern on [his]1068-his errand high up aloft . [Birdalone]108-birdalone waked in [her]108-birdalone loneliness till the day was spent , and somewhat worn of the night ; then [she]108-birdalone fell asleep for weariness ; but so it was , that before dusk [she]108-birdalone had deemed that a blue cloud lay before [her]108-birdalone in the offing which moved not . [She]108-birdalone slept the short night through , and was awakened by [the boat]850-the boat smiting against something , and when [her]108-birdalone eyes opened [she]108-birdalone saw that [she]108-birdalone was come aland and that the sun was just risen . [She]108-birdalone stood up , and for the first minute wondered where [she]108-birdalone was , and [she]108-birdalone beheld [her]108-birdalone nakedness and knew not what it meant ; then [she]108-birdalone loosened [her]108-birdalone hair , and shook its abundance all about [her]108-birdalone , and thereafter [she]108-birdalone turned [her]108-birdalone eyes on [this new land]1070-this new land and saw that it was fair and goodly . The flowery grass came down to [the very water]1071-the very water , and first was [a fair meadow - land]1072-a fair meadow - land besprinkled with big ancient trees ; thence arose [slopes of vineyard]1073-slopes of vineyard , and [orchard and garden]1074-orchard and garden ; and , looking down on all , was [a great White House]1075-a great white house , carven and glorious . A little air of wind had awakened with the sunrise , and bore [the garden]1076-the garden sweetness down to [her]108-birdalone ; and warm it was after the chill of the wide water . [No other land]1077-no other land could [she]108-birdalone see when [she]108-birdalone looked [lakeward thence]1078-lakeward thence . [She]108-birdalone stepped ashore , and stood ankle - deep in the sweet grass , and looked about [her]108-birdalone for a while , and saw no shape of [man astir]1079-man astir . [She]108-birdalone was yet weary , and stiff with abiding so long amongst the hard ribs of [the boat]850-the boat , so [she]108-birdalone laid [herself]108-birdalone down on the grass , and its softness solaced [her]108-birdalone ; and presently [she]108-birdalone fell asleep again . Chapter II ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone Falleth in with [New Friends]106-new friends When [she]108-birdalone next awoke , the sun was not yet high , and the morning young , yet [she]108-birdalone stood upon [her]108-birdalone feet much refreshed by that short slumber . [She]108-birdalone turned toward [the hill]1081-the hill and [the gay house]1082-the gay house , and saw one coming over [the meadow]499-the meadow to [her]108-birdalone , [a woman to wit]1084-a woman to wit , in a shining golden gown , and as [she]108-birdalone drew nigh [Birdalone]108-birdalone could see that [she]1084-a woman to wit was young and fair , tall , white - skinned and hazel - eyed , with long red hair dancing all about [her]1084-a woman to wit as [she]1084-a woman to wit tripped lightly and merrily over [the greensward]670-the greensward . Now [she]1084-a woman to wit comes up to [Birdalone]108-birdalone with wonder in [her]1084-a woman to wit eyes , and greets [her]108-birdalone kindly , and asked [her]108-birdalone of [her]108-birdalone name , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone told it all simply ; and [the new - comer]510-the new - comer said : What errand hast [thou]1087-thou hither , that [thou]1087-thou art come thus naked and alone in [this ill - omened ferry]1088-this ill - omened ferry ? [Birdalone]108-birdalone trembled at [her]1084-a woman to wit words , though [she]108-birdalone spake kindly to [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone said : It is a long story , but fate drave [me]0-i thereto , and misery , and [I]0-i knew not whither [I]0-i was bound . But is there no welcome for [me]0-i in [this lovely land]1089-this lovely land ? [I]0-i lack not deftness wholly ; and [I]0-i will be [a servant of [servants]1091-servants]1090-a servant of servants , and ask no better if it must be so . Said [the new - comer]510-the new - comer : Unto that mayst [thou]1087-thou come , but sore will be [thy]1087-thou servitude . [I]0-i fear [me]0-i [thy]1087-thou welcome here may be but evil . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : Wilt [thou]1087-thou not tell [me]0-i how so ? Quoth [that lady]1093-that lady : [We]1094-we know [[thy]1087-thou ferry]1095-thy ferry here , that it is the craft wherein cometh hither now and again [the sister of [[our]1094-we lady]477-our lady the Queen , into whose realm [thou]1087-thou art now come , and who liveth up in [the white palace yonder]1098-the white palace yonder , and whom [we]1094-we serve]1096-the sister of our lady the queen , into whose realm thou art now come , and who liveth up in the white palace yonder , and whom we serve . And meseems [thou]1087-thou wilt not have come hither by [her]1093-that lady leave , or [thou]1087-thou wouldst be in other guise than this ; so that belike [thou]1087-thou wilt be [the runaway of [[thy]1087-thou mistress]553-thy mistress]1099-the runaway of thy mistress . Wherefore [I]0-i fear that [thou]1087-thou wilt be sent back to [[thy]1087-thou said mistress]1101-thy said mistress after a while , and that that while will be grievous to [thee]1087-thou , body and soul . [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s heart sank , and [she]108-birdalone was pale and trembling ; but [she]108-birdalone said : [O dear lady]1102-o dear lady , might [I]0-i then depart as [I]0-i have come hither , without the wotting of [this Queen]1103-this queen ! after [thou]1087-thou hast given [me]0-i a morsel of bread , for [I]0-i am hungry . Said [the gold - clad one]1104-the gold - clad one , looking on [her]108-birdalone pitifully : Nay , [maiden]1105-maiden , [I]0-i can not choose but bring [thee]108-birdalone before [[our]1106-our mistress]1107-our mistress , whereas most like [she]1107-our mistress hath already seen [thee]108-birdalone from above there . For [she]1107-our mistress is far - sighted beyond the wo nt of [folk who be more manlike]1108-folk who be more manlike . But as for the bread , see [thou]1087-thou ! [I]0-i have brought a manchet in [my]0-i pouch , and cheese withal , as [I]0-i came hurrying ; for [I]0-i thought , [she]1107-our mistress will be hungry .
