And [she]1107-our mistress reached the victual out to [her]108-birdalone . And [Birdalone]108-birdalone took it and kissed [the golden lady]1109-the golden lady â€™s hands , and [she]108-birdalone might not refrain [her]108-birdalone tears , but wept as [she]108-birdalone ate . Meanwhile [the golden lady]1109-the golden lady spake unto [her]108-birdalone and said : Nevertheless , [[thou]108-birdalone [poor maiden]1112-poor maiden]1111-thou poor maiden , somewhat may be done for thine helping , and [I]0-i will presently speak to [[my]0-i sisters]1113-my sisters thereon , who are , both of [them]1113-my sisters , wiser than [I.]0-i [Sisters]1114-sisters by blood are [we]1114-sisters not , but by love and fellowship . And [I]0-i doubt not but that as [we]1114-sisters go up into [the house]311-the house [we]1114-sisters shall happen upon [them]1113-my sisters in [the garden]1076-the garden . But now [I]0-i look upon [thee]108-birdalone , how fair [a woman]235-a woman art [thou]108-birdalone ! [Thou]108-birdalone art kind and friendly , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , smiling amidst of [her]108-birdalone tears , might [I]0-i know by what name to call so dear [a woman]235-a woman ? [Thou]108-birdalone shalt call [me]0-i [Aurea]107-aurea , said [the other]250-the other ; and [[my]0-i next sister]1120-my next sister is [Viridis]108-birdalone , and the third , [Atra]109-atra ; for that is according to the hues of [our]1114-sisters raiment , and other names [we]1114-sisters have not now . And lo ! here cometh [Viridis]108-birdalone over [the meadow]499-the meadow . [Birdalone]108-birdalone looked , and saw [a woman]235-a woman coming toward [them]1123-them clad all in green , with a rose - wreath on [her]235-a woman head . And [she]235-a woman drew nigh , and greeted [Birdalone]108-birdalone kindly , and [she]235-a woman also was [a very beauteous woman]1124-a very beauteous woman ; not great of body , whereas [Aurea]107-aurea was tall and big - made , though excellently shapen . Light brown and goodly waved of hair was [Viridis]108-birdalone , [her]108-birdalone eyes brown , and rather long than great ; [her]108-birdalone lips full and ruddy , [her]108-birdalone cheeks soft and sweet and smooth , and as rosy - tinted pearl ; [her]108-birdalone hands small and delicate of fashion ; [her]108-birdalone whole body soft - shapen as an egg ; a kind , wheedling look [her]108-birdalone face bore . When [she]235-a woman had looked a while on [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [she]235-a woman kissed [her]235-a woman , and said : [I]0-i would [thou]1125-thou wert happier , for [thou]1125-thou art beauteous , and all but the evil must love [thee]1125-thou . Therewith [she]235-a woman drew a cate from [her]235-a woman pouch , and said : Eat somewhat , for [thou]1125-thou wilt be hungry ; and let [us]1126-we go meet [[our]1126-we other sister]1127-our other sister , who is wiser than [we]1126-we . So [they]1126-we went , [all three of [them]1126-we]1128-all three of them , and came from off [the meadow]499-the meadow on to [the garden - slopes]1130-the garden - slopes , and at the entry thereof was come [Atra]109-atra to meet [them]1126-we ; [she]109-atra was clad all in black , [a tall , slim woman , with the grace of the willow - bough in the wind , with dark plenteous hair and grey hawk - eyes]1131-a tall , slim woman , with the grace of the willow - bough in the wind , with dark plenteous hair and grey hawk - eyes ; [her]109-atra skin privet - white , with but little red in [her]109-atra cheeks . [She]109-atra also greeted [Birdalone]108-birdalone kindly , but sadly withal . [She]109-atra gave [her]109-atra strawberries to eat laid on a big kale - blade ; and [she]109-atra said : [Sisters]1114-sisters , here are [we]1126-we hidden by the trees , and can not be seen from [the house]311-the house ; therefore [we]1126-we may sit here for a minute or two , while [we]1126-we talk together as to what may perchance be done for the helping of [this unhappy maiden , who is so fair and lovely , and hath strayed into so ugly a trap]1134-this unhappy maiden , who is so fair and lovely , and hath strayed into so ugly a trap . Then [she]109-atra said to [Birdalone]108-birdalone : [Thou]1135-thou must know , [poor wanderer]1136-poor wanderer , that [this Queen]1103-this queen , [[our]1126-we mistress]1107-our mistress , who is [sister to [the Witch Under the Wood]1140-the witch under the wood]1139-sister to the witch under the wood , is big and strong , well - made , and white - skinned , so that [she]109-atra deems [herself]109-atra [a Queen of all beauty]1141-a queen of all beauty : keen - eyed is [she]109-atra to see a fly where others would see nought smaller than a coney ; fine - eared withal ; wise in wizardry ; not altogether dull - witted , though [she]109-atra be proud , and crueller than the cruellest . But herein [she]109-atra faileth , that [her]109-atra memory is of the shortest for matters of the passing hour , albeit [she]109-atra remembers [her]109-atra spells and witch - songs over well . But other matters will scarce abide in [her]109-atra head for four and twenty hours . Wherefore , [sisters]1114-sisters , if [we]1126-we may keep [this maiden]1143-this maiden out of [her]109-atra sight ( after [she]109-atra hath seen [her]109-atra and given doom upon [her]109-atra ) till the dead of tomorrow night , [we]1126-we may perchance do some good for [her]1143-this maiden ; and it is in [my]0-i mind that then [she]1143-this maiden may do good for [us]1126-we also . Now [they]1126-we rejoiced in this word of [Atra]109-atra the wise ; and [Atra]109-atra prayed [Birdalone]108-birdalone to tell [them]1126-we somewhat more of [her]109-atra story ; and [she]109-atra told [them]1126-we much ; but , whyso it were , [she]109-atra said nought concerning [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife , whose outward semblance was the same as [hers]109-atra . Then [they]1126-we pitied [her]1143-this maiden , and caressed [her]1143-this maiden ; but [Atra]109-atra said : [We]1126-we must tarry here no more , but go straight up to [the lady]1145-the lady , or maybe [we]1126-we shall lose all . So [they]1126-we went [their]1126-we ways and came into the pleasance , and trod [the sweet greensward]1146-the sweet greensward betwixt the garland flowers and the beauteous trees ; which now indeed , though [Birdalone]108-birdalone saw them all clear and over - clear , were become nought to [her]1143-this maiden . [Those three]1147-those three also spake gently to [her]1143-this maiden , and now and then asked [her]1143-this maiden somewhat , as if to show [her]1143-this maiden that [she]1143-this maiden was one of [themselves]1147-those three ; but [she]1143-this maiden spake not , or answered at random , and to say sooth scarce heard [their]1147-those three words : forsooth [she]1143-this maiden was now become heart - sick , and was half dead for fear ; and [her]1143-this maiden nakedness , which would have troubled [her]1143-this maiden little across [the water]347-the water , was now grown a shame and a terror unto [her]1143-this maiden , and every deal of [her]1143-this maiden body quivered with the anguish thereof . Chapter III ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone is Brought Before [[the Witch - Wife]336-the witch - wife â€™s Sister]1150-the witch - wife â€™s sister So came [they]1147-those three at last to [the very house]1151-the very house , and whereas [it]1151-the very house stood high on the bent , a great stair or perron of stone went up to it , and was of much majesty . [They]1147-those three went through [the porch]652-the porch , which was pillared and lovely , and into [a great hall most nobly builded]1153-a great hall most nobly builded , and at the other end thereof , on a golden throne raised upon a dais , sat [a big woman clad in red scarlet]1154-a big woman clad in red scarlet . [The three damsels]1155-the three damsels led [Birdalone]108-birdalone to some four paces of [the great lady]1156-the great lady , and then stood away from [her]108-birdalone , and left [her]108-birdalone standing there alone , [the scarlet - clad woman before [her]108-birdalone]1157-the scarlet - clad woman before her ; on the right and the left the tall pillars going up gleaming toward the roof , and about [her]108-birdalone feet the dark polished pavement , with the wallowing of strange beasts and great serpents and dragons all done on the coal - blue ground . When [she]108-birdalone was so left alone , at first [she]108-birdalone tottered , and went nigh to falling ; but then came back some little heart to [her]108-birdalone , as [she]108-birdalone said to [herself]108-birdalone that now [she]108-birdalone should verily die once for all , and that no long while would be the passing from life into death . [She]108-birdalone looked up and beheld [the lady - witch]1158-the lady - witch , that [she]1158-the lady - witch was somewhat like to [[her]1158-the lady - witch sister]1159-her sister , white - skinned and of plenteous golden - hair as was [she]1158-the lady - witch , but younger of aspect , and nowise so ill - looked as that other had now become ; for somewhat well - shapen of body [she]1158-the lady - witch was ; but [her]1158-the lady - witch face forbidding ; [her]1158-the lady - witch lower lip thrust out , [her]1158-the lady - witch cheeks flaggy and drooping , [her]1158-the lady - witch eyes little more than half open ; to be short , a face both proud , foolish , and cruel ; terrible indeed , sitting in judgment in that place on a shrinking naked creature . Now [she]1158-the lady - witch spake ; and if there were no majesty or solemnity in the voice , there was ugly glee and malice therein ; but [she]1158-the lady - witch said to [those damsels]1160-those damsels : Is this [the woman that [my]0-i keen eyes beheld come aland from [[my]0-i sister]1162-my sister â€™s Sending Boat eâ€™en now]1161-the woman that my keen eyes beheld come aland from my sister â€™s sending boat eâ€™en now ? [Aurea]107-aurea knelt on one knee , and said : [Yea]1163-yea , so please [you]108-birdalone , [[my]0-i lady]603-my lady . Then said [the witch]394-the witch : Ho [thou]1166-thou ! Wilt [thou]1166-thou plead some errand hither from [[my]0-i sister]1162-my sister ? Dost [thou]1166-thou deem [me]0-i so witless as not to know that if [she]1162-my sister had sent [thee]1166-thou hither [thou]1166-thou wouldst not have come in this plight ? Nay , [I]0-i know ; [thou]1166-thou hast stolen [thyself]1168-thyself from [her]1162-my sister : [thou]1166-thou art [a thief]1169-a thief , and as [a thief]1169-a thief shalt [thou]1166-thou be dealt with . [Spake Birdalone]110-birdalone in a clear voice : No errand do [I]0-i feign from [[thy]0-i sister]550-thy sister , [lady]493-lady : when [I]0-i could bear [my]0-i life there no longer , [I]0-i took occasion to flee from [her]550-thy sister : this is all the tale . Yet once and again it hath been in [my]0-i mind that it was [[thy]0-i sister]550-thy sister who stole [me]0-i from [them]1174-them that loved [me]0-i . [Hah]1175-hah , thrall ! said [the lady]1145-the lady , [thou]0-i art bold ; [thou]0-i art over - bold , [thou]0-i naked wretch , to bandy words with [me]0-i . What heed [I]0-i [thy]0-i tale now [thou]0-i art under [my]0-i hand ? [Her]1145-the lady voice was cold rather than fierce , yet was there the poison of malice therein . But [Birdalone]110-birdalone spake : If [I]0-i be bold , [lady]493-lady , it is because [I]0-i see that [I]0-i have come into [the House of Death]1178-the house of death . [The dying]1179-the dying may well be bold . [The House of Death]111-the house of death ! cried [the stupid lady]1180-the stupid lady ; and wilt [thou]0-i call [[my]0-i noble house [the House of Death]1178-the house of death]1181-my noble house the house of death ? Now art [thou]0-i no longer bold , stripped thrall , but impudent . Scorn rose into [Birdalone]110-birdalone â€™s heart at this word , but [she]110-birdalone refrained [her]110-birdalone , and spake : [I]0-i meant that [I]0-i have stirred the wrath in [thee]0-i , and that [thou]0-i wilt slay [me]0-i therefor ; and that it availeth not to crave mercy of [thee]0-i . Laughed [the lady]1145-the lady : [Thou]0-i art [a fool]482-a fool , thrall , said [she]1145-the lady ; if a sparrow fled hither from [[my]0-i sister]1162-my sister , [I]0-i should not wring its neck , but keep it for [her]1162-my sister . So shall [I]0-i do with [thee]0-i . [I]0-i shall not slay [thee]0-i , and so destroy [[my]0-i sister]1162-my sister â€™s chattel ; nor shall [I]0-i spoil [thee]0-i , and spoil [her]1162-my sister possession . [I]0-i shall send [thee]0-i back unto [her]1162-my sister , the stolen thrall in [the stolen boat]1187-the stolen boat , when [I]0-i have learned [thee]0-i a lesson here . Forsooth it was for that cause meseemeth that [she]1162-my sister let [thee]0-i slip through [her]1162-my sister fingers , for [she]1162-my sister is wise enough to have stayed [thee]0-i from this holiday had [she]1162-my sister willed it . But [she]1162-my sister is tender - hearted , and kind , and soft , and might well deem that if [thy]0-i chastisement were done to [her]1162-my sister hand here , it were better done than by [her]1162-my sister mercy . Now , thrall , [I]0-i have spoken enough to [thee]0-i , or more than enough : get [thee]0-i back out of earshot ! Chapter IV ~ Of [the Witch]394-the witch â€™s Prison in [the Wailing - Tower]1189-the wailing - tower [Birdalone]110-birdalone did as [she]110-birdalone was bidden , and [the witch]394-the witch called unto [her]110-birdalone Atra , who came and stood humbly on the footpace beside [her]110-birdalone , and held converse with [[her]110-birdalone mistress]407-her mistress a while . Then [she]394-the witch went backward from [her]394-the witch a little , and then came to [Birdalone]110-birdalone , and in a somewhat harsh voice bade [her]110-birdalone come with [her]394-the witch . [Birdalone]110-birdalone followed [her]394-the witch , quaking , and [they]1192-we came out of [the hall]1193-the hall and into [a long passage]1194-a long passage , which led to a wide stair winding round a newel ; and all was builded exceeding fair , had [Birdalone]110-birdalone â€™s heart suffered [her]110-birdalone eyes to see it ; but [her]110-birdalone flesh was weak , and quaked before the torment to come , so that [her]110-birdalone knees well - nigh failed [her]110-birdalone . But now [Atra]109-atra lays a hand kindly on [her]110-birdalone shoulder and stays [her]110-birdalone , and says : Now meseems the walls of [the Wailing â€“ Tower]14-the wailing â€“ tower , for so it hight , have no ears to hear , and [we]1192-we may talk together . Wottest [thou]1195-thou why [I]0-i have brought [thee]1195-thou hither ? Said [Birdalone]110-birdalone in a faint voice : Hast [thou]1195-thou been bidden to whip [me]0-i ? And if [I]0-i had been so bidden , [dear maiden]1196-dear maiden , said [Atra]109-atra laughing , nowise would [I]0-i do it . Hold up [thine]1197-thine heart ! For all hath gone well so far , and now meseems betwixt [us]1192-we three [we]1192-we shall save [thee]1195-thou . [Birdalone]110-birdalone â€™s spirit came back to [her]110-birdalone at that word , and [she]110-birdalone put [her]110-birdalone hands to [her]110-birdalone face and fell a - weeping . But [Atra]109-atra was kind to [her]110-birdalone and made much of [her]110-birdalone ; and [she]109-atra kissed [her]110-birdalone and wiped [her]110-birdalone tears , and [Birdalone]110-birdalone smiled again amidst [her]110-birdalone sobs , and [she]110-birdalone thanked [Atra]109-atra ; who said to [her]110-birdalone : First of all [I]0-i must tell [thee]110-birdalone that [I]0-i am taking [thee]110-birdalone to prison by [the witch]394-the witch â€™s bidding . [Yea]1199-yea , said [Birdalone]110-birdalone , and what is prison ? Said [Atra]109-atra : [A prison]1200-a prison is a grim place where [poor folk who have done that which pleaseth not rich folk]1201-poor folk who have done that which pleaseth not rich folk are shut up , that [they]1201-poor folk who have done that which pleaseth not rich folk may be grieved and tormented by not being able to fare abroad , or go where [they]1201-poor folk who have done that which pleaseth not rich folk would ; and by suffering whatsoever [[their]1201-poor folk who have done that which pleaseth not rich folk masters]1202-their masters may lay upon [them]1201-poor folk who have done that which pleaseth not rich folk , as darkness , and cold , and hunger , and stripes . Somewhat so , or worse , [[our]1203-we lady]477-our lady would have it for [thee]110-birdalone ; but so would not [we]1203-we . Therefore for [thee]110-birdalone shall [this prison]1205-this prison be [a place where [thou]110-birdalone shalt be safe till [we]1203-we may bring [thee]110-birdalone forth when the night hath worn towards its ending]1206-a place where thou shalt be safe till we may bring thee forth when the night hath worn towards its ending . For [she]477-our lady will have forgotten [thee]110-birdalone by tomorrow ; and this [she]477-our lady knoweth ; wherefore just now , when [thou]110-birdalone stoodest out of earshot , [she]477-our lady was bidding [me]0-i , amongst other matters , to bring [thee]110-birdalone before [her]477-our lady tomorrow morning , and tell [her]477-our lady the tale of [thee]110-birdalone , that [she]477-our lady might call it to mind then what [she]477-our lady had will to this morning . Yea , said [Birdalone]110-birdalone , but will [she]477-our lady not remember that [she]477-our lady hath given [thee]110-birdalone a charge concerning [me]0-i ? But little thereof , said [Atra]109-atra , and with a few words [I]0-i may easily confuse [her]477-our lady memory so that speech thereon will fail [her]477-our lady . Keep up [thine]1207-thine heart , sweetling ; but let [us]1208-us up this stair now forthwith , for [I]0-i were fain to have [thee]110-birdalone hid away in [this prison]1205-this prison , and then will [I]0-i down to [her]477-our lady and tell [her]477-our lady that [thou]110-birdalone art lying therein in all misery and terror , lest it come into [her]477-our lady head to send for [thee]110-birdalone ere [her]477-our lady memory is grown dim . Again did [Birdalone]110-birdalone take heart , and [they]1208-us hastened a long way up the stair , till [Atra]109-atra stayed at last at a door all done with iron , endlong and over - thwart . Then [she]109-atra took a leash of keys from [her]109-atra girdle , one big and two little , and set the big one in the lock and turned it , and shoved the heavy door and entered thereby [a chamber four - square and vaulted]1210-a chamber four - square and vaulted ; and [the vault]1211-the vault was upheld by a pillar of red marble , wherein , somewhat higher than [a man]217-a man â€™s head , were set stanchions of latten , that could be clasped and unclasped . [This chamber]1213-this chamber was in a way goodly , but yet grim to look on ; for the walls were all of black ashlar stone close - jointed , and the floor black also , but of marble polished so wholly that it was as dark water , and gave back the image of [Birdalone]110-birdalone â€™s dear feet and legs as [she]109-atra went thereon . The windows were not small , and [the chamber]292-the chamber was light in every corner because of [them]1215-them , but [they]1215-them were so high up under the vaulting that none might see thereout aught save the heavens . There was nought in [the chamber]292-the chamber save a narrow bench of oak and three stools of the same , a great and stately carven chair dight with cushions of purple and gold , and in one corner a big oaken coffer . Now spake [Atra]109-atra : This is [[[our]1208-us lady]477-our lady â€™s prison]1218-our lady â€™s prison , and [I]0-i fear [me]0-i [we]1208-us can not make it soft for [thee]109-atra , [dear stranger]1219-dear stranger . Yea , [I]0-i must tell [thee]109-atra ( and [she]109-atra reddened therewith ) that it is part of [my]0-i charge to set [thee]109-atra in irons . [Birdalone]110-birdalone smiled on [her]109-atra , and was over weary to ask what that meant , though [she]110-birdalone knew not . But [Atra]109-atra went to the big coffer and opened it and thrust in [her]109-atra hands , and there was a jangling therewith , and when [she]109-atra turned about to [Birdalone]110-birdalone again [she]109-atra had iron chains in [her]109-atra hands , and [she]109-atra said : This shameth [me]0-i , [dear friend]1220-dear friend ; yet if [thou]109-atra wouldst wear them it might be well , for [she]109-atra may have a mind to go visit [[her]109-atra prison]1221-her prison , and if [she]109-atra find [thee]109-atra there unshackled [she]109-atra shall be wroth , and oftenest [her]109-atra wrath hath a whip in its hand . And these are the lightest that [I]0-i might find . [Birdalone]110-birdalone smiled again , and spake not , for [she]110-birdalone was very weary , and [Atra]109-atra did the irons on [her]109-atra wrists and [her]109-atra ankles ; and said thereafter : Yet bear in mind that it is [a friend that hath the key of these things]1222-a friend that hath the key of these things . And now [I]0-i will go away for a little , but [I]0-i shall be on thine errands ; for first [I]0-i shall tell [the mistress]698-the mistress that [thou]109-atra art lying here shackled and in all wanhope ; and next , by the will and command of [her]698-the mistress , [I]0-i am to see that [thou]109-atra be well fed and nourished today that [thou]109-atra mayst be the stronger for tomorrow . Now if [I]0-i may give [thee]109-atra rede , it is that [thou]109-atra forbear to open the coffer yonder ; for ugly things shalt [thou]109-atra find there , and that may dishearten [thee]109-atra again . Therewith [she]0-i kissed [her]0-i kindly on the cheek and went [her]0-i ways , and the great key turned in the lock behind [her]0-i . There then was [Birdalone]110-birdalone left to [herself]110-birdalone ; and [she]110-birdalone was over weary even to weep ; true it is that [she]110-birdalone made a step or two towards [the coffer]1224-the coffer , but reframed [her]110-birdalone , and took two of the pillows from the great chair and turned aside into the other corner , [her]110-birdalone chains jingling as [she]110-birdalone went . There [she]110-birdalone laid [herself]110-birdalone down , and nestled into the very wall - nook , and presently fell asleep , and slumbered dreamlessly and sweetly a long while . Chapter V ~ [They]1225-they Feast in [the Witch â€™s Prison]1226-the witch â€™s prison [Birdalone]110-birdalone was awakened by the sound of the key in the lock , and the door opened , and there was [Atra]109-atra bearing dishes and platters , and behind [her]109-atra [Viridis]108-birdalone with the like gear , and beakers and a flagon to boot , and both [they]1225-they were smiling and merry . [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s heart leapt up to meet [them]1225-they , and in especial was [she]108-birdalone gladdened by the coming of [Viridis]108-birdalone , who had seemed to be the kindest of [them]1225-they all . [Viridis]108-birdalone spake : Now is come the meat for [the dear sister]1227-the dear sister , and it is time , for surely [thou]1228-thee art famished , and it is now long past high noon . Do off [her]108-birdalone irons , [Atra]109-atra . Said [Atra]109-atra : Maybe it were well to let the fetters abide on [her]108-birdalone ankles , lest [the mistress]698-the mistress should come ; but for the wrists , reach out thine hands , [wayfarer]1230-wayfarer . So did [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and [Atra]109-atra laid [her]109-atra things on the ground , and unlocked the hand - shackles , and did them off : and meanwhile [Viridis]108-birdalone spread forth the banquet , partly on the floor , and partly on that ill - omened coffer . Then [she]108-birdalone went up to [Birdalone]108-birdalone and kissed [her]108-birdalone , and said : Now shalt [thou]1228-thee sit in [[our]1231-us lady]477-our lady â€™s throne , and [we]1231-us shall serve [thee]1228-thee , and [thou]1228-thee shalt deem [thee]1228-thee a great one . Nought else would [they]1231-us have , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone laid [her]108-birdalone nakedness on the purple cushions , and then [they]1231-us fell all three to the feast . The victual was both plenteous and dainty , of venison and fowl , and cream and fruits and sweetmeats , and good wine [they]1231-us had withal : never had [Birdalone]108-birdalone feasted in like manner , and the heart came back unto [her]108-birdalone , and [her]108-birdalone cheeks grew rosy and [her]108-birdalone eyes glittered . But [she]108-birdalone said : How if [[your]108-birdalone lady]1233-your lady were to come upon [us]1231-us here , and [we]1231-us so merry ? Said [Atra]109-atra : Out of the chair must [thou]1228-thee when [thou]1228-thee hearest the key in the lock , and then is all well , and [she]1233-your lady would have nought against [us]1231-us ; for [she]1233-your lady [herself]1233-your lady bade [us]1231-us , and [me]0-i in special , to keep [thee]1228-thee company here , and talk with [thee]1228-thee ; and [Aurea]107-aurea also would have been here , but that [she]1233-your lady is serving [the lady]1145-the lady as now . Hath [she]1233-your lady then some pity on [me]0-i , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , that [she]1233-your lady hath bidden [thee]1228-thee do by [me]0-i what is most to [my]0-i pleasure ? Laughed Viridis thereat , and [Atra]109-atra said : [She]1233-your lady hath no pity , nor ever shall have ; but so hard of heart is [she]1233-your lady , that [she]1233-your lady may not deem that [we]1231-us could love [thee]1228-thee , [a stranger]1235-a stranger , and unhappy , who can serve [us]1231-us in nowise ; so [she]1233-your lady feareth not the abatement of [thy]1228-thee grief from any compassion of [us]1231-us . Rather [she]1233-your lady hath sent [us]1231-us , and [me]0-i in especial , not to comfort [thee]1228-thee , but to grieve [thee]1228-thee by words ; for [she]1233-your lady biddeth [me]0-i tell [thee]1228-thee fair tales , forsooth , of what tomorrow shall be to [thee]1228-thee , and the day after ; and of how [she]1233-your lady shall begin on [thee]1228-thee , and what shall follow the beginning , and what [thou]1228-thee mayst look for after that . For by all this [she]1233-your lady deemeth to lower [thy]1228-thee pride and abate [thy]1228-thee valour , and to make every moment of today a terror to [thy]1228-thee flesh and [thy]1228-thee soul , so that thereby [thou]1228-thee mayest thole the bitterness twice over . Such is [her]1233-your lady pity for [thee]1228-thee ! And yet belike this cruelty hath saved [thee]1228-thee , for but for that [she]1233-your lady had not refrained [her]1233-your lady from [thee]1228-thee today , and tomorrow [thou]1228-thee shalt be far away from [her]1233-your lady . Meanwhile , said [Viridis]108-birdalone , in [her]108-birdalone soft sweet voice , none of all these things will [we]1236-we talk over with [thee]1228-thee , but things comfortable and kind ; and [we]1236-we will tell each to each of [our]1236-we story . Will [we]1236-we not , [Atra]109-atra ? Yea , verily , said [she]109-atra . [Birdalone]108-birdalone looked upon [them]1237-them and said : Wondrous is [your]1228-thee compassion and loving - kindness unto [me]0-i , and scarce do [I]0-i know how to bear the burden thereof . But tell [me]0-i one thing truly ; will [ye]1228-thee not suffer in [my]0-i place when [this witch]1238-this witch cometh to know that [ye]1228-thee have stolen [me]0-i away from [her]1238-this witch ? Nay , said [Atra]109-atra , [I]0-i have told [thee]1228-thee that by tomorrow [she]1238-this witch will have altogether , or at least almost , forgotten [thee]1228-thee and [thy]1228-thee coming hither . Moreover , [she]1238-this witch is foreseeing , and hath come to know that if [she]1238-this witch raise a hand against any of [us]1239-us three , it will lead [her]1238-this witch to [her]1238-this witch bane , save it be for heavy guilt clearly proven against [us]1239-us . Forsooth , in the earlier days of [our]1239-us captivity such a guilt [we]1239-us fell into , and did not wholly escape , as [Viridis]108-birdalone can bear [me]0-i witness . But [we]1239-us are now grown wiser , and know [[our]1239-us mistress]1107-our mistress better , and will give [her]1238-this witch no such joy . [Viridis]108-birdalone cast [her]108-birdalone eyes down at those words and [Atra]109-atra â€™s smile , and turned red and then pale , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone looked on [her]109-atra wondering what ailed [her]109-atra ; then [she]108-birdalone said : Do [ye]1241-ye [sisters]1114-sisters work in [the field]752-the field and [the garden]1076-the garden ? [I]0-i mean at milking the kine and the goats , and digging the earth , and sowing and reaping , and the like . Nay , said [Atra]109-atra ; either [[our]1239-us mistress]1107-our mistress or [someone else who is of marvellous might , [hath]1247-hath so ordained , that here everything waxeth of itself without tillage , or sowing or reaping , or any kind of tending]1246-someone else who is of marvellous might , hath so ordained , that here everything waxeth of itself without tillage , or sowing or reaping , or any kind of tending ; and whatso [we]1239-us need of other matters [the mistress]698-the mistress taketh it for [us]1239-us from out of [her]698-the mistress Wonder - coffer , or suffereth [us]1239-us to take it for [ourselves]1239-us . For [thou]1249-thou must know that [this land]1250-this land is one of [the Isles of [the Lake]15-the lake]1251-the isles of the lake , and is called [the Isle of]1252-the isle of [Increase Unsought]112-increase unsought . [Meseemeth]113-meseemeth then , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , were [the mistress of [you]1254-ye]1253-the mistress of you to gainsay [you]1254-ye the gifts of the Wonder - coffer , [ye]1254-ye were undone . [Yea]1255-yea , verily , said [Atra]109-atra ; then would be but the fruits of [the earth]432-the earth and the wild creatures for [our]1239-us avail , and these , [we]1239-us have not learned how to turn them into dinner and supper . And [they]1257-they all laughed thereat ; but [Birdalone]108-birdalone said : See [ye]1254-ye then how [I]0-i was right to offer [myself]0-i unto [you]1254-ye as [a servant]1258-a servant , for in all matters of [the house]311-the house and the byre and [the field]752-the field have [I]0-i skill . But since [ye]1254-ye would not or could not have [me]0-i , [I]0-i wonder not that [ye]1254-ye be ill at ease here , and long to be gone , for as plenteous and lovely as [the isle]631-the isle is , and though [ye]1254-ye live here without present mishandling or pining . For , sooth to say , [ye]1254-ye have over [you]1254-ye [a tyrant]1262-a tyrant and [a fool]482-a fool . [Viridis]108-birdalone answered : Yet is there something else , [dear friend]1220-dear friend , that whets [our]1265-us longing to depart . Tell [her]108-birdalone thereof , [Atra]109-atra . [Atra]109-atra smiled and said : Simple it is : there are [they]1266-they who long for [us]1265-us and for whom [we]1265-us long , and [we]1265-us would be together . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : Be [these]1267-these kinsfolk of [yours]1254-ye , as [fathers]1268-fathers , [mothers]1269-mothers , [sisters]1114-sisters , [brothers]1271-brothers , or [the like]1272-the like ? Reddened [Viridis]108-birdalone again ; but [Atra]109-atra spake , and [she]108-birdalone also blushed somewhat , though [she]108-birdalone smiled : Those whom [we]1265-us love , and who love [us]1265-us , be not queans , but [carles]1273-carles ; neither be [they]1266-they of [our]1265-us blood , but aliens , till love overcometh [them]1266-they and causeth [them]1266-they to long to be of one flesh with [us]1265-us ; and [their]1266-they longing is beyond measure , and [they]1266-they desire [our]1265-us bodies , which [they]1266-they deem far fairer than belike [they]1266-they be . And [they]1266-they would bed [us]1265-us , and beget [children]1274-children on [us]1265-us . And all this [we]1265-us let [them]1266-they do with a good will , because [we]1265-us love [them]1266-they for [their]1266-they might , and [their]1266-they truth , and the hotness of [their]1266-they love toward [us]1265-us . Looked up [Viridis]108-birdalone thereat , and [her]108-birdalone eyes gleamed amidst the flushing of [her]108-birdalone cheeks , and [she]108-birdalone said : [Sister]773-sister , [sister]773-sister ! even in such wise , and no other , as [they]1266-they desire [us]1265-us do [we]1265-us desire [them]1266-they ; it is no mere good will toward [them]1266-they from [us]1265-us , but longing and hot love . Now must [Atra]109-atra blush no less than [Viridis]108-birdalone ; yet [she]108-birdalone but said : [I]0-i have told [thee]1277-thee hereof , [Birdalone]108-birdalone , because [I]0-i deem that [thou]1278-thou hast lived simply and without the sight of [men]204-men ; but it is what all know in the world of [the sons of [Adam]96-adam]439-the sons of adam . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : [Thou]1278-thou sayest sooth concerning [me]0-i . Yet about this love have [I]0-i learned somewhat even ere today , and now , as [ye]1281-ye speak and [I]0-i , meseems the lore of it comes pouring in on [me]0-i and fills [my]0-i heart with its sweetness . And O , to have such love from any , and with such love to be loved withal ! [Dear sister]782-dear sister , said [little Viridis]108-birdalone , fear not ; such as [thou]1278-thou shall not fail of the love of [some man whom [thou]1278-thou must needs love]1283-some man whom thou must needs love . Is it not so , [sister Atra]109-atra ? Said [Atra]109-atra : [Yea]1284-yea ; such love shall come unto [her]1284-yea as surely as death . [They]1285-they were silent now a little , and it was as if some sweet incense had been burned within [the chamber]292-the chamber . For [Birdalone]108-birdalone the colour came and went in [her]108-birdalone cheeks , [her]108-birdalone flesh quaked , [her]108-birdalone heart beat quick , and [she]108-birdalone was oppressed by the sweetness of longing . More daintily [she]108-birdalone moved [her]108-birdalone limbs , and laid foot to foot and felt the sleekness of [her]108-birdalone sides ; and tender [she]108-birdalone was of [her]108-birdalone body as of that which should one day be so sorely loved . Now [she]108-birdalone spake timidly to [the others]1287-the others , and said : [Each one of [you]1287-the others]1288-each one of you then has [a man who loves [her]1288-each one of you]1289-a man who loves her , and longs for [her]1288-each one of you and for none else ? So it is , said [Viridis]108-birdalone . How sweet that shall be ! said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; and now all the more [I]0-i wonder that [ye]1287-the others could trouble [yourselves]1287-the others over [me]0-i , or think of [me]0-i once ; and the kinder [I]0-i think it of [you]1287-the others . Said [Atra]109-atra smiling on [her]109-atra : Nay , now must the cat be out of the bag , and [I]0-i must tell [thee]1287-the others that [thou]1287-the others art to think of [us]1290-us as chapmen who with [our]1290-us kindness would buy something of [thee]1287-the others , to wit , that [thou]1287-the others wouldst do an errand for [us]1290-us to [those three lovers of [ours]1290-us]1291-those three lovers of ours . Surely , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , it were a little payment to set against [your]1287-the others saving of [my]0-i life and [my]0-i soul ; and had [I]0-i to go barefoot over red gleeds [I]0-i would do it . And yet , if [I]0-i may go hence to [[your]1287-the others lovers]1292-your lovers , why not [all three of [you]1287-the others]1293-all three of you along with [me]0-i ? Said [Atra]109-atra : For this reason ; [[thy]1287-the others ferry]1095-thy ferry , the Sending Boat , wherein [ye]1287-the others came hither , is even somewhat akin to [[thy]1287-the others mistress]553-thy mistress and [ours]1290-us ; and [the mistress]698-the mistress here hath banned it against bearing [us]1290-us ; and now , were [we]1290-us so much as to touch it , such sore turmoil would arise , and such hideous noise as if [earth]451-earth and heaven were falling together ; and [the lady]1145-the lady would be on [us]1290-us straightway , and [we]1290-us should be undone ; and , as [thou]1299-thou shalt hear presently , this hath been proved . But [thou]1299-thou , [thou]1299-thou art free of [the said ferry]1300-the said ferry . Forsooth [I]0-i wot not why [[thy]1287-the others mistress]553-thy mistress banned it not against [thee]1287-the others ; maybe because [she]698-the mistress deemed not that [thou]1299-thou wouldst dare to use it or even go anigh it . [Birdalone]108-birdalone considered , and thought that even so it was ; that [the witch]394-the witch deemed that [she]394-the witch would not dare use [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat , nor know how to , even if [she]394-the witch came upon it , and that if [she]394-the witch did so find it , [she]394-the witch would sicken [her]394-the witch of [the road thereto]1304-the road thereto . So now [she]394-the witch told [[her]394-the witch friends]1305-her friends the whole tale thereof more closely than [she]394-the witch had afore , save again what pertained to [Habundia]97-habundia ; withal [she]394-the witch told every word of what [[her]394-the witch mistress]407-her mistress had said to [her]394-the witch at that time when [she]407-her mistress changed [her]394-the witch into a hind . And [Viridis]108-birdalone heard and wondered , and pitied [her]394-the witch . But [Atra]109-atra sat somewhat downcast a while . Then [she]109-atra said : However this may be , [we]1307-we will send [thee]1308-ye forth tomorrow in the dawn , and take the risk of what may befall thereafter ; and [thou]1308-ye shalt bear a token for each of [those three that love [us]1307-we]1309-those three that love us . For [we]1307-we deem that [they]1309-those three that love us have not forgotten aught , but are still seeking [us]1307-we . [Birdalone]108-birdalone said : Whatsoever [ye]1308-ye bid [me]0-i ; that will [I]0-i do , and deem [me]0-i [[your]1308-ye debtor]1310-your debtor still . But now [I]0-i pray [you]1308-ye , pleasure [a poor captive]1311-a poor captive somewhat more . Wherein ? said [they]1309-those three that love us both ; [we]1307-we be all ready thereto . Said [the maiden]393-the maiden : Would [ye]1308-ye do so much as to tell [me]0-i the tale of how [ye]1308-ye came hither , and then how it hath been with [you]1308-ye from [your]1308-ye first coming until now ? With a good will , said [Atra]109-atra ; hearken ! Chapter VI ~ [Atra]109-atra Tells of How [They]1309-those three that love us Three Came Unto [the Isle of Increase Unsought]17-the isle of increase unsought [We]1307-we were born and bred in [the land that lies south - west along [this Great Water]13-the great water]1313-the land that lies south - west along this great water , and [we]1307-we waxed happily , and became [fellows]1314-fellows when [we]1307-we were yet but [children]1274-children , and thus grew up [dear friends]1316-dear friends into maidenhood and womanhood . [We]1307-we were wooed by [many men]1317-many men , but [our]1307-we hearts turned to none of [them]1317-many men save unto [three , who were goodly , kind , and valiant]1318-three , who were goodly , kind , and valiant ; and [thou]1319-thou mayst call [them]1318-three , who were goodly , kind , and valiant [the Golden Knight , who is [[Aurea]107-aurea â€™s man]1321-aurea â€™s man]1320-the golden knight , who is aurea â€™s man ; [the Green Knight , who is [man of Viridis]1323-man of viridis]1322-the green knight , who is man of viridis ; and [[my]0-i man]253-my man , [the Black Squire]1325-the black squire . But in this was unhap , that because of certain feuds which had endured from old time , this love was perilous unto [them]1318-three , who were goodly , kind , and valiant and [us]1307-we ; so that [we]1307-we lived in doubt and unrest . Came a day , now three years ago , when [the king of [the whole land]1327-the whole land]1326-the king of the whole land brought [[his]1326-the king of the whole land folk]1328-his folk into [[our]1307-we lakeside country]1329-our lakeside country , and there held a court and a mote in [a fair great meadow anigh to [the water]347-the water]1330-a fair great meadow anigh to the water . But even as the mote was hallowed , and the Peace of [God]114-god proclaimed at the blast of the war - horn , came [[we]1307-we three woeful ladies clad in black and knelt before [the lord king]1333-the lord king]1332-we three woeful ladies clad in black and knelt before the lord king , and prayed [him]1333-the lord king hearken [us]1307-we . And [he]1333-the lord king deemed that [we]1307-we were fair , so [he]1333-the lord king had compassion on [us]1307-we , and raised [us]1307-we up , and bade [us]1307-we speak . So [we]1307-we told [our]1307-we tale , how that strife and wounds and death stood betwixt [us]1307-we and love ; and [we]1307-we wept , and bewailed it , that [our]1307-we love must be slain because [men]204-men were wroth with each other and not with [us]1307-we . [The king]1335-the king looked on [us]1307-we kindly , and said : Who be [the swains for whom these lovely damsels]1336-the swains for whom these lovely damsels make such a piece of work ? So [we]1307-we named [them]1336-the swains for whom these lovely damsels , and said that [they]1336-the swains for whom these lovely damsels were there in [the mote]1337-the mote ; and [the king]1335-the king knew [them]1336-the swains for whom these lovely damsels for [valiant men who had done [him]1335-the king good service]1339-valiant men who had done him good service ; and [he]1335-the king cried out [their]1336-the swains for whom these lovely damsels names , and bade [them]1336-the swains for whom these lovely damsels stand forth out of [the throng]233-the throng . So forth [they]1336-the swains for whom these lovely damsels stood , [the Golden Knight]115-baudoin , [the Green Knight]1341-the green knight , and [the Black Squire]1325-the black squire ( and [he]1335-the king also was now [a knight]1343-a knight ) ; but now were [they]1336-the swains for whom these lovely damsels [all three clad in black]1344-all three clad in black , and [they]1336-the swains for whom these lovely damsels were unarmed , save for [their]1336-the swains for whom these lovely damsels swords girt to [their]1336-the swains for whom these lovely damsels sides , without which [no man amongst [us]1346-us]1345-no man amongst us may come to [the mote]1337-the mote , be [he]1335-the king [baron]1348-baron or [earl or duke]1349-earl or duke , or [the very lord king]1350-the very lord king [himself]1350-the very lord king . So [the king]1335-the king looked upon [us]1346-us and [them]1336-the swains for whom these lovely damsels , and laughed and said : [Fair ladies]1352-fair ladies , [ye]1352-fair ladies have got [me]0-i by the nose , so needs must [my]0-i body follow . Do [[ye]1352-fair ladies three knights , whom [I]0-i know for [valiant men]1354-valiant men and true]1353-ye three knights , whom i know for valiant men and true , take each [his]1335-the king love by the hand , and let the weddings be tomorrow . Who then were joyful but [us]1346-us ? But even at the word [the king]1335-the king spake arose great turmoil in the mote , for [they]1336-the swains for whom these lovely damsels smote the feud and contention awake , and [men]204-men thronged forward against [each other]569-each other , and swords were drawn and brandished . But [the king]1335-the king arose in [his]1335-the king place and spake long and deftly , and waxed exceeding wroth , while [none]1359-none heeded [him]1335-the king nor hearkened . And there stood [[our]1346-us three men]1360-our three men , who laid no hand to hilt , but abode heart - whole by seeming amid the tumult . And lovely [they]1360-our three men were to look on . At last [the wise men]1361-the wise men and [old barons]1362-old barons went between , and by fair words appeased the trouble , and [the mote]1337-the mote grew hushed . Then spake [the king]1335-the king : What is this , [[my]0-i thanes]1365-my thanes ? [I]0-i had deemed that [[my]0-i foemen]1366-my foemen were far away , and that [ye]1367-ye that here are were [all friends]1368-all friends unto [me]0-i and unto [each other]569-each other . But now must [we]1346-us try another rede . Therewith [he]1335-the king turned unto [[our]1346-us men]1370-our men and said : [[Ye]1370-our men champions]1371-ye champions , are [ye]1370-our men so much in love with Love that [ye]1370-our men will fight for [him]1335-the king ? [They]1370-our men all yeasaid that , and then [the king]1335-the king said : Then do [I]0-i declare that [these three]1373-these three will hold [the field]752-the field against [all comers]1375-all comers from matins till high noon , and that [he]1335-the king who vanquisheth [any one of [them]1373-these three]1376-any one of them shall have [[his]1335-the king lady]1377-his lady and [we]1346-us d [her]1377-his lady if [he]1335-the king will , and , if [he]1335-the king will , shall ransom [her]1377-his lady . And [this field]1378-this field shall be foughten after two months â€™ frist in [these fair meadows]4368-these fair meadows , when [I]1380-the old man return from [the outermost marches of [the south]4370-the south]4369-the outermost marches of the south , whereto [I]1380-the old man am now wending . But when the battle is done , then let [all men]212-all men bow to the judgment of [God]114-god , whether [he]114-god be well content or not , and this on peril of life and limb . And now let there be deep peace between [all men]212-all men meanwhile ; and if any break the peace , be [he]114-god high or low , [rich or unrich , churl or earl]4373-rich or unrich , churl or earl , [I]1380-the old man swear it by the souls of [[my]1380-the old man fathers]4374-my fathers that [he]114-god shall lose nought save [his]114-god life therefor . At these words was there a rumour of yeasay , and [all men]212-all men were content , save [[we]4376-us three poor maidens]4377-we three poor maidens , [into whose hearts had now entered fear of loss and death]4378-into whose hearts had now entered fear of loss and death . But [[our]4376-us kindreds]4379-our kindreds on both sides were glad and proud , and [they]4379-our kindreds were not so bitter against [us]4376-us as [they]4379-our kindreds had been ; [they]4379-our kindreds put hand to pouch , and let rear for [us]4376-us a fair pavilion of painted timber , all hung with silk and pictured cloths and Saracen tapestry , by the very lake - side ; and gay boats gaily bedight lay off [the said pavilion]4380-the said pavilion for [our]4376-us pleasure ; and when all was done , it yet lacked a half month of the day of battle , and thither were [we]4376-us brought in triumph by [the kindreds]4381-the kindreds on a fair day of May , and there was not a sword or a spear amongst [the whole company]4382-the whole company , and peaceful and merry was all by seeming . But [we]4376-us were not suffered to meet [[our]4376-us lovers]4383-our lovers all this while , from the time when the mote was . Now on a day came [a messenger on the spur]4384-a messenger on the spur , and did [us]4376-us to wit that [the king]1335-the king would be with [us]4376-us on the morrow , and that the day after , [the fateful field]4386-the fateful field should be foughten . Then , though the coming of this day had been so longed for by [us]4376-us , yet now it was at hand it cast [us]4376-us into all unrest and trouble , so that [we]4376-us scarce knew whether to go , or stand , or sit , or what to do with [our]4376-us bodies . [[Our]4376-us folk]4387-our folk , and [all other men withal]4388-all other men withal , were so busy making ready for the morrow of tomorrow , that [they]4387-our folk left [us]4376-us alone to wear through the day as [we]4376-us might . Now it was afternoon , and the day hot and hazy , and [we]4376-us stood on [the very lip of [the land]198-the land]4389-the very lip of the land wearied with hope and fear , and striving to keep good countenance to [each other]569-each other ; and there came [a boat]676-a boat unto [the shore]344-the shore gaily painted and gilded , and bedight with silken cloths and cushions ; and [the steerer]4394-the steerer thereof was [a woman , not young , by seeming of fifty winters]4395-a woman , not young , by seeming of fifty winters ; red - haired [she]4395-a woman , not young , by seeming of fifty winters was , thin - lipped and narrow - eyed , flat - breasted and strait - hipped ; [an ungoodly woman]4396-an ungoodly woman , though [her]4395-a woman , not young , by seeming of fifty winters skin was white and smooth as for [her]4395-a woman , not young , by seeming of fifty winters age . Hast [thou]4397-thou ever seen such [an one]4398-an one , [guest]4399-guest ? Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , smiling : Forsooth that have [I]1380-the old man ; for such [an one]4398-an one is [[my]1380-the old man mistress]4401-my mistress to behold . Well , said [Atra]109-atra , [this dame]4402-this dame stretched out [her]4402-this dame hands to [us]4403-we , and said : Will not [the pretty ladies]4404-the pretty ladies , [the dear ladies , who have nought on hand this afternoon]4405-the dear ladies , who have nought on hand this afternoon , come into [[my]1380-the old man boat]4406-my boat and look on the face of the water , so calm and fair as it is , and let [their]4404-the pretty ladies lovely hands go over the gunwale and play with the ripple , and so beguile this heavy time for a two hours ; and then give a little gift of a piece or two of silver to [a poor carline]4407-a poor carline , who loveth [all fair ladies]4408-all fair ladies and [bright warriors]4409-bright warriors , and who needeth a little livelihood ? Now [the woman]237-the woman seemed nought lovely unto [us]4403-we , and to [me]1380-the old man forsooth [she]237-the woman seemed hateful ; but [we]4403-we looked on [each other]569-each other , and [we]4403-we found that [we]4403-we were utterly weary of going up and down on [the meadow]499-the meadow , and lying about in [the pavilion]4413-the pavilion , and it seemed as if this would give [us]4403-we a little rest ; withal [we]4403-we saw not that [the woman]237-the woman could do [us]4403-we any hurt , whereas [we]4403-we were three , and strong enough as [women]420-women go ; nor were [we]4403-we mariners so evil but that [we]4403-we might sail or steer [a boat]676-a boat at a pinch . So [we]4403-we stepped into [the boat]850-the boat straightway , and [the woman]237-the woman sat aft and paddled deftly with the steering oar , and [we]4403-we glided away from [the land]198-the land . Soon [we]4403-we were come so far that [we]4403-we could but just see [[our]4403-we pavilion]4420-our pavilion through the haze , which had somewhat thickened , and [we]4403-we said to [the woman]237-the woman that [she]237-the woman should go about and make for [the shore]344-the shore , and that then [we]4403-we would go to and fro a while along by [our]4403-we stead . [She]237-the woman nodded yeasay , and began by seeming to dight [the craft]682-the craft for return . But therewith the haze was grown suddenly into a low cloud , which came down upon [us]4403-we from [the south - west]4424-the south - west in the arms of a cold breeze , that grew stronger every minute , so no wonder it was though [the steerer]4394-the steerer might not keep head to wind ; and then who was afraid and ashamed save [ourselves]4403-we ? But [the woman]237-the woman said , and there seemed to be a mock in [her]237-the woman voice : Ill luck , [pretty ladies]4427-pretty ladies ! Now is there nought for it but to drive , if [we]4403-we would not drown . But belike this duskiness will clear presently , and then at least [we]4403-we shall know whither [we]4403-we be going ; and [we]4403-we may either turn back , or seek some other shelter , for [I]1380-the old man know [the lake]355-the lake well ; [I]1380-the old man know , [I]1380-the old man know . [We]4403-we were too terror - stricken to speak , for [we]4403-we felt that still the wind grew stronger , and [the lake]355-the lake began to rise into waves , and [the craft]682-the craft to wallow ; but well - nigh therewith was the dusk and the mist gone ; the sky was bright blue overhead , and the westering sun shone cloudless ; but on [no land]1064-no land [it]4432-it shone , or on aught save the blue waters and the white wave - crests . Then wept [Aurea]107-aurea , and this Viridis here , but as to [me]1380-the old man , [I]1380-the old man grew wroth and cried out to [the steerer]4394-the steerer : [Accursed carline]4434-accursed carline ! [thou]4435-thou hast betrayed [us]4403-we ; never now may [we]4403-we get back to [[our]4403-we pavilion]4420-our pavilion till the fight is foughten , and [[our]4403-we lovers]4383-our lovers will deem that [we]4403-we have forsaken [them]4383-our lovers , and [we]4403-we are shamed for ever . Well , well , said [the carline]4438-the carline , what remedy save patience for the winds and waves ? And [she]4438-the carline laughed mockingly . Quoth [I]1380-the old man : There is this remedy , that [we]4403-we three arise and lay hands on [thee]4435-thou , and cast [thee]4435-thou outboard , save [thou]4435-thou straightway turn [the boat]850-the boat â€™s head and back to the main . Forsooth [I]1380-the old man doubt not but that as [thou]4435-thou hast raised this foul wind against [us]4403-we , [thou]4435-thou canst raise a fair wind for [us]4403-we . Hearken to [the lovely lady]4440-the lovely lady ! quoth [the carline]4438-the carline , how [she]4438-the carline deemeth [me]1380-the old man to be none other than [the great God [himself]4442-the great god himself]4442-the great god himself , to hold the winds in the hollow of [my]1380-the old man hand , and still the waves with a word ! What ! am [I]1380-the old man wrought somewhat after [his]4442-the great god himself image , [kind ladies]4443-kind ladies ? And [she]4438-the carline grinned horribly therewith . Then [she]4438-the carline said again : As to [thy]4438-the carline remedy , sweetling , meseemeth it nought . For how shall [ye]4438-the carline sail this stormy water when [[your]4438-the carline captain]4444-your captain is gone , and [ye]4438-the carline but [holiday sailors]4445-holiday sailors belike ? As [she]4438-the carline spake , a great wave came up from the windward , and brake over [us]4403-we , and half filled [the craft]682-the craft , and lifted [her]4438-the carline bows up towering , and then down [we]4403-we went into the trough ; and [I]1380-the old man sat cowed and quaking , and spake never another word . Now began the sun to sink , and the wind abated , and [the sea]201-the sea went down , but [the boat]850-the boat sped on as swift as ever over [the landless waters]4449-the landless waters . Now the sun was down , and dusk was at hand , and [the carline]4438-the carline spake , and drew a bright - gleaming sax from under [her]4438-the carline raiment : [Damsels]116-damsels , [I]1380-the old man warn [you]116-damsels that now it were best that [ye]116-damsels obey [me]1380-the old man in all things ; for though [ye]116-damsels be three and [I]1380-the old man one , yet whereas [I]1380-the old man have [here]244-here [an edge - friend]4452-an edge - friend , [I]1380-the old man may take the life of [any one of [you]116-damsels]4453-any one of you , or of all three , as simply as [I]1380-the old man could cut a lamb â€™s throat . Moreover it will serve [you]116-damsels better in [the house whereto [ye]116-damsels are wending]4454-the house whereto ye are wending , that [I]1380-the old man make a good tale of [you]116-damsels rather than a bad . For [the mistress of [that house]4456-that house]4455-the mistress of that house is of all might ; and [I]1380-the old man must say it of [her]4455-the mistress of that house , though [she]4455-the mistress of that house is [[my]1380-the old man very sister]4457-my very sister , yet [she]4455-the mistress of that house is not so sweet - tempered and kind of heart as [I]1380-the old man am , but somewhat rough and unyielding of mood , so that it is best to please [her]4455-the mistress of that house . Wherefore , [maidens]4458-maidens , [I]1380-the old man rede [you]116-damsels be [sage]4459-sage . [Our]4460-we unhappy hearts were now so sunken in wan - hope , that [we]4460-we had no word wherewith to answer [her]1380-the old man , and [she]1380-the old man spake : Now obey [ye]116-damsels [my]1380-the old man bidding and eat and drink , that [ye]116-damsels may come hale and sound to [your]116-damsels journey â€™s end , for [I]1380-the old man would not give starvelings to [[my]1380-the old man dear sister]4461-my dear sister . Therewith [she]1380-the old man brought forth victual for [us]4460-we , and that nought evil , of flesh and bread , and cheese and cakes , and good wine withal ; and [we]4460-we were hunger - weary as well as sorrow - weary ; and hunger did at that moment overcome sorrow , so [we]4460-we ate and drank , and , would [we]4460-we , would [we]4460-we not , something of heart came back to [us]4460-we thereby . Then again spake [the carline]4438-the carline : Now [my]1380-the old man will is that [ye]116-damsels sleep ; and [ye]116-damsels have cushions and cloths enough to dight [you]116-damsels a fair bed ; and this bidding is easy for [you]116-damsels to obey . Forsooth , so weary were [we]4460-we with sorrow , and [our]4460-we hunger was now quenched , that [we]4460-we laid [us]4460-we down and slept at once , and forgat [our]4460-we troubles . When [we]4460-we awoke it was after the first dawn , and [we]4460-we were come aland even where [thou]4463-thou didst this morning , [guest]4399-guest . And [thou]4463-thou mayst deem it wondrous , but so it was , that close to where [[our]4460-we boat]4465-our boat took [land]641-land lay [the ferry]4467-the ferry which brought [thee]116-damsels hither . Now [the carline]4438-the carline bade [us]4460-we get ashore , and [we]4460-we did so , and found [the land wondrous]4469-the land wondrous fair , little as that solaced [us]4460-we then . But [she]4438-the carline said unto [us]4460-we : Hearken ! now are [ye]4460-we come [home]373-home ; and long shall [ye]4460-we dwell here , for never shall [ye]4460-we depart hence save by the will of [[my]1380-the old man sister]1162-my sister and [me]1380-the old man , wherefore , once more , [I]1380-the old man rede [you]4460-we be good , for it will be better for [you]4460-we . Go forth now unto [yonder house]4472-yonder house , and on the way [ye]4460-we shall meet [the Queen of [this land]1250-this land]4473-the queen of this land , and [ye]4460-we have nought to do but to say to [her]4438-the carline that [ye]4460-we are the Gift ; and then shall [she]4438-the carline see to [your]4460-we matter . Therewith [she]4438-the carline gat into [[her]4438-the carline own craft]4475-her own craft , [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat , and therein did the deed and spake the words [ye]4460-we wot of , and was gone [north - away]4477-north - away ; and when [we]4478-we turned to seek for [[our]4478-we boat]4465-our boat wherein [we]4478-we had come hither , it was gone . [We]4478-we stood miserably for a while on [the lip of [the land]198-the land]4480-the lip of the land , and then [I]1380-the old man said that [we]4478-we might as well go meet [our]4478-we fate as die there of grief and hunger . So [we]4478-we went , and came into [those fair gardens]4482-those fair gardens , and as [we]4478-we went slowly up toward [the house]311-the house came on [us]4478-we [a woman clad in red scarlet and grandly dight]4484-a woman clad in red scarlet and grandly dight . [A big woman]4485-a big woman [she]4485-a big woman was , and like to [her]4485-a big woman that beguiled [us]4478-we , but far younger and fairer of favour , foolish and proud of visage . [She]4485-a big woman stared on [us]4478-we , and seemed half afeard of [us]4478-we at first , but asked [us]4478-we what [we]4478-we were , and [I]1380-the old man answered that [we]4478-we were the Gift . The Gift ? said [she]4485-a big woman , what meaneth that ? Will [ye]4478-we obey [me]1380-the old man in all things ? If [ye]4478-we gainsay it , [ye]4478-we will perish , unless [ye]4478-we can eat grass ; for on [this isle]4486-this isle everything cometh from [my]1380-the old man hand . What might [we]4478-we do ? [We]4478-we all knelt down before [her]4485-a big woman , and swore to do [her]4485-a big woman will . Then [she]4485-a big woman said , after [she]4485-a big woman had stared on [us]4478-we a while : Now [I]1380-the old man know : [ye]4478-we are [they]4478-we of whom [[my]1380-the old man sister]1162-my sister spake , that [she]1162-my sister would fetch [me]1380-the old man a gift of a leash of [damsels]4488-damsels for [my]1380-the old man service . Now [I]1380-the old man take the Gift and thank [her]1162-my sister good heart . But if [ye]4478-we would do [my]1380-the old man will , then . . . But [she]4485-a big woman broke off here and stared at [us]4478-we a long while , and then [she]4485-a big woman said : Now [I]1380-the old man know ; [she]1162-my sister bade [me]1380-the old man treat [you]4478-we well , and hold [my]1380-the old man hand from [you]4478-we , or evil would come of it , belike at last [my]1380-the old man bane . So go [ye]4478-we [home]373-home to [the house]311-the house , and [I]1380-the old man will give [you]4478-we meat and drink , and show [you]4478-we [[my]1380-the old man stores]4491-my stores and the Wonder - coffer , and [ye]4478-we shall serve [me]1380-the old man in honour . Even so did [we]4478-we ; and [we]4478-we ate and drank and rested , and nought [we]4478-we lacked , save leave to depart [home]373-home to [[our]4478-we lovers]4383-our lovers , and [some mistress better than this stupid and proud lump of flesh]4494-some mistress better than this stupid and proud lump of flesh . But the next morning when [we]4478-we came before [the lady]1145-the lady , [she]1145-the lady knew nought of what [we]4478-we were ; and again [we]4478-we had to tell [her]1145-the lady that [we]4478-we were the Gift , and again [she]1145-the lady glared at [us]4478-we balefully , and again [she]1145-the lady called to mind [[her]1145-the lady sister]1159-her sister and [her]1145-the lady rede concerning [us]4478-we . And this went on for many days , till at last [she]1145-the lady got to know what [we]4478-we were ; and [she]1145-the lady followed [[her]1145-the lady sister]1159-her sister â€™s rede in that [she]1145-the lady never mishandled [us]4478-we , though [we]4478-we could see that it irked [her]1145-the lady to forbear , nor did [she]1145-the lady speak to [us]4478-we more roughly than [[her]1145-the lady fool]4498-her fool â€™s wo nt was ; and [we]4478-we had in [our]4478-we hands all that was needed for [our]4478-we sustenance , and lived easily enough . Now [our]4478-we coming hither betid three years ago , and a month thereafter comes [[thy]4499-thy witch]4500-thy witch hither in [[her]4500-thy witch ferry]4501-her ferry , and [she]4500-thy witch greeted [us]4478-we when [we]4478-we met , and asked [us]4478-we , grinning , had [she]4500-thy witch not been kind to win [us]4478-we such good days ? [Yea]4502-ye , and over kind , said [she]4500-thy witch , [ye]4502-ye would deem [me]1380-the old man , knew [ye]4502-ye what would have betid [you]4502-ye save for [my]1380-the old man good word . Forsooth [we]4478-we deemed it no kind deed to steal [us]4478-we from [[our]4478-we lovers]4383-our lovers ; but [we]4478-we kept good tongues in [our]4478-we heads , for thralls must needs kiss the rod . [She]4500-thy witch went away in two days , but came again many times thereafter , till [we]4478-we won the secret of the Sending Boat , and [her]4500-thy witch spell therewith ; but [we]4478-we knew not that was banned against [us]4478-we . Wherefore on a day in the grey of the morning , when [we]4478-we had been on [this isle]4486-this isle somewhat less than a year , [we]4478-we went down to [it]4486-this isle and stepped in , and reddened stem and stern and said the spell - words . But straightway arose an hideous braying and clatter , and thunder came therewith , and trembling of [the earth]432-the earth , and the waters of [the lake]355-the lake arose in huge waves ; nor might [we]4478-we move from [our]4478-we seats in [the boat]850-the boat till [the two witches]4508-the two witches came running down to [us]4478-we , and haled [us]4478-we out ashore , and had [us]4478-we up into [the house]311-the house , and into [this very prison - chamber]4510-this very prison - chamber , wherein [we]4478-we are now sitting so merry . And here [we]4478-we bore what was laid upon [us]4478-we , whereof , [dear guest]4511-dear guest , [we]4478-we shall tell [thee]4511-dear guest nought . But this came of it , that never thereafter durst [we]4478-we try the adventure of the Sending Boat , but have lived on in lazy sorrow and shameful ease , till [thou]4512-thou , [dear guest]4511-dear guest and [sister]773-sister , [wert]4478-we sent hither by [heaven]4515-heaven for [our]4478-we helping . Now what became of [[the king]1335-the king â€™s court]4517-the king â€™s court , and the hazelled field of [[our]4478-we champions]4518-our champions , [we]4478-we wot not , or whether [they]4518-our champions be yet alive [we]4478-we can not tell [thee]4511-dear guest ; but if [they]4518-our champions be alive , it is to [them]4518-our champions that [we]4478-we would have [thee]4511-dear guest do [our]4478-we errand , and thereof will [we]4478-we tell [thee]4511-dear guest closely tomorrow . And so , sweetling , an end of [my]1380-the old man tale . Chapter VII ~ [The Three Damsels]1155-the three damsels Take [Birdalone]108-birdalone Out of [[the Witch]100-the witch - wife â€™s Prison [Birdalone]108-birdalone]4520-the witch â€™s prison birdalone thanked [Atra]109-atra much for [her]109-atra tale , and strange it was to [her]109-atra to hear of such new things and the deeds of [folk]4521-folk ; but the dealing of [the witches]4522-the witches with those three was familiar to [her]109-atra and was of [her]109-atra world . Now [they]4522-the witches talked merrily , till there came a footstep to the door and one without knocked . [Viridis]108-birdalone paled thereat , and a pang of fear smote [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone swiftly got from out the chair and sat down on a stool ; but when [Atra]109-atra opened , it was but [Aurea]107-aurea come from [her]107-aurea service to bid [Atra]109-atra take [her]107-aurea place . So [she]108-birdalone went , and again was there pleasant converse betwixt [Aurea]107-aurea and [the other twain]4523-the other twain ; and certain matters did [Aurea]107-aurea tell [Birdalone]108-birdalone which had been left untold by [Atra]109-atra . And chiefly , when [Birdalone]108-birdalone asked if [any other folk]4524-any other folk had come into [the isle]631-the isle while [they]4522-the witches dwelt [there]215-there , [she]108-birdalone said [yea]4527-yea ; once had come [a knight]1343-a knight with [a lady]4529-a lady , [his]1343-a knight love , fleeing from war and mishap , and these had [the witch]394-the witch overcome by wizardry , and destroyed [them]4522-the witches miserably : and that again another had strayed thither , and [him]1343-a knight also [the witch]394-the witch undid , because [he]1343-a knight would not do [her]394-the witch will and lie in [her]394-the witch bed . [Withal]117-withal had come drifting there [a young damsel]4532-a young damsel , [a castaway of the winds and waves]4533-a castaway of the winds and waves ; [her]4532-a young damsel [the witch]394-the witch kept as a thrall , and after a while took to mishandling [her]4532-a young damsel so sorely , that at last , what for shame and what for weariness of life , [she]4532-a young damsel cast [herself]4532-a young damsel into [the water]347-the water and was drowned . [None of [these folk]4537-these folk]4536-none of these folk might [the damsels]4538-the damsels help so as to do [them]4538-the damsels any good , though [they]4538-the damsels tried it , and went nigh to suffer therefor [themselves]4538-the damsels . Now the day wore , and in a while [Atra]109-atra came back , and [Viridis]108-birdalone must serve . At last the dusk and the dark was come . Then said [Atra]109-atra : Now must [we]4539-we twain begone to wait upon [[our]4539-we lady]477-our lady , as the wo nt is : and that is now for [our]4539-we good hap , for if [we]4539-we be with [her]477-our lady all three , and especially , to say sooth , if [I]1380-the old man be with [her]477-our lady , [we]4539-we may well keep [her]477-our lady from visiting [thee]4541-thou here ; since belike [she]477-our lady shall yet dimly remember that [thou]4541-thou art in [[her]477-our lady prison]1221-her prison . Therefore [thou]4541-thou must forgive it if [I]1380-the old man shackle [thy]4541-thou wrists again . And now if [thou]4541-thou wilt follow [my]1380-the old man rede , [thou]4541-thou shalt try to sleep some deal , and it were well if [thou]4541-thou mightâ€™st sleep till [we]4539-we come for [thee]4541-thou in the grey dawn . Therewith [they]4539-we left [her]477-our lady [there]215-there , and [she]477-our lady nestled in the corner once more , and there did verily fall asleep , and slept till the key in the lock and the opening door awakened [her]477-our lady , and [Atra]109-atra came stealing soft - footed into [the prison]4544-the prison . Eager [she]477-our lady was and panting , and [she]477-our lady kneeled before [Birdalone]108-birdalone and unlocked [her]477-our lady leg - shackles , and then stood up and did the like by the irons on [her]477-our lady wrists . Then [she]477-our lady said : Look up , [dear friend]1220-dear friend , to [[thy]4541-thou prison windows]4546-thy prison windows , and behold the dawn beginning to break on the day of [thy]4541-thou deliverance , and [ours]4539-we maybe . But come now at once : and again , wilt [thou]4541-thou pardon [me]1380-the old man , that [we]4539-we clothe [thee]4541-thou not here for [thy]4541-thou journey ? For from [our]4539-we own bodies must [we]4539-we clothe [thee]4541-thou , and if by any hap [[our]4539-we lady]477-our lady were to see any one of [us]4539-we more or less unclad , it might draw [her]477-our lady on to see what was toward , and [we]4539-we might yet be found out , for [our]4539-we undoing . Therewith [she]477-our lady took [her]477-our lady hand , and led [her]477-our lady forth of [the prison]4544-the prison , and locked the door behind [her]477-our lady ; and then [downstairs]4549-downstairs [they]4539-we went , and out - a - doors by a little wicket at the stair - end . The dawn drew on apace now , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone saw at once the other twain lurking in the wall - nook hard by . No word was spoken between [them]4539-we , and with noiseless feet [they]4539-we went forth into [the orchard]456-the orchard , where the blackbirds and thrushes were beginning [their]4539-we first morning song , and ere [they]4539-we came out on to [the meadow]499-the meadow the full choir of [them]4539-we was a - singing . Chapter VIII ~ In What Wise [Birdalone]108-birdalone Was Clad , and How [She]108-birdalone Went [Her]108-birdalone Ways from [the Isle of Increase]4552-the isle of increase Unsought When [they]4539-we were all clear of [the orchard trees]4553-the orchard trees [the three damsels]1155-the three damsels kept [Birdalone]108-birdalone between [them]4539-we closely , so that [her]108-birdalone white body should not be seen if [the lady]1145-the lady were awake and looking forth . Thus [they]1155-the three damsels brought [her]108-birdalone to where a few thorn - bushes made a cover for [them]4539-we close to [the water â€™s edge]4556-the water â€™s edge , some twenty yards from [the Sending Boat]9-the sending boat . There [they]4539-we stood together , and [Atra]109-atra said : Now , [dear guest]4511-dear guest , and [dearest messenger]4558-dearest messenger , it is [our]4539-we matter to clothe [thee]108-birdalone from [our]4539-we very bodies ; and do [thou]4559-thou , Viridis , begin . [Viridis]108-birdalone came forward blushing , as [her]108-birdalone wo nt was , and took off [her]108-birdalone green gown and laid it on the grass ; then [she]108-birdalone set [her]108-birdalone hand to [her]108-birdalone smock , and did it off , and stood naked , knee set to knee , and swaying like the willow branch ; and then was seen all the dainty fashion of [her]108-birdalone body , and how lovely of hue and sweet of flesh [she]108-birdalone was . But [she]108-birdalone said : [Dear sister]782-dear sister [Birdalone]108-birdalone , here is [my]1380-the old man smock , which [I]1380-the old man lend [thee]108-birdalone , but as to [my]1380-the old man love , [I]1380-the old man give it [thee]108-birdalone therewith ; therefore grudge it not , though [thou]4559-thou give [me]1380-the old man back the linen , for happy will be the day to [me]1380-the old man when [I]1380-the old man have it again ; for now none may do it on [me]1380-the old man save [the Green Knight]1341-the green knight , [my]1380-the old man own love . Therewith [she]108-birdalone gave [her]108-birdalone the smock , and kissed [her]108-birdalone , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone did it on , and felt the valianter and mightier when [she]108-birdalone had a garment upon [her]108-birdalone . Then [Aurea]107-aurea did off [her]107-aurea golden gown , and stood in smock alone , so that [her]107-aurea naked arms shone more precious than the golden sleeves that had covered them . And [she]107-aurea spake : [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [dear messenger]4562-dear messenger , take now [my]1380-the old man golden gown , and send it back to [me]1380-the old man when [thou]4563-thou hast found [the man unto whom it is due]4564-the man unto whom it is due ; and think meanwhile that , when [thou]4563-thou wearest it , [thou]4563-thou wearest [my]1380-the old man love , and that when [thou]4563-thou pullest it off , [thou]4563-thou art clad with [my]1380-the old man love instead of it . So [Birdalone]108-birdalone did on the gown , and became to look on as [the daintiest of [the queens of [the earth]432-the earth]4566-the queens of the earth]4565-the daintiest of the queens of the earth ; and [she]108-birdalone turned [her]108-birdalone head about to look on [her]108-birdalone gold - clad flanks , and wondered . Thereafter [Atra]109-atra knit up [her]109-atra skirts into [her]109-atra girdle , and then did off [her]109-atra shoon , so that [her]109-atra slim feet shone like pearls on the green grass ; and [she]109-atra said : [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [sweet friend]4568-sweet friend ! wilt [thou]4563-thou be [[my]1380-the old man messenger]4569-my messenger to bear these shoon to [[my]1380-the old man Black Squire]4570-my black squire , and meanwhile put [my]1380-the old man love for [thee]4563-thou under [thy]4563-thou feet , to speed [thee]4563-thou and to bear [thee]4563-thou up ? Wherefore be good to [me]1380-the old man . [Birdalone]108-birdalone then shod [herself]108-birdalone , and though pity it were to hide [her]108-birdalone feet from the eyes of Earth , yet felt [she]108-birdalone the stouter - hearted thereby , and [her]108-birdalone cheeks flushed and [her]108-birdalone eyes brightened . Thereafter [Aurea]107-aurea gave [her]108-birdalone withal a golden collar for the neck , and [Viridis]108-birdalone a girdle of silver well - wrought , and [Atra]109-atra a gold finger - ring set with a sapphire stone ; and all these [she]108-birdalone did on [her]108-birdalone ; but yet [she]108-birdalone knew that they were tokens to be delivered to [the three lovers]4571-the three lovers according as was due . Then spake [Atra]109-atra : Lo , [sister]773-sister , [we]4573-we pray [thee]4563-thou to bear these lendings on [thy]4563-thou body in such wise that when [thou]4563-thou comest to [the mainland]1030-the mainland [they]4575-they may be seen by [knights seeking adventures]4576-knights seeking adventures , and that [thou]4563-thou mayst answer to any who may challenge [thee]4563-thou thereof and say that [thou]4563-thou bearest this raiment and these jewels from [Aurea]107-aurea and [Viridis]108-birdalone and [Atra]109-atra to [Baudoin the Golden Knight]115-baudoin , and to [Hugh the Green Knight]118-hugh , and to [Arthur the Black Squire]119-arthur . And if [thou]4563-thou deem that [thou]4563-thou hast found these , then shall [they]4575-they tell [thee]4563-thou a token , such as [we]4573-we shall tell [thee]4563-thou , that they be truly these and none other ; and thereafter , when [thou]4563-thou art made sure , [they]4575-they shall take of [thee]4563-thou the raiment , the gems , and the Sending Boat , and come hither if [they]4575-they may . And [God]114-god look to the rest ! But as for the token to be told aforesaid , [we]4573-we have determined that each of [us]4573-we shall tell [thee]4563-thou privily what question [thou]4563-thou shalt ask for [her]4563-thou , and what answer [thou]4563-thou must look for . When [she]4563-thou had done speaking , [each]4577-each came up to [Birdalone]108-birdalone and spake something into [her]4563-thou ear amidst blushes enough forsooth . And what [they]4575-they said will be seen hereafter . Then again said [Atra]109-atra : Now by this errand shall [we]4573-we be well paid for the care [we]4573-we have had of [thee]4563-thou . It may be , forsooth , that [thou]4563-thou shalt not find [our]4573-we speech - friends ; for [they]4575-they may be dead , or [they]4575-they may deem [us]4573-we untrue , and may have forsaken [us]4573-we and [[their]4575-they land]4578-their land ; and in any such case [thou]4563-thou art free of [our]4573-we errand ; but whatsoever may betide [us]4573-we , [God]114-god speed [thee]4563-thou ! Then [Viridis]108-birdalone drew forth a basket from under a bush , and said : [We]4573-we know not how long [thy]4563-thou voyage may be , but some little provision for the way [we]4573-we may at least give [thee]4563-thou : now wilt [thou]4563-thou bear this aboard [thyself]4579-thyself ; for [we]4573-we dare not touch [[thy]4563-thou craft]4580-thy craft , nay , nor come nigh it , [no one of [us]4573-we]4581-no one of us . And [she]108-birdalone set down the basket and cast [her]108-birdalone arms about [her]108-birdalone , and kissed [her]108-birdalone and wept over [her]108-birdalone ; and [the other twain]4523-the other twain , [they]4573-we also kissed [her]108-birdalone lovingly . [Birdalone]108-birdalone wept even as [Viridis]108-birdalone , and said : May [ye]4573-we do well , who have been so kind to [me]1380-the old man ; but now am [I]1380-the old man both so glad and so sorry , that the voice of [me]1380-the old man will not make due words for [me]1380-the old man . O farewell !
