Therewith [she]108-birdalone took up [her]108-birdalone basket , and turned and went speedily to [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat ; and [they]4573-we beheld [her]108-birdalone how [she]108-birdalone stepped aboard and bared [her]108-birdalone arm , and drew blood from it with the pin of [her]108-birdalone girdle - buckle , and therewith reddened stem and stern ; and a pang of fear smote into [their]4573-we hearts lest [[their]4573-we lady]4584-their lady had banned it for [Birdalone]108-birdalone as for [them]4573-we . But [Birdalone]108-birdalone sat down on the thwart , and turned [her]108-birdalone face south , and spake : The red raven - wine now Hast [thou]4573-we drunk , stern and bow ; Awake then , awake ! And the southward way take : The way of the Wender forth over the flood , For the will of [the Sender]859-the sender is blent with the blood . No cloud barred the gateway of the sun as [she]108-birdalone spoke ; no wave rose upon the bosom of [the lake]355-the lake ; no clatter nor tumult was there ; but [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat stirred , and then shot out swiftly into [the wide water]4588-the wide water ; and the sun arose as [they]4573-we looked , and [his]859-the sender path of light flashed on [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s golden gown for a moment , and then it grew grey again , and presently [she]108-birdalone was gone from before [their]4573-we eyes . So [they]4573-we turned up into [the orchard]456-the orchard : and now was [Viridis]108-birdalone of good cheer , and [Aurea]107-aurea no less ; but [Atra]109-atra lagged behind , and as [she]109-atra went , some passion took [her]109-atra , [she]109-atra knew not wherefore ; [her]109-atra bosom swelled , [her]109-atra shoulders heaved therewith , and [she]109-atra wept . Chapter IX ~ How [Birdalone]108-birdalone Came to [the Isle of [the Young]120-the young]19-the isle of the young and the Old All went well with [Birdalone]108-birdalone when [she]108-birdalone had left [the Isle of Increase Unsought]4590-the isle of increase unsought , much as it had on [her]108-birdalone first voyage , save that now [she]108-birdalone was both clad and victualled , and [her]108-birdalone heart , if yet it harboured fear , was also full of new and strange hope ; and oft , even as [she]108-birdalone sat there amidst [the waste of waters]4591-the waste of waters , [she]108-birdalone wondered what new longing this was which wrought so sweet a pain in [her]108-birdalone , that it made [her]108-birdalone cheeks burn , and [her]108-birdalone eyes dim , and [her]108-birdalone hands and [her]108-birdalone limbs restless . And then would [she]108-birdalone set [her]108-birdalone mind to [[her]108-birdalone friends]1305-her friends and [their]1305-her friends errand , and would hope and pray for [them]1305-her friends ; but again would [she]108-birdalone fall to picture to [herself]108-birdalone what manner of [men]204-men [they]1305-her friends were who were so sore longed for by [those three beauteous women]4594-those three beauteous women ; and [she]108-birdalone deemed that since [they]1305-her friends were thus desired , [they]1305-her friends must be fairer even than [[her]108-birdalone friends of [the isle]631-the isle]4595-her friends of the isle ; and again the nameless longing overtook [her]108-birdalone , and held [her]108-birdalone till it wearied [her]108-birdalone into sleep . When [she]108-birdalone awoke again [the boat]850-the boat had stayed , and [she]108-birdalone was come aland ; but the dawn was not yet come , and the night was moonless , yet was there light enough to see , from the water and the stars , that the bows of [the boat]850-the boat were lying safe on [a little sandy beach]4599-a little sandy beach . So [she]108-birdalone stepped out and looked around , and deemed [she]108-birdalone could see great trees before [her]108-birdalone , and imagined also dark masses of [she]108-birdalone knew not what . So [she]108-birdalone walked warily up [the said strand]4600-the said strand till [she]108-birdalone came on to soft grass , and smelled the scent of the clover as [her]108-birdalone foot - soles crushed it . There [she]108-birdalone sat down , and presently lay along and went to sleep . After a while [she]108-birdalone awoke , and felt happy and well at ease , and had no will to move : the sun was shining brightly , but had not been up long : the song of birds was all about [her]108-birdalone , but amidst it [she]108-birdalone deemed [she]108-birdalone heard some speech of [man]537-man , though it were not like to what [she]108-birdalone had heard in [her]108-birdalone life before . So [she]108-birdalone raised [herself]108-birdalone on [her]108-birdalone elbow , and looked up and saw a new thing , and sat up now , and beheld and wondered . For there stood before [her]108-birdalone , gazing wide - eyed on [her]108-birdalone , [two little children , some three winters of age]4602-two little children , some three winters of age , [a man]217-a man and [a woman]235-a woman as it seemed . [The man - child with light and fine white - golden hair , falling straight down and square over his brow , and blue - grey eyes which were both kind and merry , and shyly seeking as it were]4605-the man - child with light and fine white - golden hair , falling straight down and square over his brow , and blue - grey eyes which were both kind and merry , and shyly seeking as it were . Plump and rosy [he]217-a man was , sturdy and stout - limbed . No less fair was [the woman]237-the woman ; [her]237-the woman hair golden - brown , as oft it is with [children who grow up dark - haired]4607-children who grow up dark - haired , and curling in fair little rings all over [her]237-the woman head ; [her]237-the woman eyes were big and dark grey ; [she]237-the woman was thinner than [the lad]4608-the lad , and somewhat taller . [These two babes]4609-these two babes had between [them]4609-these two babes a milk - white she - goat , and had been playing with [her]237-the woman , and now [she]108-birdalone turned [her]108-birdalone head to this and that one of [them]4609-these two babes , bleating , as if to crave more of the game ; but [they]4609-these two babes had no eyes for [her]108-birdalone , but stood staring with might and main on [the new - comer]510-the new - comer and [her]108-birdalone shining golden gown . [Birdalone]108-birdalone laughed with joy when [she]108-birdalone saw [the little ones]4611-the little ones , and a dim memory of the days of [Utterhay]1-utterhay passed before [her]108-birdalone : [she]108-birdalone stretched out a hand to [them]4611-the little ones , and spake softly and caressingly , and [the little lad]4612-the little lad came forward smiling , and took [her]108-birdalone hand , and made as if [he]4612-the little lad would help [her]108-birdalone up for courtesy â€™s sake . [She]108-birdalone laughed on [him]4612-the little lad , and arose ; and when [she]108-birdalone stood up , tall and golden , [he]4612-the little lad seemed somewhat afeard of so big a creature , but stood [his]4612-the little lad ground valiantly . Then [she]108-birdalone stooped down to [him]4612-the little lad and kissed [him]4612-the little lad , and [he]4612-the little lad naysaid [her]108-birdalone not , but seemed rather glad when it was over ; but when [Birdalone]108-birdalone went to [the little maid]4613-the little maid , and kissed [her]4613-the little maid , [the child]238-the child clung to [her]4613-the little maid as if [she]4613-the little maid were [[her]238-the child mother]318-her mother , and babbled to [her]4613-the little maid . Then comes [the lad]4608-the lad to [her]108-birdalone , and takes [her]108-birdalone hand , and would draw [her]108-birdalone away , and speaks to [her]108-birdalone in [his]4608-the lad prattle , and [she]108-birdalone understood [him]4608-the lad to mean that [she]108-birdalone should come with [him]4608-the lad to see [the father]4617-the father . So [she]108-birdalone went , wondering what should next betide ; and [the little maiden]4618-the little maiden went on the other side of [her]108-birdalone , holding by a fold of [her]4618-the little maiden skirt . [Forsooth]108-birdalone [the goat]4619-the goat followed bleating , not well pleased to be forgotten . Now had [Birdalone]108-birdalone time to look about [her]108-birdalone , though [the two babes]4620-the two babes fell to prattling with [her]108-birdalone in [their]4620-the two babes way , and [she]108-birdalone thought it sweet to look down on the two little faces that looked up to [her]108-birdalone so pleased and merry . [She]108-birdalone was in [a grassy plain]4621-a grassy plain , somewhat over rough and broken to be called [a meadow]4622-a meadow , and not enough be - timbered to be called a wood ; [it]4621-a grassy plain rose up a little and slowly as [they]4620-the two babes left [the water]347-the water , but scarce so much as one might call [it]4621-a grassy plain [a hill]4624-a hill . Straight before [her]108-birdalone on the way that [they]4620-the two babes were going went up into the air great masses of grey stone builded by [man]537-man â€™s hand , but looking , even from this way off , ragged and ruinous . It may well be thought that [Birdalone]108-birdalone wondered what things might lie betwixt the trees and [the towers]4626-the towers . Now as [they]4620-the two babes went [they]4620-the two babes came on other goats , who seemed tame , and these joined [them]4620-the two babes to [their]4620-the two babes fellow , and suffered [the younglings]4627-the younglings to play with [them]4620-the two babes . Moreover there were rabbits great plenty scuttling in and out of the brakes and the rough ground upon the way , and [the younglings]4627-the younglings beheld [them]4620-the two babes , and [the little lad]4612-the little lad said , after [his]4612-the little lad fashion : Why do the rabbits run away from [us]4620-the two babes , and the goats follow [us]4620-the two babes ? Now , sooth to say , [Birdalone]108-birdalone scarce knew why , and had no word ready for [the child]238-the child ; but [she]108-birdalone said at last : Mayhappen [they]4620-the two babes will come to [me]1380-the old man ; so it was once when [I]1380-the old man dwelt away from [here]244-here . Shall [I]1380-the old man go fetch [thee]238-the child one ? [The little ones]4611-the little ones yeasaid that , though somewhat shyly and doubtfully . Then said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : Do [ye]4611-the little ones , sweetlings , abide [me]1380-the old man here , and go not away . [They]4611-the little ones nodded [their]4611-the little ones heads thereat , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone kilted [her]108-birdalone skirts and went [her]108-birdalone ways to some broken bushed ground , where was a many rabbits playing about ; but [she]108-birdalone went not out of eye - shot of [the babes]4633-the babes . Before [she]108-birdalone was well - nigh to the little beasts , [she]108-birdalone fell to talking to [them]4611-the little ones in a low sweet voice , as had been [her]108-birdalone wo nt when [she]108-birdalone was little ; and when [they]4611-the little ones heard it , [those who had not scuttled away at first glance of [her]108-birdalone]4634-those who had not scuttled away at first glance of her , fell to [creeping little short creeps one to the other]4635-creeping little short creeps one to the other , as [their]4611-the little ones manner is when [they]4611-the little ones be alone together and merry ; and [they]4611-the little ones suffered [her]108-birdalone to come quite amongst [them]4611-the little ones , and crept about [her]108-birdalone feet while [she]108-birdalone stood , still talking unto [them]4611-the little ones . Then [she]108-birdalone stooped down and took up one in [her]108-birdalone arms and caressed it , and then laid [him]4636-him down and took up another , and so with three or four of [them]4611-the little ones ; and [she]108-birdalone fell to pushing them , and rolling them over with [her]108-birdalone foot ; then [she]108-birdalone turned a little away from [them]4611-the little ones toward [the children]4637-the children , and then a little more , and the rabbits fell to following [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone turned and took up one in [her]108-birdalone arms , and went straight on toward [the children]4637-the children , but turning and talking to the rabbits now and again . As to [the babes]4633-the babes , [she]108-birdalone saw the goats , of whom were now a dozen , or thereabouts , standing together in a kind of ring , and [the little ones]4611-the little ones going from one to the other playing with [them]4611-the little ones happily . But presently [the lad]4608-the lad turned and saw [her]108-birdalone coming with [her]108-birdalone tail of little beasts , and [he]4608-the lad cried out a great Oh and ran toward [her]108-birdalone straightway , and [the maiden]393-the maiden after [him]4608-the lad ; and [he]4608-the lad held out [his]4608-the lad arms to have the rabbit [she]108-birdalone bore , and [she]108-birdalone gave it to [him]4608-the lad smiling , and said : Lo now ! here be [pretty playmates]4643-pretty playmates ; but look to it that [ye]4608-the lad be soft and kind with [them]4643-pretty playmates , for [they]4643-pretty playmates are but [feeble people]4644-feeble people . So [the younglings]4627-the younglings fell to sporting with [[their]4627-the younglings new friends]4646-their new friends , and for a little forgat both goats and [golden lady]4647-golden lady ; but the goats drew nigh , and stood about [them]4643-pretty playmates bleating , nor durst [they]4643-pretty playmates run at the rabbits to butt [them]4643-pretty playmates , because of [Birdalone]108-birdalone and [the little ones]4611-the little ones . There then stood [the slim maiden]4649-the slim maiden , tall and gleaming above [her]4649-the slim maiden little flock ; and [her]4649-the slim maiden heart was full of mirth and rest , and the fear was all forgotten . But as [she]4649-the slim maiden looked up toward the grey walls , [lo]4650-lo , new tidings to hand ! For [she]4649-the slim maiden saw [an old man with a long white beard]4651-an old man with a long white beard slowly coming toward [them]4627-the younglings : [she]4649-the slim maiden started not , but abode [his]4651-an old man with a long white beard coming quietly , and as [he]4651-an old man with a long white beard drew nigh [she]4649-the slim maiden could see of [him]4651-an old man with a long white beard that [he]4651-an old man with a long white beard was big and stark , and , old as [he]4651-an old man with a long white beard was , not yet bowed with [his]4651-an old man with a long white beard many years . [He]4651-an old man with a long white beard stood looking on [this Queen]1103-this queen and [[her]1103-this queen court]4653-her court silently a while , and then [he]4651-an old man with a long white beard spake : Such a sight [I]1380-the old man looked not to see on [this Isle of [the Young and the Old]4655-the young and the old]4654-this isle of the young and the old . [She]4649-the slim maiden said : But meseemeth it is full meet that [these younglings]4656-these younglings should sport with [the creatures]4657-the creatures . [He]4651-an old man with a long white beard smiled and said : Such a voice [I]1380-the old man looked not to hear on [the Isle]32-the isle of nothing of the Young and [the Old]4658-the old . [Birdalone]108-birdalone became somewhat troubled , and said : Am [I]1380-the old man welcome here ? for if [I]1380-the old man be not , [I]1380-the old man will pray [thy]1380-the old man leave to depart . [He]1380-the old man said : [Thou]1380-the old man art as welcome as the very spring , [[my]1380-the old man child]907-my child ; and if [thou]1380-the old man have a mind to abide here , who shall naysay [thee]1380-the old man ? For surely [thou]1380-the old man art young ; nay , in regard to [me]1380-the old man [thou]1380-the old man art scarce older than [babes]4660-babes . All blessings be with [thee]1380-the old man . But though [thou]1380-the old man art true and kind , as is clear to be seen by [thy]1380-the old man playing with [these children]4661-these children and the landward beasts in peace and love , yet it may be so that [thou]1380-the old man hast brought hither somewhat less than peace . And [he]1380-the old man smiled upon [her]907-my child strangely . [She]907-my child looked somewhat scared at [his]1380-the old man last words , and said : But how so ? If [I]1380-the old man might [I]1380-the old man would bear nought but peace and happiness to any place . [The old carle]4662-the old carle laughed outright now , and said : How so , [dear child]4663-dear child ? because [ladies so sweet and lovesome]4664-ladies so sweet and lovesome as [thou]1380-the old man be sent by love , and love rendeth apart that which was joined together . [She]907-my child wondered at [his]1380-the old man word , and was bewildered by it , but [she]907-my child held [her]907-my child peace ; and [he]1380-the old man said : Now [we]4665-we may talk hereof later on ; but the matter to hand now is the quenching of thine hunger ; for [I]1380-the old man will not ask [thee]907-my child whereby [thou]1380-the old man camest , since by [water]687-water [thou]1380-the old man needs must have come . Wherefore now [I]1380-the old man bid [thee]907-my child to [[our]4665-we house]4667-our house , and [these little ones]4668-these little ones shall go with [us]4665-we , and [the three of these horned folk whom [we]4665-we are wo nt to tether amidst the wrack and ruin of what once was fair]4669-the three of these horned folk whom we are wo nt to tether amidst the wrack and ruin of what once was fair ; [the rest]4670-the rest have [our]4665-we leave to depart , and [these nibblers]4671-these nibblers also ; for [we]4665-we have [a potherb garden]366-a potherb garden by [[our]4665-we house]4667-our house , and are fain to keep the increase of the same for [ourselves]4665-we . [Birdalone]108-birdalone laughed , and shook [her]108-birdalone skirts at [the coneys]4674-the coneys , and [they]4674-the coneys all scuttled away after the manner of [their]4674-the coneys kind . Thereat [the little lad]4612-the little lad looked downcast and well - nigh tearful , but [the maid]589-the maid stamped [her]589-the maid foot , and roared well - favouredly . [Birdalone]108-birdalone did [her]108-birdalone best to solace [her]1379-her , and plucked a bough from a hawthorn bush far above [the little ones]4611-the little ones â€™[1380-the old man] reach whereon was yet some belated blossom , and gave it to [her]1379-her and stilled [her]1379-her . But [the old man]1380-the old man picked out [his]1380-the old man milch - goats from the flock ( whereof was the white ) , and drave them before [him]1380-the old man , while [the two babes]4620-the two babes went on still beside [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [the little carle]1382-the little carle holding [her]1382-the little carle hand and playing with the fingers thereof ; [the maiden]393-the maiden sometimes hanging on to [her]393-the maiden gown , sometimes going loose and sporting about beside [her]393-the maiden . So came [they]4620-the two babes to where the ground became smoother , and there was a fair piece of greensward in a nook made by those great walls and towers , which sheltered [it]1384-it from the north . The said walls seemed to be the remnant of what had once been [a great house]1385-a great house and castle ; and up aloft , where was now no stair to come at [them]4620-the two babes , were chimneys and hearths here and there , and windows with fair seats in them , and arched doors and carven pillars , and many things beautiful , but now was all ruined and broken , and [the house]311-the house was roofless and floorless : [withal]1387-withal [it]311-the house was overgrown with ash - trees and quicken - beam , and other berry - trees and key - trees , which had many years ago seeded in the rent walls , and now grew there great and flourishing . But in [the innermost nook of this mighty remnant]1388-the innermost nook of this mighty remnant , and using for [its]311-the house lowly walls two sides of [the ancient ashlar ones]1389-the ancient ashlar ones , stood a cot builded not over trimly of small wood , and now much overgrown with roses and woodbine . In front of [it]311-the house was a piece of [garden ground]1390-garden ground , wherein waxed potherbs , and a little deal of wheat ; and therein was a goodly row of bee - skeps ; and all without it was [the pleasant greensward aforesaid]1391-the pleasant greensward aforesaid , wherein stood three great ancient oaks , and divers thorns , which also were ancient after [their]4620-the two babes kind . [The elder]1392-the elder led [[his]1392-the elder guest]1393-his guest into the cot , which had but simple plenishing of stools and benches , and a table unartful , and then went to tether [his]1392-the elder goats in [the ruined hall of [the house]311-the house]1394-the ruined hall of the house , and [the children]4637-the children must needs with [him]1392-the elder , though [Birdalone]108-birdalone had been glad of one of [them]4637-the children at least ; but there was no nay , but that [they]4637-the children must go see [their]4637-the children dear white goat in [her]108-birdalone stall . Howsoever [all three]1397-all three came back again presently , [the old carle]4662-the old carle with a courteous word in [his]4662-the old carle mouth , and [he]4662-the old carle took [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s hand , and kissed it and bade [her]108-birdalone welcome to [[his]4662-the old carle house]1399-his house , as though [he]4662-the old carle had been [a great lord at [home]373-home in [[his]4662-the old carle own castle]1402-his own castle]1400-a great lord at home in his own castle . Therewith must [the little ones]4611-the little ones also kiss [her]108-birdalone hand and be courteous ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone suffered it , laughing , and then caught [them]4611-the little ones up in [her]108-birdalone arms , and clipped and kissed [them]4611-the little ones well - favouredly ; wherewith belike [they]4611-the little ones were not over - well pleased , though [the boy]1404-the boy endured it kindly . Thereafter [the elder]1392-the elder set forth [his]1392-the elder banquet , which was simple enough : upland cheer of cream and honey , and rough bread ; but sweet it was to [Birdalone]108-birdalone to eat it with good welcome , and the courtesy of [the old man]1380-the old man . When [they]4611-the little ones were done , [they]4611-the little ones went out - a - doors , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone and [the old man]1380-the old man laid [them]4611-the little ones down under an oak - tree , and [the children]4637-the children sported about anigh [them]4611-the little ones . Then spake [Birdalone]108-birdalone : [Old man]1409-old man , [thou]1410-thou hast been kind unto [me]0-i ; but now wouldest [thou]1410-thou tell [me]0-i about [thee]1410-thou , what [thou]1410-thou art , and what are these walls about [us]1411-us here ? Said [he]1409-old man : [I]0-i doubt if [I]0-i may do so , this day at least . But belike [thou]1410-thou shalt abide with [us]1411-us , and then some day the word may come into [my]0-i mouth . [She]108-birdalone held [her]108-birdalone peace , and into [her]108-birdalone mind it came that it would be sweet to dwell there , and watch [those fair children]1412-those fair children waxing , and [the lad]4608-the lad growing up and loving [her]108-birdalone ; yea , even [she]108-birdalone fell to telling up the years which would make [him]4608-the lad [a man]217-a man , and tried to see [herself]108-birdalone , how [she]108-birdalone would look , when the years were worn thereto . Then [she]108-birdalone reddened at the untold thought , and looked down and was silent . But [the elder]1392-the elder looked on [her]108-birdalone anxiously , and said : It will be no such hard life for [thee]108-birdalone , for [I]0-i have still some work in [me]0-i , and [thou]1410-thou mayst do something in spite of [thy]1410-thou slender and delicate fashion . [She]108-birdalone laughed merrily , and said : Forsooth , [good sire]1416-good sire , [I]0-i might do somewhat more than something ; for [I]0-i am deft in all such work as here [ye]1416-good sire need ; so fear not but [I]0-i should earn [my]0-i livelihood , and that with joy . Merry days shall [we]1417-we have then , said [he]1392-the elder . But therewith [her]108-birdalone eye caught the gleam of [her]108-birdalone golden sleeve , and [she]108-birdalone thought of [Aurea]107-aurea , and [her]108-birdalone heart smote [her]108-birdalone for [her]108-birdalone errand ; then [she]108-birdalone laid [her]108-birdalone hand on [her]108-birdalone girdle and called to mind [little Viridis]108-birdalone , and the glitter of the ring on [her]108-birdalone finger brought the image of [Atra]109-atra before [her]108-birdalone ; then [she]108-birdalone rose up and said : [Thou]1418-thou art kind , [father]1419-father , but [I]0-i may not ; [I]0-i have an errand ; this day must [I]0-i depart from [thee]1419-father . [He]1419-father said : [Thou]1418-thou hast broken [my]0-i heart ; if [I]0-i were not so old , [I]0-i would weep . And [he]1419-father hung adown [his]1419-father head . [She]108-birdalone stood before [him]1419-father abashed , as if [she]108-birdalone had done [him]1419-father a wrong . At last [he]1419-father looked up and said : Must it be today ? Wilt [thou]1418-thou not abide with [us]1420-us night - long , and go [thy]1418-thou ways in the early morning ? Now [she]108-birdalone scarce knew how to gainsay [him]1419-father , so wretched as [the old carle]4662-the old carle looked ; so it came to this , that [she]108-birdalone yeasaid the abiding till tomorrow . Then suddenly [he]1419-father became gay and merry , and [he]1419-father kissed [her]108-birdalone hand , and fell to much speaking , telling tales of little import concerning [his]1419-father earlier days . But when [she]108-birdalone asked [him]1419-father again of how [he]1419-father came [there]215-there , and what meant [the great ruined house]1423-the great ruined house , then [he]1419-father became foolish and wandering , and might scarce answer [her]108-birdalone ; whereas otherwise [he]1419-father was [a well - spoken old carle of many words , and those of the grandest]1424-a well - spoken old carle of many words , and those of the grandest . Then changed [his]1419-father mood again , and [he]1419-father fell to bewailing [her]108-birdalone departure , and how that henceforth [he]1419-father should have none to speak to [him]1419-father with understanding . Then [she]108-birdalone smiled on [him]1419-father and said : But [yonder babes]1425-yonder babes will grow up ; month by month [they]1425-yonder babes will be better fellows unto [thee]1419-father . [Fair child]950-fair child , [he]1419-father said , [thou]1427-thou dost not know . [My]0-i days to come are but few , so that [I]0-i should see but little of [their]1425-yonder babes waxing in any case . But furthermore , wax [they]1425-yonder babes will not ; such as they be now , such shall [they]1425-yonder babes be till [I]0-i at least see the last of them and [the earth]432-the earth . [Birdalone]108-birdalone wondered at this word , and the place seemed changed to [her]108-birdalone , yea , was grown somewhat dreary ; but [she]108-birdalone said to [the carle]1429-the carle : And [thou]1427-thou , dost [thou]1427-thou change in any wise , since these change not ? [He]1429-the carle laughed somewhat grimly , and said : [The old that be here]1430-the old that be here change from old to dead ; how could [I]0-i change to better ? Yea , the first thing [I]0-i had to do here was to bury [an old man]1431-an old man . Quoth [she]108-birdalone : And were there [any children]1432-any children [here]244-here then ? [Yea]1434-yea , said [he]1429-the carle ; these same , or [I]0-i can see no difference in [them]1432-any children . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : And how long ago is that ? And how camest [thou]1427-thou hither ? [His]1429-the carle face became foolish , and [he]1429-the carle gibbered rather than spake : No , [I]0-i wot not ; no , no , no , not a whit , a whit . But presently after was [he]1429-the carle [himself]1429-the carle again , and telling [her]108-birdalone a tale of [a great lady of [the earl - folk]1436-the earl - folk]1435-a great lady of the earl - folk , [[a baron]1437-a baron â€™s dame]1438-a baron â€™s dame , and how dear [he]1429-the carle was unto [her]108-birdalone . [He]1429-the carle lay yet on the grass , and [she]108-birdalone stood before [him]1429-the carle , and presently [he]1429-the carle put forth a hand to [her]108-birdalone gown - hem and drew [her]108-birdalone to [him]1429-the carle thereby , and fell to caressing [her]108-birdalone feet ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone was ashamed thereat , and a little angry . [He]1429-the carle was nought abashed , but sat up and said : Well , since [thou]1439-thou must needs depart tomorrow , be [we]1440-we merry today . And [I]0-i pray [thee]108-birdalone talk much with [me]0-i , [fair child]950-fair child , for sweet and sweet is [thy]108-birdalone voice to hearken . Then [he]1429-the carle arose and said : Now will [I]0-i fetch [thee]108-birdalone somewhat to eke the joy of [us]1440-we both . And [he]1429-the carle turned therewith and went into [the house]311-the house . [Birdalone]108-birdalone stood there , and was now perplexed and downhearted ; for now the look of [the elder]1392-the elder scarce liked [her]108-birdalone , and [the children]4637-the children began to seem to [her]108-birdalone as images , or at the best not more to [her]108-birdalone than the rabbits or the goats ; and [she]108-birdalone rued [her]108-birdalone word that [she]108-birdalone would abide there the night through . For [she]108-birdalone said to [herself]108-birdalone : [I]0-i fear some trap or guile ; is [the witch behind this]1445-the witch behind this also ? for [the old man]1380-the old man is yet stark , and though [he]1380-the old man be foolish at whiles , yet may [wizardry]1447-wizardry have learned [him]1380-the old man some guile . With that cometh out the carle again , bearing a little keg and a mazer roughly wrought ; and [he]1429-the carle came to [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and sat down , and bade [her]108-birdalone sit by [him]1429-the carle , and said to [her]108-birdalone : Maybe [I]0-i shall hear more of [thy]108-birdalone sweet voice when [thy]108-birdalone sweet lips have been in the cup . Therewith [he]1429-the carle poured forth into the mazer , and handed it to [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and lo ! it was clear and good mead . [She]108-birdalone sipped thereof daintily , and , to say sooth , was well - pleased therewith , and it stirred the heart in [her]108-birdalone . But then [she]108-birdalone gave back the cup to [the elder]1392-the elder , and would no more of it . As for [him]1429-the carle , [he]1429-the carle drank what was left in the cup , looking over the rim thereof meanwhile ; and then filled [himself]1429-the carle another , and another , and yet more . But whereas it might have been looked for that [his]1429-the carle tongue should be loosened by the good mead into foolishness and gibbering , [he]1429-the carle became rather few - spoken , and more courteous and stately even than [he]1429-the carle had been at the first . But in the end , forsooth , [he]1429-the carle was forgetting [Birdalone]108-birdalone , what [she]108-birdalone was , and [he]1429-the carle fell a - talking , always with much pomp and state , as if to barons and earls , and [great ladies]1449-great ladies ; till suddenly [his]1429-the carle head fell back , [he]1429-the carle turned over on [his]1429-the carle face , and all wit was gone from [him]1429-the carle . At first , then , [Birdalone]108-birdalone was afraid that [he]1429-the carle was dead , or nigh unto death , and [she]108-birdalone knelt down and raised [his]1429-the carle head , and fetched water and cast it over [his]1429-the carle face . But when [she]108-birdalone saw that [he]1429-the carle was breathing not so ill , and that the colour was little changed in [his]1429-the carle lips and cheeks , [she]108-birdalone knew that it was but the might of the mead that had overcome [him]1429-the carle . Wherefore [she]108-birdalone laid [him]1429-the carle so that [he]1429-the carle was easy , and then stood up and looked about [her]108-birdalone , and saw [the children]4637-the children playing together a little way off ; and nought else anigh [her]108-birdalone , save the birds in the brake , or flying on [their]4637-the children errands eagerly from place to place . Then , as it were , without [her]108-birdalone will being told [them]4637-the children , [her]108-birdalone limbs and [her]108-birdalone feet turned [her]108-birdalone about to [the shore]344-the shore where lay [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat , and [she]108-birdalone went speedily but quietly thitherward , [her]108-birdalone heart beating quick , for fear lest something should yet stay [her]108-birdalone , and [her]108-birdalone eyes glancing from brake to bush , as if [she]108-birdalone looked to see [some enemy , old or new]1453-some enemy , old or new , come out thence . So now [her]108-birdalone will was clear enough to [her]108-birdalone feet , and [they]4637-the children brought [her]108-birdalone down to the water - side and [the long strand]1454-the long strand , past which the wide water lay windless and gleaming in the hot afternoon . Then lightly [she]108-birdalone stepped aboard , and awoke the Sending Boat with blood - offering , and [it]823-the sending boat obeyed [her]108-birdalone , and sped swiftly on the way to the southward . Chapter X ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone Comes to [the Isle of]1252-the isle of [the Queens Birdalone]108-birdalone awoke the next morning while [the boat]850-the boat was yet speeding over [the water]347-the water , and the sun was up : but [she]108-birdalone was hard on [the land]198-the land , which sat low and green , like [a meadow exceeding fair]1459-a meadow exceeding fair , on the bosom of [the water]347-the water , and many goodly trees were sprinkled about [the greenland]1461-the greenland . But from amidst the trees , no great way from [the water]347-the water â€™s edge , rose [a great house]1385-a great house , white and fair , as if [it]1385-a great house were new - builded , and all glorious with pinnacles , and tabernacles set with imagery . Presently [the boat]850-the boat â€™s bows ran into the reed and rush at the brim of [the water]347-the water , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone stepped ashore without more ado , and the scent of the meadow - sweet amongst which [she]108-birdalone landed brought back unto [her]108-birdalone the image of [Green Eyot]6-green eyot that while agone . But now when [she]108-birdalone was ashore the dread took hold of [her]108-birdalone again , and [her]108-birdalone knees trembled under [her]108-birdalone , so that [she]108-birdalone might scarce stand , so fearful was [she]108-birdalone of walking into some trap ; especially when [she]108-birdalone beheld [that goodly house]1466-that goodly house , lest therein awaited [her]108-birdalone [some proud and cruel lady]1467-some proud and cruel lady , and no kind damsels to deliver [her]108-birdalone . [She]108-birdalone looked about [her]108-birdalone , and saw in all [the fair meadow]1468-the fair meadow neither [man]537-man nor [woman]1470-woman , nor draught - beast nor milch - beast , nought but the little creatures of the brake and the bent - grass , which were but as the blossoms thereof ; and the birds running in the herbage or singing amidst the tree - boughs . Then [she]108-birdalone thought that [she]108-birdalone must needs go forward , or belike [her]108-birdalone errand would not speed ; that the Sending Boat might not obey [her]108-birdalone , unless [she]108-birdalone saw through the adventure to the end ; so [she]108-birdalone went on toward [the house]311-the house quaking . Soon was [she]108-birdalone at [the porch of [the white palace]1473-the white palace]1472-the porch of the white palace , and had seen [no man]534-no man nor heard any voice of [men]204-men ; much [she]108-birdalone marvelled , despite [her]108-birdalone dread , at the beauty of [the said house]372-the said house , and the newness thereof ; for it was as one flower arisen out of [the earth]432-the earth , and every part of it made the beauty of the other parts more excellent ; and so new it was , that it would have seemed as if [the masons thereof]1478-the masons thereof had but struck [their]1478-the masons thereof scaffold yesterday , save that under the very feet of the walls the sweet garden flowers grew all uncrushed . Now comes [Birdalone]108-birdalone through [the porch]652-the porch unto the screens of [the great hall]1480-the great hall ; and [she]108-birdalone stopped a little to recover [her]108-birdalone breath , that [she]108-birdalone might be [the quieter and calmer amongst [the great folk]1482-the great folk and mighty whom [she]108-birdalone looked to find therein]1481-the quieter and calmer amongst the great folk and mighty whom she looked to find therein . So [she]108-birdalone gathered heart ; but one thing daunted [her]108-birdalone , to wit , that [she]108-birdalone heard no sound come from [that great and goodly hall]1483-that great and goodly hall , so that [she]108-birdalone doubted if it were perchance left desert by [them]1484-them who had been [[its]1483-that great and goodly hall lords]1485-its lords . [She]108-birdalone raised [her]108-birdalone hand to the door of the screen , and it opened easily before [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone entered , and there indeed [she]108-birdalone saw new tidings . For the boards end - long and over - thwart were set , and thereat were sitting [a many folk]1486-a many folk , and [their]1486-a many folk hands were reached out to knife and to dish , and to platter and cup ; but such a hush there was within , that the song of the garden birds without sounded to [her]108-birdalone as loud as they were the voices of [the children of Adam]551-the children of adam . Next [she]108-birdalone saw that [all that company]1488-all that company , from [the great folk on the dais]1489-the great folk on the dais down to [those who stood about the hall to do the service]1490-those who stood about the hall to do the service , were [women]420-women , [one and all]1492-one and all ; not one carle might [she]108-birdalone see from where [she]108-birdalone stood : lovely were [they]420-women many of [them]420-women , and [none less than comely]1493-none less than comely ; [their]420-women cheeks were bright , and [their]420-women eyes gleamed , and [their]420-women hair flowed down fair of fashion . And [she]108-birdalone stood , and durst not move a long while , but expected when [someone]485-someone would speak a word , and [all]881-all should turn [their]881-all heads toward [the new - comer]510-the new - comer . But [none]1359-none moved nor spake . And the fear increased in [her]108-birdalone amidst that hush , and weighed so heavy on [her]108-birdalone heart , that at last [she]108-birdalone might endure it no longer , but fell swooning to the floor . When [she]108-birdalone came to [herself]108-birdalone ; and the swoon - dreams had left [her]108-birdalone , [she]108-birdalone saw by the changing of the sun through [the hall]1193-the hall - windows , that [she]108-birdalone had lain there long , more nearly two hours than one ; and at first [she]108-birdalone covered [her]108-birdalone face with [her]108-birdalone hands as [she]108-birdalone crouched there , that [she]108-birdalone might not see the sight of [the silent hall]1499-the silent hall , for yet was it as hushed as before . Then slowly [she]108-birdalone arose , and the sound of [her]108-birdalone raiment and [her]108-birdalone stirring feet was loud in [her]108-birdalone ears . But when [she]108-birdalone was upright on [her]108-birdalone feet , [she]108-birdalone hardened [her]108-birdalone heart , and went forth into [the hall]1193-the hall , and no less was [her]108-birdalone wonder than erst . For when [she]108-birdalone came close to [those ladies]1501-those ladies as [they]1501-those ladies sat at table , and [her]108-birdalone raiment brushed the raiment of [the serving - women]1502-the serving - women as [she]108-birdalone passed by , then saw [she]108-birdalone how no breath came from any of these , and that [they]1501-those ladies neither spake nor moved , because [they]1501-those ladies were dead . At first , then , [she]108-birdalone thought to flee away at once , but again [she]108-birdalone had mind of [her]108-birdalone errand , and so went up [the hall]1193-the hall , and so forth on to the dais ; and there again , close by the high table , [she]108-birdalone saw new tidings . For there was set a bier , covered with gold and pall , and on it was laid [a tall man]1504-a tall man , [a king , belted and crowned]1505-a king , belted and crowned ; and beside the said bier , by the head of [the king]1335-the king , knelt [a queen of exceeding goodly body , clad all in raiment of pearl and bawdekin]1507-a queen of exceeding goodly body , clad all in raiment of pearl and bawdekin ; and [her]1507-a queen of exceeding goodly body , clad all in raiment of pearl and bawdekin hands were clasped together , and [her]1507-a queen of exceeding goodly body , clad all in raiment of pearl and bawdekin mouth was drawn , and [her]1507-a queen of exceeding goodly body , clad all in raiment of pearl and bawdekin brow knit with the anguish of [her]1507-a queen of exceeding goodly body , clad all in raiment of pearl and bawdekin grief . But athwart [the king]1335-the king â€™s breast lay a naked sword all bloody ; and this [Birdalone]108-birdalone noted , that whereas [the lady]1145-the lady was of skin and hue as if [she]1145-the lady were alive , [the king]1335-the king was yellow as wax , and [his]1335-the king cheeks were shrunken , and [his]1335-the king eyes had been closed by the wakers of the dead . Long [Birdalone]108-birdalone looked and wondered ; and now if [her]108-birdalone fear were less , [her]108-birdalone sorrow was more for [all that folk sitting there dead in [their]1511-all that folk sitting there dead in their ancient state and pomp ancient state and pomp]1511-all that folk sitting there dead in their ancient state and pomp . And was not the thought clean out of [her]108-birdalone head , that yet [they]1511-all that folk sitting there dead in their ancient state and pomp might awake and challenge [her]108-birdalone , and that [she]108-birdalone might be made [one of that silent company]1512-one of that silent company . Withal [she]108-birdalone felt [her]108-birdalone head beginning to fail [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone feared that [she]108-birdalone might swoon again and never waken more , but lie for ever beside that image of [the dead king]1513-the dead king . So then [she]108-birdalone refrained [her]108-birdalone both of fear and sorrow , and walked speedily down [the hall]1193-the hall , looking neither to the right nor left : and [she]108-birdalone came forth into the pleasance , but stayed there nought , so nigh it seemed to [that hushed company]1515-that hushed company . Thence came [she]108-birdalone forth into [the open meadow]1516-the open meadow , and sweet and dear seemed its hot sunshine and noisy birds and rustling leaves . Nevertheless , so great was the tumult of [her]108-birdalone spirits , that once more [she]108-birdalone grew faint , and felt that [she]108-birdalone might scarce go further . So [she]108-birdalone dragged [herself]108-birdalone into the shade of a thorn - tree , and let [her]108-birdalone body sink unto the ground , and lay there long unwitting . Chapter XI ~ And Now [She]108-birdalone Comes to [the Isle of [the Kings]124-the kings]54-the isle of kings When [Birdalone]108-birdalone came to [herself]108-birdalone it was drawing toward the glooming , and [she]108-birdalone rose up hastily , and went down to [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat , for [she]108-birdalone would not for aught abide the night in [that fearful isle]1518-that fearful isle , lest [the flock of the hall]1519-the flock of the hall should come alive and walk in the dusk and the dark . [She]108-birdalone stepped aboard lightly , and yielded [her]108-birdalone blood to the pride of [that ferry]1520-that ferry , and it awoke and bore [her]108-birdalone forth , and [she]108-birdalone went through the night till [she]108-birdalone fell asleep . When [she]108-birdalone awoke it was broad day and the sun just arising , and lo ! before [her]108-birdalone , some half mile off , [an isle rugged and rocky]1521-an isle rugged and rocky , and going up steep from [the shore]344-the shore ; and then , held as [it]1523-it were by the fangs of the rocks and pikes of [the higher land]1524-the higher land , was [a castle]1525-a castle , white , high , and hugely builded , though , because of [the rock - land]1526-the rock - land belike , [it]1525-a castle spread not much abroad . Like to [the lovely house of yesterday]1527-the lovely house of yesterday , [it]1527-the lovely house of yesterday seemed new - builded ; and , little as [Birdalone]108-birdalone knew of such matters , [her]108-birdalone heart told [her]108-birdalone that [this new house]1528-this new house was fashioned for battle . [She]108-birdalone was downcast when [she]108-birdalone saw [the isle]631-the isle so rugged and forbidding , but when [the boat]850-the boat came aland in [a stony bight]1531-a stony bight , whence the ground went up somewhat steeply toward [the heights]1532-the heights , [she]108-birdalone went ashore straightway , and toiled up toward the white battlement . Presently [she]108-birdalone found [herself]108-birdalone in [a strait and rugged path betwixt two walls of rock]1533-a strait and rugged path betwixt two walls of rock , so that [she]108-birdalone lost sight of [the castle]1534-the castle a while , till [she]108-birdalone came out on to [a level place which looked down from aloft on to [the blue water]1536-the blue water]1535-a level place which looked down from aloft on to the blue water , but all over against [her]108-birdalone close at hand were the great towers and walls . [She]108-birdalone was worn by [the rough road]1537-the rough road , and over helpless [she]108-birdalone felt [her]108-birdalone , and all too little to deal with that huge morsel of [the world]417-the world ; and [her]108-birdalone valiancy gave way , and [her]108-birdalone trust in [her]108-birdalone errand . [She]108-birdalone sat down on a stone and wept abundantly . After a while [she]108-birdalone was amended , and [she]108-birdalone looked up and saw the huge hold , and said : Yea , but if it were less by the half than it is , it would still be big enough to cow [me]0-i . Yet [she]108-birdalone stood not up . Then [she]108-birdalone put forth a foot of [her]108-birdalone , and said aloud : Sorely hath [this rough road]1539-this rough road tried [[Atra]109-atra â€™s shoon]1540-atra â€™s shoon and [their]1540-atra â€™s shoon goodly window - work ; if [they]1540-atra â€™s shoon are to be known [I]0-i must be speedy on [my]0-i journey or go barefoot . As [she]108-birdalone spoke [she]108-birdalone stood up , and the sound of [her]108-birdalone own voice frighted [her]108-birdalone , though nought noiseless was [the place]1541-the place ; for the wind was there , and beat to and fro [the castle]1534-the castle and [the rock]1543-the rock , and ran baffled into every corner of [that market - place of nothing]1544-that market - place of nothing . For in [that garth]1545-that garth was [neither knight]1546-neither knight nor [squire]1547-squire nor [sergeant]1548-sergeant ; no spear - head glittered from the wall , no gleam of helm showed from the war - swales ; [no porter]1549-no porter was at the gate ; [the drawbridge over [the deep ghyll]1551-the deep ghyll]1550-the drawbridge over the deep ghyll was down , the portcullis was up , and the great door cast wide open . [Birdalone]108-birdalone steeled [her]108-birdalone heart and went forward swiftly , and over [the bridge]1552-the bridge , and entered [the basecourt]1553-the basecourt , and came without more ado to the door of [the great hall]1480-the great hall , and opened [it]1555-it easily , as with the door of yesterday , looking to find another show like unto that one ; and even so it fell out . Forsooth [the hall]1193-the hall was nought light and lovely , and gay with gold and bright colours , as that other , but beset with huge round pillars that bore aloft a wide vault of stone , and of stone were the tables ; and the hallings that hung on the wall were terrible pictures of battle and death , and the fall of [cities]1557-cities , and towers a - tumbling and houses a - flaming . None the less there also were the shapes of [folk that moved not nor spake]1558-folk that moved not nor spake , though not so thronged was [that hall]1559-that hall as the other one ; and it seemed as if [men]204-men were sitting there at a council rather than a feast . Close by [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s right hand as [she]108-birdalone entered were standing in a row along the screen [big men - at - arms]1561-big men - at - arms all weaponed , and [their]1561-big men - at - arms faces hidden by [their]1561-big men - at - arms sallets ; and down below the dais on either side of the high table was again a throng of [all - armed men]1562-all - armed men ; and at the high - table itself ; and looking down [the hall]1193-the hall , sat [three crowned kings]1564-three crowned kings , each with [his]1564-three crowned kings drawn sword lying across [his]1564-three crowned kings knees , and [three long - hoary wise men]1565-three long - hoary wise men stood before [them]1564-three crowned kings at the nether side of the board . [Birdalone]108-birdalone looked on it all , striving with [her]108-birdalone fear : but yet more there was , for [she]108-birdalone deemed that needs must [she]108-birdalone go through [the hall]1193-the hall up to [the dais]1567-the dais , lest [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat deny its obedience . Up toward [the dais]1567-the dais [she]108-birdalone went then , passing by weaponed men who sat as if abiding [the council]1570-the council â€™s end at the end - long tables . And now , though no shape of [man there spake or breathed]1571-man there spake or breathed , yet sound lacked not ; for within [the hall]1193-the hall went the wind as without , and beat about from wall to wall , and drave clang and clash from the weapons hung up , and waved the arras , and fared moaning in the nooks , and hummed in the vault above . Came [she]108-birdalone up to [the dais]1567-the dais then , and stood beside [one of [the wise men]1361-the wise men]1574-one of the wise men , and looked on [the kings]1576-the kings , and saw the mightiness which had been in [them]1576-the kings , and quaked before [them]1576-the kings . Then [she]108-birdalone turned from [them]1576-the kings and looked down to the floor , and lo ! there , just below the dais , lay [a woman on a golden bier]1577-a woman on a golden bier ; exceeding fair had [she]1577-a woman on a golden bier been , with long yellow hair streaming down from [her]1577-a woman on a golden bier head ; but now waxen white [she]1577-a woman on a golden bier was , with ashen lips and sunken cheeks . Clad was [she]1577-a woman on a golden bier in raiment of purple and pall , but the bosom of [her]1577-a woman on a golden bier was bared on one side , and therein was the road whereby the steel had fared which had been [her]1577-a woman on a golden bier bane . Now when [Birdalone]108-birdalone had gazed thereon a while , [she]108-birdalone deemed that if [she]108-birdalone tarried there long amidst [those fierce men by [the dead woman]1579-the dead woman]1578-those fierce men by the dead woman , [she]108-birdalone should lose [her]108-birdalone wit full soon , so sore the fear , held back , beset [her]108-birdalone now . Wherefore [she]108-birdalone turned and went hastily down [the hall]1193-the hall , and out - a - doors , and over [the bridge]1552-the bridge , and ran fleet - foot down the rocky way whereby [she]108-birdalone had come , till [she]108-birdalone could run no further , and lay down under [a great stone breathless and fordone]1582-a great stone breathless and fordone ; yet [her]108-birdalone heart upheld [her]108-birdalone and suffered [her]108-birdalone not to swoon , belike because [she]108-birdalone had given [her]108-birdalone limbs such hard work to do . There [she]108-birdalone lay awake and troubled for an hour or more , and then [she]108-birdalone fell asleep , and slept till the day was worn toward sunset , and nought meddled with [her]108-birdalone . [She]108-birdalone arose and went to [[her]108-birdalone ship]1583-her ship somewhat downhearted , wondering how many such terrors should befall [her]108-birdalone ; nay , whether the Sending Boat would so lead [her]108-birdalone that henceforth [she]108-birdalone should happen on [no children of Adam but such as were dead images of the living]1584-no children of adam but such as were dead images of the living . Had all [the world]417-the world died since [she]108-birdalone left [the Isle of [the Young]1586-the young]19-the isle of the young and [the Old]4658-the old ? Howsoever , [she]108-birdalone had nought to do save to board [[her]108-birdalone ferry]4501-her ferry , and content its greedy soul with [her]108-birdalone blood , and drive it with the spell - words . And thereafter , when it was speeding on , and the twilight dusking apace , [she]108-birdalone looked aback , and seemed to see [the far - off woodland]1589-the far - off woodland in [the northern ort]1590-the northern ort , and [the oak - clad ridge]1591-the oak - clad ridge , where [she]108-birdalone had met [[her]108-birdalone wood - mother]900-her wood - mother ; and then it was as if [Habundia]97-habundia were saying to [her]108-birdalone : Meet again [we]1593-we shall . And therewith straightway became life sweeter unto [her]108-birdalone . Deepened then the dusk , and became night , and [she]108-birdalone floated on through it , and was asleep alone on the bosom of [the water]347-the water . Chapter XII ~ Of [Birdalone]108-birdalone , How [She]108-birdalone Came Unto [the Isle of Nothing]1595-the isle of nothing Long before sunrise , in the very morn - dusk , [she]108-birdalone awoke and found that [[her]108-birdalone ferry]4501-her ferry had taken [land]641-land again . Little might [she]108-birdalone see what [the said land]1598-the said land was like ; so [she]108-birdalone sat patiently and abode the day in [the boat]850-the boat ; but when day was come , little more was to see than erst . For flat was [the isle]631-the isle , and scarce raised above [the wash of [the leeward ripple]1602-the leeward ripple]1601-the wash of the leeward ripple on a fair day ; nor was [it]631-the isle either timbered or bushed or grassed , and , so far as [Birdalone]108-birdalone might see , [no one foot of it]1603-no one foot of it differed in aught from another . [Natheless]125-natheless [she]108-birdalone deemed that [she]108-birdalone was bound to go ashore and seek out the adventure , or spoil [her]108-birdalone errand else . Out of [the boat]850-the boat [she]108-birdalone stepped then , and found [the earth]432-the earth all paved of a middling gravel , and nought at all growing there , not even the smallest of herbs ; and [she]108-birdalone stooped down and searched the gravel , and found neither worm nor beetle therein , nay nor [any one of the sharp and slimy creatures which are wo nt in such ground]1606-any one of the sharp and slimy creatures which are wo nt in such ground . A little further [she]108-birdalone went , and yet a little further , and no change there was in [the land]198-the land ; and yet [she]108-birdalone went on and found nothing ; and [she]108-birdalone wended [her]108-birdalone ways southward by the sun , and the day was windless . At last [she]108-birdalone had gone a long way and had no sight of [water south of [the isle]631-the isle]1608-water south of the isle , nor had [she]108-birdalone seen [any hill]1610-any hill , nay , not so much as an ant - heap , whence [she]108-birdalone might look further around ; and it seemed to [her]108-birdalone that [she]108-birdalone might go on for ever , and reach [the heart of Nowhither]1611-the heart of nowhither at last . Wherefore [she]108-birdalone thought [she]108-birdalone would turn back and depart [this ugly isle]1612-this ugly isle , and that no other adventure abided [her]108-birdalone therein . And by now it was high noon ; and [she]108-birdalone turned about and took a few steps on [the backward road]1613-the backward road . But even therewith it seemed as if the sun , which heretofore had been shining brightly in the heavens , went out as a burnt - down candle , and all was become dull grey over head , as all under foot was a dull dun . But [Birdalone]108-birdalone deemed [she]108-birdalone could follow a straight course back again , and so walked on sturdily . Hour after hour [she]108-birdalone went and stayed not , but saw before [her]108-birdalone no glimpse of [the northern shore]1614-the northern shore , and no change in the aspect of the ground about [her]108-birdalone . It had so happened that a little before [she]108-birdalone had turned to go back , [she]108-birdalone had eaten [her]108-birdalone dinner of a piece of bread and a morsel of cheese , and now as [she]108-birdalone stooped and peered on the ground , looking for some sign of the way , as [her]108-birdalone foot - prints going south , and had [her]108-birdalone eyes low anigh [the earth]432-the earth , [she]108-birdalone saw something white at [her]108-birdalone feet in the gathering dusk ( for the day was wearing ) , and [she]108-birdalone put [her]108-birdalone hand to it and lifted it , and found it a crumb of bread , and knew that it must have come from [her]108-birdalone dinner of â€™ seven hours ago , whereas till that time [her]108-birdalone bread had lain unbroken in [her]108-birdalone scrip . Fear and anguish smote [her]108-birdalone therewith , for [she]108-birdalone saw that in [that dull land]4678-that dull land , every piece whereof was like every other piece , [she]108-birdalone must have gone about in a ring , and come back again to where [she]108-birdalone first turned to make for [the northern shore]1614-the northern shore . Yet would [she]108-birdalone not cast aside all hope , but clad [herself]108-birdalone in [her]108-birdalone valiancy . [Forsooth]108-birdalone [she]108-birdalone knew it availed nought to try to move on in the twilight ; so [she]108-birdalone laid [herself]108-birdalone down on [that waste]4680-that waste , and made up [her]108-birdalone mind to sleep if [she]108-birdalone might , and abide the new day there , and then to strive with the way once more , for belike , [she]108-birdalone thought , it may be fair tomorrow , and the sun shining . And as [she]108-birdalone was very weary with tramping [the waste]4681-the waste all day , [she]108-birdalone fell asleep at once , and slept the short night through . But when [she]108-birdalone awoke , and saw what the new day was , [her]108-birdalone heart fell indeed , for now was [she]108-birdalone encompassed and shut in with a thick dark mist ( though it seemed to be broad day ) , so that had there been aught to see [she]108-birdalone would not have seen it [her]108-birdalone own length away from [her]108-birdalone . So there [she]108-birdalone stood , hanging [her]108-birdalone head , and striving to think ; but the master - thought of death drawing nigh scattered all other thoughts , or made them dim and feeble . Long [she]108-birdalone stood there ; but suddenly something came into [her]108-birdalone mind . [She]108-birdalone set [her]1616-her hand to the fair - broidered pouch which hung from [Viridis]108-birdalone â€™[1616-her] loin - girdle , and drew out thence flint and steel and tinder , which matters , forsooth , had served [her]1616-her before in [the boat]850-the boat to make fire withal . Then [she]1616-her set [her]1616-her hand to [her]1616-her head , and drew forth the tress of hair which [Habundia]97-habundia had given [her]1616-her , and which was coiled up in the crown of [her]1616-her own abundant locks which decked [her]1616-her so gloriously ; [she]1616-her drew two hairs from the said tress , and held them between [her]1616-her lips while [she]1616-her did up the tress in its place again , and then , pale and trembling , fell to striking a light , and when [she]1616-her had the tinder burning , [she]1616-her cried out : [O wood - mother]1618-o wood - mother , [wood - mother]1619-wood - mother ! How then may [we]1620-we meet again as [thou]1621-thou didst promise [me]0-i , if [I]0-i die here in this empty waste ? [O wood - mother]1618-o wood - mother , if [thou]1621-thou mightest but come hither for [my]0-i deliverance ! Then [she]1616-her burned the hairs one after another , and stood waiting , but nought befell a great while , and [her]1616-her heart sickened , and there [she]1616-her stood like a stone . But in awhile , lo ! there came as it were a shadow amidst the mist , or rather lying thereon , faint and colourless , and it was of the shape of [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother , with girt - up gown and bow in hand . [Birdalone]108-birdalone cried aloud with joy , and hastened toward the semblance , but came to it no nigher , and still [she]108-birdalone went , and the semblance still escaped [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone followed on and on ; and this lasted long , and faster and faster must [she]108-birdalone follow lest it vanish , and [she]108-birdalone gathered [her]108-birdalone skirts into [her]108-birdalone girdle , and fell to running fleet - foot after the fleeing shadow , which [she]108-birdalone loved dearly even amidst the jaws of death ; and all [her]108-birdalone fleetness of foot had [Birdalone]108-birdalone to put forth in following up the chase ; but even to die in the pain would [she]108-birdalone not miss that dear shadow . But suddenly , as [she]108-birdalone ran , the mist was all gone from before [her]108-birdalone , the sun shone hot and cloudless ; there was no shadow or shape of [Habundia]97-habundia there , nought but [the blue lake]1624-the blue lake and the ugly lip of [that hideous desert]1625-that hideous desert , with [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat lying a half score yards from [her]108-birdalone feet ; and behind [her]108-birdalone stood up , as it were a wall , the mist from out of which [she]108-birdalone had come . [Forsooth Birdalone]108-birdalone was too breathless to cry out [her]108-birdalone joy , but [her]108-birdalone heart went nigh to breaking therewith , and lovely indeed to [her]108-birdalone was the rippled water and the blue sky ; and [she]108-birdalone knew that [[her]108-birdalone wood - mother]900-her wood - mother had sped a sending to [her]108-birdalone help , and [she]108-birdalone fell a - weeping where [she]108-birdalone stood , for love of [[her]108-birdalone wise mother]1628-her wise mother , and for longing to behold [her]1628-her wise mother : [she]108-birdalone stretched out [her]108-birdalone arms to [the north quarter]1629-the north quarter , and said blessings on [her]1628-her wise mother in a voice faint for weariness . Then [she]108-birdalone laid [her]108-birdalone down on [the desert]1630-the desert , and rested [her]108-birdalone with sleep , despite the hot sun , and when [she]108-birdalone awoke , some three hours thereafter , all was as before , save that the sky had now some light - flying clouds , and still was the wall of mist behind [her]108-birdalone . Wherefore [she]108-birdalone deemed [she]108-birdalone had yet time , and the blue rippling water wooed [her]108-birdalone much - besweated limbs ; so [she]108-birdalone did off [her]108-birdalone raiment and took the water , and became happy and unweary therein . Then [she]108-birdalone landed and stood in the sun to dry [her]108-birdalone , and so , strengthened with that refreshing , clad [her]108-birdalone , and went aboard and did the due rites , and sped over [the waters]624-the waters , and had soon lost sight of that ugly blotch on the fair face of [the Great Water]13-the great water . Empty was the day to [Birdalone]108-birdalone save for [her]108-birdalone thoughts , and [she]108-birdalone slept not a good while of the night . When [she]108-birdalone awoke in the morning there was [no land before [her]108-birdalone]1632-no land before her , and [she]108-birdalone began to fear somewhat that so it might be many days , and that [she]108-birdalone might have to fare [the water landless]1633-the water landless , and perchance till [she]108-birdalone starved for hunger ; for now was there but little victual left of that which the kind [Viridis]108-birdalone had given [her]108-birdalone . So [she]108-birdalone wore the day somewhat uneasily , and by then night fell had eaten but little ; yet was that little the last crumb and gobbet of [her]108-birdalone store . Wherefore it is no wonder though [she]108-birdalone were dismayed when [she]108-birdalone awoke early on the morrow , and beheld nought before [her]108-birdalone save [the landless water]1634-the landless water . But about noon [she]108-birdalone deemed [she]108-birdalone saw a little cloud in the offing that moved not as the other clouds , and [she]108-birdalone watched it closely at first , and it changed not any the more , and [she]108-birdalone grew weary of watching it and strove to sleep , turning [her]108-birdalone head to the after part of [her]108-birdalone ferry ; and thus betwixt sleeping and waking [she]108-birdalone wore away three hours : then [she]108-birdalone stood up and looked ahead , and lo , the white cloud had taken shape , and was a white castle far away ( for the day was exceeding clear ) , sitting , as it seemed , on [the very face of the water]1635-the very face of the water . [The boat]850-the boat sped on swiftly thitherward , so that it was not right long ere [Birdalone]108-birdalone beheld [the green shore]1637-the green shore on either side of [the said castle]1638-the said castle , and at last , three hours before sunset , [she]108-birdalone was drawing nigh thereto , and beheld it all clearly , what it was . It was brand - new , and was fair enough , builded part of stone and lime , part of framed work , but was but middling big . As [she]108-birdalone drew nigher yet , [she]108-birdalone saw that there were [folk]4521-folk on the walls of [it]1638-the said castle , and [they]4521-folk seemed to see [her]108-birdalone , for a horn was winded from the battlement , and [folk]4521-folk were running together to somewhither . And now was [Birdalone]108-birdalone come so near , that [she]108-birdalone saw the water - gate of [the castle]1534-the castle , and [folk]4521-folk coming out thereby on to [the landing - place]1643-the landing - place ; and [she]108-birdalone saw presently , that [a very tall man with grizzled hair]1644-a very tall man with grizzled hair stood foremost of [them]1645-them , and [he]1644-a very tall man with grizzled hair waved [his]1644-a very tall man with grizzled hair hand to [her]108-birdalone , and spake something , but the wind bore the words away from [her]108-birdalone ; yet [she]108-birdalone seemed to know that [this folk]1646-this folk would do [her]108-birdalone to wit that [they]1646-this folk would have none of [her]108-birdalone ; and [her]108-birdalone heart died within [her]108-birdalone , so faint and hungry as [she]108-birdalone was . Howsoever [the ferry]4467-the ferry sped on [its]4467-the ferry way swiftly , and in a minute or two had stayed itself at [the landing - stair]1648-the landing - stair , whereabout were gathered [a score of men]1649-a score of men , [some armed some unarmed]1650-some armed some unarmed , and [they]1645-them seemed for the more part to be grey - headed and past middle - age . [Birdalone]108-birdalone stood up in [her]108-birdalone craft , and [the aforesaid tall grey man , who was unarmed , but clad in knightly raiment]1651-the aforesaid tall grey man , who was unarmed , but clad in knightly raiment , stood on the stair and spake unto [her]108-birdalone , and said : [Lady]493-lady , this is [an house where [women]420-women enter never since first the roof was done thereon , which forsooth was but a year ago]1653-an house where women enter never since first the roof was done thereon , which forsooth was but a year ago . [We]1655-we will pray [thee]108-birdalone therefore to turn [thy]108-birdalone boat â€™s head away , and seek some other lodging by [the water]347-the water , either eastward or westward . [Little]126-little knew [Birdalone]108-birdalone of worldly courtesy , or [she]108-birdalone had made [him]1651-the aforesaid tall grey man , who was unarmed , but clad in knightly raiment a sharp answer belike ; but [she]108-birdalone only looked on [him]1651-the aforesaid tall grey man , who was unarmed , but clad in knightly raiment ruefully , and said : [Good warrior]1657-good warrior , [I]0-i am come a long way , and may not turn back from [mine]0-i errand ; and [I]0-i am now lacking victual and hungry , and if [ye]1657-good warrior help [me]0-i not , it is like that [I]0-i shall die . Much lieth on [mine]0-i errand , if [ye]1657-good warrior knew it . [She]108-birdalone was weeping - ripe , but refrained [her]108-birdalone tears , though [her]108-birdalone lip quivered . [She]108-birdalone stretched out [her]108-birdalone hands to [the greybeard]1658-the greybeard , and [he]1658-the greybeard looked on [her]108-birdalone and found [her]108-birdalone exceeding fair ; and [he]1658-the greybeard deemed [her]108-birdalone to be guileless , both because of [her]108-birdalone simple speech and sweet voice , and the goodliness of [her]108-birdalone face and eyes . But [he]1658-the greybeard said : [Lady]493-lady , thine errand hath nought to do with it , it is [thy]108-birdalone womanhood that bars [our]1660-our door . For all [we]1660-our are bound by oath not to suffer [a woman]235-a woman to abide in [this castle]1662-this castle till [[our]1660-our lords]1663-our lords take the bann off , and bid [us]1660-our open to [women]420-women . [She]108-birdalone smiled faintly , and said : If [I]0-i might but see [[thy]108-birdalone lords]1665-thy lords then , since [thou]108-birdalone art not master [here]244-here . [He]1658-the greybeard said : [They]1665-thy lords are away , and will not be back till tomorrow morning ; and [I]0-i wot not the hour of [their]1665-thy lords return . And yet , said [he]1658-the greybeard , [I]0-i would [we]1660-our might help [thee]108-birdalone somewhat . O [I]0-i pray [thee]108-birdalone , [I]0-i pray [thee]108-birdalone ! [she]108-birdalone said , or [mine]108-birdalone errand will come to nought after all . Therewith came [another man down the stair]1667-another man down the stair , and stood by [the old knight]1668-the old knight and plucked [his]1668-the old knight sleeve , and fell to talk with [him]1668-the old knight softly . [This man]1669-this man was by [his]1669-this man habit [a religious]1670-a religious , and was [a younger man than the others]1671-a younger man than the others , it might be of five and thirty winters , and [he]1669-this man was fair of favour . While [they]1660-our spake together [Birdalone]108-birdalone sat [her]108-birdalone down again , and was well - nigh spent . At last [the old man]1380-the old man spake : [Damsel]127-damsel , [he]1380-the old man said , [we]1673-we deem [we]1673-we may suffer [thee]108-birdalone to enter [the castle]1534-the castle since [thy]108-birdalone need is so great , and have a meal â€™s meat at [our]1673-we hands , and yet save [our]1673-we oath , if [thou]108-birdalone depart thence by the landward gate before sunset . Will this serve [thee]108-birdalone ? [Fair sir]1675-fair sir , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , it will save [my]0-i life and [mine]0-i errand ; [I]0-i may say no more words for [my]0-i faintness , else would [I]0-i thank [thee]1380-the old man . [She]108-birdalone stood up on [her]108-birdalone feet , and [the old man - at - arms]1676-the old man - at - arms reached out [his]1676-the old man - at - arms hand to [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone took it and came [her]108-birdalone ways up the stair , but found [herself]108-birdalone but feeble . But [the priest]1677-the priest ( forsooth [he]1677-the priest was [chaplain of [the castle]1534-the castle]1678-chaplain of the castle ) helped [her]108-birdalone on the other side . But when [she]108-birdalone stood on the level stones by the water - gate , [she]108-birdalone turned to [the old man]1380-the old man and said : One thing [I]0-i will ask of [thee]1380-the old man , Is [this place one of [the Wondrous Isles]23-the wondrous isles]1681-this place one of the wondrous isles ? [The elder]1392-the elder shook [his]1392-the elder head . [We]1683-we know not [the Wondrous Isles]1684-the wondrous isles , said [he]1392-the elder ; [this castle]1662-this castle is builded on [the mainland]1030-the mainland . [Her]108-birdalone face flushed for joy at the word , and [she]108-birdalone said : One thing [I]0-i will crave of [thee]1380-the old man , to wit , that [thou]1380-the old man wilt leave [my]0-i barge lying here untouched till [[thy]1380-the old man masters]1687-thy masters come back , and wilt give command that [none]1359-none meddle therewith . [He]1380-the old man would have answered , but [the priest]1677-the priest brake in , and said : This will [he]1380-the old man do , [lady]493-lady , and [he]1380-the old man is [the castellan]1691-the castellan , and moreover [he]1380-the old man will swear to obey [thee]493-lady herein . And therewith [he]1380-the old man drew forth a cross with [God]114-god nailed thereon , and [the castellan]1691-the castellan swore on it with a good will . Then [the priest]1677-the priest drew [Birdalone]108-birdalone on , and between [them]1694-them [they]1694-them brought [her]108-birdalone into [the great hall]1480-the great hall , and set [her]108-birdalone down in a chair and propped [her]108-birdalone with cushions . And when [she]108-birdalone was thus at rest , [she]108-birdalone began to weep somewhat , and [the castellan]1691-the castellan and [the priest]1677-the priest stood by and comforted [her]108-birdalone ; for themseemed , despite [her]108-birdalone grief , that [she]108-birdalone had brought the sun into [[their]1694-them house]1698-their house . Next were victual brought unto [her]108-birdalone of broth and venison , and good wine and cates and strawberries ; and [she]108-birdalone was not so famished but [she]108-birdalone might eat and drink with a good will . But when [she]108-birdalone was done , and had rested a little , [the castellan]1691-the castellan stood up and said : [Lady]493-lady , the sun is gone off the western windows now , and [I]0-i must save [mine]0-i oath ; but ere [thou]1701-thou depart , [I]0-i were fain to hear [thy]1701-thou voice giving [me]0-i pardon for [my]0-i evil cheer and the thrusting of [thee]1701-thou forth . And therewith [he]1691-the castellan put one knee to the ground , and took [her]108-birdalone hand and kissed it . But [Birdalone]108-birdalone was grown merry again , and [she]108-birdalone laughed and said : What pardon [thou]1701-thou canst have of [me]0-i , [kind knight]1702-kind knight , [thou]1701-thou hast ; but now methinks [thou]1701-thou makest overmuch of [me]0-i , because [I]0-i am [the only woman who hath come into [[thy]1701-thou castle]1704-thy castle]1703-the only woman who hath come into thy castle . [I]0-i am but [a simple maiden]1705-a simple maiden , though [mine]0-i errand be not little . Forsooth [she]108-birdalone wondered that [the stark and gruff old man]1706-the stark and gruff old man was so changed to [her]108-birdalone in little space ; for nought [she]108-birdalone knew as yet how the sight of [her]108-birdalone cast a hot gleed of love into the hearts of [them]1707-them who beheld [her]108-birdalone . Now [Birdalone]108-birdalone arose ; but [the castellan]1691-the castellan knelt at [her]108-birdalone feet , and kissed [her]108-birdalone hand again , and again , and yet again . Then [he]1691-the castellan said : [Thou]108-birdalone art gracious indeed . But methinks [the father]4617-the father here will lead [thee]108-birdalone out - a - gates ; for [he]4617-the father may show [thee]108-birdalone a lair , wherein [thou]108-birdalone shalt be safe enough to - night ; and tomorrow may bring new tidings . So [the priest]1677-the priest made obeisance to [her]108-birdalone and led [her]108-birdalone down [the hall]1193-the hall , and [the castellan]1691-the castellan â€™s eyes were following [them]1713-them till the screen hid [them]1713-them . [The priest]1677-the priest left [her]108-birdalone in [the hall - porch]1715-the hall - porch a while , and went into [the buttery]1716-the buttery , and came back with a basket of meat and drink , and [they]1713-them went forth at the great gate together , and there was the last of the sun before [them]1713-them . Chapter II ~ Now Shall Be Told of [the House]311-the house by [the Water - Side]351-the water - side On [a fair smooth road]1719-a fair smooth road went [they]1713-them amidst of [a goodly meadow - land]1720-a goodly meadow - land , wherein were little copses here and there . When [they]1713-them were fairly out of the gate , [the priest]1677-the priest reached for [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s hand , and [she]108-birdalone let [him]1677-the priest take it and lead [her]108-birdalone along thereby , thinking no evil ; but [he]1677-the priest might scarce speak for a while , so great was the stir in [his]1677-the priest heart at the touch of [her]108-birdalone bare flesh . But [Birdalone]108-birdalone spake and said : [Thou]1677-the priest art kind , [father]1419-father , to lead [me]0-i on [my]0-i way thus . [He]1677-the priest answered in a husky voice with [his]1677-the priest eyes cast down , and forsooth set on the feet of [her]108-birdalone : It is not far that [I]0-i am leading [thee]108-birdalone ; there is a broken cot by the copse at the turn of [the road yonder]1723-the road yonder , where [thou]1677-the priest mayst abide to - night ; it is better lodging than none , evil as it is for such an one as [thou]1677-the priest . [Birdalone]108-birdalone laughed : Worse have [I]0-i had , said [she]108-birdalone , than would be the copse without the cot . And [she]108-birdalone thought withal of [the prison in [the Isle of Increase Unsought]4590-the isle of increase unsought]1724-the prison in the isle of increase unsought .
