[She]5201-damsel paled but answered nought ; then [she]5201-damsel mounted [her]5201-damsel palfrey , and [the knight]1813-the knight went to [her]5201-damsel bridle - rein without more words , and so led [her]5201-damsel on up [the valley]4994-the valley by the easiest way amongst [the Greywethers]142-the greywethers . Chapter XI ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone is Led Up [the Black Valley]33-the black valley As [they]5205-they went , [the knight]1813-the knight fell a - talking to [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and that without any of the covert jeering which [he]1813-the knight had used erewhile ; and [he]1813-the knight showed [her]108-birdalone places in [the dale]4999-the dale , as caverns under [the burgs]5208-the burgs , and little eyots in [the stream]1777-the stream , and certain stones amongst the Greywethers whereof stories ran ; and how this and [the other one]5210-the other one had fared in dealings with [the land - wights]5211-the land - wights , and how [one]504-one had perished , and another had been made happy , and so forth . Withal [he]1813-the knight told of [the mountain - folk]5213-the mountain - folk , and in especial how [they]5213-the mountain - folk of [the plains]5214-the plains , when [he]1813-the knight was scarce more than [a boy]5215-a boy , had met [them]5213-the mountain - folk in battle in [that same dale]5216-that same dale , and how fierce the fight was ; whereas [the mountain - men]5217-the mountain - men were fighting for a life of desires accomplished , which hitherto had been but a dream unto [them]5217-the mountain - men ; and [the men of [the plain]4991-the plain]5218-the men of the plain fought for dear life itself , and for all that made it aught save death in life . Wherefore up and down [the dale]4999-the dale [they]5217-the mountain - men fought , at first in ordered ranks and then in knots , and lastly sword to sword and [man]537-man to [man]537-man , till there was no foot of grass or black sand there which had not its shower of blood ; and [the stream]1777-the stream was choked with the dead , and ran red out of [the dale]4999-the dale ; till at last well - nigh [all the host of [the mountain - men]5217-the mountain - men]5225-all the host of the mountain - men was fallen , and scarce less of [the folk of [the plains]5214-the plains]5227-the folk of the plains , but [these men]5229-these men held the field and had the victory . All this [he]1813-the knight told [her]5230-she deftly and well , and though [he]1813-the knight said not so right out , yet let [her]5230-she wot that , youth as [he]1813-the knight was , [he]1813-the knight was of the battle ; and [his]1813-the knight voice was clear and good , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s wrath ran off [her]5230-she , and [she]5230-she hearkened [his]1813-the knight tale , and even asked [him]1813-the knight a question here and there ; and so courteous was [this Black Knight]5231-this black knight now become , that [Birdalone]108-birdalone began to think that [she]5230-she had fallen short of courtesy to [him]1813-the knight , because of [her]5230-she fear and the weariness of the waiting which so oppressed [her]5230-she ; and that shamed and irked [her]5230-she , for [she]5230-she would fain be of all courtesy . Wherefore now [she]5230-she deemed that perchance [she]5230-she had erred in deeming [him]1813-the knight [an evil man]5232-an evil man ; and [she]5230-she looked on [him]1813-the knight from time to time , and deemed [him]1813-the knight goodly of fashion ; [she]5230-she thought [his]1813-the knight eyes were deep , and [his]1813-the knight face sober and fair of aspect , but that [his]1813-the knight nose turned down at the end , and was over thin at the bridge , and moreover [his]1813-the knight lips looked over - sweet and licorous . Now when [the knight]1813-the knight was silent of [his]1813-the knight tales , [Birdalone]108-birdalone fell to asking [him]1813-the knight questions sweetly concerning [this Stony People which was all about [them]5234-this stony people which was all about them]5234-this stony people which was all about them ; and [he]1813-the knight told [her]5230-she all [he]1813-the knight knew , soberly enough at first , yet indeed ended by mocking [them]5234-this stony people which was all about them somewhat , but mocked not at [her]5230-she any more . At last [he]1813-the knight said : [Fair lady]1833-fair lady , that [thou]5236-thou hast not come here all for nought [I]2135-i partly know by those words which [I]2135-i heard come from [thy]1833-fair lady mouth at [[the King]1335-the king â€™s Stone]5238-the king â€™s stone ; wherefore [I]2135-i marvelled indeed when [I]2135-i heard [thee]1833-fair lady say that [thou]5236-thou wouldst go straight out of [the dale]4999-the dale ; for [I]2135-i had deemed [thee]1833-fair lady desirous of trying the adventure of waking [this Stony People]5240-this stony people a - night - tide . Forsooth was this [thy]1833-fair lady mind when [thou]5236-thou soughtest hither to [the dale]4999-the dale ? [She]5230-she reddened at [his]1813-the knight word , and yeasaid [him]1813-the knight shortly . Then said [he]1813-the knight : Is it not [thy]1833-fair lady mind still ? [Sir]4684-sir , said [she]5230-she , as now [I]2135-i have got to fear it . [Yea]4684-sir ? and that is strange , said [he]1813-the knight , for [thou]5236-thou wouldst have waked [the dale]4999-the dale alone ; and now [thou]5236-thou art no longer alone , but hast [me]2135-i to watch and ward [thy]5236-thou waking , [thou]5236-thou art more afeard . [She]5230-she looked on [his]1813-the knight face steadily , to wot if there were no half - hidden smile therein ; but herseemed that [he]1813-the knight spake in all soberness ; and [she]5230-she had nought to say to [him]1813-the knight save this : [Sir]4684-sir , [I]2135-i am now become afraid of the waking . And [he]1813-the knight said no more thereof . Now [they]5245-they went thus , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone not without pleasure , since [her]108-birdalone fear of [the knight]1813-the knight was minished , some three hours up [the dale]4999-the dale , and still were the Greywethers everywhere about [them]5245-they , so that there were well - nigh as many hours as miles in [their]5245-they wending . At last [they]5245-they seemed to be drawing nigh to [the head of [the dale]4999-the dale]5248-the head of the dale , and [the burgs]5208-the burgs and [the rocks]5251-the rocks were before [them]5245-they all round [it]5248-the head of the dale as a wall , though yet about a mile aloof at the further end ; and this end it was wider than elsewhere . Came [they]5245-they then to [a level space of greensward]5252-a level space of greensward clear of the grey stones , which were drawn all around [it]5248-the head of the dale in ordered rings , so that it was as some doom - ring of [an ancient people]5253-an ancient people ; and within [the said space]5254-the said space [Birdalone]108-birdalone beheld a great black horse tethered and cropping the grass . [The knight]1813-the knight led [her]108-birdalone into the ring , and said : Now are [we]5245-they come [home]373-home for the present , [[my]2135-i lady]603-my lady , and if it please [thee]108-birdalone to light down [we]5245-they shall presently eat and drink , and sithence talk a little . And [he]1813-the knight drew nigh to help [her]108-birdalone off [her]108-birdalone horse , but [she]108-birdalone suffered [him]1813-the knight not , and lighted down of [herself]108-birdalone ; but if [she]108-birdalone suffered not [his]1813-the knight hand , [his]1813-the knight eyes [she]108-birdalone must needs suffer , as [he]1813-the knight gazed greedily on the trimness of [her]108-birdalone feet and legs in [her]108-birdalone sliding from [her]108-birdalone horse . Howsoever , [he]1813-the knight took [her]108-birdalone hand , and led [her]108-birdalone to a little mound on the other side of the ring , and bade [her]108-birdalone sit down there , and so did [she]108-birdalone , and from under the nighest of the stones [he]1813-the knight drew forth a pair of saddle - bags , and took victual and wine thence , and [they]5258-they ate and drank together like [old companions]5259-old companions . And now [Birdalone]108-birdalone told [herself]108-birdalone that [the knight]1813-the knight was frank and friendly ; yet forsooth [she]108-birdalone wotted that [her]108-birdalone heart scarce trowed what it feigned , and that [she]108-birdalone yet feared [him]1813-the knight . Chapter XII ~ How Those Twain Get [Them]5258-they from Out of [the Black Valley of]5012-the black valley of [the Greywethers]142-the greywethers When [they]5258-they had dined , and had sat a while talking , [the knight]1813-the knight said : [I]2135-i will ask [thee]108-birdalone once more wherefore [thou]108-birdalone must needs depart from [this dale]5181-this dale leaving [the Greywethers]142-the greywethers unwaked ? Yet this must [I]2135-i tell [thee]108-birdalone first , that this ring at [the dale]4999-the dale â€™s end is the only one due place where the Greywethers can be rightly waked , and that there be [few who wot this]5265-few who wot this . Wilt [thou]108-birdalone not tell [me]2135-i then what is in [thy]108-birdalone mind ? [Birdalone]108-birdalone gazed down on the ground a while ; then [she]108-birdalone lifted up [her]108-birdalone head and looked on [the Black Knight]128-the black knight , and said : [Sir Knight]118-hugh , [we]5258-they have been brought so close together today , and as [meseemeth]113-meseemeth [I]2135-i am so wholly in [thy]118-hugh power , that [I]2135-i will tell [thee]118-hugh the very truth as it is . [My]2135-i mind it was to wake [the dale]4999-the dale here to - night , and take what might befall [me]2135-i . And well indeed might [I]2135-i fear the adventure , which few , [meseemeth]113-meseemeth , would not fear . But so strong is [my]2135-i longing for that which [I]2135-i would crave of [these wights]5036-these wights , that it overmastered [my]2135-i fear , and [my]2135-i purpose held when [I]2135-i entered [the dale]4999-the dale . Then [I]2135-i met [thee]118-hugh ; and here again is the truth , take it how [thou]118-hugh wilt , that presently [I]2135-i feared [thee]118-hugh , and yet [I]2135-i fear [thee]118-hugh ; for [I]2135-i have noted [thee]118-hugh closely all this while , and have seen of [thee]118-hugh , that [thou]118-hugh art over heedful of [my]2135-i poor body , and wouldst have it for thine own if [thou]118-hugh mightest . And there is this in [thee]118-hugh also , as [I]2135-i deem , though [thou]118-hugh [thyself]118-hugh mayst not know it , that [thou]118-hugh wouldst have [thy]118-hugh pleasure of [me]2135-i whether it pleasure [me]2135-i or grieve [me]2135-i ; and this [thy]118-hugh pleasure must [I]2135-i needs gainsay ; for though [thou]118-hugh mayest hereafter become [[my]2135-i friend]304-my friend , yet are there [other friends of [mine]2135-i]5270-other friends of mine , who be such , that [my]2135-i grief would mar any pleasure [they]5270-other friends of mine might have . Hast [thou]118-hugh heard and understood ? [She]2135-i looked on [his]5271-his face steadily as [she]2135-i spake , and saw that it flushed , and darkened , and scowled , and that [his]5271-his hands were clenched , and [his]5271-his teeth set hard together . And again [she]2135-i spake : [Sir]4684-sir , [thou]118-hugh shalt know that beside these shot - weapons , [I]2135-i have a thing here in [my]2135-i girdle that may serve either against [thee]118-hugh or against [me]2135-i , if need drive [me]2135-i thereto ; wherefore [I]2135-i will pray [thee]118-hugh to forbear . Forsooth , [thou]118-hugh shalt presently happen on [other women , who shall be better unto [thee]118-hugh than [I]2135-i can be]5273-other women , who shall be better unto thee than i can be . By then [Birdalone]108-birdalone had spoken the word , [the knight]1813-the knight â€™s face had cleared , and [he]5271-his laughed aloud and said : As to [thy]118-hugh last words , therein at least [thou]118-hugh liest , [[my]2135-i lady]603-my lady . But for the rest , [I]2135-i see that it must all be as [thou]118-hugh wiliest . [Yea]5276-yea , if such be [thy]118-hugh will , [we]5277-we shall presently to horse and ride down [the dale]4999-the dale again , and at the end thereof [I]2135-i shall leave [thee]118-hugh to go [home]373-home alone at [thy]118-hugh will . [She]2135-i said : For that [I]2135-i can [thee]5271-his thanks with all [my]2135-i heart . But why hast [thou]118-hugh not asked [me]2135-i of whence [I]2135-i am , and whither [I]2135-i would go [home]373-home ? Again [he]2135-i laughed and said : Because [I]2135-i know already . [I]2135-i have had more than two or three tales from [them]5281-them who have seen [thee]2135-i , or spoken unto others who have seen [thee]2135-i , how [the gay Champions of the Castle of the Quest]5282-the gay champions of the castle of the quest had fished up a wondrous pearl of price from out of [the Great Water]13-the great water ; and when [I]2135-i set eyes on [thy]2135-i beauty , [I]2135-i knew that the said pearl could be nowhere else than under [mine]2135-i eyes . Let that pass , [she]2135-i said , and blushed not ; but now tell [me]2135-i the truth as [I]2135-i have told [thee]2135-i , why [thou]2135-i art so instant with [me]2135-i to wake the Greywethers to - night ? [He]2135-i kept silence a while , and , as [she]2135-i looked on [him]2135-i , [she]2135-i thought [she]2135-i saw confusion in [his]2135-i face ; but at last [he]2135-i said : [Thou]2135-i wert wrong in saying that [I]2135-i heeded not [thy]2135-i pleasure , and solace , and welfare . Meseemed , and yet doth , that it might be to thine avail to wake the Greywethers to - night ; and never again mayst [thou]2135-i have a chance of the waking , as erst [I]2135-i said . [I]2135-i say [I]2135-i wish [thee]2135-i to have fulfilment of [thy]2135-i craving . Nor hast [thou]2135-i aught to fear of [them]2135-i , seeing that it is but dastards and [fools]5283-fools that [they]2135-i undo . [He]2135-i broke off [his]2135-i speech , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone yet looked on [him]2135-i , and after a little [he]2135-i said : [Thou]2135-i drawest the truth out of [me]2135-i ; for moreover [I]2135-i would have [thee]2135-i with [me]2135-i longer than [thou]2135-i wouldst be if [we]5284-we but rode together down [the water]347-the water and out of [the dale]4999-the dale , and [thou]2135-i to fare away alone . [Birdalone]108-birdalone spake in a while , and that while [he]2135-i gazed upon [her]108-birdalone eagerly ; [she]108-birdalone said : [I]2135-i shall now tell [thee]2135-i that [I]2135-i shall abide the adventure of the waking to - night , whatever befall . And [I]2135-i , said [he]2135-i , will so do that [thou]2135-i mayst fear [me]2135-i the less ; for [I]2135-i will unarm [me]2135-i when the night cometh , and [thou]2135-i [thyself]2135-i shalt keep [mine]2135-i hauberk and sword and anlace . [She]108-birdalone said : It is well ; [I]2135-i will take that , lest desire overmaster [thee]2135-i . [They]5287-they spake no more of it at that time , and it was now five hours after noon . [Birdalone]108-birdalone arose , for [she]108-birdalone found it hard to sit still and abide nightfall : [she]108-birdalone went without the two first rings of the Greywethers , which were set in more open order beyond that , and [she]108-birdalone looked all about [her]108-birdalone , to [the black rocks on either side]5288-the black rocks on either side , and to the great black wall at [the dale]4999-the dale â€™s ending , and [the blue mountains]5290-the blue mountains aloof beyond [it]4999-the dale ; then down toward [the plain of the dale]5291-the plain of the dale came [her]108-birdalone eyes , and [she]108-birdalone looked through the tangle of the grey stones . Now [she]108-birdalone seemed to be looking more intently upon some one thing ; with that [she]108-birdalone called to [her]108-birdalone the Black Knight , who was hanging about watching [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone said to [him]2135-i : Fair sir , art [thou]2135-i clear - seeing and far - seeing ? [I]2135-i am not thought to be purblind , quoth [he]2135-i . Then [Birdalone]108-birdalone reached out [her]108-birdalone hand and pointed and said : Canst [thou]2135-i see aught which [thou]2135-i didst not look to see , there , up [the dale]4999-the dale as [I]2135-i point ? Said [he]2135-i : All too clear [I]2135-i see the hand and the wrist of [thee]108-birdalone , and that blinds [me]2135-i to aught else . [I]2135-i pray [thee]2135-i fool not , [she]108-birdalone said , but look heedfully , and [thou]2135-i mayst see what [I]2135-i see , and then tell [me]2135-i what it means . Though forsooth [I]2135-i am exceeding in far sight . [He]2135-i looked under the sharp of [his]2135-i hand heedfully , then [he]2135-i turned unto [her]108-birdalone and said : By [All - hallows]5184-all - hallows ! there is in [thee]108-birdalone every excellency ! [Thou]2135-i art right ; [I]2135-i see a bay horse up there feeding on the bites of grass amongst the Greywethers . Look again ! [she]108-birdalone said ; what else canst [thou]2135-i see ? Is there aught anigh to the bay horse which is like to the gleam and glitter of metal . Christ ! said [he]2135-i , once more [thou]2135-i art right . There be [weaponed men in [the dale]4999-the dale]5294-weaponed men in the dale . Tarry not , [I]2135-i beseech [thee]2135-i , but get to horse forthright , and [I]2135-i will do no less . There goeth the waking of [the dale]4999-the dale for this time , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , laughing . But art [thou]2135-i not in haste , [fair sir]1675-fair sir ? may not [these]5298-these be [friends]404-friends ? [The knight]1813-the knight laid [his]1813-the knight hand upon [her]108-birdalone shoulder , and thrust [her]108-birdalone on toward [her]108-birdalone palfrey , and spake fiercely , but not loud : [Thee]2135-i [I]2135-i pray not to fool now ! There is not a minute to spare . If [thou]2135-i deemest [me]2135-i evil , as [I]2135-i think [thou]2135-i dost , there are worser than [I]2135-i , [I]2135-i tell [thee]2135-i , there are worser . But [we]5301-we will talk of it when [we]5301-we be in the saddle , and clear of [this accursed dale]5302-this accursed dale . [Birdalone]108-birdalone knew not what to do save obey [him]1813-the knight , so [she]108-birdalone lightly gat into [her]108-birdalone saddle , and followed [him]1813-the knight , for [he]1813-the knight was mounted in a twinkling , and riding on . [He]1813-the knight led out of the ring , and fell to threading the maze of the Greywethers , keeping ever toward the steep side of [the dale]4999-the dale , which was on that hand that looked toward [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest , that is to say , the eastern bent . [Birdalone]108-birdalone wondered at this leading , and when [she]108-birdalone was come up with [the knight]1813-the knight [she]108-birdalone spake to [him]1813-the knight breathlessly , and said : But , [fair sir]1675-fair sir , why wend [we]5301-we not down [the dale]4999-the dale ? [He]1813-the knight answered : First , [lady]493-lady , because [we]5301-we must hide [us]5301-we from [them]5309-they straightway ; and next because [they]5309-they be more than [we]5301-we , many more , and [their]5309-they horses be fresh , while thine at least is somewhat spent ; and if [they]5309-they were to spur down [the dale]4999-the dale in chase , [they]5309-they would soon be upon [us]5301-we ; for think not that [I]2135-i would escape and leave [thee]493-lady behind . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : But [thou]493-lady knowest [them]5309-they , then , what [they]5309-they be ? since [thou]493-lady wottest of [their]5309-they numbers and [their]5309-they riding . Hearken now ! Upon [thy]493-lady soul and [thy]493-lady salvation , be [they]5309-they more friends unto [thee]493-lady than unto [me]2135-i ? [He]2135-i said , as be rode on a little slower than erst : Upon [my]2135-i soul and [my]2135-i salvation [I]2135-i swear it , that [the men yonder]5311-the men yonder be of the worst unfriends to [thee]493-lady that may be in [the world]417-the world . And now , [lady]493-lady , [I]2135-i promise [thee]493-lady that [I]2135-i will unravel [thee]493-lady the riddle , and tell [thee]493-lady the whole truth of [these haps]5314-these haps , whatsoever may come of [my]2135-i words , when [we]5315-we be in [a safer place than this]5316-a safer place than this ; and meantime [I]2135-i beseech [thee]493-lady to trust in [me]2135-i thus far , as to believe that [I]2135-i am leading [thee]493-lady out of the very worst peril that might befall [thee]493-lady . Nay , [thou]493-lady must needs trust [me]2135-i ; for [I]2135-i tell [thee]493-lady , that though [I]2135-i now love [thee]493-lady better than all [the world]417-the world and all that is in it , [I]2135-i would slay [thee]493-lady here in [this dale]5181-this dale rather than suffer [thee]493-lady to fall into the hands of [these men]5229-these men . [Birdalone]108-birdalone heard [him]2135-i with a sick heart ; but such passion went with [his]2135-i words that [she]108-birdalone believed what [he]2135-i said ; and [she]108-birdalone spake softly : Sir , [I]2135-i will trust [thee]2135-i thus far ; but [I]2135-i beseech [thee]2135-i to have pity upon [a poor maiden who hath had but little pity shown unto [her]5320-a poor maiden who hath had but little pity shown unto her until these latter days until these latter days]5320-a poor maiden who hath had but little pity shown unto her until these latter days ; and then : O woe â€™s [me]2135-i , to have fallen out of the kindness and love once more ! [The Black Knight]5179-the black knight spake to [her]108-birdalone in a little while , and said : What pity [I]2135-i can to [thee]108-birdalone , that [I]2135-i will . Once more [I]2135-i tell [thee]108-birdalone , that if [thou]108-birdalone but knew it [thou]108-birdalone wouldst thank [me]2135-i indeed for what [I]2135-i have done for [thee]108-birdalone in this hour ; and henceforth [I]2135-i will do and forbear with [thee]108-birdalone to the uttermost that love will suffer [me]2135-i . But lo [thou]108-birdalone ! here are [we]5322-they safe for this present ; but [we]5322-they must nowise tarry . [Birdalone]108-birdalone looked and saw that [they]5322-they were come to the wall of [the dale]4999-the dale , and that [there]215-there [it]215-there went down sheer to [the plain thereof]5325-the plain thereof , and that before [them]5322-they was a cleft that narrowed speedily , and over which the rocks well - nigh met , so that it was indeed almost [a cave]5326-a cave . [They]5322-they rode into [it]4999-the dale straightway , and when that [they]5322-they had gone but a little , and because it had winded somewhat , [they]5322-they could but see [the main valley]5327-the main valley as a star of light behind [them]5322-they , then it narrowed no more , but was as [a dismal street of [the straitest]5329-the straitest]5328-a dismal street of the straitest , whiles lighter and whiles darker , according as the rocks roofed it in overhead or drew away from it . Long [they]5322-they rode , and whiles came trickles of water from out the rocks on one hand or the other ; and now and again [they]5322-they met [a stream which covered all the ground of [the pass]5331-the pass]5330-a stream which covered all the ground of the pass from side to side for the depth of a foot or more . Great rocks also were strewn over [their]5322-they path every here and there , so that whiles must [they]5322-they needs dismount and toil afoot over [the rugged stones]5332-the rugged stones ; and in most places the way was toilsome and difficult . [The knight]1813-the knight spake little to [Birdalone]108-birdalone , save to tell [her]108-birdalone of the way , and warn [her]108-birdalone where it was perilous ; and [she]108-birdalone , for [her]108-birdalone part , was silent , partly for fear of [the strange man]5334-the strange man , or , it might be , even for hatred of [him]5334-the strange man , who had thus brought [her]108-birdalone into such sore trouble , and partly for grief . For , with all torment of sorrow , [she]108-birdalone kept turning over and over in [her]108-birdalone mind whether [[her]108-birdalone friends]1305-her friends had yet come home to [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest , and whether [they]1305-her friends would go seek [her]108-birdalone to deliver [her]108-birdalone . And such shame took hold of [her]108-birdalone when [she]108-birdalone thought of [their]1305-her friends grief and confusion of soul when [they]1305-her friends should come [home]373-home and find [her]108-birdalone gone , that [she]108-birdalone set [her]108-birdalone mind to asking if it had not been better had [she]108-birdalone never met [them]1305-her friends . Yet in good sooth [her]108-birdalone mind would not shape the thought , howsoever [she]108-birdalone bade it . Chapter XIII ~ Now [They]1305-her friends Rest for the Night in [the Strait Pass]40-the strait pass At last , when [they]1305-her friends had been going a long while , it might be some six hours , and it had long been night in [the world without]5338-the world without , but moon - lit , and [they]1305-her friends had rested but seldom , and then but for short whiles , [the knight]1813-the knight drew rein and spake to [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and asked [her]108-birdalone was [she]108-birdalone not weary . O yea , [she]108-birdalone said ; [I]2135-i was at point to pray [thee]1813-the knight suffer [me]2135-i to get off and lie down on [the bare rock]5340-the bare rock . To say sooth , [I]2135-i am now too weary to think of any peril , or what [thou]1813-the knight art , or whither [we]1305-her friends be going . [He]1813-the knight said : By [my]2135-i deeming [we]1305-her friends be now half through [this mountain highway]5341-this mountain highway , and belike there is little peril in [our]1305-her friends resting ; for [I]2135-i think not that [any one of [them]1305-her friends]1376-any one of them knoweth of [this pass]5343-this pass , or would dare it if [he]1813-the knight did ; and [they]1305-her friends doubtless came into [the dale]4999-the dale by [the upper pass]5345-the upper pass , which is strait enough , but light and open . As [he]1813-the knight spoke , [Birdalone]108-birdalone bowed forward on [her]108-birdalone horse â€™s neck , and would have fallen but that [he]1813-the knight stayed [her]108-birdalone . Then [he]1813-the knight lifted [her]108-birdalone off [her]108-birdalone horse , and laid [her]108-birdalone down in [the seemliest place [he]1813-the knight might find]5346-the seemliest place he might find ; and [the pass]5331-the pass there was much widened , and such light as there was in [the outer world]5348-the outer world came down freely into [it]5331-the pass , though it were but of the moon and the stars ; and [the ground]5349-the ground was rather sandy than rocky . So [he]1813-the knight dight [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s bed as well as [he]1813-the knight might , and did off [his]1813-the knight surcoat and laid it over [her]108-birdalone ; and then stood aloof , and gazed on [her]108-birdalone ; and [he]1813-the knight muttered : It is an evil chance ; yet the pleasure of it , the pleasure of it ! [Yea]5350-yea , said [he]1813-the knight again , [she]108-birdalone might well be wearied ; [I]2135-i [myself]2135-i am ready to drop , and [I]2135-i am not [the least tough of [the band]5352-the band]5351-the least tough of the band . And therewith [he]1813-the knight laid [him]1813-the knight down on the further side of [the pass]5331-the pass , and fell asleep straightway . Chapter XIV ~ [The Black Knight]128-the black knight Tells the Truth of [Himself]128-the black knight When the morning was come down into the straitness of [[their]5354-they secret road]5355-their secret road , [Birdalone]108-birdalone opened [her]108-birdalone eyes and saw [the Black Knight]128-the black knight busy over dighting [their]5354-they horses : so [she]108-birdalone arose and thrust [her]108-birdalone grief back into [her]108-birdalone heart , and gave [[her]108-birdalone fellow - farer]5356-her fellow - farer the sele of the day , and [he]1813-the knight brought [her]108-birdalone victual , and [they]5354-they ate a morsel , and gat to horse thereafter and departed ; and the way became smoother , and it was lighter overhead everywhere now , and the rocks never again met overhead athwart the way ; and it seemed to [Birdalone]108-birdalone that now [they]5354-they were wending somewhat downward . [The knight]1813-the knight was courteous unto [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and no longer for the present thrust [his]1813-the knight love upon [her]108-birdalone , so that now [she]108-birdalone had some solace of [his]1813-the knight fellowship , though [he]1813-the knight was but few - spoken to [her]108-birdalone . It was betimes when [they]5354-they arose , and [they]5354-they rode all the morning till it was noon , which [they]5354-they might well wot of , because the way was much wider , and the cliff - walls of [the pass]5331-the pass much lower , so that the sun shone in upon [them]5354-they and cheered [them]5354-they . Now [the Black Knight]128-the black knight drew rein and said : Shall [we]5354-they rest , [lady]493-lady , and eat ? And thereafter , if [thou]5360-thou wilt , [I]2135-i shall tell [thee]5360-thou [my]2135-i tale . Or rather , if [thou]5360-thou wilt suffer [me]2135-i , [I]2135-i shall speak first and eat afterwards , or else the morsel might stick in [my]2135-i throat . [Knight]128-the black knight , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , smiling , [I]2135-i hope [thou]5360-thou hast no lie to swallow down before the meat . Nay , [lady]493-lady , said [he]2135-i ; no lie that is of moment at least . So [they]5354-they lighted down , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone sat on the wayside under a birch - bush that came thrusting out from the rock , and [the knight]1813-the knight stood before [her]493-lady , hanging [his]1813-the knight head , as though [he]1813-the knight were [one accused who would plead [his]1813-the knight cause]5363-one accused who would plead his cause ; and [he]2135-i began : [Lady]5364-lady , [I]2135-i must tell [thee]5364-lady first of all , that today [I]2135-i have done as [an unfaithful servant]5365-an unfaithful servant and [a traitor to [[my]2135-i lord]2039-my lord]5366-a traitor to my lord . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone simply : Shall [I]2135-i tell [thee]5364-lady the truth , and say that from the first [I]2135-i seemed to see in [thee]5364-lady that [thou]5364-lady [wert]5364-lady scarce trusty ? [He]2135-i said : Well , that mind [I]2135-i saw in [thee]5364-lady , and it went to [my]2135-i heart that [thou]5364-lady shouldest think it , and that it should be no less than true . But now [I]2135-i must tell [thee]5364-lady , that it is for [thy]5364-lady sake that [I]2135-i have been untrusty to [[my]2135-i lord]2039-my lord . How so ? said [she]5364-lady . Quoth [he]2135-i : Heardest [thou]5364-lady ever of [the Red Knight]135-the red knight ? Yea , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [I]2135-i have heard of [him]135-the red knight ever as [a tyrant and oppressor]5369-a tyrant and oppressor . Then [she]5364-lady grew pale , and said : Art [thou]5364-lady [he]135-the red knight ? Nay , said [the knight]1813-the knight , [I]2135-i am but [a kinsman of [his]135-the red knight]5371-a kinsman of his , and [[his]135-the red knight best - trusted man]5372-his best - trusted man ; nor have [I]2135-i failed [him]135-the red knight ever till yesterday . [He]1813-the knight kept silence a while , and then said : This is the true tale : that [we]5373-we have had tidings of [thee]5364-lady and of [thy]5364-lady ridings abroad with [that old fool]5374-that old fool , [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris , and how [thou]5364-lady hadst been twice to look into [the Black Valley]33-the black valley . This [I]2135-i say [hath]5375-hath [the Red One]145-the red one heard , and the heart of [him]2135-i was touched by the mere hearsay of [thee]2138-thee ; and moreover â€™[2135-i] tis blessed bread to [him]2135-i the doing of any grief to [the knights of [Quest Castle]41-quest castle]2136-the knights of quest castle ; wherefore [he]2135-i hath sent [me]0-i to hang about [the dale]4999-the dale , to lay hands on [thee]2138-thee if [I]0-i might for ; [he]2135-i knew being wise , that [thou]2138-thee wouldst hanker after it ; and moreover [he]2135-i let one of [[his]2135-i wise women]2139-his wise women sit out in spells on [thee]2138-thee . So [I]0-i espied , and happened on [thee]2138-thee all alone ; and [mine]0-i errand it was , since [I]0-i came upon [thee]2138-thee thus , to draw [thee]2138-thee till [I]0-i had [thee]2138-thee safe at [home]373-home in [the Red Hold]42-the red hold . Forsooth [I]0-i began [mine]0-i errand duly , and fell to beguiling [thee]2138-thee , so that [thou]2138-thee mayst well have seen [the traitor]2141-the traitor in [me]0-i . But then , and then [my]0-i heart failed [me]0-i , because [I]0-i fell , not to desiring [thee]2138-thee as coveting [[my]0-i master]2142-my master â€™s chattel , but to loving [thee]2138-thee and longing for [thee]2138-thee as [[my]0-i fellow and speech - friend]2143-my fellow and speech - friend . And [I]0-i said to [myself]0-i : Into [the Red Hold]42-the red hold [she]2138-thee shall not go if [I]0-i may hinder it . [Birdalone]108-birdalone was very pale , but [she]108-birdalone refrained [her]108-birdalone from grief and fear , and said : But [those horsed and weaponed men up [the dale]4999-the dale]2144-those horsed and weaponed men up the dale , who were [they]2144-those horsed and weaponed men up the dale ? [He]2146-he said : [I]0-i will not lie now , not even a little ; [they]2144-those horsed and weaponed men up the dale came into [the dale]4999-the dale by that upper pass whereof [I]0-i told [thee]2138-thee ; [they]2144-those horsed and weaponed men up the dale were of [[our]2148-we men]1370-our men ; [I]0-i brought [them]2144-those horsed and weaponed men up the dale . [I]0-i was never all alone in [the dale]4999-the dale ; [I]0-i was to have fetched [thee]2138-thee to [them]2144-those horsed and weaponed men up the dale , so that [thou]2138-thee mightest not see a rout of [folk]4521-folk and flee away ; and then would [we]2148-we all have gone [home]373-home together by [the upper pass]5345-the upper pass . But [we]2148-we two must have gone on unto [them]2144-those horsed and weaponed men up the dale in [the dale]4999-the dale â€™s head , whereas for all that [I]0-i could say [I]0-i might not bring [them]2144-those horsed and weaponed men up the dale down into that doom - ring where [we]2148-we ate and talked yesterday . [We]2148-we two have been valianter than [thou]2138-thee mayst have deemed , to have done the deed of dining there ; for [all men]212-all men fear it . But as for [me]0-i , [I]0-i have been there more than twice or thrice , and thence have [I]0-i wandered , and found this pass wherein now [we]2148-we be ; concerning which [I]0-i have held [my]0-i tongue , deeming that it might one day serve [my]0-i turn ; as it hath done now abundantly , since it hath been a refuge unto [thee]2156-thee . [Yea]2157-yea , but whither are [we]2148-we going now ? said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; is it perchance to [the Red Hold]42-the red hold ? Nay , never , said [the knight]1813-the knight , so help [me]0-i [God]114-god and [All - hallows]5184-all - hallows ! Whither then ? said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; tell [me]0-i , that [I]0-i may at least trust [thee]2156-thee , even though [I]0-i owe [thee]2156-thee for all the pain and grief which [thou]2156-thee hast wrought [me]0-i . [He]1813-the knight reddened and said : Wait a while ; [I]0-i bring [thee]2156-thee to [no ill place]2160-no ill place ; there shall no harm befall [thee]2156-thee . And [he]1813-the knight fretted and fumed , and was confused of speech and look , and then [he]1813-the knight said : When [we]2161-we come [there]215-there [I]0-i shall belike crave a boon of [thee]2156-thee . O , but [I]0-i crave a boon of [thee]2156-thee here and now , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone . Wipe away thine offence to [me]0-i and take [me]0-i back to [[my]0-i friends]1795-my friends and [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest ! So mayst [thou]2156-thee yet be dear unto [me]0-i , though maybe not wholly as [thou]2156-thee wouldst have it . And [she]108-birdalone reached out [her]108-birdalone two hands toward [him]1813-the knight . [His]1813-the knight breast heaved , and [he]1813-the knight seemed nigh to weeping ; but [he]1813-the knight said : Nay , [lady]493-lady , ask [me]0-i not here and now , but there and tomorrow . But again [I]0-i swear to [thee]493-lady by thine hands that to the Red Hold [I]0-i will not bring [thee]493-lady , nor suffer [thee]493-lady to be brought , if [I]0-i may hinder it ; nay , not though [I]0-i give [my]0-i life therefor . [Birdalone]108-birdalone was silent awhile ; then [she]108-birdalone said : And what shall befall [me]0-i if [I]0-i come to the Red Hold ? What is [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight , and what would [he]4913-the red knight do with [me]0-i ? Said [he]1813-the knight : [The Red Knight]4913-the red knight is terrible and fierce and wise ; and [I]0-i fear [him]4913-the red knight , [I.]0-i [He]4913-the red knight held [his]4913-the red knight peace , and said : [I]0-i must needs say it , that to [thee]493-lady [he]4913-the red knight would have been as Death and [the Devil]2168-the devil . [He]4913-the red knight would have bedded [thee]493-lady first . [She]108-birdalone broke in : Nay , never ! and flushed very red . But [the knight]1813-the knight went on : And after , [I]0-i wot not ; that were according to [his]1813-the knight mood . And as to [thy]493-lady never , [lady]493-lady , [thou]493-lady wottest not the like of [him]1813-the knight or of [the folk [he]1813-the knight hath about [him]1813-the knight]2171-the folk he hath about him . Such as [thou]493-lady ? [she]108-birdalone said angrily . Nay , [he]1813-the knight said , far worse than [me]0-i ; [men who fare little afield , and are not sweetened by adventures and war - perils]2172-men who fare little afield , and are not sweetened by adventures and war - perils ; and [women worser yet]2173-women worser yet ; and far worser were [they]2172-men who fare little afield , and are not sweetened by adventures and war - perils dealing with [a woman]235-a woman . [She]108-birdalone was silent again awhile , and paled once more ; then [her]108-birdalone colour came back to [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone held out [her]108-birdalone hand to [him]1813-the knight and said kindly : [Thou]493-lady being what [thou]493-lady art , [I]0-i thank [thee]1813-the knight for [thy]1813-the knight dealings with [me]0-i ; and now until tomorrow , when [I]0-i shall ask [thee]1813-the knight of that again , [I]0-i am friends with [thee]1813-the knight ; so come now , and let [us]2175-they eat and drink together . [He]1813-the knight took [her]108-birdalone hand and kissed it , and then came and sat down meekly beside [her]108-birdalone , and [they]2175-they ate and drank in that wild place as though [they]2175-they had been [friends of long acquaintance]2176-friends of long acquaintance . Chapter XV ~ [The Black Knight]5179-the black knight Brings [Birdalone]108-birdalone to [the Bower]43-the bower in [the Dale]44-the dale When [they]2175-they had made an end of [their]2175-they meal , [they]2175-they gat to horse again and rode on [their]2175-they ways ; and every mile now was [[their]2175-they road]2178-their road the easier , [the pass]5331-the pass wider , and [its]5331-the pass walls lower and now also more broken ; till at last [they]2175-they began to go down hill swiftly , and after a little [[their]2175-they road]2178-their road seemed to be swallowed in a great thicket of hornbeam and holly ; but [the knight]1813-the knight rode on and entered [the said thicket]2182-the said thicket , and ever found some way amidst the branches , though [they]2175-they were presently in the very thick of the trees , and saw no daylight between the trunks for well - nigh an hour , whereas the wood was thick and tangled , and [they]2175-they had to thread [their]2175-they way betwixt its mazes . At last the wood began to grow thinner before [them]2175-they , and the white light to show between the trunks ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone deemed that [she]108-birdalone heard the sound of falling water , and presently was sure thereof ; and [the knight]1813-the knight spake to [her]108-birdalone : Patience , [[my]0-i lady]603-my lady ; now are [we]2175-they near [home]373-home for today . [She]108-birdalone nodded kindly to [him]1813-the knight , and therewith [they]2175-they rode on to open ground , and were on the side of a steep bent , broken on [their]2175-they right hands into [a sheer cliff]2186-a sheer cliff as [Birdalone]108-birdalone saw when [the knight]1813-the knight led [her]108-birdalone to the edge and bade [her]108-birdalone look over . Then [she]108-birdalone saw down into [a fair dale]2188-a fair dale lying far below [them]2175-they , through the which ran [a little river]2189-a little river , clear and swift , but not riotous , after it had fallen over a force at [the upper end of [the dale]4999-the dale]2190-the upper end of the dale , and made the sound of water which [she]108-birdalone had heard . [The said dale]5011-the said dale was so , that whatsoever was on the other side thereof was hidden by tall and great trees , that stood close together some twenty yards aloof from [the stream]1777-the stream , and betwixt [them]2175-they and [it]2194-it was fair greensward with a few bushes and thorn - trees thereon . Quoth [the knight]1813-the knight : Down there shall [we]2175-they rest till tomorrow , if it please [thee]108-birdalone , [lady]493-lady ; and since the sun will set in an hour , [we]2175-they were best on [our]2175-they way at once . It pleases [me]0-i well , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and [I]0-i long to tread the turf by [the river - side]2197-the river - side , for [I]0-i am weary as weary may be of the saddle and [the pass]5331-the pass . So down the bent [they]2175-they rode , and it was but a little ere [they]2175-they had ridden it to an end , and had met [the river]1845-the river as it swept round [the cliff - wall of [the valley]4994-the valley]2200-the cliff - wall of the valley ; and [they]2175-they rode through [it]2202-it , and came on to [the pleasant greensward aforesaid under the trees]2203-the pleasant greensward aforesaid under the trees ; and in a bight of the wood was a bower builded of turf and thatched with reed ; and there , by the bidding of [the knight]1813-the knight , [they]2175-they alighted ; and [the knight]1813-the knight said : This is thine house for to - night , [[my]0-i lady]603-my lady ; and [thou]2207-thou mayest lie there in all safety after [thou]2207-thou hast supped , and mayst have [my]0-i weapons by [thy]2207-thou side if [thou]2207-thou wilt , while [I]0-i lie under the trees yonder . And if [thou]2207-thou wilt bathe [thee]2207-thou in the cool water , to comfort [thee]2207-thou after the long ride and the weariness , [I]0-i swear by [thy]2207-thou hand that [I]0-i will take [myself]0-i out of eye - shot and abide aloof till [thou]2207-thou call [me]0-i . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , smiling somewhat : [Fair sir]1675-fair sir , [I]0-i will not have [my]0-i watch and ward unarmed ; keep [thou]2207-thou [thy]2207-thou weapons ; and [thou]2207-thou wilt not forget , perchance , that [I]0-i am not wholly unarmed , whereas [I]0-i have [my]0-i bow and arrows and [my]0-i knife here . And as to [my]0-i bathing , [I]0-i will take [thee]2207-thou at [thy]2207-thou word , and bid [thee]2207-thou go aloof a while now at once ; for [I]0-i will go down to [the water]347-the water ; and if [thou]2207-thou spy upon [me]0-i , then will it be [thy]2207-thou shame and not [mine]0-i . [The knight]1813-the knight went [his]1813-the knight ways therewith , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone went down to [the water]347-the water and unclad [her]2207-thou ; but ere [she]2207-thou stepped into [the river]1845-the river , [she]2207-thou laid [her]2207-thou bow and three shafts on the lip thereof . Then [she]2207-thou took the water , and disported [her]2207-thou merrily therein ; and now , forsooth , [she]2207-thou was nowise downcast , for [she]2207-thou said to [herself]2207-thou , [this man]1669-this man is not all evil and [he]1669-this man lovest [me]0-i well , and [I]0-i look for it that tomorrow [he]1669-this man will bring [me]0-i on [my]0-i way toward [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest , for mere love of [me]0-i ; and then shall [he]1669-this man be [a dear friend to [me]0-i]2215-a dear friend to me , and [I]0-i will comfort [him]1669-this man what [I]0-i can for as long as [we]2216-they both live . So [she]2207-thou came out of [the water]347-the water and clad [her]2207-thou , and then called aloud for [the knight]1813-the knight , and [he]1813-the knight came speedily unto [her]2207-thou , as if [he]1813-the knight had been not exceeding far away , though [he]1813-the knight swore with a great oath that [he]1813-the knight had nowise espied [her]2207-thou . [She]2207-thou answered [him]1813-the knight nought , and [they]2216-they went side by side to the bower ; and there [the knight]1813-the knight dight the victual , and [they]2216-they sat together and ate [their]2216-they meat like [old friends]2220-old friends ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone asked [the knight]1813-the knight concerning [this valley]5003-this valley and the bower , if [he]1813-the knight had known it for long , and [he]1813-the knight answered : [Yea]2223-yea , [lady]493-lady , [I]0-i was but [a stripling]2225-a stripling when [I]0-i first happened on [the dale]4999-the dale ; and [I]0-i deem that [few]2227-few know thereof save [me]0-i ; at least [none of [[our]2216-they flock]2229-our flock]2228-none of our flock knoweth thereof , and [I]0-i am fain thereof , and keep [them]2230-them unknowing , for if [[my]0-i lord]2039-my lord were to hear of [my]0-i having [a haunt privy unto [me]0-i]2232-a haunt privy unto me [he]2039-my lord would like it but ill . [Birdalone]108-birdalone turned pale when [she]108-birdalone heard [him]2039-my lord speak of [[his]2039-my lord lord]2233-his lord ; for fear of [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight had entered into [her]108-birdalone soul , so that now the flesh crept upon [her]108-birdalone bones . But [she]108-birdalone enforced [her]108-birdalone to smile , and said : Yea , and what would [he]4913-the red knight do to [thee]108-birdalone were [he]4913-the red knight ill - content with [thy]108-birdalone ways ? Forsooth , [lady]493-lady , said [he]4913-the red knight , if [he]4913-the red knight could spare [me]0-i [he]4913-the red knight would make an end of [me]0-i in some miserable way ; nay , if [he]4913-the red knight were exceeding ill - content , [he]4913-the red knight would do as much for [me]0-i whether [he]4913-the red knight could spare [me]0-i or not ; otherwise [he]4913-the red knight would watch [his]4913-the red knight occasion , and so grieve [me]0-i that what [he]4913-the red knight did would go to [my]0-i very heart . Woe â€™s [me]0-i ! said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [thou]2236-thou servest [an evil master]2237-an evil master . [The knight]1813-the knight answered not , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone went on speaking earnestly : It is a shame to [thee]1813-the knight to follow [this fiend]2239-this fiend ; why dost [thou]1813-the knight not sunder [thee]1813-the knight from [him]2239-this fiend , and become wholly [an honest man]2240-an honest man ? Said [he]1813-the knight gruffly : It is of no use talking of this , [I]0-i may not ; to boot , [I]0-i fear [him]2239-this fiend . Then did [Birdalone]108-birdalone hold [her]108-birdalone peace , and [the knight]1813-the knight said : [Thou]2236-thou dost not know ; when [I]0-i part from [thee]1813-the knight [I]0-i must needs go straight to [him]2239-this fiend , and then must that befall which will befall . Speak [we]2242-we no more of these matters . [Birdalone]108-birdalone flushed with hope and joy as [he]1813-the knight spake thus , for [she]108-birdalone took [him]1813-the knight to mean that [he]1813-the knight would lead [her]108-birdalone , on the morrow , on [her]108-birdalone way to [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest . But [the knight]1813-the knight spake in a voice grown cheerful again : As to [this bower]2245-this bower , [lady]493-lady , the tale thereof is soon told ; for with [mine]0-i own hands [I]0-i builded it some fifteen years ago ; and [I]0-i have come to [this place]2247-this place time and again when [my]0-i heart was overmuch oppressed with black burdens of evil and turmoil , and have whiles prevailed against the evil , and whiles not . Mayst [thou]2248-thou prevail this time , then ! said [she]108-birdalone . [He]1813-the knight answered [her]108-birdalone not , but presently fell to talking with [her]108-birdalone of other matters , and [the two]2249-the two were frank and friendly together , till the August night grew dark about [them]2249-the two ; and then [spake Birdalone]108-birdalone : Now would [I]0-i rest , for [I]0-i can no longer keep [mine]0-i eyes open . Abide aloof from [me]0-i tomorrow morning till [I]0-i call to [thee]108-birdalone , as [thou]2248-thou didst this evening ; and then , before [we]2249-the two eat together again , [thou]2248-thou shalt tell [me]0-i what [thou]2248-thou wilt do with [me]0-i . [He]1813-the knight stood up to depart , and [she]108-birdalone reached out [her]108-birdalone hand to [him]1813-the knight in the glimmer , and [he]1813-the knight saw it , but said : Nay , if [I]0-i take thine hand , [I]0-i shall take thine whole body . And therewith [he]1813-the knight departed , and [she]108-birdalone laid [her]108-birdalone down in [her]108-birdalone smock alone , and slept anon , and was dreamless and forgetting everything till the sun was up in the morning . Chapter XVI ~ Yet A Day and A Night [They]2250-they [Tarry]45-tarry in [the Dale]4999-the dale [Birdalone]108-birdalone awoke when the sun came into the bower to [her]108-birdalone , and stood up at once , and went down to [the river]1845-the river and washed the night off [her]108-birdalone ; and then , when [she]108-birdalone was clad , called on [the knight]1813-the knight to come to [her]108-birdalone ; and [he]1813-the knight came , looking downcast and troubled ; so that [Birdalone]108-birdalone thought within [herself]108-birdalone : It is well , [he]1813-the knight will do [my]0-i will . [She]108-birdalone stood before [him]1813-the knight , and gave [him]1813-the knight the sele of the day , and [he]1813-the knight looked on [her]108-birdalone sorrowfully . Then [she]108-birdalone said : Now is come the time when [I]0-i am to ask [thee]1813-the knight to take [me]0-i back to [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest and [[my]0-i own people]2255-my own people]2254-the castle of the quest and my own people . [He]1813-the knight was not hasty to answer [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone spake again : This must [thou]1813-the knight do , or else take [me]0-i to [the Red Hold]2256-the red hold and deliver [me]0-i to [the tyrant there]2257-the tyrant there ; and [I]0-i have heard it from [thine]2258-thine own mouth that will be nought else than casting [me]0-i into shame and torment and death . And [I]0-i deem [thou]1813-the knight canst not do it . Nay , [she]108-birdalone said , staying the words that were coming from [his]1813-the knight mouth , [I]0-i wot that [thou]1813-the knight canst do it if [thine]2258-thine heart can suffer it ; for [thou]1813-the knight art stronger than [I]0-i , and [thou]1813-the knight mayst break [my]0-i bow , and wrest this knife out of [mine]0-i hand ; and [thou]1813-the knight canst bind [me]0-i and make [me]0-i fast to the saddle , and so lead [my]0-i helpless body into thraldom and death . But [thou]1813-the knight hast said that [thou]1813-the knight lovest [me]0-i , and [I]0-i believe [thee]1813-the knight herein . Therefore [I]0-i know that [thou]1813-the knight canst not will to do this . [He]1813-the knight answered in [his]1813-the knight surly voice : [Thou]1813-the knight art right , [lady]493-lady , [I]0-i can not . Nay , hearken [thou]493-lady this time . [I]0-i have been turning over night - long what [thou]1813-the knight didst say about leaving [[my]0-i lord]2039-my lord , that is , betraying [him]2039-my lord , for it comes to that ; and now [I]0-i have made up [my]0-i mind to do it , and [I]0-i will betray [him]2039-my lord for [thy]493-lady sake . Wherefore there is a third way to take which [thou]1813-the knight hast not seen ; [we]2261-we will ride out of [this dale]5181-this dale in an hour â€™s time , and [I]0-i will bring [thee]1813-the knight to [[them]1813-the knight who are only less [the mortal foes of [the Red Knight]135-the red knight]2264-the mortal foes of the red knight than are [[thy]1813-the knight fellows of [the Quest]26-the quest]2265-thy fellows of the quest , to wit , to [the captain and burgesses of [the good town of Greenford]2267-the good town of greenford by [the Water]5-the water]2266-the captain and burgesses of the good town of greenford by the water]2263-them who are only less the mortal foes of the red knight than are thy fellows of the quest , to wit , to the captain and burgesses of the good town of greenford by the water ; and [I]0-i will do [them]1813-the knight to wit that [I]0-i have rescued [thee]1813-the knight from the hands of [the Red Knight]135-the red knight , and am become [[his]135-the red knight foe]2268-his foe ; and will show [them]1813-the knight all [his]135-the red knight incomings and outgoings , and every whit of rede , and entrap [him]135-the red knight , so that [he]135-the red knight fall into [their]1813-the knight hands . Now , though were [I]0-i to be taken in battle by [them]1813-the knight , [I]0-i should be speedily brought to the halter , or may be to the bale - fire ( for [we]2269-we be wizards all in [the Red Hold]42-the red hold ) ; yet with this word in [my]0-i mouth , if [they]1813-the knight trow in it , [I]0-i shall be made [[their]1813-the knight captain]2270-their captain , and presently [[their]1813-the knight master]2271-their master . Trow in [my]0-i tale [they]1813-the knight will , if [thou]2272-thee bear [me]0-i out therein , and [they]1813-the knight will honour [thee]2272-thee , and suffer [thee]2272-thee to give [thyself]2273-thyself to [me]0-i in marriage ; and then [I]0-i know [thee]2272-thee , and [myself]0-i also , and that ere long [we]2274-we shall be both mighty and wealthy and beloved , and fair will be the days before [us]2274-we . [His]2275-thou voice had grown softer as [he]2275-thou spake , and toward the end of [his]2275-thou words [he]2275-thou faltered , and at last brake out a - weeping , and cast [himself]2275-thou wordless on the grass before [her]2272-thee . [She]2272-thee was pale , and [her]2272-thee brow was knitted , and [her]2272-thee face quivered ; but [she]2272-thee spake coldly to [him]2275-thou and said : This way [I]0-i can not take ; and [I]0-i wonder at [thee]2275-thou that [thou]2275-thou hast shown it unto [me]0-i , for [thyself]2275-thou [thou]2275-thou knowest that [I]0-i can not go with [thee]2275-thou . [I]0-i will go nowhere hence save to [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest . If [thou]2275-thou wilt not lead [me]0-i thereto , or put [me]0-i on [the road]1797-the road , [I]0-i ask [thee]2275-thou straight , Wilt [thou]2275-thou stay [me]0-i if [I]0-i go seek the way thither [myself]0-i ? [He]2275-thou rose up from the ground with a pale face full of anger as well as grief , and caught [her]0-i by the wrists and said , scowling the while : Tell [me]0-i now which of [them]2278-they it is ; is it [the stupid oaf Baudoin]2279-the stupid oaf baudoin , or [the light fool Hugh]2280-the light fool hugh , or [the dull pedant Arthur]2281-the dull pedant arthur ? But it matters not ; for [I]0-i know , and [all the country - side]2282-all the country - side knows , that [they]2278-they be vowed , [each man of [them]2278-they]2283-each man of them , to [[his]2283-each man of them own woman]2284-his own woman ; and if [they]2278-they find not [the women]1990-the women [themselves]2278-they , such dolts [they]2278-they are , that [they]2278-they will ever be worshipping the mere shadows of [them]2278-they , and turn away from flesh and blood , were it the fairest in [the world]417-the world , as [thou]2287-thou art , as [thou]2287-thou art . [She]2284-his own woman shrank away from [him]2283-each man of them what [she]2284-his own woman might , but [he]2283-each man of them still held [her]2284-his own woman wrists ; then [she]2284-his own woman spake in a quivering voice , [her]2284-his own woman very lips pale with fear and wrath : It is well seen that [thou]2287-thou art [a man of the Red Knight]2288-a man of the red knight ; and belike [thou]2287-thou wouldst do with [me]0-i as [he]2283-each man of them would . But one thing [I]0-i crave of [thee]2284-his own woman , if there is any grain of mercy in [thee]2284-his own woman , that [thou]2287-thou wilt draw [thy]2287-thou sword and thrust [me]0-i through ; [thou]2287-thou mayst leave [thine]2289-thine hold of [me]0-i to get at the blade , [I]0-i will not stir from where [I]0-i stand . O ! to think that [I]0-i deemed [thee]2284-his own woman well - nigh [a true man]2290-a true man . [He]2283-each man of them dropped [her]2284-his own woman hands now and stood aloof from [her]2284-his own woman , staring at [her]2284-his own woman , and presently cast [himself]2283-each man of them on the ground , rolling about and tearing at the grass . [She]2284-his own woman looked on [him]2283-each man of them a moment or two , and then stepped forward and stooped to [him]2283-each man of them , and touched [his]2283-each man of them shoulder and said : Rise up , [I]0-i bid [thee]2284-his own woman , and be [a man]217-a man and not a wild beast . So in a while [he]2283-each man of them arose , and stood before [her]2284-his own woman hang - dog - like ; then [she]2284-his own woman looked on [him]2283-each man of them pitifully , and said : [Fair sir and valiant knight]2292-fair sir and valiant knight , [thou]2284-his own woman hast gone out of [thy]2284-his own woman mind for a while , and thus hast [thou]2284-his own woman shamed both [me]0-i and [thyself]2293-thyself ; and now [thou]2284-his own woman wert best forget it , and therewithal [my]0-i last words to [thee]2284-his own woman . Therewith [she]2284-his own woman held out [her]2284-his own woman hand to [him]2283-each man of them , and [he]2283-each man of them went on [his]2283-each man of them knees and took it , sobbing , and kissed it . But [she]2284-his own woman said , and smiled on [him]2283-each man of them : Now [I]0-i see that [thou]2284-his own woman wilt do what [I]0-i prayed of [thee]2283-each man of them , and lead [me]0-i hence and put [me]0-i on the road to [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest . [He]2283-each man of them said : [I]0-i will lead [thee]2284-his own woman to [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : Then shall it be as [I]0-i promised , that [I]0-i will be [[thy]2284-his own woman dear friend]2296-thy dear friend while both [we]2297-we live . And now , if [thou]2284-his own woman canst , be a little merrier , and come and sit with [me]0-i , and let [us]2297-we eat [our]2297-we meat , for [I]0-i hunger . [He]2283-each man of them smiled , but woefully , and presently [they]2297-we sat down to [their]2297-we meat ; and [he]2283-each man of them strove to be somewhat merry of mood , and to eat as one at a feast ; but whiles [his]2283-each man of them heart failed [him]2283-each man of them , and [he]2283-each man of them set [his]2283-each man of them teeth and tore at the grass , and [his]2283-each man of them face was fierce and terrible to look on ; but [Birdalone]108-birdalone made as if [she]108-birdalone heeded it nought , and was blithe and debonair with [him]2283-each man of them . And when [they]2297-we had done [their]2297-we meat [he]2283-each man of them sat looking at [her]108-birdalone a while , and at last [he]2283-each man of them said : [Lady]493-lady , dost [thou]108-birdalone deem that , when all is said , [I]0-i have done somewhat for [thee]108-birdalone since first [we]2297-we met the day before yesterday at [the lower end of [the Black Valley]33-the black valley]2299-the lower end of the black valley ? [Yea]2300-yea , [she]108-birdalone said , as erst [I]0-i spake , all things considered [I]0-i deem that [thou]2301-thou hast done much . And now , said [he]2283-each man of them , [I]0-i am to do more yet ; for [I]0-i am to lead [thee]108-birdalone to where henceforth [I]0-i shall have no more part or lot in [thee]108-birdalone than if [thou]2301-thou wert in [heaven]4515-heaven and [I]0-i in [hell]2303-hell . [I]0-i pray [thee]108-birdalone say not so , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; have [I]0-i not said that [I]0-i will be [[thy]108-birdalone friend]4800-thy friend ? [Lady]493-lady , said [the knight]1813-the knight , [I]0-i wot well that according to the sweetness of thine heart wilt [thou]2301-thou do what [thou]2301-thou canst do . And therewith [he]1813-the knight was silent a while and [she]493-lady also . Then [he]1813-the knight said : [I]0-i would ask [thee]493-lady a grace if [I]0-i durst . Ask it , said [she]493-lady , and [I]0-i will grant it if [I]0-i may ; [I]0-i have gainsaid [thee]108-birdalone enough meseemeth . [Lady]493-lady , [he]1813-the knight said , [I]0-i will ask this as a reward of [the way - leader]2308-the way - leader , to wit , that [thou]493-lady abide with [me]0-i here in [this dale]5181-this dale , in all honour holden , till tomorrow morning ; and let [this place]2247-this place , which has helped [me]0-i aforetime , be hallowed by [[thy]493-lady dwelling here]2311-thy dwelling here ; and [I]0-i , [I]0-i shall have had one happy day at least , if never another . Canst [thou]493-lady grant [me]0-i this ? If [thou]493-lady canst not , [we]2312-we will depart in an hour . [Her]493-lady countenance fell at [his]1813-the knight word , and [she]493-lady was silent a while ; for sore [she]493-lady longed to be speedily whereas [[her]493-lady friends]1305-her friends should find [her]493-lady if [they]1305-her friends came back to [the castle]1534-the castle . But [she]493-lady thought within [herself]493-lady how wild and fierce [the man]5167-the man was , and doubted if [he]5167-the man might not go stark mad on [her]493-lady hands and destroy [her]493-lady if [she]493-lady thwarted overmuch ; and , moreover , frankly [she]493-lady pitied [him]5167-the man , and would do what [she]493-lady might to ease [his]5167-the man pain and solace [his]5167-the man grief of heart . Wherefore [she]493-lady cleared [her]493-lady face of its trouble and let it be vexed no longer , but smiled upon [the knight]1813-the knight and said : [Fair sir]1675-fair sir , [this meseemeth]2318-this meseemeth but a little thing for [me]0-i to do , and [I]0-i grant it [thee]1813-the knight with a good will , and this shall now be the first day of the friendship if so [thou]2319-thou wilt take it ; and may it solace [thee]1813-the knight . Who then was gleeful but [the knight]1813-the knight , and strange it was to see all [his]1813-the knight sorrow run off [him]1813-the knight ; and [he]1813-the knight became glad and gamesome as [a youth]2321-a youth , and yet withal exceeding courteous and kind with [her]493-lady , as though [he]1813-the knight were serving [a mighty queen]2322-a mighty queen . So then [they]2323-they wore the day together in all good fellowship ; and first [they]2323-they went up [the dale]4999-the dale together and right to the foot of that great force , where [the stream]1777-the stream came thundering down from [the sheer rocks]5151-the sheer rocks ; and long [Birdalone]108-birdalone stood to look thereon , and much [she]108-birdalone marvelled at it , for no such thing had [she]108-birdalone seen before . Thereafter [they]2323-they went afoot into the wood behind the green bower , and when [they]2323-they had gone some way therein for [their]2323-they pleasure , [they]2323-they fell to seeking venison for [their]2323-they dinner ; and [the knight]1813-the knight took [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s bow and shafts to strike [the quarry withal]2328-the quarry withal , but [he]1813-the knight would have [her]1813-the knight gird [his]1813-the knight sword to [her]108-birdalone , that [she]108-birdalone might not be weaponless . So [they]2323-they gat [them]2323-they a roe and came back therewith to the bower , and [the knight]1813-the knight dight it and cooked it , and again [they]2323-they ate in fellowship and kindness ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone had been to [the river]1845-the river and fetched thence store of blue - flowered mouse - ear , and of meadow - sweet , whereof was still some left from the early days of summer , and had made [her]108-birdalone garlands for [her]108-birdalone head and [her]108-birdalone loins ; and [the knight]1813-the knight sat and worshipped [her]108-birdalone , yet [he]1813-the knight would not so much as touch [her]108-birdalone hand , sorely as [he]1813-the knight hungered for the beauty of [her]108-birdalone body . Next , when dinner was done , and [they]2323-they lay in the shadow of the trees , and hearkened the moor - hen crying from the water , and the moaning of the wood - doves in [the high trees]2332-the high trees , [she]108-birdalone turned to [him]1813-the knight and bade [him]1813-the knight tell [her]108-birdalone somewhat of the tale of [his]1813-the knight life and deeds ; but [he]1813-the knight said : Nay , [lady]493-lady , [I]0-i pray [thee]493-lady pardon [me]0-i , for little have [I]0-i to tell [thee]493-lady that is good , and [I]0-i would not have [thee]493-lady know of [me]0-i aught worse than [thou]493-lady knowest of [me]0-i already . Rather be [thou]493-lady kind to [me]0-i , and tell [me]0-i of [thy]493-lady days that have been , wherein [I]0-i know full surely shall be nought but good . [She]493-lady smiled and blushed , but without more ado fell to telling [him]1813-the knight of [her]493-lady life in [the House under the Wood]4835-the house under the wood , and spared not even to tell [him]1813-the knight somewhat of [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother . And [he]1813-the knight said no word to [her]493-lady thereover , save thanks and praises for the kindness of [her]493-lady story . At last the day wore to its ending , and then [the knight]1813-the knight â€™s grief strode over [him]1813-the knight again , and [he]1813-the knight was moody and few - spoken ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone was blithe with [him]1813-the knight still , and would have solaced [his]1813-the knight grief ; but [he]1813-the knight said : Let it be ; as for [thee]493-lady , [thou]493-lady shalt be happy tomorrow , but this happy day of [mine]1813-the knight is well - nigh worn , and it is as the wearing of [my]0-i life . And the dark night came , and [he]1813-the knight bade [her]493-lady good - night sorrowfully , and departed to [his]1813-the knight lair in [the wood]335-the wood . [Birdalone]108-birdalone lay in the bower , and might not sleep a long while for [her]493-lady joy of the morrow , which should bring [her]493-lady back to [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest . But when morning was , and the sun was but just risen , [Birdalone]108-birdalone awoke , and stood up and did on [her]108-birdalone raiment , and called [[her]108-birdalone servant]2339-her servant [the knight]1813-the knight , and [he]1813-the knight came at once leading the two horses , and said : Now go [we]2341-they to [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]25-the castle of the quest . And [he]1813-the knight was sober and sorrowful , but nought fierce or wild . So [Birdalone]108-birdalone thanked [him]1813-the knight kindly and praised [him]1813-the knight , and [he]1813-the knight changed countenance no whit therefor . Then [they]2341-they mounted and set forth , and [the knight]1813-the knight led straight into [the wood]335-the wood , and by roads that [he]1813-the knight wotted of , so that [they]2341-they went nowise slowly for wenders through [the thick woodland]2344-the thick woodland . Thus went [they]2341-they on [their]2341-they way together , [he]1813-the knight sorry and [she]108-birdalone glad . But now leaves the tale to tell of [Birdalone]108-birdalone and [the knight on whom [she]108-birdalone happened in [the Black Valley]33-the black valley of the Greywethers]2345-the knight on whom she happened in the black valley of the greywethers , and turns to [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest and [the folk thereof]2347-the folk thereof , and what [they]2341-they did in this while and thereafter . Tells the tale that when [the chaplain]1985-the chaplain had departed from [Birdalone]108-birdalone at the bower in the copse , [he]1985-the chaplain went [home]373-home to [the castle]1534-the castle sadly enough , because of [his]1985-the chaplain love and longing for [her]108-birdalone , which well [he]1985-the chaplain wotted might never be satisfied . Moreover when [he]1985-the chaplain was come into [the castle]1534-the castle again , there fell fear upon [him]1985-the chaplain for what might betide [her]108-birdalone , and [he]1985-the chaplain rued it that [he]1985-the chaplain had done [her]108-birdalone will in getting [her]108-birdalone forth of [the castle]1534-the castle ; and in vain now [he]1985-the chaplain set before [himself]1985-the chaplain all the reasons for deeming that [her]108-birdalone peril herein was little or nothing , even as [he]1985-the chaplain had laid them before [her]108-birdalone , and which [he]1985-the chaplain then believed in utterly , whereas now himseemed there was an answer to every one of [them]2353-them . So [he]1985-the chaplain sighed heavily and went into [the chapel]5078-the chapel , wherein was an altar of [St. Leonard]130-leonard ; and [he]1985-the chaplain knelt thereat , and prayed [the saint]2355-the saint , as [he]1985-the chaplain had erst delivered [folk]4521-folk from captivity , now to deliver both [him]1985-the chaplain and [Birdalone]108-birdalone from peril and bonds ; but though [he]1985-the chaplain was long a - praying and made many words , it lightened [his]1985-the chaplain heart little or nothing ; so that when [he]1985-the chaplain rose up again , that if anything evil happened to this pearl of [women]420-women , [he]1985-the chaplain wished heartily that [some one]2358-some one might take [his]1985-the chaplain life and [he]1985-the chaplain be done with it . Now was [the house astir]2359-the house astir , and [the chaplain]1985-the chaplain came from out [the chapel]5078-the chapel , and thinking all things over , [he]1985-the chaplain thought [he]1985-the chaplain would go straight to [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris and make a clean breast of it , so that [weaponed men]1799-weaponed men might be sent at once to seek [Birdalone]108-birdalone . And [he]1985-the chaplain said to [himself]1985-the chaplain : What matter if [he]131-sir aymeris slay [me]0-i or cast [me]0-i into prison , if [Birdalone]108-birdalone be lost ? So [he]1985-the chaplain went [his]1985-the chaplain ways to [the highest tower]2363-the highest tower , which looked landward and hight the Open Eye , deeming to find [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris ; but when [he]1985-the chaplain got to the topmost , [he]1985-the chaplain found neither [captain nor carle there]2364-captain nor carle there : wherefore [he]1985-the chaplain stayed a little and looked forth betwixt the battlements , if perchance there were some wild chance of seeing [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s coming [home]373-home again ; but [his]1985-the chaplain keen eyes beheld nothing more than [he]1985-the chaplain looked to see , as sheep and neat , and [the field - folk of thereabouts]2366-the field - folk of thereabouts . So [he]1985-the chaplain turned away and went by the swale toward [the next tallest tower]2367-the next tallest tower , which looked lakewards , and was called [Hearts]146-hearts â€™ Hope ; and as [he]1985-the chaplain went [he]1985-the chaplain fell to framing in [his]1985-the chaplain mind the words which [he]1985-the chaplain should say to [the castellan]1691-the castellan . Thus came [he]1985-the chaplain , haggard and hapless , on the leads of [the tower]5377-the tower , which were nought small ; and there gathered together in a knot , and all gazing eagerly out over [the lake]355-the lake , [he]1985-the chaplain found [a dozen of [men - at - arms]1749-men - at - arms and [the castellan]1691-the castellan amongst [them]5379-a dozen of men - at - arms and the castellan amongst them]5379-a dozen of men - at - arms and the castellan amongst them . [They]5379-a dozen of men - at - arms and the castellan amongst them took no heed of [him]1985-the chaplain as [he]1985-the chaplain came up , though [he]1985-the chaplain stumbled as [he]1985-the chaplain crossed the threshold and came clattering over the lead floor , and [he]1985-the chaplain saw at once that there was something unwonted toward ; but [he]1985-the chaplain had but one thought in [his]1985-the chaplain mind , to wit , the rescuing of [Birdalone]108-birdalone . [He]1985-the chaplain went up now behind where [the castellan]1691-the castellan was leaning over the battlement , and pulled [his]1985-the chaplain skirt , and when [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris turned round , [he]1985-the chaplain said : [Lord]2064-lord , [I]146-hearts have a word for thine ear . But [the old knight]1668-the old knight did but half turn round , and then spake peevishly : Tush , [man]537-man ! another time ! seest [thou]5386-thou not [I]146-hearts have got no eyes for aught save what [we]5387-our see on [the lake]355-the lake ? [Yea]2064-lord , but what then ? said [the priest]1677-the priest . There cometh [a boat]676-a boat , said [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris , not looking back at [him]1668-the old knight , and [our]5387-our thought is that therein be [[our]5387-our lords]1663-our lords . When [the priest]1677-the priest heard that word , it was to [him]1677-the priest as if hell had opened underneath [his]1677-the priest feet ; and [he]1677-the priest had no might to speak for a minute ; then [he]1677-the priest cried out : [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris , hearken , [I]146-hearts pray [thee]131-sir aymeris . But [the old knight]1668-the old knight but thrust [him]1668-the old knight back with [his]1668-the old knight hand , and even therewith one of [the men - at - arms]4947-the men - at - arms cried out : [I]146-hearts hear the voice of [their]4947-the men - at - arms horn ! Then shouted [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris : Where art [thou]131-sir aymeris , Noise ? Blow , [man]537-man , blow , if ever [thou]131-sir aymeris blewest in all [thy]131-sir aymeris life ! And therewithal came the blare of the brass , and [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris nodded to [the trumpeter , who blew blast after blast]5396-the trumpeter , who blew blast after blast with all [his]5396-the trumpeter , who blew blast after blast might , so that [the priest]1677-the priest might as well have been dumb for any hearing [he]5396-the trumpeter , who blew blast after blast might get ; and all the while to [Leonard]130-leonard the minutes seemed hours , and [he]130-leonard was well - nigh distraught . And then when [the knight]1813-the knight held up [his]1813-the knight hand for the Noise to stay [his]1813-the knight blowing , and [Leonard]130-leonard strove to speak , [the castellan]1691-the castellan turned on [him]130-leonard and said : Peace , [Sir Leonard]139-birdalone ; dost [thou]131-sir aymeris not know that now [we]131-sir aymeris would listen with [our]131-sir aymeris ears to heed if [they]1691-the castellan answer [us]131-sir aymeris ? Not a word [any one man of [you]139-birdalone]5400-any one man of you , learned or lewd , or [ye]139-birdalone shall rue it ! Even therewith came clearly the sound of the horn from the water , and again and yet again ; and [no man]534-no man spake but [the chaplain]1985-the chaplain , who cried out : Hearken , [knight]2054-knight , it is of [Birdalone]139-birdalone . But [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris laid [his]131-sir aymeris hand on [his]131-sir aymeris shoulder and said in an angry whisper : [Thou]131-sir aymeris shalt be put [downstairs]4549-downstairs , [priest]5405-priest , if [thou]131-sir aymeris hold not [thy]131-sir aymeris peace . [Leonard]139-birdalone drew aback scowling , and went out of the door , and so slowly down the stair , and withdrew [him]139-birdalone into the cover of the door of [the first chamber down from the tower - top]5406-the first chamber down from the tower - top , with the mind to waylay [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris as [he]139-birdalone came down ; and meanwhile [he]139-birdalone cursed [him]139-birdalone for [a fool]482-a fool and a dull - wit , and [himself]139-birdalone yet more , as was but right , for [a fool]482-a fool and [a licorous traitor]5409-a licorous traitor . But [he]139-birdalone had not tarried there more than a score of minutes , ere [he]139-birdalone heard a great shout from [those up above]5410-those up above : [They]5410-those up above are come ! [they]5410-those up above are come ! And next thereafter came [all the men]5411-all the men clattering down [the stair]5412-the stair past [him]139-birdalone , scarce refraining [them]5411-all the men from shoving [each [his]139-birdalone neighbour]5413-each his neighbour on to the next one ; [Leonard]139-birdalone followed on [them]5411-all the men , and presently arose great shouting and tumult through all [the house]311-the house , and [all folk]5415-all folk , [men]204-men and [women]420-women , hurried flock - meal toward the water - gate , and with [them]5411-all the men went [Leonard]139-birdalone perforce ; and sick of heart [he]139-birdalone was , calling to mind the first coming thither of [Birdalone]108-birdalone . But now when [they]5410-those up above came to the water - gate , there verily was the Sending Boat just coming to hand ; and in the stern stood [the three knights]5418-the three knights together , all clad in [their]5418-the three knights armour , and before [them]5418-the three knights sat [three lovely ladies]5419-three lovely ladies , clad [one in gold , one in green , and one in black]5420-one in gold , one in green , and one in black : and lo , there was the Quest come [home]373-home .
