Chapter II ~ Now Ask [They]5410-those up above of [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and [Sir Leonard]139-birdalone Speaks Now the prow touched the stones of the stair , and [folk]4521-folk were busy to lay hold of it that [the wayfarers]5423-the wayfarers might land , but [Sir Baudoin]115-baudoin cried out in a great voice : Let none be so hardy as to touch [this ferry]5424-this ferry , either now or hereafter ; for there is peril therein . And therewith [he]115-baudoin took [Aurea]107-aurea by the hand , and led [her]107-aurea out of [the boat]850-the boat and up the stair , and [she]107-aurea all joyous and wondering ; and thereafter came [Hugh]118-hugh and [[his]115-baudoin darling]5426-his darling , and last of all [Arthur]119-arthur and [Atra]109-atra , and [she]107-aurea alone of [the three women]5427-the three women looked downcast , and [her]107-aurea eyes wandered about the throng that was before [them]5427-the three women there , as though [she]107-aurea sought something , yet feared to see it . But when [they]5427-the three women were all standing together on [the landing - plain]5428-the landing - plain , and [the folk]228-the folk were all about [them]5427-the three women in a ring , [Sir Baudoin]115-baudoin spake to [the castellan]1691-the castellan and said : [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris , [thee]131-sir aymeris and [other folk [I]146-hearts see here]5431-other folk i see here , the sight of whom doth [me]146-hearts great joy ; but where , [I]146-hearts pray [thee]131-sir aymeris , is [the lady]1145-the lady , [[our]5427-the three women friend]5433-our friend [Birdalone]139-birdalone , by whom it is that all [we]5427-the three women are come happily hither ? And [he]115-baudoin looked around with an anxious face ; but [Arthur]119-arthur was as pale as ashes , yet [he]119-arthur spake nought , and [Atra]109-atra let [her]109-atra hand fall away from [his]119-arthur . Then spake [the castellan]1691-the castellan , and said : No harm hath befallen [the Lady Birdalone]108-birdalone ; but whiles [she]108-birdalone hath been somewhat ailing of late , and it is like that [she]108-birdalone wotteth not what is toward , and keepeth [[her]108-birdalone chamber]4893-her chamber now , for it is yet betimes in the morning . As [he]119-arthur spake , came thrusting [a man through the throng]5436-a man through the throng , eager and pale - faced ; who but [the chaplain]1985-the chaplain ; and [he]119-arthur said : [He]119-arthur would not let [me]146-hearts speak , [this fool]5438-this fool ; [I]146-hearts can not choose [my]146-hearts time . [Lords]1887-lords , [I]146-hearts bear evil tidings and an ugly welcome home . [The Lady Birdalone]108-birdalone is in peril , and [she]108-birdalone is not in [the castle]1534-the castle ; [I]146-hearts wot not where [she]108-birdalone is . [Ye]5441-ye must send [armed men]5442-armed men to seek [her]108-birdalone out . Thereat fell the silence of woe upon [the throng]233-the throng ; but [Arthur]119-arthur ran forward on [the priest]1677-the priest with drawn sword , and cried out : [I]146-hearts misdoubt [me]146-hearts that [thou]5438-this fool art [a traitor]5445-a traitor ; speak ! or [I]146-hearts will slay [thee]5438-this fool here and now . If [I]146-hearts be [a traitor]5445-a traitor , [quoth]5447-quoth [Leonard]139-birdalone , [I]146-hearts shall tell [thee]5438-this fool in little while what [ye]5438-this fool must do to undo [my]146-hearts treason , if there be yet time thereto ; so slay [me]146-hearts not till [ye]5438-this fool have heard , and then do what [ye]5438-this fool will with [me]146-hearts . But [Baudoin]115-baudoin put [Arthur]119-arthur aside , and said : Refrain [thee]119-arthur a little , [fair brother]5448-fair brother , else shall words tumble over each other and [we]5449-we shall know nothing clear . [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris , bring [[our]5449-we dear ladies]5450-our dear ladies to [the fairest chambers]5451-the fairest chambers , and do all honour and courtesy to [them]5450-our dear ladies . And [ye]5438-this fool , [sweetlings]5452-sweetlings , [ye]5438-this fool will not begrudge [us]5449-we that [we]5449-we go to seek [[your]5438-this fool friend]5453-your friend . [[Thou]5438-this fool priest]5454-thou priest , come with [us]5449-we a little apart , and tell [thy]5438-this fool tale as shortly as [thou]5438-this fool mayst , and fear nought ; [we]5449-we be not [[God]114-god â€™s dastards , as [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight and [[his]4913-the red knight men]5457-his men]5455-god â€™s dastards , as the red knight and his men . [Viridis]108-birdalone wept and kissed [her]108-birdalone love before [all folk]5415-all folk , and bade [him]5454-thou priest go and do [his]5454-thou priest best to find [[her]108-birdalone friend]433-her friend , or never come back to [her]108-birdalone else . Much moved , even to tears , was [Aurea withal]107-aurea , and reached [her]108-birdalone hand to [Baudoin]115-baudoin , and said : If [any man on earth]5460-any man on earth can help [us]5449-we it is [thou]5438-this fool . Go [thou]5438-this fool . But [Atra]109-atra wept not , and but said to [Arthur]119-arthur : Go [thou]5438-this fool , it is meet . Therewith were [the ladies]1877-the ladies brought to [fair chambers]5462-fair chambers ; but [the three knights]5418-the three knights went with [the priest]1677-the priest and [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris into [the solar]5465-the solar , and set a guard at the door that [their]5418-the three knights talk should be privy . Chapter III ~ How [They]5418-the three knights Follow the Slot of [Birdalone]108-birdalone and [the Black Knight]5179-the black knight It was but five minutes ere [the priest]1677-the priest had told [them]5418-the three knights all that need was ; so [they]5418-the three knights let [him]5179-the black knight abide alone there , though sooth to say there was none of [them]5418-the three knights but had good will to break [his]5179-the black knight neck ; and [the same rede]5468-the same rede had [all three]1397-all three , that there was nought for it but to go [their]5418-the three knights ways with all speed to [the Black Valley of [the Greywethers]142-the greywethers]5470-the black valley of the greywethers , and follow up [the slot of [Birdalone]108-birdalone]5471-the slot of birdalone if it might yet be found ; wherefore [they]5418-the three knights bade saddle [their]5418-the three knights horses straightway ; and while that was a - doing [they]5418-the three knights ate a morsel , and bade farewell to [[their]5418-the three knights lovelings]5472-their lovelings . And [they]5418-the three knights dight [them]5472-their lovelings to go , [they]5418-the three knights three together , with but [one squire]5473-one squire and [a sergeant]5474-a sergeant , who were [both of [them]5418-the three knights keen trackers and [fell woodsmen]5476-fell woodsmen]5475-both of them keen trackers and fell woodsmen . But ere [they]2369-they went , by the rede of [Arthur]119-arthur [they]2369-they bade [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris to arm a two score of [men]204-men and ride toward the Red Hold , and beset the ways â€˜[146-hearts] twixt that and [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest ; for one and all [they]2369-they deemed that if any harm befell [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight would be at the bottom of it . So rode [those fellows]2371-those fellows , and came unto [the dale]4999-the dale but some four hours after [Birdalone]108-birdalone had happened on [the stranger knight]2373-the stranger knight ; and [they]2369-they took up the slot of [her]108-birdalone , but not easily , whereas [the ground]5349-the ground was hard and stony ; howbeit , [they]2369-they found tokens of [the knight]1813-the knight also , finding here and there what [they]2369-they deemed the footprints of [a tall man]1504-a tall man . And this was grievous to [those fellows]2371-those fellows , since now [they]2369-they could not but deem that somewhat untoward had befallen [Birdalone]108-birdalone . But [they]2369-they went on making out the slot , and [they]2369-they followed it with much toil until [they]2369-they came to the doom - ring in [the head of [the dale]4999-the dale]5248-the head of the dale , whereas [Birdalone]108-birdalone and [the stranger]287-the stranger had sat down to meat ; but by that time , so toilsome had been [their]2369-they going , it was somewhat more than dusk , and there was nought for it but to abide there night - long . So a while [they]2369-they sat talking , [all of [them]2369-they]2381-all of them , and [the squire]2382-the squire and [the sergeant aforesaid]2383-the sergeant aforesaid were not a little timorous of the adventure of making that stead unkenned [[their]2369-they sleeping chamber]2384-their sleeping chamber ; and to while away the time , [[their]2369-they lords]2385-their lords made [them]2369-they tell tales such as [they]2369-they knew concerning [that place]2386-that place ; and both [they]2369-they said that [they]2369-they had never erst come into [the dale]4999-the dale but a very little way , and said that [they]2369-they had done so then but trusting in [[their]2369-they lords]2385-their lords â€™ bidding and the luck of the Quest . Thereafter turned the talk as to what had befallen [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and the chances of coming on [her]108-birdalone ; and , as [folk]4521-folk will in such a plight , [they]2369-they talked the matter over and over again till [they]2369-they were weary and could say no more . Then [they]2369-they went to sleep , and nought befell [them]2369-they till [they]2369-they awoke in the broad daylight ; but [they]2369-they had little inkling of what hour it was , for all [the dale]4999-the dale was full of thick white mist that came rolling down from [the mountains]200-the mountains , so that [they]2369-they could scarce see [their]2369-they hands before [them]2369-they , and there [they]2369-they had to tarry still , would [they]2369-they , would [they]2369-they not ; and [the sergeant]5481-the sergeant fell to telling tales of [folk who had been lost in that stony maze]5482-folk who had been lost in that stony maze ; and [all of [them]2381-all of them]2381-all of them deemed , more or less , that this was the work either of [evil wights]5191-evil wights , or it might be of [the wizardry of [the Red Knight]135-the red knight]5485-the wizardry of the red knight ; and , to be short , [they]2381-all of them all deemed that [he]135-the red knight it was who had wielded it , save [the sergeant]5481-the sergeant , who said that [the mountain wights]5487-the mountain wights were [the masters]5488-the masters and not [the servants of [[him]135-the red knight of [the Red Hold]2256-the red hold]5490-him of the red hold]5489-the servants of him of the red hold . Thus , then , it betided ; but when the said mist had been hanging upon [them]2381-all of them for some six hours , it rolled up like a curtain , and lo the blue sky and the sun , and [the mountains]200-the mountains as clear blue as in a picture ; and [they]2381-all of them saw by the sun that it was but a little after high noon . But as [they]2381-all of them rejoiced herein , and betook [them]2381-all of them once more to tracking out the slot of [Birdalone]108-birdalone and the other , the sky became suddenly overcast , and down from the jaws of [the mountain]5493-the mountain came a storm of wind and rain , and thunder and lightning , so great that [they]2381-all of them might scarce see [each other]569-each other â€™s faces , and when it cleared off , in about an hour and a half , and went down the wind to the south - east , [the stream]1777-the stream was waxen great , and ran brown and furious down [the dale]4999-the dale , so that it was fordable only here and there ; and as for tracking the slot of [those twain]5497-those twain , there was no need to talk thereof , for the fury of the driving rain had washed all away . Thus fared [they]2381-all of them the whole day betwixt fog and clear weather , and [they]2381-all of them laid [them]2381-all of them down to rest at night sore disheartened . When the day broke [they]2381-all of them talked together as to what was best to do ; and [the sergeant]5481-the sergeant aforesaid spake : [Lords]1887-lords , said [he]5481-the sergeant , meseemeth [I]2369-they am more at home in [the Black Valley]33-the black valley than [ye]1887-lords be ; heed [ye]1887-lords not wherefore . Now so it is that if [we]2381-all of them tarry here till night come [we]2381-all of them wot not what of evil may betide [us]2381-all of them , or at the least [we]2381-all of them do nought . Or if [we]2381-all of them turn back and go southward out of [the dale]4999-the dale [we]2381-all of them shall be safe indeed ; but safe should [we]2381-all of them have been at [[your]1887-lords house]5501-your house , [lords]1887-lords , and should have done no less . But now [I]2369-they shall tell [you]1887-lords that , if [ye]1887-lords will , [lords]1887-lords , [I]2369-they shall guide [you]1887-lords to a pass that goeth out of [the head of [the dale]4999-the dale to [our]2381-all of them right hands]5504-the head of the dale to our right hands , and so turneth the flank of [the mountains]200-the mountains , and cometh out into [the country which lieth about [the Red Hold]42-the red hold]5507-the country which lieth about the red hold ; and meseemeth it is thitherward that [we]2381-all of them must seek if [we]2381-all of them would hear any tidings of [the lady]1145-the lady ; for there may [we]2381-all of them lay in ambush and beset the ways that lead up to [the Hold]5509-the hold , by which [she]1145-the lady must have been brought if [she]1145-the lady hath not been carried through the air . How say [ye]1887-lords , [lords]1887-lords ? Soothly there is peril therein ; yet [meseemeth]113-meseemeth peril no more than in [our]2381-all of them abiding another night in [the Black Valley]33-the black valley . Said [Arthur]119-arthur : [We]2381-all of them heed not the peril if there be aught to be done ; wherefore let [us]2381-all of them be stirring straightway . And so said [they]2381-all of them all . Wherefore [they]2381-all of them gat to horse , and rode up to [the very head of [the valley]4994-the valley]5511-the very head of the valley , and the weather was now calm and bright . But [the sergeant]5481-the sergeant brought [them]2381-all of them to [the pass whereof [the stranger knight]2373-the stranger knight had spoken to [Birdalone]108-birdalone , which led into [the Red Knight â€™s country]5516-the red knight â€™s country]5514-the pass whereof the stranger knight had spoken to birdalone , which led into the red knight â€™s country , and without more ado [they]2381-all of them entered [it]5516-the red knight â€™s country when it was now about three hours after noon . But the way was both steep and rough , so that [they]2381-all of them had much toil , and went not very far ere night fell upon [them]2381-all of them , and the moon was not yet up . So when [they]2381-all of them had stumbled on another two hours , and [their]2381-all of them horses were much spent and [they]2381-all of them [themselves]2381-all of them not a little weary , [they]2381-all of them laid [them]2381-all of them down to sleep , after [they]2381-all of them had eaten such meat as [they]2381-all of them had with [them]2381-all of them , in a place where was a little grass for the horses to bite ; for all [the road]1797-the road hitherto had been mere grim stones and big rocks , walled on either side by stony screes , above which rose [steep and beetling crags]5518-steep and beetling crags . In the dawn [they]2381-all of them arose again , and made no ado till [they]2381-all of them were in the saddle , and rode till [they]2381-all of them came to [the crest of [the pass]5331-the pass]5519-the crest of the pass , and came out thence after a while on to the swelling flank of a huge mountain ( as it might be the side of [the mountain of Plinlimmon in [Wales]46-wales]5521-the mountain of plinlimmon in wales ) , which was grassed and nought craggy , but utterly treeless . Now [the sergeant]5481-the sergeant led [them]2381-all of them somewhat athwart [the said mountain]5523-the said mountain till [they]2381-all of them began to go down , and saw below [them]2381-all of them [a country of little hills much covered with wood]5524-a country of little hills much covered with wood , and in a while , and ere it was noon , [they]2381-all of them were among [the said woods]5525-the said woods , which were grown mostly with big trees , as oak here and beech there , and the going was good for [them]2381-all of them . Chapter IV ~ Of the Slaying of [Friend]147-friend and Foe So came [they]2381-all of them , three hours after noon , to where was [a clearing in [the woodland]657-the woodland]5526-a clearing in the woodland , and [a long narrow plain some furlong over]5528-a long narrow plain some furlong over lay before [them]2381-all of them , with [a river]5529-a river running along [it]5528-a long narrow plain some furlong over , and the wood rose on the other side high and thick , so that [the said plain]5530-the said plain looked even as a wide green highway leading from somewhence to somewhither . At the edge hereof [their]2381-all of them way - leader , [the sergeant]5481-the sergeant , bade draw rein , and said : [Lords]148-lords , [we]2381-all of them are now in [the lands of [the Red Hold]2256-the red hold]5532-the lands of the red hold , and therein is mickle peril and dread to any save stout hearts as [ye]148-lords be ; but meseems [we]2381-all of them are so steaded , that whatever may come out of [the Black Valley]33-the black valley of [the Greywethers]142-the greywethers to [the Red Hold]42-the red hold , [ye]148-lords now may scarce miss . Yonder along [this plain to the north]5534-this plain to the north lies the way to [the said Hold]5535-the said hold , and [any man coming from [the head of [the valley]4994-the valley]5537-the head of the valley]5536-any man coming from the head of the valley is sure to come by the way [we]2381-all of them have come , and will pass [us]2381-all of them not many yards at the worst from where [we]2381-all of them now be . On the other hand , if any come to the Hold from [the mouth of [the Black Valley]33-the black valley]5539-the mouth of the black valley , then along [this green road]5540-this green road must [they]5541-they needs pass under [your]148-lords very eyes . Lastly , if [we]2381-all of them do what [we]2381-all of them are come to do , to wit , to deliver [the lady]1145-the lady from [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight , then , the deed done , [we]2381-all of them have to take [the green road]5544-the green road southward , and ride it for a league and then turn east , and [we]2381-all of them shall have [our]2381-all of them heads turned toward [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest , and shall speedily fall in with [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris and [[our]2381-all of them men who be guarding [the out - gates of [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight â€™s country]5547-the out - gates of the red knight â€™s country toward [[our]2381-all of them house]4667-our house]5546-our men who be guarding the out - gates of the red knight â€™s country toward our house . So now , by [my]2369-they rede , [ye]148-lords shall lay in covert here and abide a while what may befall ; if nought come hereby ere two hours be lacking of sunset , then may [we]2381-all of them seek further . [They]5550-they all yeasaid this , and gat off [their]5550-they horses , and lay quiet on the grass , not even speaking save softly . And when [they]5550-they had abided thus scarce an hour â€™s space , [the squire]2382-the squire , who was [a man of very fine ear]5552-a man of very fine ear , held up [his]2382-the squire hand as though to bid utter silence , and all hearkened eagerly . Presently [he]2382-the squire said : Hear [ye]148-lords not ? Said [Arthur]119-arthur : [Meseemeth]113-meseemeth [I]2369-they hear a faint tinkle as of a sheep - bell . Said [the squire]2382-the squire : â€™[2369-they] Tis the clashing of swords down [the plain]4991-the plain to the south , and meseemeth â€™ tis but of two : ride [we]2381-all of them thither ? Quoth [Baudoin]115-baudoin : Nay , not by [my]2369-they rede ; for if [we]2381-all of them can hear [them]5550-they [they]5550-they can hear [us]2381-all of them ; let [us]2381-all of them quietly edge along afoot somewhat nigher [their]5550-they way , ever keeping the cover of the wood betwixt [us]2381-all of them and [the open plain]5554-the open plain . Now then to it ; and let [each man]5555-each man keep [his]5555-each man weapons ready . Even so did [they]5550-they , and spread out in a line as [they]5550-they went , in such wise that there was some six paces betwixt [each man of [them]5550-they]2283-each man of them , and [they]5550-they went softly forward ; [Baudoin]115-baudoin went first , [Hugh]118-hugh second , then [Arthur]119-arthur ; then [the squire]2382-the squire and [the sergeant last of all]5558-the sergeant last of all . Now when [they]5550-they had gone but a quarter of an hour , [the squire]2382-the squire caught up with [Arthur]119-arthur , and spake to [him]119-arthur softly , and said : The voice of the swords has been silent now a while , and [I]2369-they heard a voice crying out eâ€™en now , [a woman]235-a woman â€™s voice . And now again [I]2369-they could well - nigh deem that [I]2369-they hear horse - hoofs . [Arthur]119-arthur nodded to [him]119-arthur , and [they]5550-they went but a little further ere [he]119-arthur said : Lo , lo ! â€™[2369-they] tis the time of the eyes now ! Here come [folk]4521-folk . And therewithal [they]4521-folk stayed [them]4521-folk . For [the wood]335-the wood turned somewhat here , so as to hide all but a little of [the plain]4991-the plain , and round the wood neb [the new - comers]2393-the new - comers hove in sight , and were close on [them]4521-folk at once , so that [they]4521-folk might see [them]4521-folk clearly , to wit , [a knight weaponed , clad all in red]2394-a knight weaponed , clad all in red , [a very big man]2395-a very big man , riding on a great bay horse , and behind [him]2395-a very big man [a woman going afoot in very piteous plight]2396-a woman going afoot in very piteous plight ; for [she]2396-a woman going afoot in very piteous plight was tethered to the horse â€™s crupper by a thong that bound [her]2396-a woman going afoot in very piteous plight wrists together , so that [she]2396-a woman going afoot in very piteous plight had but just room left â€˜ twixt [her]2396-a woman going afoot in very piteous plight and the horse that [she]2396-a woman going afoot in very piteous plight might walk , and round about [her]2396-a woman going afoot in very piteous plight neck was hung [a man]217-a man â€™s head newly hewn off . This sight [they]4521-folk all saw at once , and were out of the wood in a trice with weapons aloft , for [they]4521-folk knew both [the man]5167-the man and [the woman]237-the woman , that [they]4521-folk were [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight and [Birdalone]108-birdalone . So swift and sudden had [they]4521-folk been , that [he]2395-a very big man had no time either to spur or even to draw [his]2395-a very big man sword ; but [he]2395-a very big man had a heavy steel axe in [his]2395-a very big man hand as [the first man]5565-the first man came up to [him]2395-a very big man , which was [the tall Baudoin]115-baudoin ; and therewith [he]2395-a very big man smote down on [Baudoin]115-baudoin so fierce and huge a stroke , that came on [him]2395-a very big man betwixt neck and shoulder , that all gave way before it , and [the Golden Knight]1811-the golden knight fell to earth all carven and stark dead : but even therewith fell [Hugh]118-hugh , [the squire]2382-the squire , and [the sergeant]5481-the sergeant on [the Red Knight]135-the red knight ; for [Arthur]119-arthur had run to [Birdalone]108-birdalone and sheared [her]108-birdalone loose from [her]108-birdalone tether . [The sergeant]5481-the sergeant smote [him]2395-a very big man on the right arm with a maul , so that the axe fell to the ground ; [the squire]2382-the squire â€™s sword came on the side of [his]2395-a very big man head , and , as it was cast back beneath the stroke , [Hugh]118-hugh thrust [his]118-hugh sword through the throat of [him]2395-a very big man , and down [he]2395-a very big man fell unto [the earth]432-the earth and was dead in less than a minute . Then gathered [the others]1287-the others round about [Baudoin]115-baudoin , and saw at once that [he]115-baudoin was dead ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone came thrusting through the press of [them]1287-the others , and knelt down beside [him]115-baudoin , and when [she]108-birdalone saw [[her]108-birdalone friend]433-her friend so piteously dight , [she]108-birdalone wept and wailed over [him]115-baudoin as one who might not be comforted ; and [Hugh]118-hugh stood over [her]108-birdalone and let [his]118-hugh tears fall down upon [the dead man]5574-the dead man ; and withal [the squire]2382-the squire and [the sergeant]5481-the sergeant did not refrain [their]1287-the others lamentations , for sore beloved was [Sir Baudoin the Golden Knight]115-baudoin . But [Arthur]119-arthur spake dry - eyed , though there was grief in [his]119-arthur countenance , and [he]119-arthur said : [Fellows]149-fellows , and [thou]149-fellows , [lady]493-lady , let [us]5578-us lament afterwards , but now is time for [us]5578-us to get [us]5578-us gone hence as speedily as may be . Yet [I]108-birdalone will ask , doth any know whose is this head that [the slain tyrant here]5579-the slain tyrant here had hung about [the lady]1145-the lady â€™s neck ? May [the fiends]5581-the fiends curse [him]5574-the dead man therefor ! Said [the sergeant]5481-the sergeant : [Yea]5583-yea , [lords]1887-lords , that wot [I]108-birdalone ; this is [the head of [[the Red Knight]4913-the red knight â€™s captain]5587-the red knight â€™s captain and head man , [Sir Thomas of [Estcliffe]47-estcliffe]5588-sir thomas of estcliffe]5585-the head of the red knight â€™s captain and head man , sir thomas of estcliffe ; [one of the hardiest of [knights]5590-knights [he]5574-the dead man was while [he]5574-the dead man was alive , as [ye]1887-lords surely wot , [lords]1887-lords]5589-one of the hardiest of knights he was while he was alive , as ye surely wot , lords ; neither , as [I]108-birdalone have heard say , was [he]5574-the dead man as cruel a tyrant as [[his]5574-the dead man lord]2233-his lord that lieth there ready for the ravens . Now had [Birdalone]108-birdalone arisen and was standing facing [Arthur]119-arthur ; [her]108-birdalone face was pale and full of anguish , and [she]108-birdalone was dabbled with blood from [the dead man]5574-the dead man â€™s neck ; but there was nought of shame in [her]108-birdalone face as [she]108-birdalone stood there and spoke : [O [[my]108-birdalone living friends]5595-my living friends , who have but now saved [me]108-birdalone , [ye]1887-lords and [[my]108-birdalone dead friends]5596-my dead friends]5594-o my living friends , who have but now saved me , ye and my dead friends , from what shame and death [I]108-birdalone know not , the tale of [this woeful hap]5597-this woeful hap is over long to tell if there be peril at hand , and [I]108-birdalone scarce alive from dread and sorrow ; but shortly thus it is : [This man , whose head here lieth]5598-this man , whose head here lieth , entrapped [me]108-birdalone as [I]108-birdalone foolishly wandered in [the Black Valley]33-the black valley , and afterwards delivered [me]108-birdalone , and was leading [me]108-birdalone to [[your]1887-lords castle]5599-your castle , [[my]108-birdalone friends]1795-my friends , when [this other one]5601-this other one , [[his]5601-this other one master]5602-his master , [the tyrant of the Red Hold]5603-the tyrant of the red hold , came upon [him]5601-this other one , and fell upon [him]5601-this other one and slew [him]5601-this other one as [a traitor]5445-a traitor , and dighted [me]108-birdalone as [ye]1887-lords saw . And woe â€™s [me]108-birdalone ! [I]108-birdalone am [the fool whose folly has slain [[your]1887-lords friend]5453-your friend and [mine]108-birdalone]5605-the fool whose folly has slain your friend and mine . Wherefore [I]108-birdalone am not worthy of [your]1887-lords fellowship , and [ye]1887-lords shall cast [me]108-birdalone forth of it ; or to slay [me]108-birdalone were better . So [she]108-birdalone spake , gazing earnestly on [Arthur]119-arthur ; and so troubled and grieved , that [she]108-birdalone might well have died but for [her]108-birdalone woodland breeding , and the toil of the days [she]108-birdalone had won through in [the House under [the Wood]335-the wood]4835-the house under the wood . But [Hugh spake]118-hugh gently to [her]108-birdalone and said : Keep up [thine]5609-thine heart yet , [maiden]1105-maiden ; for the hand of Fate it is that led [thee]108-birdalone , and none doeth grievously amiss but if [he]119-arthur mean wrong - doing in [his]119-arthur heart ; and [we]5611-our know [thee]108-birdalone for true ; and [thou]108-birdalone hast been [[our]5611-our helper]5612-our helper , and brought [[our]5611-our lovelings]5613-our lovelings unto [us]5611-our to make [us]5611-our happy . But [she]108-birdalone brake out weeping afresh , and said : O no , no ! it is but woe and weariness [I]108-birdalone have brought unto [[my]108-birdalone friends]1795-my friends ; and to [myself]108-birdalone woe and weariness yet more . And [she]108-birdalone looked piteously into [Arthur]119-arthur â€™s face , and hard and stern it seemed unto [her]108-birdalone ; and [she]108-birdalone writhed and wrung [her]108-birdalone hands for anguish . But [he]119-arthur spake and said : This will [we]5611-our look into when [we]5611-our be safe behind [our]5611-our walls , and see what [she]108-birdalone hath done amiss and what not amiss . But now is there but one thing to do , and that is to get [us]5611-our speedily on [our]5611-our way to [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest , and bind [[our]5611-our fellow]5616-our fellow â€™s body on [his]119-arthur horse that [he]119-arthur also may ride with [us]5611-our , and [the lady]1145-the lady shall ride the horse of [the accursed thief]5618-the accursed thief . Then [they]5611-our turned to go toward [their]5611-our horses ; but therewith [Birdalone]108-birdalone smote [her]108-birdalone foot against [the slain knight]5619-the slain knight â€™s head , and shrank aback from it , and pointed down toward it and spake no word ; and [Hugh]118-hugh said : [Friends]404-friends , [the lady]1145-the lady is right , this at least [we]5611-our will cover with earth . Do [ye]404-friends go fetch hither [[our]5611-our horses]5622-our horses , since [we]5611-our be on [the road]1797-the road , and [I]108-birdalone will do here what need is meanwhile . So [they]5611-our went on that errand , and then [Hugh]118-hugh and [Birdalone]108-birdalone between [them]5611-our dug a hole with the swords and laid the head of [the captain of the Red Knight therein]5624-the captain of the red knight therein . And forsooth , somewhat would [Birdalone]108-birdalone have wept for [him]5619-the slain knight had [she]108-birdalone had a tear to spare . Then [they]5611-our fell to and bound the dead [Baudoin]115-baudoin on [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight â€™s mighty bay steed , so that no time might be wasted ; and when that was done , and [the others]1287-the others had not come back with [their]1287-the others horses , [Hugh]118-hugh took [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s hand and led [her]108-birdalone down to [the stream]1777-the stream and washed the gore off [her]108-birdalone bosom , and [she]108-birdalone washed [her]108-birdalone face and [her]108-birdalone hands and let [him]118-hugh lead [her]108-birdalone back again in such wise that now [she]108-birdalone could hearken to the words of comfort [he]118-hugh spake to [her]108-birdalone , and piteous kind [he]118-hugh seemed unto [her]108-birdalone ; so that at last [she]108-birdalone plucked up heart , and asked [him]118-hugh how [Viridis]108-birdalone did . Quoth [he]118-hugh : [They]5628-they be all safe at [home]373-home in [the castle]1534-the castle , and [Viridis]108-birdalone is well and loveth [thee]118-hugh well . And [Aurea]107-aurea was well , woe worth the while for [her]107-aurea now ! As for [Atra]109-atra , [she]109-atra has not been so glad as [the other twain]4523-the other twain , [I]108-birdalone wot not wherefore . Even as [he]118-hugh spake were [the others]1287-the others come up with the horses , and [Arthur]119-arthur nodded yeasay when [he]119-arthur saw what had been done with [Baudoin]115-baudoin dead ; and so [they]5628-they gat to horse , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone it was that rode [Baudoin]115-baudoin â€™s steed . Then [they]5628-they went [their]5628-they ways , crossing [the river]1845-the river into [the wood]335-the wood ; and [the sergeant]5481-the sergeant was ever way - leader , but [the squire]2382-the squire led the horse which bore the sorrowful burden of [the dead Knight of the Quest]5637-the dead knight of the quest . Chapter V ~ [They]5628-they Come Home to [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest Now [they]5628-they had gone but some three hours , riding dreary and nigh speechless [all of [them]5628-they]2381-all of them , ere [they]5628-they began to know [the land]198-the land [they]5628-they were in , and that [they]5628-they were coming to the place where [they]5628-they might look presently to fall in with [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris and [[his]131-sir aymeris company]5064-his company ; and even so the meeting betid , that [they]5628-they saw [men]204-men standing and going about [their]204-men horses beside [a little wood]5643-a little wood , and knew [them]204-men presently for [[their]204-men folk]5644-their folk , who mounted at once and spurred forward to meet [them]204-men , spears aloft . Speedily then was the joy of [those abiders]5645-those abiders turned into sorrow , nor may the grief of [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris be told , so great it was ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone looked on and saw the mourning and lamentation of [the warriors]5646-the warriors , and eked was [her]108-birdalone anguish of mind ; and [she]108-birdalone beheld [Arthur]119-arthur the Black Squire , how [he]119-arthur sat still upon [his]119-arthur horse with a hard and dreary countenance , and looked on [those mourners]5647-those mourners almost as if [he]119-arthur contemned [them]5647-those mourners . But [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris came up to [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and knelt before [her]108-birdalone and kissed [her]108-birdalone hand , and said : If [my]108-birdalone heart might rejoice in aught , as some day it will , it would rejoice in seeing [thee]108-birdalone safe and sound , [lady]493-lady ; here at least is gain to set beside the loss . [She]108-birdalone thanked [him]131-sir aymeris , but looked askance toward [Arthur]119-arthur , who said : If that be gain , yet is there more , for [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight lieth in [the green plain]626-the green plain for a supper to the wolf and the crow . Vengeance there hath been , and belike more yet may come . But now , if [ye]108-birdalone have lamented as much as [ye]108-birdalone deem befitteth [warriors]1809-warriors , let [us]5652-they tarry here no longer ; for even yet meseemeth shall [we]5652-they be safer behind walls , now that [[our]5652-they chief]5653-our chief and [captain]5654-captain is slain , [I]108-birdalone scarce know in what quarrel . [None]1359-none naysaid it , so [they]5652-they all rode forth together , and [the sergeant]5481-the sergeant and [the squire]2382-the squire and [Sir Hugh]118-hugh told of [their]5652-they tale what [they]5652-they might to [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris and [the others]1287-the others ; but [Arthur]119-arthur held [his]119-arthur peace , and rode aloof from [Birdalone]108-birdalone , whereas [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris and [Hugh]118-hugh rode on either side of [her]108-birdalone , and did not spare to comfort [her]108-birdalone what [they]5652-they might . [They]5652-they rode straight on , and made no stay for nightfall , and thus came [home]373-home to [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest before the day was full ; and woeful was [their]5652-they entry as [they]5652-they went in the dawn underneath the gate of [the said castle]1638-the said castle , and soon was [the whole house]5662-the whole house astir and lamenting . As for [Birdalone]108-birdalone , when [she]108-birdalone got down from [her]108-birdalone horse in the gateway , and was stiff and weary of body , and all dazed and confused of mind , there was but little life in [her]108-birdalone ; nor could [she]108-birdalone so much as think of the new day and [Aurea]107-aurea â€™s awakening , but crept up unto [[her]108-birdalone own chamber]5663-her own chamber , so long as it seemed since [she]108-birdalone had left [it]5663-her own chamber , though it was but a little while ; and [she]108-birdalone cast [herself]108-birdalone upon the bed and fell asleep whether [she]108-birdalone would or not , and so forgat [her]108-birdalone much sorrow and [her]108-birdalone little hope . Chapter VI ~ Of the Talk Betwixt [Birdalone]108-birdalone and [Viridis]108-birdalone When [she]108-birdalone woke again , [she]108-birdalone had slept the night away , and it was broad day , and for a moment [she]108-birdalone lay wondering what was the burden upon [her]108-birdalone ; but presently [she]108-birdalone called it all to mind , and deemed it were well might [she]108-birdalone forget it all again . Anon [she]108-birdalone became aware of [someone]485-someone moving about [the chamber]292-the chamber , and [she]108-birdalone looked about unhappily ; and lo ! [a woman , fair and dainty , clad all in green]5666-a woman , fair and dainty , clad all in green , and it was [Viridis]108-birdalone that had come [there]215-there . But when [she]108-birdalone saw [Birdalone]108-birdalone stirring , [she]108-birdalone came up to [her]108-birdalone and kissed [her]108-birdalone sweetly and kindly , and wept over [her]108-birdalone , so that [Birdalone]108-birdalone might nowise refrain [her]108-birdalone tears . But when [she]108-birdalone might cease weeping , [she]108-birdalone said to [Viridis]108-birdalone : Tell [me]108-birdalone , art [thou]108-birdalone weeping for [[thy]108-birdalone friend]4800-thy friend who is lost , and who shall be [[thy]108-birdalone friend]4800-thy friend no more ; or [[thy]108-birdalone friend whom [thou]108-birdalone hast found]5670-thy friend whom thou hast found ? Said [Viridis]108-birdalone : [Forsooth]108-birdalone [I]108-birdalone have wept for [Baudoin]115-baudoin plenteously , and [he]115-baudoin is worthy of it , for [he]115-baudoin was valiant and true and kind . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : True is that ; but [I]108-birdalone meant not [my]108-birdalone question so ; but rather [I]108-birdalone would ask [thee]108-birdalone if [thou]108-birdalone weepest because [thine]108-birdalone heart must needs cast [me]108-birdalone away , or because [thou]108-birdalone hast found [me]108-birdalone again ? Quoth Viridis : Whoso may be dead , or whoso alive , but if it were [Hugh]118-hugh , [[my]108-birdalone loveling]5671-my loveling , [I]108-birdalone were rejoiced beyond measure to find [thee]108-birdalone , [[my]108-birdalone friend]304-my friend . And again [she]108-birdalone kissed [her]108-birdalone as one who was glad and kind . But for new rest of soul and for joy , [Birdalone]108-birdalone fell a - weeping afresh . Again [she]108-birdalone spake : And what mind have the others about [me]108-birdalone ? For [thou]108-birdalone art but one , though the dearest , save . . . And would [they]5673-they punish [me]108-birdalone for [my]108-birdalone fault and folly that has slain [the best man in [the world]417-the world]5674-the best man in the world ? If the punishment be short of putting [me]108-birdalone forth of [their]5673-they fellowship , [I]108-birdalone were fain thereof . [Viridis]108-birdalone laughed : Forsooth , [she]108-birdalone said , [they]5673-they have much to punish [thee]108-birdalone for ! whereas it was by [thy]108-birdalone doing and [thy]108-birdalone valiance that [we]5676-we all came together again and the Quest was accomplished . Nay , but tell [me]108-birdalone , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , what do [they]5673-they say of [me]108-birdalone , [each one of [them]5673-they]1918-each one of them ? [Viridis]108-birdalone reddened ; [she]108-birdalone said : [Hugh]118-hugh , [[my]108-birdalone mate]5678-my mate , saith all good of [thee]108-birdalone ; though [no one of carl - folk]5679-no one of carl - folk may be sorrier of the loss of [[his]5679-no one of carl - folk fellow]5680-his fellow . [Aurea]107-aurea layeth not the death of [[her]107-aurea man]5681-her man upon [thee]108-birdalone ; and [she]107-aurea saith : When the fountain of tears is dried up in [me]108-birdalone , [I]108-birdalone will see [her]107-aurea and comfort [her]107-aurea , as [she]107-aurea [me]108-birdalone . Atra saith : [she]107-aurea saith but little , yet [she]107-aurea saith : So is it fated . [I]108-birdalone had done belike no better , but worse than [she]107-aurea . Now turned [Birdalone]108-birdalone red and then pale again , and [she]107-aurea said , but in a quavering voice : And [the Black Squire]1325-the black squire , [Arthur]119-arthur , what sayeth [he]119-arthur ? Said [Viridis]108-birdalone : [He]119-arthur sayeth nought of [thee]108-birdalone , but that [he]119-arthur would hear all the tale of what befell [thee]108-birdalone in [the Black Valley]33-the black valley . [Sweet friend]4568-sweet friend , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [I]108-birdalone pray [thee]4568-sweet friend of [thy]4568-sweet friend kindness and sweetness that [thou]4568-sweet friend go unto [him]119-arthur presently and bring [him]119-arthur in hither , and then [I]108-birdalone will tell [him]119-arthur all ; and [he]119-arthur and [thou]4568-sweet friend and [I]108-birdalone together . [Viridis]108-birdalone said : There is this to be said , that when [a man]217-a man loveth [a woman]235-a woman [he]217-a man coveteth [her]235-a woman , to have [her]235-a woman all wholly to [himself]217-a man , and hard and evil [he]217-a man groweth for the time that [he]217-a man misdoubteth [her]235-a woman whom [he]217-a man loveth . And [I]108-birdalone will tell [thee]4568-sweet friend that [this man]1669-this man is jealous lest [thou]4568-sweet friend wert never so little kind to [the slain stranger knight whose head [the tyrant]5688-the tyrant hung about [thee]4568-sweet friend]5687-the slain stranger knight whose head the tyrant hung about thee . Furthermore , [I]108-birdalone fear there is no help for it that [thou]4568-sweet friend wilt undo the happiness of one of [us]5689-our , that is [Atra]109-atra ; yet were it better that that befell later than sooner . And if [Sir Arthur]150-arthur come in here to [thee]4568-sweet friend , and hath [thy]150-arthur tale with none beside save [me]108-birdalone , meseems [the poor Atra]5690-the poor atra will feel a bitter smart because of it . Were it not better that [we]5689-our all meet presently in the solar , and that there [thou]4568-sweet friend tell [thy]150-arthur tale to [us]5689-our all ? and thereafter shall [we]5689-our tell the tale of [our]5689-our deliverance and [our]5689-our coming hither . And thus doing , it will seem less like to the breaking up of [our]5689-our fellowship . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : It will be hard for [me]108-birdalone to tell [my]108-birdalone tale before [Atra]109-atra and before [him]150-arthur . Might it not be that [thou]4568-sweet friend hearken to it here and now , and tell it to the others hereafter ? Nay , nay , said [Viridis]108-birdalone , [I]108-birdalone am [not a proper minstrel]5691-not a proper minstrel to take the word out of [thy]4568-sweet friend mouth . Never shall [I]108-birdalone be able to tell it so that [they]4568-sweet friend shall trow it as if [they]4568-sweet friend had seen it all . Besides , when all is told , then shall [we]5689-our be more bound together again . [I]108-birdalone pray [thee]4568-sweet friend , and [I]108-birdalone pray [thee]4568-sweet friend , sweet , do so much for [me]108-birdalone as to tell [thy]4568-sweet friend tale to [the fellowship of [us]5689-our]5692-the fellowship of us . And if it be hard to [thee]4568-sweet friend , look upon it as [my]108-birdalone share of the punishment which is due to [thee]4568-sweet friend for falling into that mishap . [Smiled Birdalone]108-birdalone ruefully , and said : So be it ; and may the share of [the others]1287-the others be as light as thine , [sister]773-sister . Yet soothly were [I]108-birdalone liefer that [my]108-birdalone body and [my]108-birdalone skin should pay the forfeit . But now , since [I]108-birdalone must needs do this , the sooner is [the better meseemeth]5695-the better meseemeth . In a little half hour , said [Viridis]108-birdalone , will [I]108-birdalone bring what is left of [our]5689-our fellowship into [the solar]5465-the solar to hearken [thee]4568-sweet friend . So come [thou]4568-sweet friend there unto [us]5689-our when [thou]4568-sweet friend art clad . And hear [thou]4568-sweet friend ! be not too meek and humble , and bow [thyself]5697-thyself to [us]5689-our in fear of [our]5689-our sorrow . For whereas [thou]4568-sweet friend didst speak of [our]5689-our punishing [thee]4568-sweet friend , there will be one there whom [thou]4568-sweet friend mayst easily punish to [thy]4568-sweet friend pleasure ; forsooth , [friend]5069-friend , [I]108-birdalone rue that so it is ; but since it will not better be , what may [I]108-birdalone do but wish [thee]4568-sweet friend happy and [him]5699-him also . Therewith [she]108-birdalone turned and went out of [the chamber]292-the chamber , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone , left to [herself]108-birdalone , felt a secret joy in [her]108-birdalone soul that [she]108-birdalone might not master , despite the sorrow of [[her]108-birdalone friends]1305-her friends , whatever it might be . Chapter VII ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone Telleth the Tale of [Her]108-birdalone Wandering Up [the Valley of]5702-the valley of [the Greywethers]142-the greywethers Now [Viridis]108-birdalone did as [she]108-birdalone said , and brought [them]1305-her friends all in to the solar ; there was none lacking save [Baudoin]115-baudoin , and [they]1305-her friends sat silently in a half ring , till the door opened and [Birdalone]108-birdalone came in to [them]1305-her friends , clad all simply in but a black coat ; and [she]108-birdalone made obeisance to [them]1305-her friends , and stood there with [her]108-birdalone head bent down as if [they]1305-her friends were [[her]108-birdalone judges]5703-her judges , for so in sooth [she]108-birdalone deemed [them]1305-her friends . Then [Hugh]118-hugh bade [her]108-birdalone sit down amongst [them]1305-her friends ; but [she]108-birdalone said : Nay , [I]108-birdalone will not sit amongst [you]118-hugh till [ye]118-hugh have heard [my]108-birdalone story , and [ye]118-hugh have told [me]108-birdalone that [I]108-birdalone am yet of [your]118-hugh fellowship . None said aught ; [Atra]109-atra looked straight before [her]109-atra , and [her]109-atra eyes met not [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s eyes ; [Arthur]150-arthur looked down on the ground ; but [Hugh]118-hugh and [Viridis]108-birdalone looked kindly on [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and to [Viridis]108-birdalone â€™[108-birdalone] eyes the tears were come . Then spake [Birdalone]108-birdalone and said : [I]0-i am here as one that hath done amiss ; but [I]0-i will tell [you]108-birdalone , so that [ye]108-birdalone may not think worse of [me]0-i than [ye]108-birdalone should , that when [ye]108-birdalone were gone , [ye]108-birdalone Champions , and the time wore long that [ye]108-birdalone came not again , it lay heavy on [my]0-i heart , and hope waned and fear waxed , and [my]0-i soul so grieved [my]0-i body that [I]0-i thought to fall sick thereof , and [I]0-i knew that it would be ill for [you]108-birdalone to come [home hither]2397-home hither and find [me]0-i sick ; so that [I]0-i longed sore to do somewhat which should make [me]0-i whole again . Then weird would that [I]0-i should hear all the tale of [the Black Valley of the Greywethers]5470-the black valley of the greywethers , and of how therein is whiles granted fulfilment of desire ; and methought how well it were if [I]0-i might seek the adventure there and accomplish it . [Thereof]2399-thereof , doubtless , hath [the chaplain]1985-the chaplain , [Sir Leonard]139-birdalone , told [you]108-birdalone ; but this furthermore would [I]0-i say , that [his]1985-the chaplain doing herein was nought ; all was done by [my]0-i doing and by [my]0-i bidding , and [he]1985-the chaplain might not choose but do it . Wherefore [I]0-i do pray [you]108-birdalone all earnestly that [ye]108-birdalone keep no grudge against [him]1985-the chaplain , but pardon [him]1985-the chaplain all . Tell [me]0-i , then , will [ye]108-birdalone do thus much ? Said [Hugh]118-hugh : Let [him]1985-the chaplain be pardoned , if [he]1985-the chaplain can take pardon . But [Arthur]150-arthur spake not , and [Birdalone]139-birdalone looked on [him]1985-the chaplain anxiously , and [her]2401-she face was moved , and it was with [her]2401-she throat as if [she]2401-she had swallowed something down . Then [she]2401-she spake again , and fell to tell [them]2402-we all that had betid to [her]2401-she when [she]2401-she went to [the Black Valley]33-the black valley , even as is hereafore writ , hiding nought that had been done and said ; and freely [she]2401-she told it , without fear or shame , and with such clearness and sweetness of words that [no one of [them]2402-we]2403-no one of them doubted [her]2401-she aught ; and [Arthur]150-arthur lifted up [his]150-arthur head , and once and again [his]150-arthur eyes met [hers]2401-she , and there was nought of hardness in them , though [they]2404-they turned away at once . So at last fell [Birdalone]139-birdalone to telling what betid after [they]2402-we two , [the stranger knight]2373-the stranger knight and [she]2401-she , left [the valley of the force]2406-the valley of the force and fell to riding the wildwood with [their]2402-we heads turned toward [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest ; and [she]2401-she said : When [we]2402-we turned into [the wood]335-the wood away from [the said valley]4984-the said valley [it]2410-it lacked some four hours of noon ; and [we]2402-we rode till noon was , and rested by a stream - side and ate , for [we]2402-we knew no cause wherefore [we]2402-we should hasten overmuch ; but [[my]0-i fellow]2411-my fellow [the strange knight]2412-the strange knight was downcast and heavy , and some might have called [him]2412-the strange knight sullen . But [I]0-i strove to make [him]2412-the strange knight of better cheer , and spake to [him]2412-the strange knight kindly , as to one who of [an enemy]2413-an enemy had become [a friend]509-a friend ; but [he]2412-the strange knight answered [me]0-i : [Lady]493-lady , it availeth not ; [I]0-i grieve that [I]0-i am no better company than [thou]2416-i seest [me]0-i , and [I]0-i have striven to be merrier ; but apart from all that [I]0-i wot and that [thou]2416-i wottest which should make [me]0-i of evil cheer , there is now a weight upon [my]0-i heart which [I]0-i can not lift , such as never have [I]0-i felt erst . So by [thy]2416-i leave [we]2417-we will to horse at once , that [we]2417-we may [the speedier]2418-the speedier come to [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest and [[Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris â€™ prison]5704-sir aymeris â€™ prison . So [I]2416-i arose , but smiled on [him]131-sir aymeris and said : Hold up [thine]2416-i heart , [friend]5069-friend ! for [thee]2416-i shall be no prison at [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest , but the fair welcome of [friends]404-friends . [He]131-sir aymeris said nought , and mended not [his]131-sir aymeris cheer ; and in this plight [we]2417-we gat to horse and rode on for some three hours more , till [we]2417-we came out of [the thick forest]5708-the thick forest into a long clearing , which went like a wide highway of greensward between the thicket , and it seemed as if [the hand of man]5709-the hand of man had cleared [that said green road]5710-that said green road . Thereto [we]2417-we had come , following [a little river which came out on to [the clearing]5712-the clearing with [us]2417-we]5711-a little river which came out on to the clearing with us , and then , turning , ran well - nigh amidst [it]5711-a little river which came out on to the clearing with us toward [the north]666-the north . Now when [we]2417-we were come thither , and were betwixt [the thicket]5714-the thicket and [the water â€™s edge]4556-the water â€™s edge , [we]2417-we drew rein , and it seemed to [me]2416-i as fair a stead as might be in [the woodland]657-the woodland , and [I]2416-i looked thereon well pleased and with a happy heart . But [the knight]1813-the knight said : [Lady]493-lady , art [thou]1813-the knight not exceeding weary ? Nay , said [I]2416-i , not in any wise . Said [he]1813-the knight : It is strange then , for so weary am [I]2416-i , that [I]2416-i must in any case get off [my]2416-i horse and lay [me]2416-i down on the grass here , or [I]2416-i shall drop from the saddle . And therewith [he]1813-the knight lighted down and stood by [me]2416-i a little , as to help [me]2416-i off [my]2416-i horse ; but [I]2416-i said to [him]1813-the knight : [Knight]118-hugh , [I]2416-i pray [thee]1813-the knight , even if [ye]1813-the knight be weary , to struggle forward a little , lest [we]5719-we be in peril here . In peril ? quoth [he]1813-the knight ; [yea]5720-yea , that might be if [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight knew of [our]5719-we whereabouts ; but how should that be ? [He]1813-the knight spoke this heavily , as [one scarce awake]5722-one scarce awake ; and then [he]1813-the knight said : [I]2416-i pray [thee]2416-i pardon [me]2416-i , [lady]493-lady , but for nought may [I]2416-i hold [my]2416-i head up ; suffer [me]2416-i to sleep but a little , and then will [I]2416-i arise and lead [thee]2416-i straight to [thy]2416-i journey â€™s end . Therewithal [he]1813-the knight laid [him]1813-the knight down on [the grass]5724-the grass and was presently asleep , and [I]2416-i sat down by [him]1813-the knight all dismayed . At first , indeed , [I]2416-i doubted some treachery in [him]1813-the knight , for how might [I]2416-i trust [him]1813-the knight wholly after all that had come and gone ? but when [I]2416-i saw that there was no feigning in [his]1813-the knight sleep , [I]2416-i set that doubt aside , and knew not what to make of it . Thus passed an hour , and from time to time [I]2416-i shook [him]1813-the knight and strove to waken [him]1813-the knight , but it was all in vain ; so [I]2416-i knew none other rede than to abide [his]1813-the knight awakening ; for [I]2416-i knew not the way to take toward [this castle]1662-this castle ; and , moreover , though [he]1813-the knight were [a knight , and armed]5726-a knight , and armed , yet might it be perilous for [him]1813-the knight if [he]1813-the knight were left there alone and unguarded ; so [I]2416-i abode . But now came new tidings . Methought [I]2416-i heard the sound of the tinkling of weapons and armour ; [the green highway]5727-the green highway so turned that [a wood neb about an hundred yards to the north]5728-a wood neb about an hundred yards to the north hid it from [my]2416-i sight , so that [a man]217-a man might have drawn somewhat near to [us]5730-us without being seen , came [he]217-a man on [the hither side of [the river]1845-the river]5731-the hither side of the river . So [I]2416-i stood up hastily , and strung [my]2416-i bow , and took a shaft in [my]2416-i fingers , and no sooner was it done than there came [a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb . [He]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb was all - armed and had a red surcoat , and rode a great shining bay horse . [I]2416-i kept [my]2416-i eye upon [him]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb while [I]2416-i stirred [the sleeping knight]5734-the sleeping knight with [my]2416-i foot , and cried to [him]5734-the sleeping knight to wake , but [he]5734-the sleeping knight scarce moved , and but uttered words without sense . Now [the new - comer]510-the new - comer drew rein for a moment when [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb saw [us]5730-us , and then moved on a little toward [me]2416-i , but [I]2416-i nocked a shaft and pointed it at [him]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb , and cried out to [him]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb to stay . Then [I]2416-i heard a great rattling laugh come from [him]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb , and [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb shouted : Nay , do [thou]5736-thy stay , [fair wood - wife]5737-fair wood - wife , and [I]2416-i will risk [thy]5736-thy shafts to come at [thee]5736-thy . But why doth not the sluggard at [thy]5736-thy feet rise up and stand before [me]2416-i , if [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb be [thy]5736-thy loveling ? Or is [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb dead ? [His]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb voice was harsh and big , and [I]2416-i feared [him]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb sore ; and it was as much because of fear as of hardihood , that [I]2416-i drew and loosed straightway ; and doubtless it was because of fear that [I]2416-i saw [my]2416-i shaft fly an inch or so over [his]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb right shoulder . [I]2416-i heard [his]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb rattling laugh again , and saw [him]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb bend forward as [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb spurred ; [I]2416-i knew that time lacked for drawing another shaft , so [I]2416-i caught up [my]2416-i skirts and ran all [I]2416-i might ; but swift - foot as [I]2416-i be , it availed [me]2416-i nought , for [I]2416-i was cumbered with [my]2416-i gown , and moreover [I]2416-i was confused with not knowing whither to run , since [I]2416-i wotted that in the water the horse would do better than [I.]2416-i So [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb was up with [me]2416-i in a twinkling , and reached out [his]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb hand and caught hold of [me]2416-i by the hair , and tugged [me]2416-i to [him]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb as [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb reined back [his]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb horse . Then [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb laughed again and said : Forsooth [she]5738-she will look better when [she]5738-she is no longer reddened and roughened with fleeing ; and , by [Red Peter]151-red peter ! what limbs [she]5738-she hath . Then [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb let [me]2416-i loose and got off [his]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb horse , and shoved [me]2416-i on before [him]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb till [we]5739-we came to where [the Black One]5740-the black one lay still sleeping heavily . Then [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight stood against [me]2416-i , and looked hard into [my]2416-i face ; and [I]2416-i saw how huge [a man]217-a man [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb was , and how a lock of bright red hair came out from under [his]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb sallet . [His]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb eyes were green and fierce underneath shaggy red eyebrows ; terrible [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb was to look on . Now [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb spake fiercely and roughly , and as though [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb had something against [me]2416-i : Tell [me]2416-i , [thou]5743-thou , who [thou]5743-thou art and who this is ? [I]2416-i answered nought , for fear had frozen [my]2416-i speech . [He]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb stamped [his]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb foot on the ground and cried : Hah ! art [thou]5743-thou gone dumb ? Speak ! [thou]5743-thou wert best ! [I]2416-i said , all quaking : [My]2416-i name is [Birdalone]139-birdalone ; [I]2416-i belong to [no one]815-no one ; [I]2416-i have [no kindred]5745-no kindred : as for [this man]1669-this man , [I]2416-i know not [his]1669-this man name . [He]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb said : Comest [thou]5743-thou from [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest ? Art [thou]5743-thou [the whore of those lily - and - rose champions]5748-the whore of those lily - and - rose champions [there]215-there ? [My]2416-i heart was hot with anger in spite of [my]2416-i dread , but [I]2416-i spake : [I]2416-i came from [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest . [He]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb said : And [this man]1669-this man ( therewith [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb turned about and spurned [him]1669-this man in the side ) , where didst [thou]5743-thou happen upon [him]1669-this man ? Again [I]2416-i was silent , and [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb roared out at [me]2416-i : So [thou]5743-thou wilt not answer ! Beware , or [I]2416-i may see how to compel the speech of [thee]5743-thou . Now answer [me]2416-i this : Was it in [the Black Valley]33-the black valley of [the Greywethers]142-the greywethers that [ye]5743-thou two came together ? Again [I]2416-i knew not how to answer , lest [I]2416-i might do a wrong to [him]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb who had repented [him]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb of the wrong [he]5733-a rider round about the aforesaid wood neb had done [me]2416-i . But [the Red Knight]135-the red knight burst out a - laughing and said : It shall be remembered against [thee]5743-thou , first , that [thou]5743-thou didst let fly a shaft at [me]2416-i ; second , that [thou]5743-thou didst run from [me]2416-i ; and thirdly , that [thou]5743-thou hast been slack in answering [my]2416-i questions . But all this scathes [me]2416-i nought ; first , because [thy]5743-thou shaft missed [me]2416-i ; second , because [thy]5743-thou legs failed [thee]5743-thou ( though they were fair to look on , running ) ; and third , because all [thou]5743-thou canst tell [me]2416-i [I]2416-i know without thine answering . Now [thee]5743-thou will [I]2416-i tell that this is Friday , and that [ye]5743-thou two first met in [the Black Valley]33-the black valley on Tuesday ; now [I]2416-i will ask this last question , and [thou]5743-thou mayst answer it or not as [thou]5743-thou wilt ; for presently [I]2416-i shall wake [this brisk and stirring knight]5752-this brisk and stirring knight , and [I]2416-i deem that [he]5752-this brisk and stirring knight will tell [me]2416-i the truth of this if of nought else . Tell [me]2416-i , [[thou]5743-thou whore of [the Questing Champions]5754-the questing champions]5753-thou whore of the questing champions , where and how many times [thou]5743-thou hast lain in [this good knight]5755-this good knight â€™s arms since last Tuesday ? Nowhere and never , quoth [I.]2416-i [Thou]5743-thou liest , [I]2416-i doubt [thee]5743-thou , said [the Red Knight]135-the red knight ; howsoever , let [us]5756-us see what [this doughty one]5757-this doughty one will say . [Hah]5758-hah ! [thou]5743-thou deemest [he]5757-this doughty one shall be hard to wake up , dost [thou]5743-thou not ! Well , [I]2416-i shall see to that . [He]5757-this doughty one who giveth sleep may take it away again . Therewith [he]135-the red knight went up to the Black One and stooped adown over [his]5757-this doughty one head , and spake some words over [him]5757-this doughty one , but so softly that [I]2416-i heard not their import ; and straightway [the sleeper]5759-the sleeper rose up so suddenly that [he]135-the red knight wellnigh smote against [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight . [He]135-the red knight stood awhile staggering , and blinking at [the other one]5210-the other one , but somehow got [his]135-the red knight sword drawn forth , and [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight hindered [him]135-the red knight nought therein , but spake anon when [the other]250-the other was come to [himself]250-the other somewhat : The sele of the day to [thee]5743-thou , [Sir Thomas]152-sir thomas , [True Thomas]153-true thomas ! Fair is [thy]5743-thou bed , and most fair [thy]5743-thou bedfellow . [The Black Knight]5179-the black knight drew aback from [him]135-the red knight and was now come awake , wherefore [he]5179-the black knight stood on [his]5179-the black knight guard , but said nought . Then said [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight : [Sir Thomas]152-sir thomas , [I]2416-i have been asking [this fair lady]5766-this fair lady a question , but [her]5766-this fair lady memory faileth [her]5766-this fair lady and [she]5766-this fair lady may not answer it ; perchance [thou]5743-thou mayst do better . Tell [me]2416-i where and how many times hast [thou]5743-thou bedded [her]5766-this fair lady betwixt last Tuesday and this ? Nowhere and never , cried [Sir Thomas]152-sir thomas , knitting [his]152-sir thomas brows and handling [his]152-sir thomas sword . [Hah]5767-hah , said [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight , an echo of [her]5766-this fair lady speech is this . [Lo]93-lo , the tale [ye]152-sir thomas have made up betwixt [you]152-sir thomas . But at least , having done [mine]2416-i errand , though [meseemeth]5769-meseemeth somewhat leisurely , and having gotten [the woman]237-the woman for [me]2416-i , [thou]5743-thou art now bringing [her]237-the woman on to the Red Hold , whatever [thou]5743-thou hast done with [her]237-the woman on [the road]1797-the road ? [I]2416-i am not , said [[my]2416-i fellow]2411-my fellow , [I]2416-i am leading [her]237-the woman away from [the Red Hold]2256-the red hold . Pity of [thee]237-the woman , quoth the other , that [thou]5743-thou hast fallen in with [me]2416-i , and [thou]5743-thou but half - armed . And [he]2416-i raised aloft [his]2416-i sword ; but presently sank it again , and let the point rest on [the earth]432-the earth . Then [he]2416-i spoke again , not mockingly as erst : A word before [we]5775-we end it , [Thomas]152-sir thomas : [thou]5743-thou hast hitherto done well by [me]2416-i , as [I]2416-i by [thee]237-the woman . [I]2416-i say [thou]5743-thou hast gotten [this woman]412-this woman , and [I]2416-i doubt not that at first [thou]5743-thou hadst the mind to bring [her]412-this woman to [me]2416-i unminished ; but then [thou]5743-thou wert overcome by [her]412-this woman beauty , as forsooth [I]2416-i know [thee]237-the woman woman - mad , and [thou]5743-thou hadst meant to keep [her]412-this woman for thyself , as forsooth [I]2416-i marvel not . But in [thy]237-the woman love - making [thou]5743-thou hast not bethought [thee]237-the woman that keep [her]412-this woman to [thyself]5743-thou [thou]5743-thou mayst not while [I]2416-i am above ground , save [thou]5743-thou bewray [me]2416-i , and join [thee]237-the woman to [[my]2416-i foemen]1366-my foemen and thine . Because [I]2416-i am such [a man]217-a man , that what [I]2416-i desire that will [I]2416-i have . For this reason , when [I]2416-i misdoubted [me]2416-i of [thee]237-the woman for [thy]237-the woman much - tarrying , [I]2416-i cast the sleep over [thee]237-the woman , and have caught [thee]237-the woman . For what wilt [thou]5743-thou do ? Doubt it not , that if [our]5779-our swords meet , [I]2416-i shall pay [thee]237-the woman for trying to take [my]2416-i bedthrall from [me]2416-i by taking from [thee]237-the woman no more than [thy]237-the woman life . But now will [I]2416-i forgive [thee]237-the woman all if [thou]237-the woman wilt ride [home]373-home quietly with [me]2416-i and [this damsel - errant to the Red Hold]5781-this damsel - errant to the red hold , and let [her]5781-this damsel - errant to the red hold be [mine]2416-i and not thine so long as [I]2416-i will ; and then afterwards , if [thou]237-the woman wilt , [she]5781-this damsel - errant to the red hold shall be thine as long as [thou]237-the woman wilt . Now behold , both this chance and [thy]237-the woman life is a mere gift of [me]2416-i to [thee]237-the woman , for otherwise [thou]237-the woman shalt have neither damsel nor life . Yea , yea , said [[my]2416-i friend]304-my friend , [I]2416-i know what [thou]237-the woman wouldest : [I]2416-i have been no unhandy devil to [thee]237-the woman this long while , and [thou]237-the woman wouldst fain keep [me]2416-i still ; but now [I]2416-i will be devil no longer , on [this earth]5783-this earth at least , but will die and take [my]2416-i luck of it . And do [thou]237-the woman , [God]114-god , see to the saving of [this damsel]1892-this damsel , since [thou]237-the woman hast taken the matter out of [my]2416-i hands . Farewell , [dear maiden]1196-dear maiden ! Scarce was the word out of [his]2416-i mouth ere [his]2416-i sword was in the air , and [he]2416-i smote so fierce and straight that [he]2416-i beat down [the huge man]5786-the huge man â€™s blade , and , ere [he]2416-i could master it again , smote [the Red Knight]135-the red knight so heavily on the crest that [he]2416-i fell to [his]2416-i knees ; and the heart rose in [me]2416-i , for [I]2416-i deemed that [he]4913-the red knight might yet prevail ; and in as â€™[2416-i] twere a flash [I]0-i bethought [me]0-i of the knife at [my]0-i girdlestead , and drew it and ran to [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight , and tore aside [his]4913-the red knight mail hood with one hand and thrust the knife into [his]4913-the red knight shoulder with the other ; but so mighty was [he]4913-the red knight that [he]4913-the red knight heeded nought the hurt , but swept [his]4913-the red knight sword back - handed at [the Black Knight]5179-the black knight â€™s unarmed leg , and smote [him]4913-the red knight so sore a wound that down [he]4913-the red knight fell clattering . Then arose [the Red Knight]4913-the red knight , and thrust [me]0-i from [him]4913-the red knight with the left hand , and strode over [[my]0-i fellow - farer]2423-my fellow - farer and thrust [his]4913-the red knight sword through [his]4913-the red knight throat . Then [he]4913-the red knight turned to [me]0-i , and spake in a braying voice as if a harsh horn were blown : Abide [thou]0-i ; if [thou]0-i takest one step [I]0-i will slay [thee]0-i at once . So [he]4913-the red knight went and sat down on a bank a little way from [the dead man]5574-the dead man , and wiped [his]4913-the red knight sword on the grass and laid it beside [him]4913-the red knight , and so sat pondering a while . Thereafter [he]4913-the red knight called [me]0-i to [him]4913-the red knight , and bade [me]0-i stand in face of [him]4913-the red knight with [my]0-i hands clasped before [me]0-i . Then [he]4913-the red knight spake to [me]0-i : [Thou]0-i art [my]0-i thrall and [my]0-i having , since [I]0-i had thus doomed it no few days ago ; and [thou]0-i art now in [my]0-i hands for [me]0-i to do with as [I]0-i will . Now instead of being meek and obedient to [me]0-i [thou]0-i hast rebelled against [me]0-i , shot an arrow at [me]0-i , run from [me]0-i , denied answer to [my]0-i questions , and thrust a knife into [me]0-i . To be short , [thou]0-i hast made [thyself]2425-thyself [[my]0-i foe]2426-my foe . Furthermore , it is by [thy]0-i doing that [I]0-i have lost [a right good servant]2427-a right good servant and [a trusty fellow]2428-a trusty fellow , and one that [I]0-i loved ; it is [thou]0-i that hast slain [him]2429-him . Now have [I]0-i been pondering what [I]0-i shall do with [thee]0-i . [I]0-i said : If [I]0-i have deserved the death , then make an end and slay [me]0-i presently ; but bring [me]0-i not to [thine house]261-thine house , [I]0-i pray [thee]0-i . [I]0-i pray by [the mother that bore [thee]0-i]2431-the mother that bore thee ! Quoth [he]2429-him : Hold [thy]0-i peace , it is not what [thou]0-i deservest that [I]0-i am looking to , but what shall pleasure [me]0-i . Now hearken ; [I]0-i say that [thou]0-i hast made [thee]0-i [[my]0-i foe]2426-my foe , and [I]0-i have overcome [thee]0-i ; [thou]0-i art [my]0-i runaway thrall , and [I]0-i have caught [thee]0-i . As [my]0-i foe [I]0-i might slay [thee]0-i in any evil way it might like [me]0-i ; as [my]0-i thrall [I]0-i might well chastise [thee]0-i as sharply and as bitterly as [I]0-i would . But it is not [my]0-i pleasure to slay [thee]0-i , rather [I]0-i will bring [thee]0-i to the Red Hold , and there see what [we]2433-we may make of [thee]0-i ; whereas [I]0-i can not but deem that in [thee]0-i is the making of somewhat more than a thrall ; and if not , then a thrall must [thou]0-i needs be . Again as to the chastising of [thee]0-i , that also [I]0-i forgive [thee]0-i since [I]0-i have gotten the hope aforesaid . Yet forsooth some shame must [I]0-i do [thee]0-i to pay [thee]0-i back for the love that was betwixt [thee]0-i and [the slain man]2434-the slain man . [I]0-i will ponder what it shall be ; but take heed that whatsoever it shall be , it will not avail [thee]0-i to pray [me]0-i to forego it , though [thy]0-i speech be as fair and sweet as [thy]0-i body . Therewith [he]2434-the slain man was silent a while , and [I]0-i stood there not daring to move , and [my]0-i heart was so downcast that all the sweetness of life seemed departed . Yet [I]0-i withheld lamentations or prayers , thinking within [myself]0-i , who knows what occasion may be between this and the Red Hold for [my]0-i escaping ; let [me]0-i keep [myself]0-i alive for that if it may be . Presently [he]2434-the slain man arose and took [his]2434-the slain man sword , and went up to [the slain man]2434-the slain man â€™s body and smote the head from off it . Then [he]2434-the slain man went to [the two horses of [Sir Thomas]152-sir thomas and of [me]0-i]2436-the two horses of sir thomas and of me , and took from [them]2436-the two horses of sir thomas and of me such gear of girths and thongs as [he]2434-the slain man would , and therewith [he]2434-the slain man dight [me]0-i as [ye]2437-ye saw , doing a girth about [my]0-i middle and making [me]0-i fast to a line wherewith to hold [me]0-i in tow . And then [he]2434-the slain man did that other thing which sickens [my]0-i very soul to tell of , to wit , that [he]2434-the slain man took [the slain man]2434-the slain man â€™s head and tied a lace thereto , and hung it about [my]0-i neck ; and as [he]2434-the slain man did so , [he]2434-the slain man said : This jewel shalt [thou]2439-thee thyself bear to [[mine]2434-the slain man house]2440-mine house ; and there belike shall [we]2441-we lay it in [earth]451-earth , since [the man]5167-the man was [[my]0-i trusty fellow]2444-my trusty fellow . [Lo]93-lo now , this is all the ill [I]0-i shall do [thee]2439-thee till it be tried of what avail [thou]2439-thee art . This is a shaming to [thee]2439-thee and not a torment , for [I]0-i will ride a footâ€™s - pace , and the green way is both soft and smooth ; wherefore fear not that [I]0-i shall throw [thee]2439-thee down or drag [thee]2439-thee along . And tomorrow [thy]2439-thee shame shall be gone and [we]2441-we shall see what is to betide . [Lo]93-lo , [friends]404-friends , this is the last word [he]5167-the man spake ere [he]5167-the man was slain , and the ending of [my]0-i tale ; for [we]2441-we had gone thus but a little way ere [ye]2446-ye brake out of the wood upon [us]2441-we ; and then befell the death of [one friend]2447-one friend , and the doubt , maybe , of the others , and all the grief and sorrow that [I]0-i shall never be quit of unless [ye]2446-ye forgive [me]0-i where [I]0-i have done amiss , and help [me]0-i in the days to come . And [she]2439-thee spread out [her]2439-thee hands before them , and bowed [her]2439-thee head , and the tears fell from [her]2439-thee eyes on to the floor . [Viridis]108-birdalone wept at [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s weeping , and [Aurea]107-aurea for [her]107-aurea own sorrow , which this other sorrow stirred . [Atra]109-atra wept not , but [her]109-atra face was sadder than weeping . But [Arthur]150-arthur spake and said : Herein hath been the hand of [Weird]154-weird , and hath been heavy on [us]2441-we ; but no blame have [we]2441-we to lay on [[our]2441-we sister]1909-our sister [Birdalone]108-birdalone , nor hath [she]108-birdalone done light - mindedly by [us]2441-we ; though maybe [she]108-birdalone erred in not trusting to the good - hap of the Quest to bring [us]2441-we back in due time : and all that [she]108-birdalone saith do [we]2441-we trow as if it were written in the Holy Gospel . [They]2449-them all yeasaid this , and called on [her]108-birdalone to come amongst [them]2449-them ; but [she]108-birdalone thought of little at first save the joy of hearing the sweetness of those words as [Arthur]150-arthur spake them ; wherefore [she]108-birdalone hung back a little , and thought shame of it that [she]108-birdalone might not give more heed to the others of [them]2449-them . Then came [Viridis]108-birdalone and took [her]108-birdalone by the hand and led [her]108-birdalone to [Sir Hugh]118-hugh , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone knelt down before [him]118-hugh and took [his]118-hugh hand to kiss it , but [he]118-hugh put both hands about [her]108-birdalone face and kissed [her]108-birdalone kindly and merrily on the lips . Then [she]108-birdalone knelt before [Aurea]107-aurea , and was hapless before [her]108-birdalone ; but [Aurea]107-aurea kissed [her]108-birdalone , and bade [her]108-birdalone be of better cheer , albeit the words came coldly from [her]108-birdalone mouth . Next [she]108-birdalone came to [Arthur]150-arthur , and knelt before [him]150-arthur and took [his]150-arthur hand and kissed it , and thanked [him]150-arthur kindly for [his]150-arthur kind words , looking into [his]150-arthur face meanwhile ; and [she]108-birdalone saw that it was pale and troubled now , and [she]108-birdalone longed to be alone with [him]150-arthur that [she]108-birdalone might ask [him]150-arthur wherefore . As for [Atra]109-atra , [she]108-birdalone arose as [Birdalone]108-birdalone came before [her]108-birdalone , and cast [her]108-birdalone arms about [her]108-birdalone neck , and wept and sobbed upon [her]108-birdalone bosom , and then went hurrying from out [the solar]5465-the solar and into [the hall]1193-the hall , and walked to and fro there a while until the passion that tore [her]108-birdalone was lulled somewhat , and [she]108-birdalone might show [her]108-birdalone face to [them]2452-them calm and friendly once more .
