But for [me]0-i , since [she]0-i so desired that water , [I]0-i knew that it was good for [us]2904-us to drink , and [I]0-i took out the stopple and drank , and it was as if fire ran through all [my]0-i veins , and [I]0-i felt [my]0-i strength three - folded straightway , and most wondrous clear was [my]0-i sight grown therewith ; and [I]0-i raised [my]0-i eyes now and looked down [the hall]1193-the hall , and lo , there was [Aurea]107-aurea , chained by the ankle to the third pillar from the dais ; and over against [her]107-aurea , [Viridis]108-birdalone ; and next , to the fourth pillar , [Atra]109-atra . Then [I]0-i cried in a loud voice that rang through [[the witch]394-the witch â€™s hall]2907-the witch â€™s hall : [Lo]93-lo what [I]0-i see ! And [I]0-i ran round the head of the board , and thrust and dragged [Baudoin]115-baudoin and [Arthur]150-arthur along with [me]0-i , crying out : Come , come ! [they]2908-they are found ! [they]2908-they are here ! And [I]0-i came to [[my]0-i sweetling]4783-my sweetling , and found [her]4783-my sweetling clad but in [her]4783-my sweetling white smock , which was flecked with blood all about , and [her]4783-my sweetling face was wan and pined , and the tears began to run when [she]4783-my sweetling saw [me]0-i , but no word came from [her]4783-my sweetling lips though the kissing of them was sweet . Then [I]0-i turned about to [[my]0-i two fellows]2888-my two fellows , and [they]2888-my two fellows stood bewildered , not knowing what was toward ; and [I]0-i came to [them]2888-my two fellows and made [them]2888-my two fellows drink of the flasket , and [their]2888-my two fellows eyes were opened and the strength of [giants]2911-giants came to [them]2888-my two fellows , and [they]2888-my two fellows ran each to [his]2912-his sweetling ; but [Baudoin]115-baudoin , before ever [he]115-baudoin kissed [Aurea]107-aurea , caught hold of the chain that bound [her]107-aurea to the pillar , and by main force dragged it out . Wise was that , meseemed , for words were again come into [the witch]394-the witch â€™s howls , and [I]0-i heard [her]107-aurea : Ah , long may [ye]2914-ye be playing with the chains , long ! for now [the house]311-the house rumbleth toward its fall . Ah , [the bitches]2916-the bitches are loose ! Woe â€™s [me]0-i ! to die alone ! And once more [she]107-aurea howled wordless , as both [I]0-i and [Arthur]150-arthur had [our]2917-we loves in [our]2917-we arms , and fell to following [Baudoin]115-baudoin out on to [the perron]2892-the perron and down into [the fresh fragrant garden]2919-the fresh fragrant garden wherein now was the moon beginning to cast shadows . Stood [we]2917-we then aloof from [the house]311-the house , and the rumbling whereof [the evil hag]2921-the evil hag had howled waxed into a thunder , and under [our]2917-we very eyes the great white walls and gold - adorned roofs fell together , and a great cloud of dust rose under the clear moonlit sky . [We]2917-we looked and wondered , and [our]2917-we loves also , but no word [they]2922-their spake ; but ere [the other two]1860-the other two had time to grieve thereat , [I]0-i gave [Viridis]108-birdalone to drink of the water of might , and [she]107-aurea fell to sweet speech straightway , of such sort and such wise as [I]0-i will not tell [you]2924-you . Then [I]0-i did the same by [Aurea]107-aurea and [Atra]109-atra , and forthwith the speech flowed from [them]1860-the other two to [[their]1860-the other two friends]2925-their friends . Full happy were [we]2917-we then in the early night - season , for the water of might gave [them]2922-their strength also , as to [us]2917-we , and healed all the stripes and wounds [their]2922-their bodies had suffered of [the foul witch]2926-the foul witch , and made [their]2922-their eyes bright , and [their]2922-their cheeks full and firm , and [their]2922-their lips most sweet , and [their]2922-their hands strong and delicious . Now when [we]2917-we had stood gazing toward the melting of [the beauteous palace]2927-the beauteous palace for a little , [we]2917-we took [[our]2917-we darlings]2928-our darlings in [our]2917-we arms again , whereas the chains would have hindered [their]2922-their walking , and went down to [the lip of the water]2929-the lip of the water whereas lay [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat , so that [we]2917-we might be anigh [[our]2917-we ferry]2529-our ferry in case of need ; for [we]2917-we knew not what might betide [the isle]631-the isle now [its mistress]2933-its mistress had perished . Then [we]2917-we fell to and sawed off the chains from the dear ankles with [our]2917-we swords , and took [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s lendings from the mail . And [Aurea]107-aurea had [her]107-aurea gown again , and [Viridis]108-birdalone [her]107-aurea smock , and [my]0-i green surcoat over it , and [Atra]109-atra wore the battle - coat of [the Black Squire]1325-the black squire . As for [their]2922-their bare feet ( for [Atra]109-atra would not have [hers]109-atra dight prouder than [[her]109-atra sisters]2935-her sisters â€™ ) , [we]2917-we so clad [them]2922-their with kisses that [they]2922-their were not ill - covered belike . So gat [we]2917-we aboard [[our]2917-we ferry]2529-our ferry , and did blood - offering to the wight thereof , and so sped merrily and lovingly over [the wide lake]5825-the wide lake back on [[our]2917-we homeward road]5826-our homeward road . And [we]2917-we said : This hath [the dear Birdalone]5827-the dear birdalone done for [us]2917-we . And now , [[my]109-atra Viridis]5828-my viridis , [I]109-atra will that [thou]5829-you fill up the tale by telling to [Birdalone]108-birdalone , as [ye]5829-you told [us]2917-we , how it fared with [you]5829-you three and [the evil one]5830-the evil one from the time that [ye]5829-you sped [Birdalone]108-birdalone on [her]108-birdalone way till the moment when [mine]109-atra eyes first beheld [you]5829-you made fast to the pillars of [the palace]5831-the palace which has crumbled into dust . Chapter X ~ How [It]5832-it Fared with [the Three Ladies]5833-the three ladies After the Escape of [Birdalone Viridis]108-birdalone took up the word without more ado , and said : [I]109-atra will do [my]109-atra best herein , and [ye]5833-the three ladies , [sisters]1114-sisters , must set [me]109-atra right if [I]109-atra err . When [we]2917-we had seen the last of [you]5829-you , dear [Birdalone]108-birdalone , that early morning , [we]2917-we turned back again to [the house]311-the house as speedily and as covertly as [we]2917-we might , lest [the witch]394-the witch might espy [our]2917-we disarray and question [us]2917-we thereover . Then [we]2917-we went to [the wonder - coffer]5837-the wonder - coffer , and gat thereout raiment for that which [we]2917-we had given away , which was easy for [us]2917-we to do , whereas [the witch - mistress]5838-the witch - mistress was so slothful that [she]5838-the witch - mistress had given to [us]2917-we the words of might wherewith to compel [the coffer]1224-the coffer to yield , so that [we]2917-we might do all the service thereof , and [she]5838-the witch - mistress not to move hand or foot in the matter . So when [we]2917-we were clad , and the time was come , [we]2917-we went into [the hall]1193-the hall , by no means well assured of [[our]2917-we mistress]1107-our mistress . When [we]2917-we came before [her]5838-the witch - mistress , [she]5838-the witch - mistress looked on [us]2917-we in surly wise , as [her]5838-the witch - mistress wo nt was , and said nought for a while ; [she]5838-the witch - mistress stared on [us]2917-we and knit [her]5838-the witch - mistress brows , as if [she]5838-the witch - mistress strove to call to mind something that ran to and fro in [her]5838-the witch - mistress memory ; and [I]109-atra noted that , and for [my]109-atra part [I]109-atra trembled before [her]5838-the witch - mistress . But [she]5838-the witch - mistress spake at last : [Meseemeth]5842-meseemeth as if there is [a woman in [the isle]631-the isle besides [[you]2917-we three]5845-you three]5843-a woman in the isle besides you three ; [some misdoer that [I]109-atra was minded to punish]5846-some misdoer that i was minded to punish . Tell [me]109-atra , [you]2917-we ! was there not [a naked one who came into [this hall]2675-this hall a while ago , one whom [I]109-atra threatened with pining ? [Atra]109-atra , who was the boldest of [us]5849-we]5847-a naked one who came into this hall a while ago , one whom i threatened with pining ? atra , who was the boldest of us , bowed the knee before [her]5838-the witch - mistress , and said : Nay , [[our]5849-we lady]477-our lady , since when do [stranger women]5851-stranger women come naked into [thine hall]5852-thine hall , and dare [thee]5838-the witch - mistress there ? Said [the witch]394-the witch : Yet have [I]109-atra an image of [a naked woman]5854-a naked woman standing down there before [me]109-atra ; and if [I]109-atra have it in [mine]109-atra eye , so should [ye]2917-we . Tell [me]109-atra therefore , and beware , for [We]5849-we are not bidden to hold [Our]5849-we hand from [you]2917-we if [We]5849-we take [you]2917-we in misdeeds . If [I]109-atra quaked before , now much more [I]109-atra quaked , till [my]109-atra legs well - nigh failed [me]109-atra for fear ; but [Atra]109-atra said : [Great lady]5855-great lady , this image will belike be of [that one whom a while ago [ye]2917-we had stripped and tied to a pillar here , and tormented while [ye]2917-we feasted]5856-that one whom a while ago ye had stripped and tied to a pillar here , and tormented while ye feasted . [The lady]1145-the lady looked on [her]1145-the lady hard , and again seemed striving to gather up the thrums of some memory , and then [her]1145-the lady face became smooth again , and [she]1145-the lady spake lightly : All that may well be ; so do [ye]2917-we go about [your]2917-we due service , and trouble [Our]5849-we rest here no longer ; for [We]5849-we love not to look on folk who be not wholly [Our]5849-we own to pine or to spare , to slay or let live , as [We]5849-we will ; and [We]5849-we would that the winds and the waves would send [Us]5849-we some such now ; for it is like to living all alone to have but such as [you]2917-we with [Us]5849-we , and none to cower before [Us]5849-we and entreat [Us]5849-we of mercy . So begone , [I]109-atra bid [you]2917-we . Thus for that time were [we]5849-we saved from [the witch]394-the witch â€™s cruelty ; but [our]5849-we time came before long . The days wore heavily , nor kept [we]5849-we count of them lest [we]5849-we should lose heart for the weariness of waiting . But on a day as [we]5849-we stood on the steps of [the perron]2892-the perron and served [[my]109-atra lady]603-my lady with dainties , of a hot afternoon , came two great white doves a - flying , who pitched down right before [[our]5849-we mistress]1107-our mistress â€™s feet ; and each had a gold ring about [his]5862-his neck , and a scroll tied thereto , and [the witch]394-the witch bade [us]5849-we take the doves and take off the scrolls and give them unto [her]394-the witch ; and [she]394-the witch looked on the gold rings which the doves bore , and for a moment on the scrolls , and then [she]394-the witch said : Take [ye]2917-we the doves and cherish them , lest [We]5849-we have need of [them]5864-them ; take also the two scrolls and keep them till tomorrow morning , and then give them into [Our]5849-we hands . And look [ye]2917-we to this , that if [ye]2917-we give [them]5864-them not unto [Us]5849-we it will be treason against [Us]5849-we , and [We]5849-we shall have a case against [you]2917-we , and [your]2917-we bodies will be [Ours]5849-we . Then [she]394-the witch rose up slowly , and bade [me]109-atra to [her]394-the witch that [she]394-the witch might lean upon [my]109-atra shoulder and be helped upstairs , so slothful a beast as [she]394-the witch was ; and as [we]5849-we went up [I]109-atra heard [her]394-the witch say softly to [herself]394-the witch : Weary on it , now must [I]109-atra drink a sup of the Water of Might , that [I]109-atra may remember and do and desire . But dear is [[my]109-atra sister]1162-my sister , and without doubt [she]1162-my sister hath matters of import to tell [me]109-atra by these doves . So when [we]5849-we were together alone [I]109-atra told [the others]1287-the others hereof , and [we]5849-we talked it over ; and [they]1287-the others deemed the tidings ill , even as [I]109-atra did ; for [we]5849-we might not doubt but that the doves were a sending from [[the witch]394-the witch - sister who dwelt at [the House under the Wood]4835-the house under the wood]5868-the witch - sister who dwelt at the house under the wood ; and sore [we]5849-we misdoubted that [they]1287-the others were sped to [[our]5849-we mistress]1107-our mistress to tell [her]1107-our mistress of [thee]5871-thee , [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and [mayhappen of the Quest]5872-mayhappen of the quest , so wise as [we]5849-we knew [she]1107-our mistress was . As to the two scrolls , forsooth , they were open , and not sealed ; but when [we]5849-we looked on them [we]5849-we could make nought of it ; for though they were writ fairly in Latin script , so that [we]5849-we read them , yet of the words no whit might [we]5849-we understand , so [we]5849-we feared the worst . But what might [we]5849-we do ? [we]5849-we had but two choices , either to cast [ourselves]5849-we into the water , or abide what should befall ; and this last one [we]5849-we chose because of the hope of deliverance . Next morning , therefore , [we]5849-we came before [[our]5849-we mistress]1107-our mistress in [the hall]1193-the hall , and [we]5849-we found [her]1107-our mistress pacing up and down before the dais ; though [her]1107-our mistress wo nt was at that hour to be sitting in [her]1107-our mistress throne of gold and ivory , lying back on the cushions half asleep . So [Atra]109-atra went up to [her]1107-our mistress , and knelt before [her]1107-our mistress and gave [her]1107-our mistress the scrolls , and [she]109-atra looked on [her]1107-our mistress grimly , and smiled evilly , and said : Kneel there yet ; and [ye]1107-our mistress [others]4825-others kneel also , till [I]109-atra see what befitteth [you]1107-our mistress . So did [we]5849-we , and indeed [I]109-atra was fain to kneel , for [I]109-atra might scarce stand up for terror ; and all of [us]5849-we , [our]5849-we hearts died within [us]5849-we . But [the witch]394-the witch read those scrolls to [herself]394-the witch , sitting in [her]394-the witch throne , and spake not a long while ; then [she]394-the witch said : Come hither , and grovel before [Us]5849-we , and hearken ! Even so [we]5849-we did ; and [she]394-the witch said again : [[Our]5849-we sister]1909-our sister , who hath been so kind unto [you]1107-our mistress , and saved [you]1107-our mistress from so many pains , here telleth [Us]5849-we , by the message of the two doves , that [ye]1107-our mistress have betrayed [Us]5849-we and [her]1909-our sister , and have stolen [her]1909-our sister thrall and [her]1909-our sister Sending [Boat]5878-boat , and sent [her]1909-our sister an errand for [Our]5849-we destruction ; and therewith [she]1909-our sister delivereth [you]1107-our mistress into [Our]5849-we hands , and [ye]1107-our mistress are [Ours]5849-we henceforward ; nor is it to be thought that [ye]1107-our mistress may escape [Us]5849-we . Now , for [your]1107-our mistress treason , [some]213-some would slay [you]1107-our mistress outright here and now , but [We]5849-we will be merciful , and let [you]1107-our mistress live , and do no more than chastise [you]1107-our mistress sharply now ; and thereafter shall [ye]1107-our mistress be [Our]5849-we very thralls to do as [We]5849-we will with : thereafter , that is to say , when [they]5880-they whom [ye]1107-our mistress have sent [[Our]5849-we sister]1909-our sister â€™s thrall to fetch have come hither ( as belike [I]109-atra may scarce stay them ) , and [I]109-atra have foiled them and used them , and sent them away empty . Now [I]109-atra tell [you]1107-our mistress , that meanwhile of [their]5880-they coming shall [ye]1107-our mistress suffer such things as [We]5849-we will ; and when [they]5880-they be [here]244-here [We]5849-we will not forbid [you]1107-our mistress to be anigh [them]5880-they ; but [We]5849-we shall see that there will be little joy to [you]1107-our mistress in that nighness . [Yea]1107-our mistress , [ye]1107-our mistress shall know now to what market [ye]1107-our mistress have brought [your]1107-our mistress wares , and what the price of treason is therein . Verily then [we]5849-we suffered at [her]1909-our sister hand what [she]1909-our sister would , whereof it would shame [me]109-atra to tell more as at this present ; and thereafter did [she]1909-our sister chain [us]5849-we to those three pillars of [the hall]1193-the hall whereas [ye]1107-our mistress found [us]5849-we chained ; and [we]5849-we were fed as dogs be , and served as dogs , but [we]5849-we endured all for the sake of hope ; and when [we]5849-we durst , and deemed [the witch]394-the witch would not hear [us]5849-we , [we]5849-we spake together and enheartened [each other]569-each other . But on the fourth day of [our]5849-we torment came [the witch]394-the witch to [us]5849-we , and gave [us]5849-we to drink a certain red water from out of a leaden flasket ; and when [I]109-atra drank [I]109-atra deemed it was poison , and was glad , if gladness might be in [me]109-atra at such a tide ; and when [I]109-atra had drunk [I]109-atra felt an icy chill go through all [my]109-atra body , and all things swam before [my]109-atra eyes , and deadly sickness came over [me]109-atra . But that passed away from [me]109-atra presently , and [I]109-atra felt helpless and yet not feeble ; all sounds heard [I]109-atra clearer than ever yet in [my]109-atra life ; also [I]109-atra saw [the hall]1193-the hall , every arch and pillar and fret , and the gleam on the pavement from the bright sun that might not enter ; and [the witch]394-the witch [I]109-atra saw walking up and down [the hall]1193-the hall by [the dais]1567-the dais ; but [[my]109-atra sisters]1113-my sisters [I]109-atra saw not when [I]109-atra looked across to [their]1113-my sisters pillars . Moreover , [I]109-atra might not see [myself]109-atra when [I]109-atra reached out [my]109-atra hand or [my]109-atra foot , though [I]109-atra saw the chain which made [my]109-atra ankle fast to the pillar ; and withal , when [I]109-atra set [my]109-atra hand on [my]109-atra face , or any other part of [my]109-atra body , or what else [I]109-atra might touch , [I]109-atra felt there what [I]109-atra looked to feel , were it flesh or linen , or the cold iron of [my]109-atra fetter , or the polished face of the marble pillar . Now [I]109-atra knew scarce if [I]109-atra were alive or dead , or if [I]109-atra were but beginning to be dead ; but there came upon [me]109-atra the desire of life , and [I]109-atra strove to cry out to [the sisters]5892-the sisters , but though [I]109-atra formed the words in [my]109-atra mouth , and did with [my]109-atra throat as when one cries out aloud , yet no sound of a voice came from [me]109-atra , and more helpless did [I]109-atra feel than erst . But even therewith [I]109-atra saw [the witch]394-the witch come toward [me]109-atra , and therewith all [my]109-atra body felt such fear of [her]394-the witch that [I]109-atra knew [I]109-atra was not dead . Then [she]394-the witch came before [me]109-atra and said : [O shadow of a thrall , whom none can see but [them]5894-o shadow of a thrall , whom none can see but them unto whom wisdom hath given eyes to see wonders withal , now have i tidings for thee and thy sisters , to wit , that your lovers and seekers unto whom wisdom hath given eyes to see wonders withal , now have [I]109-atra tidings for [thee]109-atra and [[thy]109-atra sisters]5895-thy sisters , to wit , that [[your]109-atra lovers]1292-your lovers and seekers]5894-o shadow of a thrall , whom none can see but them unto whom wisdom hath given eyes to see wonders withal , now have i tidings for thee and thy sisters , to wit , that your lovers and seekers are at hand ; and presently [I]109-atra shall bring [them]5894-o shadow of a thrall , whom none can see but them unto whom wisdom hath given eyes to see wonders withal , now have i tidings for thee and thy sisters , to wit , that your lovers and seekers into [this hall]2675-this hall , and [they]5894-o shadow of a thrall , whom none can see but them unto whom wisdom hath given eyes to see wonders withal , now have i tidings for thee and thy sisters , to wit , that your lovers and seekers shall be so nigh unto [you]109-atra that [ye]109-atra might touch [them]5894-o shadow of a thrall , whom none can see but them unto whom wisdom hath given eyes to see wonders withal , now have i tidings for thee and thy sisters , to wit , that your lovers and seekers if [I]109-atra did not forbid it ; but [they]5894-o shadow of a thrall , whom none can see but them unto whom wisdom hath given eyes to see wonders withal , now have i tidings for thee and thy sisters , to wit , that your lovers and seekers shall not see [you]109-atra , but shall wonder where [I]109-atra have hidden [you]109-atra , and shall go seeking [you]109-atra today and many days , and shall find [you]109-atra not at all . So make [ye]109-atra the most of the sight of [them]5894-o shadow of a thrall , whom none can see but them unto whom wisdom hath given eyes to see wonders withal , now have i tidings for thee and thy sisters , to wit , that your lovers and seekers , for in [them]5894-o shadow of a thrall , whom none can see but them unto whom wisdom hath given eyes to see wonders withal , now have i tidings for thee and thy sisters , to wit , that your lovers and seekers henceforward [ye]109-atra have no other part or lot . Therewith [she]109-atra spat out at [me]109-atra , and went over to [[my]109-atra sisters]1113-my sisters , and said words of like import to those which [she]109-atra had said unto [me]109-atra . And presently [she]109-atra went out of [the hall]1193-the hall ; and not long afterwards [I]109-atra heard voices speaking on the perron , and knew one for the voice of [the witch]394-the witch , and the other for the voice of [[my]109-atra lord]2039-my lord [Baudoin]115-baudoin ; and then again wore a little while , and [I]109-atra saw [the witch]394-the witch come through the great door of [the hall]1193-the hall leading [Sir Arthur]150-arthur by the hand , as if [she]394-the witch were [[his]150-arthur dear friend]5904-his dear friend , and [Baudoin]115-baudoin and [Hugh]118-hugh , [[my]109-atra man]253-my man , following [them]5906-them . And [the said witch]2791-the said witch was clad full fair , and had laid by [her]109-atra sloth and stupid pride , as meseemed ; and [her]109-atra limbs were grown rounder and sleeker , and [her]109-atra skin fairer , so that to [them]5908-them that knew [her]109-atra not [she]109-atra might well seem to be [a goodly woman]5909-a goodly woman . Now [they]5908-them sat to meat as [[my]109-atra man]253-my man hath told [you]5911-you , and then departed from [the hall]1193-the hall , and [the witch]394-the witch also . But after a while [she]109-atra came back again and loosed [us]5914-we , and grimly bade [us]5914-we go with [her]109-atra , and needs must [we]5914-we , though [we]5914-we could not so much as see [our]5914-we own feet upon the floor . And [she]109-atra set [us]5914-we to tasks about [the house]311-the house , and stood by while [we]5914-we toiled for [her]109-atra , and mocked [us]5914-we not without stripes , and in all ways was as rough and cruel and hard with [us]5914-we as [she]109-atra had been smooth and debonair to [[our]5914-we lords]1663-our lords ; but after noon [she]109-atra brought [us]5914-we back and chained [us]5914-we to [our]5914-we pillars again . And when the evening came and the banquet was , it was [we]5914-we who were [the unseen players of the string - play]5917-the unseen players of the string - play ; and [we]5914-we might play no other melody than what [the witch]394-the witch bade [us]5914-we ; else belike , could [we]5914-we have held converse , [we]5914-we might have played such tunes as would have smitten the hearts of [[our]5914-we loves]5919-our loves , and told [them]5919-our loves that [we]5914-we were anigh . To make a short story of it , thus did [she]109-atra day by day , and no comfort or converse might [we]5914-we [sisters]1114-sisters have of [each other]569-each other , or of aught else save the sight of [[our]5914-we beloved ones]5922-our beloved ones , and a glimmer of hope therewith . And , forsooth , for as grievously as [my]109-atra heart was wrung by the yearning of [me]109-atra for [my]109-atra love , yet was it a joy unto [me]109-atra to think that [he]5923-he went there desiring [me]109-atra , and that whom [he]5923-he desired was not [the poor wretched creature chained there in [her]109-atra nakedness , with [her]109-atra body spoiled by torment and misery]5924-the poor wretched creature chained there in her nakedness , with her body spoiled by torment and misery , but [the glad maiden whom [he]5923-he had so often called fair and lovesome]5925-the glad maiden whom he had so often called fair and lovesome . So passed the days , and at last hope had grown so pale and wan , that [she]109-atra was no more to be seen by [us]5914-we than [we]5914-we were by [[our]5914-we lords]1663-our lords ; and now it seemed to [me]109-atra that death was coming , so feeble and wretched as [I]109-atra grew . But [the witch]394-the witch would not let [us]5914-we die , but sustained [us]5914-we from time to time with some little draughts of a witch - drink that revived [us]5914-we . So wore the time till that evening , when came hope together with the fulfilment of hope , so that one minute [we]5914-we durst hope for deliverance , and the next [we]5914-we were delivered . Nor is there more to tell , [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [[my]109-atra dear]1824-my dear , save that [we]5914-we came safely to [the Isle of [the Young]1586-the young]5929-the isle of the young and the Old in the full morning - tide ; and as [[our]5914-we ferry]2529-our ferry drew nigh [the green shore]1637-the green shore , there were [the two younglings]5933-the two younglings whereof [thou]5934-thou didst tell [us]5914-we awaiting [our]5914-we landing , and when [we]5914-we stepped [ashore]5935-ashore [they]5933-the two younglings came to [us]5914-we bearing cakes and fruit in a fair basket , and [they]5933-the two younglings made much of [us]5914-we and [we]5914-we of [them]5933-the two younglings . And so [we]5914-we came to [the old man]1380-the old man , who was exceeding fain of [us]5914-we , and grand and courteous , till [he]1380-the old man became [a little drunk]5937-a little drunk , and then [he]1380-the old man was somewhat over - kind to [[us]5914-we women]5938-us women . Nevertheless , there in [that pleasant isle]5939-that pleasant isle [we]5914-we rested [us]5914-we for three days , that [we]5914-we might somewhat calm and refresh [our]5914-we spirits with what was small and of little account . And when [we]5914-we departed , [the old man]1380-the old man followed [us]5914-we down to [the strand]648-the strand , and lamented [our]5914-we departure , as [he]1380-the old man had done with [[our]5914-we lords]1663-our lords erewhile ; only this time yet greater was [his]1380-the old man lamentation , and needs must [we]5914-we kiss [him]1380-the old man , [each one of [us]5914-we]5943-each one of us , or never had [he]1380-the old man been done . So [he]1380-the old man turned up landward , bewailing [the miss of [us]5914-we]5944-the miss of us , but presently , before [we]5914-we had seen the last of [him]1380-the old man , was cheerful again and singing . So [we]5914-we went on [our]5914-we way ; and [we]5914-we also , [[we]5914-we maidens]5945-we maidens , in [our]5914-we turn , saw those woeful images of [the Isle of Queens]53-the isle of queens and [the Isle of [Kings]421-kings]54-the isle of kings ; and [we]5914-we came to [the Isle of Nothing]32-the isle of nothing , and abode warily by [[our]5914-we ferry]2529-our ferry , and so came away safe , and thus , as [thou]5948-thou wottest , [home]373-home to [the castle]1534-the castle to hear evil tidings of [thee]5948-thou . Now is this all [my]109-atra tale . [Birdalone]108-birdalone sat shyly and hushed when all was done ; and then all [they]5951-they did somewhat to comfort [her]108-birdalone , each after [their]5951-they own fashion ; and now sorrow for [the slain man]2434-the slain man was made softer and sweeter for [them]5951-they , whereas [they]5951-they had to lose not [two fellows]5953-two fellows , but one only . Yet , despite of all , trouble and care was on [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s soul betwixt the joy of loving and being beloved , and the pain and fear of robbing [a friend]509-a friend of [her]108-birdalone love . For [Atra]109-atra â€™s face , which [she]109-atra might not hate , and scarce might love , was a threat to [her]109-atra day by day . Chapter XI ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone and [the Black Squire]1325-the black squire Talk Together in [the Hall of [the Castle]1534-the castle]5956-the hall of the castle . Now within a few days was the body of [Baudoin]115-baudoin laid in earth in [the chapel of [the castle]1534-the castle]5958-the chapel of the castle ; and in the solemnest of fashions was the burial done . When it was over , [the two knights]5960-the two knights and [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris turned [them]5951-they heartily to dighting the war against [the Red Hold]2256-the red hold , and less than a month thereafter was the hosting at [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]25-the castle of the quest , and if [the host]5962-the host were not very many ( for it went not above sixteen hundreds of [men]204-men all told ) , yet [the men]4811-the men were of the choicest , both of [knights]5590-knights and [sergeants and archers]5966-sergeants and archers . There then [they]4811-the men held a mote without [the castle]1534-the castle , whereas [Arthur]150-arthur [the Black Squire]1325-the black squire was chosen for [captain]5654-captain , and in three days [they]4811-the men were to depart for [the Red Hold]42-the red hold . Now this while [Birdalone]108-birdalone had seen but little of [Arthur]150-arthur , who was ever busy about many matters , and never had [she]108-birdalone had any privy talk with [him]150-arthur , though sore [she]108-birdalone longed for it ; yet indeed it was more by [her]108-birdalone will than [his]150-arthur that so it was . But when it was come to the very last day before the departure , [she]108-birdalone said that [she]108-birdalone must needs see [him]150-arthur before [he]150-arthur went , and [he]150-arthur perchance never to come back again . So when [men]204-men were quiet after dinner [she]108-birdalone went into [the hall]1193-the hall and found [him]150-arthur there , pacing up and down the floor . For indeed [she]108-birdalone had sent a word to [him]150-arthur by [[Leonard]139-birdalone [the priest]1677-the priest]4960-leonard the priest that [he]150-arthur should be [there]215-there . So [she]108-birdalone went up to [him]150-arthur , and all simply [she]108-birdalone took [him]150-arthur by the hand and led [him]150-arthur into a shot - window and set [him]150-arthur down by [her]108-birdalone ; and [he]150-arthur , all trembling for love and fear of [her]108-birdalone , might not forbear , but kissed [her]108-birdalone face and [her]108-birdalone mouth many times ; and [she]108-birdalone grew as hot as fire , and somewhat [she]108-birdalone wept . Then [she]108-birdalone spake after a while : [Dear friend]1220-dear friend , [I]109-atra had it in [my]109-atra mind to say to [thee]1220-dear friend many things that [meseems]5976-meseems were sage , but now neither will the thought of them come into [my]109-atra mind , nor the words into [my]109-atra mouth . And this is a short hour . And therewith [she]108-birdalone fell to kissing [him]150-arthur , till [he]150-arthur was well - nigh beside [himself]150-arthur betwixt desire and joy and the grief of departure , and the hardness of the case . But at last [she]108-birdalone forbore and said : Will it not be when [thou]1220-dear friend art gone tomorrow as it was when [ye]1220-dear friend were away upon the Quest , and [I]109-atra knew not how to bear [myself]109-atra , so heavy lay all [the world]417-the world and its doings and its fashion upon [me]109-atra ? It will be hard to [me]109-atra , [he]150-arthur said ; evil and grim will be the days . [She]108-birdalone said : And yet , even now in these last days , when [I]109-atra see [thee]150-arthur oft , every day [my]109-atra soul is worn with grief , and [I]109-atra know not what to do with [myself]109-atra . [I]109-atra shall come back , [he]150-arthur said , and bear [my]109-atra love with [me]109-atra , and then belike [we]5978-we shall seek some remedy . [She]108-birdalone was silent a while , and then [she]108-birdalone said : Meanwhile of [thy]150-arthur coming , and [I]109-atra see [thee]150-arthur not at all for many days , how will it be with [my]109-atra grief then ? Quoth [he]150-arthur : More than enough of grief [no soul]5979-no soul may bear ; for either death comes , or else some dullness of the pain , and then by little and little the pain weareth . Then [she]108-birdalone said : And how would it be if [thou]150-arthur come not [back]5980-back and [I]109-atra see [thee]150-arthur never again , or if when [thou]150-arthur come back [thou]150-arthur find [me]109-atra not , for that [I]109-atra be either dead or gone away out of [thy]150-arthur reach ? [He]150-arthur said : [I]109-atra know not how it would be . When [thou]150-arthur sayest [thou]150-arthur shalt die , dost [thou]150-arthur wholly believe it in [thy]150-arthur sense or [thy]150-arthur body otherwise than [Holy Church]163-holy church would ? [I]109-atra will tell [thee]150-arthur , [she]108-birdalone said , that now [I]109-atra am sitting by [thee]150-arthur and seeing [thy]150-arthur face and hearing [thy]150-arthur voice , it is that only which [I]109-atra believe in ; for [I]109-atra may think of nought else of either grief or joy . [Yea]5981-yea , when [I]109-atra wept eâ€™en now , it was not for sorrow that [I]109-atra wept , but for [I]109-atra can not rightly tell what . And [she]108-birdalone took [his]150-arthur hand and looked fondly upon [him]150-arthur . But presently [she]108-birdalone looked on [his]150-arthur hand , and said : And now [meseemeth]5982-meseemeth that [we]5983-we twain are grown to be such [close friends]5984-close friends that [I]109-atra may ask [thee]150-arthur what [I]109-atra will , and [thou]150-arthur be neither angry , nor wonder thereat . [I]109-atra see on [thy]150-arthur finger here the ring that [I]109-atra brought with [me]109-atra from [the Isle of Increase]17-the isle of increase unsought , and which thereafter [thou]150-arthur hadst of [me]109-atra when [I]109-atra gave [thee]150-arthur back also the shoon which were lent unto [me]109-atra . Tell [me]109-atra how [thou]150-arthur hadst it back from [Atra]109-atra , as [I]109-atra suppose [thou]150-arthur gavest it unto [her]109-atra . But how now art [thou]150-arthur angry ? for [I]109-atra see the blood come up in [thy]150-arthur face . Nay , [beloved]5985-beloved , said [he]150-arthur , [I]109-atra am not angry , but whenso [I]109-atra hear of [Atra]109-atra , or think of [her]109-atra closely , shame comes on [me]109-atra and confusion , and maybe fear . But now will [I]109-atra answer [thee]150-arthur . For even in those hours which [we]5986-us wore on [the Isle of [the Young and the Old]120-the young]58-the isle of the young and the old , when all [we]5986-us should have been so happy together , [she]109-atra divined somewhat of [my]109-atra case , or indeed , why do [I]109-atra not say it out , all thereof . And [she]109-atra spake to [me]109-atra such words ( for [she]109-atra is both tender and wise and strong of heart ) that [I]109-atra cowered before [her]109-atra and [her]109-atra grief and pain ; and [she]109-atra gave [me]109-atra back the said ring , which forsooth [I]109-atra gave to [her]109-atra in the Sending Boat in the first hour that [the Isle of [Increase]112-increase unsought]4552-the isle of increase lay astern of [us]5986-us . And [I]109-atra wear it now as a token of [my]109-atra grief for [her]109-atra grief . See now , love , since [I]109-atra have answered [thee]109-atra this question without anger or amaze , [thou]109-atra needest not fear to ask [me]109-atra any other ; for this of all things lies closest to [my]109-atra heart . [Birdalone]139-birdalone drooped [her]109-atra head , and [she]109-atra spake in a low voice : Lo now ! the shadow of parting and the shadow of death could not come between [our]5986-us present joy ; but this shadow of [the third one]5988-the third one cometh between [us]5986-us and is present between [us]5986-us . Woe â€™s [me]109-atra ! how little did [I]109-atra think of this when [thou]109-atra wert away and [I]109-atra was sick of longing for the sight of [thee]109-atra , and deemed that that would heal it all . [He]5989-he spake not , but took [her]109-atra hand and held it ; and presently [she]109-atra looked up again and said : [Thou]109-atra art good , and wilt not be angry if [I]109-atra ask [thee]5989-he something else ; this it is : Why wert [thou]109-atra so grim with [me]109-atra that other day when [ye]109-atra found [me]109-atra in that evil plight in tow of the Red Tyrant , so that [I]109-atra deemed that [thou]109-atra of all others hadst cast [me]109-atra off ? That was worse to [me]109-atra than [the witch]394-the witch â€™s stripes , and [I]109-atra kept thinking to [myself]109-atra : How simple was [my]109-atra trouble once , and now how tangled and weary ! Then [he]5989-he might not refrain [him]5989-he , but threw [himself]5989-he upon [her]109-atra , and clipped [her]109-atra and kissed [her]109-atra all [he]5989-he might , and [she]109-atra felt all the sweetness of love , and lacked nought of kindness and love to [him]5989-he . And thereafter [they]5991-they sat still awhile , and [he]5989-he said , as if [her]109-atra question had but that moment left [her]109-atra lips : This , forsooth , was the cause that [I]109-atra looked grim on [thee]109-atra : first , that from the time [I]109-atra first saw [thee]109-atra and heard [thy]109-atra tale , and of [thy]109-atra deeds , [I]109-atra had deemed [thee]109-atra wise above the wisdom of [women]420-women . But this going forth of [thee]109-atra to [the Black Valley]5993-the black valley , whereof came the slaying of [Baudoin]115-baudoin , seemed unto [me]109-atra a mere folly , till again [I]109-atra had heard [thy]109-atra tale of that also ; and then the tale and [thy]109-atra speech overcame [me]109-atra . But again , though [I]109-atra was grieved and disappointed hereat , belike that had passed from [me]109-atra speedily , but then there was this also which would not let [my]109-atra soul rest , to wit , that [I]109-atra feared concerning [that slain knight whose head the Red One had hung about [thy]109-atra neck]5994-that slain knight whose head the red one had hung about thy neck ; for how else , methought , might [he]5994-that slain knight whose head the red one had hung about thy neck have been so wroth with [him]5994-that slain knight whose head the red one had hung about thy neck and [thee]109-atra ; and meseemed , moreover , that [thou]109-atra [wert]109-atra kind in [thine]109-atra heart to [the dead man]5574-the dead man , even when [we]109-atra were come to [thee]109-atra ; and then , seest [thou]109-atra , [my]109-atra desire for [thee]109-atra and the trouble of [Baudoin]115-baudoin â€™s slaying , and the black trouble aforesaid . [Lo]93-lo now , [I]109-atra have told [thee]109-atra this . When wilt [thou]109-atra cease to be angry with [me]109-atra ? [She]109-atra said : [I]109-atra ceased to be grieved with thine anger when thine anger died ; yet strange , meseemeth , that [thou]109-atra shouldst trust [me]109-atra so little when [thou]109-atra lovest [me]109-atra so much ! And [she]109-atra leaned against [him]5574-the dead man and caressed [him]5574-the dead man gently , and again was [he]5574-the dead man at point to take [her]109-atra in [his]5574-the dead man arms , when lo ! the sound of [men]204-men coming unto the screen of [the hall]1193-the hall ; so then [those two]4775-those two stood up and went to meet [them]4775-those two , and there was the speech of [their]4775-those two sundering done . Yet belike for a little while [both those twain]5999-both those twain were happy . Chapter XII ~ [The Knights]6000-the knights and [[Their]6000-the knights Fellows]6001-their fellows Betake [Them]6000-the knights to the Assaulting of [the Red Hold]2256-the red hold On the morrow , when the day was yet young , [the knights]6000-the knights were ready for departure , and in the very gate [they]6000-the knights bade farewell to [the ladies]1877-the ladies , who kissed [them]6000-the knights kindly one and all , and [Viridis]108-birdalone wept sore ; and [Atra]109-atra constrained [herself]109-atra to do even as [the others]1287-the others did ; but pale [she]109-atra was and quaking when [she]109-atra kissed [Arthur]150-arthur and watched [him]150-arthur get a - horseback . But [the knights]6000-the knights bade [[their]6000-the knights ladies]6007-their ladies be of good cheer , for that [they]6000-the knights would send [them]6007-their ladies tidings of how [they]6007-their ladies sped every seven days at least , whereas it was no long way thence to [the Red Hold]2256-the red hold , save there were battle on [the road]1797-the road , and [they]6000-the knights deemed [their]6000-the knights host which should beset [the Hold]60-the hold would be enough to clear all the ways behind it . For that same cause withal [they]6000-the knights had [Sir Aymeris]131-sir aymeris with [them]6000-the knights , nor left a many men behind [them]6000-the knights , and [they]6000-the knights under the rule of [three squires]6010-three squires , whereof [two were but young]6011-two were but young , and [the third]1805-the third , who was made [the captain of [the castle]1534-the castle]6013-the captain of the castle , was [an old and wise man of war]6015-an old and wise man of war , who had to name [Geoffrey of Lea]164-sir geoffrey of lea . There , [withal]117-withal , was [the priest Sir Leonard , who went about now much hushed and abashed , and seemed to fear to give a word to [Birdalone]139-birdalone]139-birdalone ; albeit [she]6016-she deemed of [him]139-birdalone that [his]139-birdalone thoughts of [her]6016-she were the same as erst they had been . So now when [the knights]6000-the knights were departed , and [all the host]6018-all the host was gone out of sight , it was heavy time indeed in [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest till [they]6000-the knights should hear tidings of [them]6000-the knights again . Both [Aurea]107-aurea and [Atra]109-atra kept much to [themselves]6020-they , and did [I]109-atra know not what to wear away the time ; for now it was not to be looked for that [they]6020-they should venture out - a - gates . But as for [Viridis]108-birdalone , [she]108-birdalone waxed of better cheer after a while , but whatever betid [she]108-birdalone would not sunder [herself]108-birdalone from [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; nay , not for an hour ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone took all [her]108-birdalone kindness kindly , though forsooth it was somewhat of a pain unto [her]108-birdalone ; it shall be told wherefore ere long . [Withal]117-withal , as if to wear the time , [Birdalone]108-birdalone betook [her]108-birdalone diligently to [her]108-birdalone needlework , and fell to the cunningest of broidery ; so that [Viridis]108-birdalone and [the others]1287-the others wondered at [her]108-birdalone , for when [they]6020-they were done it seemed indeed that the flowers and creatures and knots had grown of [themselves]6020-they upon the cloth , such wondrous work it was . Moreover , to [his]6022-his great joy , the very first day of the departure of [the host]5962-the host [she]108-birdalone called [Sir Leonard]139-birdalone unto [her]108-birdalone , and prayed to go on again with the learning [her]108-birdalone fair scribe - craft ; and therein also was [she]108-birdalone diligent hours of every day ; and [Viridis]108-birdalone would sit beside [her]108-birdalone wondering at the deftness of [her]108-birdalone fingers , and crying out for joy as the page grew fair and well - learned under [them]6020-they . Thus wore a week , and at the end thereof came a messenger from [the host]5962-the host and told how [they]6020-they had come before [the Red Hold]2256-the red hold and had summoned [them]6020-they thereof to yield , which [they]6020-they had utterly denied to do , but defied [the host]5962-the host ; wherefore [the host]5962-the host had now beset the Hold , and [more folk]6028-more folk were daily flocking unto [them]6020-they ; but that [the said Hold]5535-the said hold would be hard to win by plain assault , whereas [it]5535-the said hold was both strong and well - manned ; but [few of [the host]5962-the host]6030-few of the host had been slain or hurt as yet , and of [the chieftains]6032-the chieftains not one . Right glad were [they]6020-they of [the castle]1534-the castle because of these tidings ; though , forsooth , [the men - at - arms]4947-the men - at - arms knew well enough that the time would soon come when some fierce assault would be made , and then , forsooth , would be sore peril of life and limb unto [the chieftains]6032-the chieftains . Chapter XIII ~ [Birdalone Bethinks]108-birdalone [Her]108-birdalone to Fulfil the Promise Made Unto [Atra]109-atra Again wore a week , and once more came [the messenger]6036-the messenger , and did [them]6020-they of [the castle]1534-the castle to wit that there had been nought more done at [the Red Hold]42-the red hold , save skirmishing at the barriers , wherein [few were hurt on either side]6038-few were hurt on either side ; and also that the engines for battering the walls were now well - nigh all dight , and [they]6020-they would begin to play upon the Hold , and in especial one which hight Wall - wolf , which had been set up by [the crafts of [Greenford]39-greenford]6039-the crafts of greenford . This tidings also was deemed good by [all]881-all , save it might be by [Atra]109-atra , who , as [Birdalone]108-birdalone deemed , pined and fretted [herself]109-atra at the delay , and would fain that , one way or other , all were over . [Atra]109-atra spake but little to [Birdalone]108-birdalone , but watched [her]109-atra closely now ; oft would [she]109-atra gaze on [her]109-atra wistfully , as if [she]109-atra would that [Birdalone]108-birdalone would speak unto [her]109-atra ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone noted that , but [she]109-atra might not pluck up heart thereto . Wore a third week , and again came [the messenger]6036-the messenger , and told how three days ago , whenas [Wall - wolf]165-wall - wolf had sorely battered one of [the great towers which hight [the Poison - jar]6043-the poison - jar]6042-the great towers which hight the poison - jar , and overthrown a pan of the wall there beside , [they]6044-they had tried an assault on the breach , and hard had been the battle there , and in the end , after fierce give and take , [they]6044-they of the Hold had done so valiantly that [they]6044-they had thrust back [the assailants]6045-the assailants , and that in the hottest brunt [the Black Squire]1325-the black squire had been hurt in the shoulder by a spear - thrust , but not very grievously ; but withal that [he]1325-the black squire sent , in so many words , forbidding [the ladies]1877-the ladies to make any account of so small a matter . And , quoth [the sergeant]5481-the sergeant , most like [[my]109-atra lord]2039-my lord will wear [his]5481-the sergeant armour in four days â€™[109-atra] time ; also now [we]2936-we have reared another great slinger , which [we]2936-we call [Stone]166-stone - fretter , and soon , without doubt , [we]2936-we shall be standing victorious within [that den of [thieves]2938-thieves]2937-that den of thieves . Now though these tidings were not so altogether ill , yet were [those ladies]1501-those ladies sore troubled thereby , and especially [Atra]109-atra , who swooned outright when [she]109-atra had heard the last word thereof . As for [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [she]108-birdalone made as little semblance of [her]108-birdalone trouble as [she]108-birdalone might , but when all was quiet again [she]108-birdalone went to find [Viridis]108-birdalone , and brought [her]108-birdalone to [[her]108-birdalone chamber]4893-her chamber and spake to [her]108-birdalone , saying : [Viridis]108-birdalone , [[my]0-i sister]1162-my sister , [thou]2942-thou hast been piteous kind unto [me]0-i from the first minute that [thou]2942-thou sawest [me]0-i naked and helpless , and fleeing from evil unto worse evil ; nowise mightest [thou]2942-thou have done better by [me]0-i hadst [thou]2942-thou been verily [[my]0-i sister]1162-my sister of blood ; and [I]0-i know it that [thou]2942-thou wouldst be loth to part from [me]0-i . [Viridis]108-birdalone wept and said : Why dost [thou]2942-thou speak of parting from [me]0-i , when [thou]2942-thou knowest it would break [my]0-i heart ? Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : To say it as short as may be , because the parting must now come to pass . [Viridis]108-birdalone waxed pale and then red , and [she]108-birdalone stamped [her]108-birdalone foot and said : It is unkind of [thee]2942-thou to grieve [me]0-i thus , and [thou]2942-thou doest wrong herein . Hearken , [dear sister]782-dear sister , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : [thou]2942-thou knowest , for [thou]2942-thou [thyself]2942-thou wast the first to tell [me]0-i thereof , that [I]0-i am the supplanter in [our]2945-our fellowship , and that [I]0-i have undone [Atra]109-atra â€™s hope . This [I]0-i did not of [mine]0-i own will , but it came unto [me]0-i ; yet of [mine]0-i own will [I]0-i can do the best [I]0-i may to amend it ; and this is the best , that [I]0-i depart hence before the Red Hold is taken and [[my]0-i lords]1728-my lords come back ; for if [they]1728-my lords come back and [I]0-i see [[my]0-i lord]2039-my lord [Arthur]150-arthur , so fair and beauteous as [he]150-arthur is , before [me]0-i , never shall [I]0-i be able to go away from [him]150-arthur . And lo [thou]2948-he , [I]0-i have promised [Atra]109-atra by all the kindness [she]109-atra did [me]0-i when [we]2949-we were come to [the Wailing Tower]14-the wailing â€“ tower , and [I]0-i naked and quaking and half - dead with terror , that if occasion served [I]0-i would do [my]0-i utmost to help [her]109-atra , even if it were to [my]0-i own grief . Now behold this that now is , is the occasion , and there will not be another ; for when [my]0-i love comes home hither and beholdeth [me]0-i , think [thou]2948-he how all the desire which has been gathering in [his]2948-he heart this while will blossom and break forth toward [me]0-i ; and mayhappen [he]2948-he will make but little semblance of it before [other folk]332-other folk , for proud and high of heart is [he]2948-he ; but [he]2948-he will seek occasion to find [me]0-i alone , and then shall [I]0-i be with [him]2948-he as the lark in the talons of the sparrow - hawk , and [he]2948-he will do [his]2948-he pleasure of [me]0-i , and that with all the good - will of [my]0-i heart . And then shall [I]0-i be forsworn to [Atra]109-atra , and [she]109-atra will hate [me]0-i , as now [she]109-atra doth not , and then is all the fellowship riven , and that by [my]0-i deed . Yet was [Viridis]108-birdalone wrath , and [she]108-birdalone said : Meseemeth this is [fool]2951-fool â€™s talk . Will not the fellowship be all the more riven if [thou]2952-thou depart and [we]2953-we see [thee]2952-thou no more ? O nay , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; for when [I]0-i am gone [thy]2952-thou love shall be no less for [me]0-i , though as now [thou]2952-thou art angry ; and [Atra]109-atra will love [me]0-i for that [I]0-i shall have held to [my]0-i promise to [mine]0-i own scathe ; and [[thy]2952-thou man]2954-thy man and [Aurea]107-aurea will lay it to [me]0-i that [I]0-i have done valiantly and knightly . And [Arthur]150-arthur , how can [he]150-arthur choose but love [me]0-i ; and maybe [we]2953-we shall yet meet again . And therewithal [she]108-birdalone did at last bow down [her]108-birdalone head and fall to weeping , and [Viridis]108-birdalone was moved by [her]108-birdalone tears and fell to kissing and caressing [her]108-birdalone . After a little [Birdalone]108-birdalone lifted up [her]108-birdalone head and spake again : Moreover , how can [I]0-i dare to abide [him]150-arthur ? didst [thou]2955-thou not see how grim [he]150-arthur was to [me]0-i when [they]2956-they delivered [me]0-i and brought [me]0-i back ? and [he]150-arthur with [his]150-arthur own lips told [me]0-i so much , that it was because [he]150-arthur doubted that [I]0-i had done amiss ; and now if [I]0-i do amiss again , even if it be at [his]150-arthur bidding , will it not be so that [he]150-arthur will speedily weary of [me]0-i , and curse [me]0-i and cast [me]0-i off ? What sayest [thou]2955-thou , [Viridis]108-birdalone [mine]108-birdalone ? What is to say , said [Viridis]108-birdalone , save that [thou]2955-thou hast broken [my]0-i heart ? But [thou]2955-thou mayst heal it if [thou]2955-thou wilt take [thy]2955-thou words back , and tell [me]0-i that [thou]2955-thou wilt not sunder [thee]2955-thou from [us]2957-us . But [Birdalone]108-birdalone brake out weeping and lamenting aloud , and [she]108-birdalone cried out : Nay , nay , it may not be ; [I]0-i must depart , and [Atra]109-atra hath smitten [me]0-i amidst of [[my]0-i friends]1795-my friends . And [Viridis]108-birdalone knew not what to say or to do . At last came [Birdalone]108-birdalone to [herself]108-birdalone again , and [she]108-birdalone looked sweetly on [Viridis]108-birdalone and smiled on [her]108-birdalone from out [her]108-birdalone tears , and said : [Thou]2955-thou seest , [sister]773-sister , how little a loss [thou]2955-thou wilt have of [me]0-i , [a mere wild woman]2960-a mere wild woman . And now nought availeth either [me]0-i or [thee]2955-thou but [I]0-i must begone , and that speedily . Let it be tomorrow then . And when [the messenger]6036-the messenger comes at the end of this week , send word by [him]6036-the messenger of what [I]0-i have done ; and look [thou]2955-thou to it but [both [our]2963-our lords]2962-both our lords will praise [me]0-i for the deed . Said [Viridis]108-birdalone : But whither wilt [thou]2955-thou , or what wilt [thou]2955-thou do ? To [Greenford]39-greenford first , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and after [whither]2964-whither [the Good Lord]167-the good lord shall lead [me]0-i ; and as for what [I]0-i will do , [I]0-i am now deft in two crafts , script and broidery to wit ; and , wheresoever [I]0-i be , [folk]4521-folk shall pay [me]0-i to work herein for [them]4521-folk , whereby [I]0-i shall earn [my]0-i bread . [Hearken]168-hearken also , [[my]0-i sister]1162-my sister , canst [thou]2955-thou give [me]0-i any deal of money ? for though [I]0-i wot little of such matters , yet [I]0-i wot that [I]0-i shall need the same . And [I]0-i ask this whereas , as [eâ€™en]2967-eâ€™en now [I]0-i said , [I]0-i deem [[our]2968-our lords]1663-our lords shall praise [my]0-i deed , and that , therefore , [they]1663-our lords would not that [I]0-i should depart hence as [an outcast]741-an outcast , wherefore [they]1663-our lords shall not begrudge it to [me]0-i . Moreover , for the same cause [I]0-i would [thee]2971-thee speak to [the old squire [Geoffrey of Lea]164-sir geoffrey of lea]2972-the old squire geoffrey of lea , and tell [him]2972-the old squire geoffrey of lea that [I]0-i have an errand to [Greenford]39-greenford , and crave of [him]2972-the old squire geoffrey of lea that [he]2972-the old squire geoffrey of lea lend [me]0-i one of [the two younglings]5933-the two younglings , [Arnold]169-arnold or Anselm , and [two or three men - at - arms]2974-two or three men - at - arms to bring [me]0-i safely thither ; since now , forsooth , [I]0-i need no more adventures on [the road]1797-the road . [She]0-i smiled as [she]0-i spake ; and now all the passion of anguish seemed to have left [her]0-i for that while ; but [Viridis]108-birdalone cast [her]108-birdalone arms about [her]108-birdalone neck and wept upon [her]108-birdalone bosom , and said : Woe â€™s [me]0-i ! for [I]0-i see that [thou]2976-thou wilt go whatsoever [I]0-i may say or do ; [I]0-i strove to be angry with [thee]2976-thou , but [I]0-i might not , and now [I]0-i see that [thou]2976-thou constrainest [me]0-i as [thou]2976-thou dost all else . [I]0-i will go now straightway and do thine errand . Thus then [they]2977-they parted for that time ; but it was not till the day after the morrow that [Birdalone]108-birdalone was alboun . [Viridis]108-birdalone told of [her]0-i departure both to [Aurea]107-aurea and [Atra]109-atra ; and [Aurea]107-aurea lamented it , but would not do aught to stay [her]107-aurea ; for [she]107-aurea was waxen weary and listless since the death of [[her]107-aurea man]5681-her man . As for [Atra]109-atra , [she]107-aurea spake but little concerning it , but to [Viridis]108-birdalone praised [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s valiance and kindness . Yet unto [herself]0-i [she]0-i said : Verily [she]109-atra understood [my]0-i word that [I]0-i spake to [her]109-atra about the occasion of [her]109-atra helping . Yet woe â€™s [me]0-i ! for [she]109-atra shall carry [his]5681-her man love with [her]109-atra whithersoever [she]109-atra wendeth ; and [a happy woman]2504-a happy woman is [she]2504-a happy woman . But when [Geoffrey]164-sir geoffrey of lea [the squire]2382-the squire knew that [the ladies , all three]2981-the ladies , all three , were at one with [Birdalone]108-birdalone as to [her]108-birdalone departure , [he]164-sir geoffrey of lea doubted nothing , but bade [Arnold]169-arnold , [[his]164-sir geoffrey of lea mate]2982-his mate , take [four good men]2983-four good men with [him]164-sir geoffrey of lea , and bring [the Lady Birdalone]108-birdalone unto [Greenford]39-greenford and do [her]108-birdalone bidding there . [Albeit]171-albeit , [he]164-sir geoffrey of lea deemed no less but [they]2983-four good men would bring [her]108-birdalone back again . Chapter XIV ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone Leaves [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest On the morrow morn , then , [Birdalone]108-birdalone spake farewell both to [Aurea]107-aurea and [Atra]109-atra ; but as for [Viridis]108-birdalone , [she]108-birdalone sent [her]108-birdalone word that [she]108-birdalone had no heart thereto , and yet [she]108-birdalone sent [her]108-birdalone a word of comfort , to wit , that [she]108-birdalone deemed that [they]2985-they would one day meet again . [Aurea]107-aurea , in [her]107-aurea parting words , part praised [her]107-aurea , part chid [her]107-aurea ; saying that [she]107-aurea did well and kindly and valiantly , as [her]107-aurea wo nt was . Yet , said [she]107-aurea , when all is said , [thou]2986-thou mightest have abided this tangle and trouble , which at the worst had not been so evil as death between [us]2987-us . Yea , [sister]773-sister , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , but might not death have come of [my]0-i abiding ? As [she]107-aurea spake , in came [Atra]109-atra , with [her]109-atra head somewhat drooped , meek and humble , [her]109-atra cheeks red , [her]109-atra hands trembling ; and [she]109-atra said : Wilt [thou]2986-thou take now [my]0-i word of farewell and blessing , and the kiss of peace betwixt [us]2987-us , and bear away the memory of [our]2987-us kindness together ? [Birdalone]108-birdalone stood up proud and straight , and was somewhat pale as [she]108-birdalone suffered [Atra]109-atra to kiss [her]108-birdalone cheeks and mouth , and said : Now hast [thou]2986-thou forgiven [me]0-i that weird dragged [me]0-i in betwixt [thy]2986-thou love and [thy]2986-thou goodhap ; and [I]0-i have forgiven [thee]2986-thou that [I]0-i am led away by weird into [the waste]4681-the waste and [the wilderness of love]2990-the wilderness of love . Farewell . Therewith [she]108-birdalone went [her]108-birdalone way to the gate , and [the others]1287-the others followed [her]108-birdalone not . Without abode [her]108-birdalone [Arnold]169-arnold and [the four men - at - arms]2992-the four men - at - arms , and [her]108-birdalone palfrey and [a sumpter - horse bearing two goodly coffers]2993-a sumpter - horse bearing two goodly coffers , wherein [Viridis]108-birdalone had let load raiment and other havings for [her]108-birdalone ; and [Arnold]169-arnold came up to [her]108-birdalone smiling , and said : [[My]0-i lady]603-my lady [Viridis]108-birdalone hath given [me]0-i a pouch wherein is money to bear for [thee]108-birdalone to [Greenford]39-greenford and hand over to [thee]108-birdalone there when [we]2995-they be safe ; and [she]108-birdalone hath bidden [me]0-i to be in all wise obedient unto [thee]108-birdalone , [lady]493-lady , which needed not , whereas now and from hence forth am [I]0-i by [mine]0-i own will [[thy]108-birdalone very servant]2997-thy very servant to do [thy]108-birdalone pleasure always and everywhere . [She]108-birdalone thanked [him]169-arnold and smiled on [him]169-arnold kindly , so that [his]169-arnold heart beat fast for joy and love of [her]108-birdalone ; and therewith [she]108-birdalone gat into the saddle and [they]2995-they rode [their]2995-they ways together , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone looked back never till [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest was shut from [their]2995-they eyes by the nesses of [the little hills]2999-the little hills . [Birdalone]108-birdalone Rides to [Greenford]39-greenford and There Takes Leave of [Arnold]169-arnold and [[His]169-arnold Men]5457-his men On [the road to [Greenford]39-greenford]3001-the road to greenford nought befell to tell of ; [they]2995-they came thither when the sun was at point to set , for [they]2995-they had ridden diligently all day . As [they]2995-they rode [the streets of [the good town]3003-the good town]3002-the streets of the good town , [they]2995-they noted of [them]2995-they , that though it was evening wherein [folk]4521-folk do much disport [them]4521-folk abroad , there were [women]420-women and [children]1274-children enough in [the streets]3007-the streets or standing at [their]2995-they doors , but of [carles very few]3008-carles very few , and [they]2995-they for the more part grey - heads . Now did [Arnold]169-arnold bring [Birdalone]108-birdalone to [the town hall]3009-the town hall , wherein yet sat [the deputy of [the burgrave]3011-the burgrave , who [himself]3010-the deputy of the burgrave , who himself was in the leaguer at the red hold was in [the leaguer at [the Red Hold]2256-the red hold]3012-the leaguer at the red hold]3010-the deputy of the burgrave , who himself was in the leaguer at the red hold ; [this man , who was old and wise and nothing feeble of body]3014-this man , who was old and wise and nothing feeble of body , made much of [Birdalone]108-birdalone and [[her]108-birdalone folk]2562-her folk , and was glad of [them]2995-they when [he]3010-the deputy of the burgrave , who himself was in the leaguer at the red hold knew that [they]2995-they had the seal and let - pass of [[Geoffrey]164-sir geoffrey of lea of [Lea]62-lea]3016-geoffrey of lea ; wherefore [he]3010-the deputy of the burgrave , who himself was in the leaguer at the red hold gave [them]2995-they to eat and drink , and lodged them in [[his]3010-the deputy of the burgrave , who himself was in the leaguer at the red hold own house]3017-his own house , and made [them]2995-they the best of cheer . But betimes on the morrow did [Birdalone]108-birdalone send back [Arnold]169-arnold and [the four men - at - arms]2992-the four men - at - arms , with no tale but that such was [her]108-birdalone will ; and bidding farewell to [the said Arnold]169-arnold , [she]108-birdalone suffered [him]169-arnold to kiss [her]108-birdalone hands , and gave [him]169-arnold a ring from off [her]108-birdalone finger , so that [he]169-arnold went on [his]169-arnold way rejoicing . So soon as [she]108-birdalone saw [him]169-arnold and [[his]169-arnold men]5457-his men well on [the road]1797-the road , [she]108-birdalone went to [the old man]1380-the old man , [the vice - ruler of [the town]305-the town , who was of [the aldermen thereof]3024-the aldermen thereof]3022-the vice - ruler of the town , who was of the aldermen thereof , and did [him]1380-the old man to wit that [she]108-birdalone would wage [two or three carles who could deal with horses and beasts , and withal handle weapons if need were , to be both as [servants]1091-servants and guards for [her]108-birdalone]3025-two or three carles who could deal with horses and beasts , and withal handle weapons if need were , to be both as servants and guards for her , as [she]108-birdalone had errands in [that country - side]3027-that country - side , and belike might well have to go from [town]3028-town to [town]3028-town thereabout . [He]169-arnold took [her]108-birdalone asking kindly , but said it was none so easy to find [men who for any wage would fare forth of [Greenford]39-greenford at that stour , whereas well - nigh all [[their]3030-men who for any wage would fare forth of greenford at that stour , whereas well - nigh all their fighting - men fighting - men]3031-their fighting - men]3030-men who for any wage would fare forth of greenford at that stour , whereas well - nigh all their fighting - men were lying before the Red Hold as now . Howsoever , ere noontide [he]169-arnold brought before [her]108-birdalone [a man of over three score]3032-a man of over three score , but yet wayworthy , and [two stout young men]3033-two stout young men , [[his]169-arnold sons]3034-his sons , and told [her]108-birdalone that [these men]5229-these men were trusty and would go with [her]108-birdalone to [the world]417-the world â€™s end if need were . [She]108-birdalone took [these men]5229-these men readily , and agreed with [them]5229-these men for a good wage ; and whereas [each one]329-each one had bow and arrows and short sword , [she]108-birdalone had but to buy for [them]5229-these men jacks , sallets , and bucklers , and [they]5229-these men were well armed as for [their]5229-these men condition . Withal [she]108-birdalone bought [them]5229-these men three good horses and another sumpter - horse ; which last was loaded with sundry wares that [she]108-birdalone deemed that [she]108-birdalone needed , and with victual . Then [she]108-birdalone took leave of [the alderman]3039-the alderman , thanking [him]3039-the alderman much for [his]3039-the alderman good - will , and so departed from [Greenford]39-greenford at all adventure , when the day was yet young . [The alderman]3039-the alderman had asked [her]108-birdalone whither away , and [she]108-birdalone had told [him]3039-the alderman that [she]108-birdalone was boun for [Mostwyke]63-mostwyke first , and thereafter for [Shifford - on - the - Strand]64-shifford - on - the - strand ; whereas [she]108-birdalone had heard talk of [these two towns]3041-these two towns as being on one and [the same highway]3042-the same highway , and [Mostwyke]63-mostwyke about a score of miles from [Greenford]39-greenford ; but when [she]108-birdalone was well out - [a - gates]3043-a - gates [she]108-birdalone came to [a little road]3044-a little road on the right hand which turned clean away from [Mostwyke]63-mostwyke , and [she]108-birdalone took [the said road]3045-the said road ; and when [she]108-birdalone had followed [it]3045-the said road some three miles , [she]108-birdalone asked [the old carle whither]172-the old carle whither it led . [He]3039-the alderman looked on [her]108-birdalone and smiled somewhat , and [she]108-birdalone on [him]3039-the alderman in turn ; and [she]108-birdalone said : Wonder not , [[my]0-i friend]304-my friend , that [I]0-i am not clear about [my]0-i ways , for [I]0-i shall tell the sooth that [I]0-i am [a damsel adventurous]3047-a damsel adventurous , and am but seeking some place where [I]0-i may dwell and earn [my]0-i livelihood till better days come ; and this is the whole truth , and [thou]3048-thou shalt know it at once , to wit , that [I]0-i am indeed fleeing , and were fain to hide the footsteps of [me]0-i , and [I]0-i bid [you]3049-you three to help [me]0-i therein . But [ye]3049-you must know that [I]0-i am fleeing , not from [[my]0-i foes]3050-my foes , but from [[my]0-i friends]1795-my friends ; and , if [ye]3049-you will , as [we]3052-we go by the way , [I]0-i will tell [you]3049-you all the story of [me]0-i , and [we]3052-we will be [friends]404-friends while [we]3052-we are together , [yea]3049-you , and thereafter if it may be . Now [she]0-i said this because [she]0-i had looked carefully on [these men]5229-these men , and herseemed that [they]5229-these men were [good men]3055-good men and true , and not dull of wit . Forsooth [the old man]1380-the old man , who hight [Gerard of the Clee]173-gerard , was no weakling , and was nought loathly to look on , and [[his]1380-the old man two sons]3057-his two sons were goodly and great of fashion , clear - eyed , and well - carven of visage ; [they]3057-his two sons hight [Robert]174-robert and [Giles]175-giles gerardson . Now spake [old Gerard]173-gerard : [Lady]493-lady , [I]0-i thank [thee]493-lady heartily of [thy]493-lady much grace unto [me]0-i ; now would [I]0-i get off [my]0-i nag and kneel to [thee]493-lady in [the highway therefor]3059-the highway therefor , but that [I]0-i see that [thou]493-lady wert fain to make as much way as may be today ; wherefore , by [thy]493-lady leave , [I]0-i will tarry [my]0-i homaging till [we]3060-we rest [our]3060-we horses by the wayside . [She]493-lady laughed , and praised [his]173-gerard wisdom ; and [the young men]1982-the young men looked on [her]493-lady and worshipped [her]493-lady in [their]1982-the young men hearts . [Forsooth]108-birdalone , the fellowship of [these good and true folk]3062-these good and true folk was soft and sweet to [her]493-lady , and soothed the trouble of [her]493-lady spirit . And [she]493-lady enforced [herself]493-lady to talk cheerfully with [them]1982-the young men , and asked [them]1982-the young men many things , and learned much of them . But now went on [Gerard]173-gerard to say : [Lady]493-lady , if [thou]3064-thou wilt hide [thy]3064-thou ways from whomsoever it may be , [thou]3064-thou hast happened on no ill way ; for though [this road]1734-this road be good to ride , it is but a byway through the sheep - walks that [folk]4521-folk may drive [[their]4521-folk wains]3067-their wains hereby in the wet season of winter and spring ; and for a great way [we]3068-we shall come to but little save [the cots of [the sheep - carles]3070-the sheep - carles]3069-the cots of the sheep - carles ; scarce a hamlet or two for the space of two days â€™ riding ; and on the third day [a little town]6050-a little town , hight Upham , where are but [few folk]6051-few folk save at the midsummer wool - fair , which is now gone by . Now there is [a highway]6052-a highway cometh into [this road]1734-this road from out of [the tilled country]6054-the tilled country and [Appleham]65-appleham , [a good town]6055-a good town , and goeth through [it]1734-this road toward [the tillage]6056-the tillage , and [the City of the Bridges]6057-the city of the bridges and the liberties thereof ; and all [the land]198-the land is much builded and plentiful ; but , if [thou]3064-thou wilt , [we]3068-we will not take [either highway]6059-either highway , but wend over [the downland which lieth north - east of [Upham]66-upham]6060-the downland which lieth north - east of upham , and though it be roadless , yet is it not ill - going , and [I]2080-the master know [it]6060-the downland which lieth north - east of upham well and [its]6060-the downland which lieth north - east of upham watering - places , little dales and waters therein all running north - east , wherein be certain little thorps here and there , which shall refresh [us]3068-we mightily . Over [that downland]6061-that downland [we]3068-we may wend a four days , and then [the land]198-the land will swell up high , and from the end of [that high land]6063-that high land [we]3068-we shall behold below [us]3068-we [a fair land of tillage , well watered and wooded]6064-a fair land of tillage , well watered and wooded , and much builded ; and in the midst thereof [a great city with walls and towers]6065-a great city with walls and towers , and [a great white castle]6066-a great white castle and a minster , and [lovely houses a many]6067-lovely houses a many . In [that city]6068-that city mayst [thou]3064-thou dwell and earn [thy]3064-thou livelihood if [thou]3064-thou canst do aught of crafts . And if [thou]3064-thou mayst not , then may [we]3068-we find somewhat to swink at for a wage , and so maintain [thee]3064-thou and [us]3068-we . But [the said city]6069-the said city is called [the City of the Five Crafts]6070-the city of the five crafts , and [the land round about [it]6069-the said city]6071-the land round about it is the frank thereof ; and oftenest , frank and [city]6072-city and all , [it]6069-the said city is called the Five Crafts all simply . Now what sayest [thou]3064-thou hereof , [[my]2080-the master lady]603-my lady ? [She]603-my lady said : [I]2080-the master say that [we]3068-we will go thither , and that [I]2080-the master thank [thee]3064-thou and [[thy]3064-thou sons]6074-thy sons of [thy]3064-thou good - will , and so may [God]114-god do to [me]2080-the master as [I]2080-the master reward [you]3064-thou well therefor . But tell [me]2080-the master , [good Gerard]173-gerard , how it is that [thou]3064-thou art so willing to leave [kith]6075-kith and kin to follow [a gangrel wife]6076-a gangrel wife along the ways ? Said [Gerard]173-gerard : [Dame]90-dame , [I]2080-the master think that the face and body of [thee]3064-thou might lead [any man that yet had manhood in [him]6077-any man that yet had manhood in him to follow thee , even if he left house and all to go with thee to follow [thee]3064-thou , even if [he]6077-any man that yet had manhood in him to follow thee , even if he left house and all to go with thee left [house]919-house and all to go with [thee]3064-thou]6077-any man that yet had manhood in him to follow thee , even if he left house and all to go with thee . But as for [us]6079-us , [we]6079-us have no longer [a house]6080-a house or gear , whereas [[they]6081-they of [the Red Hold]2256-the red hold]6082-they of the red hold lifted all [my]2080-the master bestial , and burned [[my]2080-the master house]6084-my house and all that was therein a month ago . [Yea]3064-thou , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and how befalleth it , then , that [ye]3064-thou are not before the Red Hold to avenge [thee]3064-thou ? [Dame]90-dame , said [he]2080-the master , when the muster was [I]2080-the master was deemed somewhat over old , wherefore [the sheriff]6085-the sheriff took [me]2080-the master not , but suffered [[my]2080-the master sons]6086-my sons also to abide behind to earn a living for [me]2080-the master ; may [God]114-god be good to [him]2080-the master therefor , and [St. Leonard]130-leonard ! But as to [my]2080-the master kindred , [I]2080-the master must tell [thee]3064-thou that [I]2080-the master am not kinned hereabout , but in [a good town hight Utterhay]6087-a good town hight utterhay , and that when [[our]6088-our alderman]6089-our alderman sent for [me]2080-the master to bring [me]2080-the master to [thee]3064-thou , [I]2080-the master was more than half - minded to get [me]2080-the master back thither . Now sooth it is that the best way thither , though it may be indeed the safest rather than the shortest , lies through [the Five Crafts]6090-the five crafts ; for [the road]1797-the road goes thence to [Utterhay]1-utterhay a three score miles or so , making the longer of [it]1797-the road , as [it]1797-the road skirteth ever some way off [a perilous forest]6092-a perilous forest , [a place of sore dread and devilish]6093-a place of sore dread and devilish , which hight [Evilshaw]2-evilshaw , on the edge whereof lieth [Utterhay]1-utterhay , a merry cheaping - stead and a plenteous , and [the home of [[my]2080-the master kindred]6095-my kindred]6094-the home of my kindred . Wherefore now is [the City of [the Five Crafts handy to [us]6098-they]6097-the five crafts handy to us]6096-the city of the five crafts handy to us ; because when [thou]6099-thou hast done with [us]6098-they , as [I]2080-the master hope it may be long first , then are [we]6098-they [others]4825-others nigh [home]373-home , and may all simply wend [our]6098-they way thither . [Birdalone]108-birdalone thanked [him]2080-the master again full heartily ; but therewithal as [they]6098-they rode along there seemed to stir in [her]108-birdalone some memory of the earliest of [her]108-birdalone days in [[the witch]394-the witch â€™s house]6103-the witch â€™s house , and [she]108-birdalone began to have a longing to betake [her]108-birdalone to [Utterhay]1-utterhay and the skirts of [Evilshaw]2-evilshaw . Chapter II ~ Of [Birdalone]108-birdalone and [Her]108-birdalone Fellowship , [Their]6098-they Faring Over [the Downland]6104-the downland Thus rode [they]6098-they along and loitered not , though [they]6098-they talked blithely together ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone wondered to [herself]108-birdalone that [she]108-birdalone might so much as hold up [her]108-birdalone head for bitter thoughts of the days and the longings but late passed away , but so it was , that it was only now and again that [they]6098-they stung [her]108-birdalone into despair and silence , and for the most part [she]108-birdalone hearkened to the talk of [the old man]1380-the old man and [the lads]6106-the lads about the days of [Greenford]39-greenford and the alarms of lifting and unpeace , and the ways of [the chapmen]6107-the chapmen and [the craftsmen]6108-the craftsmen .
