So came [Birdalone]108-birdalone by that bower wherein [she]108-birdalone had slept that first night [she]108-birdalone came to [the castle]1534-the castle ; and [she]108-birdalone reined up to look on [it]1534-the castle ; and as [she]108-birdalone sat there gazing , came [a man out from it clad as [a man of religion]3402-a man of religion]3401-a man out from it clad as a man of religion ; and [her]108-birdalone heart beat quick , and [she]108-birdalone was like to fall from [her]108-birdalone horse , for there came into [her]108-birdalone mind what [the townsman]3341-the townsman had said , that [the Black Squire]1325-the black squire had gone into religion . But [the hermit]3405-the hermit came towards [her]108-birdalone with a cup of water in [his]3405-the hermit hand , and [he]3405-the hermit cast [his]3405-the hermit hood aback from [him]3405-the hermit , and [she]108-birdalone saw at once that it was [Leonard]130-leonard [the priest]1677-the priest , and though it was not [the friend whom [she]108-birdalone sought]3407-the friend whom she sought , yet was [she]108-birdalone glad that it was [a friend]509-a friend ; but [he]3405-the hermit came and stood by [her]108-birdalone , and said : Hail , [wayfarer]1230-wayfarer ! wilt [thou]3410-thou drink of [our]3411-our well and rest [thee]3410-thou a while ? So [she]108-birdalone took the cup and drank of the water , looking kindly on [him]3405-the hermit , while [he]3405-the hermit wondered at the beauty of [her]108-birdalone hand , and misdoubted [him]3405-the hermit . Then [she]108-birdalone gave [him]3405-the hermit back the cup and lighted down off [her]108-birdalone horse , and took the sallet from [her]108-birdalone head , and spake : [I]0-i may not pass by [a friend]509-a friend without a word ; think if [thou]3410-thou hast not seen [me]0-i before ? Then [he]3405-the hermit knew [her]108-birdalone , and might not refrain [him]3405-the hermit , but cast [his]3405-the hermit arms about [her]108-birdalone and kissed [her]108-birdalone , weeping ; and [she]108-birdalone said : It is sweet to [me]0-i to find [a friend]509-a friend after what [I]0-i have been told of [yonder house]4472-yonder house . [Yea]3415-yea , said [he]3405-the hermit , and art [thou]3410-thou going up thither ? [Certes]140-certes , said [she]108-birdalone , and why not ? Said [he]3405-the hermit : [They]3416-they are gone , and all gone ! How and whither ? said [she]108-birdalone . But [I]0-i must full certainly go thither at once ; [I]0-i will go afoot with [thee]108-birdalone ; do [thou]3410-thou tether [my]0-i horse till [thou]108-birdalone comest back . [He]3405-the hermit said : But wilt not [thou]108-birdalone come back ? [I]0-i know not , [she]108-birdalone said : [I]0-i know nought save that [I]0-i would go thither ; let it be enough that [I]0-i suffer [thee]108-birdalone to go with [me]0-i , and on the way [thou]108-birdalone shalt tell [me]0-i what [thou]108-birdalone canst of the tale . Then went [Leonard]130-leonard and tethered the horse , and [they]3417-they went together afoot to the gate ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone told what [she]108-birdalone had heard of [Arthur]119-arthur and [Hugh]118-hugh ; and [Leonard]130-leonard said : This is true , and there is not much else to be said . When [the Black Squire]1325-the black squire came back from [the leaguer of [the Red Hold]2256-the red hold]3419-the leaguer of the red hold , and had heard before of [thy]108-birdalone departure , [he]1325-the black squire was heavy of mood and few - spoken , and wandered about as [one who might find no rest]3421-one who might find no rest ; yet was [he]1325-the black squire not stern with [Atra]109-atra , who for [her]109-atra part was no less heavy - hearted : soothly a sad company [we]3417-they were , and it was somewhat better when [[my]0-i Lord]2039-my lord [Arthur]119-arthur went [his]119-arthur ways from [us]3417-they ; and indeed eager [he]119-arthur was to be gone ; and it could be seen of [him]119-arthur that [he]119-arthur was fain of the toil and peril which [they]3423-they of [Greenford]39-greenford offered [him]119-arthur . Then in some four months spake [[my]0-i lord]2039-my lord [Hugh]118-hugh that [he]118-hugh also would be gone to [a place where were both [a land]3426-a land and folk that would look friendly on [him]118-hugh]3425-a place where were both a land and folk that would look friendly on him ; so [he]118-hugh went with [[my]0-i lady]603-my lady [Viridis]108-birdalone and [[my]0-i lady]603-my lady [Aurea]107-aurea , and [they]3423-they had [Atra]109-atra also with [them]3423-they ; and [me]0-i also [they]3423-they would have had , but [my]0-i heart failed [me]0-i to leave [the place where [I]0-i had been so glad and so sorry with [thee]3430-thee]3429-the place where i had been so glad and so sorry with thee ; death had been better ; wherefore in yonder bower as in an hermitage [I]0-i serve [God]114-god and abide [my]0-i time . But though [I]0-i wot nought of where is gone [the Black Squire]1325-the black squire , [I]0-i know whereto those four are gone , and it is but a seven days â€™ ride hence , and [the land]198-the land is goodly and peaceable , and if [they]3423-they be not dead , most like [they]3423-they be there yet . How sayest [thou]6280-thou then , [thou]6280-thou dearest and kindest , wilt [thou]6280-thou thither to [them]3423-they ? For if so , [I]1325-the black squire may well lead [thee]3430-thee thither . [Birdalone]108-birdalone shook [her]108-birdalone head . Nay , [she]108-birdalone said , [I]1325-the black squire deem that [I]1325-the black squire am drawn elsewhither , but soon [I]1325-the black squire shall tell [thee]3430-thee . Lo now the gate . But ere [we]6281-we enter , tell [me]1325-the black squire of [Sir Geoffrey of Lea]164-sir geoffrey of lea , and why it was that [they]3423-they might not abide the uncouth things , or if there were any such . [Spake Leonard]139-birdalone : Things uncouth there were , and [I]1325-the black squire was called upon to lay them , and [I]1325-the black squire did as biddeth Holy Church in all wise , but prevailed not against [them]3423-they , and still were [they]3423-they seen and heard , till [folk]4521-folk might endure it no longer . And what like were these things ? said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and are they yet seen and heard ? Said [Leonard]139-birdalone : Strange it is , but last night [I]1325-the black squire went into [the great hall]1480-the great hall where [they]3423-they mostly betid , and laid [me]1325-the black squire down there , as whiles [I]1325-the black squire do , for [I]1325-the black squire fear [them]3423-they not , and would see if [they]3423-they yet appear ; but all night came nothing at all . As to the likeness of [them]3423-they . . . Then [he]1325-the black squire stopped , but said presently : Hard it is to tell [thee]6284-thee of them , but needs must [I.]1325-the black squire There be two of these things ; and one is an image of [a tall woman of middle - age]6285-a tall woman of middle - age , red - haired , white - skinned , and meagre , and whiles [she]6285-a tall woman of middle - age has a twiggen rod in [her]6285-a tall woman of middle - age hand , and whiles a naked short sword , and whiles nought at all . But the voice of [her]6285-a tall woman of middle - age is cursing and blaspheming and ill - saying . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : This is then a fetch of [[my]1325-the black squire witch - mistress of whom [I]1325-the black squire told [thee]6284-thee erst , and the image of [her]6285-a tall woman of middle - age]6286-my witch - mistress of whom i told thee erst , and the image of her ; what is the other ? Said [Leonard]139-birdalone : [I]1325-the black squire were fain not to tell [thee]6284-thee . Yet needs must [thou]6284-thee , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone . [Dear lady]3090-dear lady , said [Leonard]139-birdalone , the other is an image of [thee]6284-thee , and even most like unto [thee]6284-thee ; but [whiles clad in a scanty grey coat and barefoot]6288-whiles clad in a scanty grey coat and barefoot , and [whiles clad in a fair green gown goodly broidered , and broidered shoon]6289-whiles clad in a fair green gown goodly broidered , and broidered shoon ; and whiles all mother - naked . And what voice cometh from [mine]1325-the black squire image ? said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , smiling , yet somewhat pale withal . Said [Leonard]139-birdalone : One while [a voice of sweet singing , as of a bird in the brake]6290-a voice of sweet singing , as of a bird in the brake , and that is when [thou]6284-thee art clad ; and again , when [thou]6284-thee art naked , a voice of shrieking and wailing , as of one enduring torments . [Spake Birdalone]110-birdalone : And when did these wonders begin ? Said [he]139-birdalone : Not till after [Sir Hugh]118-hugh and [[thy]6284-thee she - friends]6291-thy she - friends were gone hence . [Pondered Birdalone]108-birdalone a little ; then [she]108-birdalone said : [I]1325-the black squire see herein the malice of [[my]1325-the black squire witch - mistress]6292-my witch - mistress ; [she]6292-my witch - mistress would not send these fetches while [Hugh]118-hugh was [here]244-here , lest [he]118-hugh should turn to seeking [me]1325-the black squire with all [his]118-hugh might . But when [they]6294-they departed , [she]108-birdalone would have [the castle]1534-the castle waste , and then [she]108-birdalone sent [them]6294-they , wotting that thereby [she]108-birdalone would rid [her]108-birdalone of [Sir Geoffrey of Lea]164-sir geoffrey of lea ; while , on the other hand , [I]1325-the black squire was nought so much unto [him]164-sir geoffrey of lea that [he]164-sir geoffrey of lea would spend all [his]164-sir geoffrey of lea life seeking [me]1325-the black squire . But now [I]1325-the black squire deem [I]1325-the black squire know so much of [her]108-birdalone that [I]1325-the black squire may bid [thee]6296-thou to look on [her]108-birdalone as dead if these fetches come not again within a little while . Then mayst [thou]6296-thou send and do [Sir Geoffrey]164-sir geoffrey of lea to wit thereof , and belike [he]164-sir geoffrey of lea will come back again ; and fain were [I]1325-the black squire thereof for it will be merrier if [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest be dwelt in once more . [Yea]6298-yea , verily , said [Leonard]139-birdalone ; but far merrier yet [wert]6299-wert [thou]6296-thou to dwell [there]215-there . Nay , [she]108-birdalone said , but now [I]1325-the black squire see that it is not fated for [me]1325-the black squire . Let [us]6299-wert go in , for [I]1325-the black squire would get to what [I]1325-the black squire would do . So therewith [they]6299-wert passed under the shadow of the archway , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone stayed not but went straightway into [the hall]1193-the hall , and through [it]1193-the hall ; and [the priest]1677-the priest , who lagged somewhat behind [her]108-birdalone speedy feet , cried out unto [her]108-birdalone : Whither wilt [thou]1677-the priest ? what chamber wilt [thou]1677-the priest visit first ? But [she]108-birdalone stayed not , and spake to [him]1677-the priest over [her]108-birdalone shoulder as [she]108-birdalone went : Follow [me]1325-the black squire if [thou]1677-the priest wilt ; [I]1325-the black squire have but one place only to come to ere [I]1325-the black squire leave [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest , save [I]1325-the black squire must needs turn back on [my]1325-the black squire footsteps . Then [Leonard]139-birdalone came up with [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone went [her]108-birdalone ways out of [the hall]1193-the hall , and out on to the waterswale of [the castle]1534-the castle , and so to [the little haven of the water - gate]6306-the little haven of the water - gate . There [Birdalone]108-birdalone looked about [her]108-birdalone eagerly ; then [she]108-birdalone turned to [Leonard]139-birdalone and pointed with [her]108-birdalone finger and said : Lo [thou]1677-the priest ! there yet lieth [[my]1325-the black squire ferry]6307-my ferry of old time , [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat ; now wot [I]1325-the black squire wherefore [I]1325-the black squire was drawn hither . And [her]108-birdalone eyes glittered and [her]108-birdalone body quivered as [she]108-birdalone spake . [Yea]6309-yea forsooth , said [Leonard]139-birdalone , there it lieth ; who of [all folk in [the castle]1534-the castle]6310-all folk in the castle had durst to touch it ? But what hath it to do with [thee]1677-the priest , [[O]1677-the priest kindest lady]6312-o kindest lady ? [Friend]5069-friend , [she]108-birdalone said , if this day weareth , and [I]1325-the black squire am yet within these walls , then [meseemeth]6314-meseemeth there must [I]1325-the black squire abide for evermore ; and there perchance shall [I]1325-the black squire meet that seeming of [myself]1325-the black squire , maybe for this night , maybe for ever , till [I]1325-the black squire die here in [this castle]1662-this castle void of all that [I]1325-the black squire love , and [I]1325-the black squire over - young for it , [friend]5069-friend . And [I]1325-the black squire know now that there is hope within [me]1325-the black squire ; for [I]1325-the black squire bethink [me]1325-the black squire of [a dear friend over yonder water of whom [I]1325-the black squire have never told any]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any , nor will tell [thee]6318-thee now , save this , that [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any is the wisdom of [my]1325-the black squire life . Wherefore now [I]1325-the black squire will try [this ferry]5424-this ferry and wot if the wight thereof will yet obey the voice of [the speaker of the spell]6320-the speaker of the spell , who has shed of [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any blood to pay therefor . Put not forth a hand therefore nor speak a word to let [me]1325-the black squire , but take this farewell of [me]1325-the black squire , with [my]1325-the black squire pity and such love as [I]1325-the black squire may give [thee]6318-thee , and let [me]1325-the black squire go , and think kindly of [me]1325-the black squire . Then [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any went up to [him]1325-the black squire , and laid [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any hands upon [his]1325-the black squire shoulders , and kissed [him]1325-the black squire , and turned about without more ado and stepped into [the boat]850-the boat ; then [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any sat down and stripped [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any arm of its sleeve , and drew forth a knife and let blood of [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any arm , and then arose and smeared stem and stern therewith , and then sat down with [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any face to the stern and sang : The red raven - wine now Hast [thou]6318-thee drunk , stern and bow ; Wake then and awake And the Northward way take : The way of [the Wenders]6322-the wenders forth over [the flood]1025-the flood , For the will of [the Senders]4848-the senders is blent with the blood . Then [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any abode a little , while [Leonard]139-birdalone stood staring on [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any speechless with grief and blinded with [his]139-birdalone bitter tears , till [the boat]850-the boat began to move under [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any , and presently glided out of [the little haven]6326-the little haven into [the wide lake]5825-the wide lake ; then [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any turned [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any face back unto [him]1325-the black squire and waved [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any hand , and [he]1325-the black squire knelt down and blessed [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any , weeping . And so [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any vanished away from before [him]1325-the black squire . Chapter IX ~ Birdalone Findeth [the Isle of Nothing]32-the isle of nothing Greatly Bettered , and is Kindly Entreated There Now it was scarce noon when [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any departed , and the dark night came upon [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any in [the midst of [the water]347-the water]6328-the midst of the water ; and [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any fell asleep in [the boat]850-the boat ere the night had grown very old , and woke up in the morning , not exceeding early , maybe about six oâ€™clock ; then [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any looked ahead and thought presently to see the ill - favoured blotch of [the Isle of Nothing]1595-the isle of nothing on [the bosom of [the blue waters]6333-the blue waters]6332-the bosom of the blue waters , whereas it was a fair and cloudless morning of latter May. Sure enough [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any saw [land ahead]6334-land ahead , and it lay low down on [the water]347-the water , but [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any deemed from the first that it was green of hue , and as [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any neared it [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any saw that it was verily as green as emerald . Thereat [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any was a little troubled , because [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any thought that mayhappen the Sending Boat had gone astray , and that if [the wight thereof]6336-the wight thereof were not wending [the old road]6337-the old road , maybe [he]6336-the wight thereof was not making for [the old haven]6338-the old haven . For now indeed [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any told [herself]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any right out that [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any will was to go back again to [the House under [the Wood]4-the wood]4835-the house under the wood , and see what might betide there , and if [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any and [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother together might not overcome [the witch]394-the witch . But whatever might happen nought could [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any do but sit in [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any place and wend as [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat would ; and in an hour â€™s space [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any was right under the lee of [the land]198-the land , and [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any saw that it was shapen even as [the Isle of Nothing]32-the isle of nothing had been aforetime . But this made [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any wonder , that now the grass grew thick down to the lip of [the water]347-the water , and all about from [the water]347-the water up were many little slim trees , and some of them with the May - tide blossom yet on them , as though it were a fair and great orchard that [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any was nearing ; and moreover , beyond all that [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any saw the thatched roofs of [houses]6346-houses rising up . Presently then [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat had brought [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any to [the land]198-the land , and [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any stepped ashore , but was wary , and gat [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any bow bent and set an arrow thereto [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any began to go up from [the water]347-the water . Yet [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any thought within [herself]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any , it will be nought ill if [I]1325-the black squire be come amongst [folk]4521-folk , so long as [they]4521-folk be peaceful , or else how might [I]1325-the black squire live the journey out to [all the isles]6351-all the isles and so [home]373-home to [the House under [the Wood]4-the wood]4835-the house under the wood ? So [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any turned [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any face to where [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any had seen [those roofs]6354-those roofs , which now [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any saw no longer because of the thick leaves of the little trees , and so went along [a narrow path]6355-a narrow path , which grew to be more and more closely beset with trees , and were now no longer apple and pear and quince and medlar , but a young - grown thicket of woodland trees , as oak and hornbeam and beech and holly . At last as [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any went [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any heard voices before [her]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any , so [she]6317-a dear friend over yonder water of whom i have never told any stole warily to the edge of the copse , finger on shaft ; and presently could see clear of the saplings and out on to [a wide space of greensward]6356-a wide space of greensward , beyond which was [a homestead of many houses]6357-a homestead of many houses and bowers , like unto that of [a good yeoman]6358-a good yeoman in [peaceful lands]6359-peaceful lands , save that [the main building]6360-the main building was longer , though [it]6360-the main building were low . But amidst [the said greensward]6361-the said greensward was [a goodly flock of sheep that had been but of late washed for the shearing]6362-a goodly flock of sheep that had been but of late washed for the shearing , and along with [the sheep]6363-the sheep [four folk]6364-four folk , [two carles]6365-two carles and [two queans]6366-two queans , [all of [them]6364-four folk in [their]6364-four folk first youth]6367-all of them in their first youth , [not one by seeming of over a score and two of summers]6368-not one by seeming of over a score and two of summers . [These folk]4537-these folk were clad but simply , [man]537-man and [woman]1470-woman , in short coats of white woollen ( but [the women]1990-the women â€™s coats a little longer than [the men]4811-the men â€™s ) , without [shoon or hosen]6374-shoon or hosen ; [they]4537-these folk had garlands of green leaves on [their]4537-these folk heads , and were wholly unarmed , save that [one of [the men]4811-the men]6375-one of the men bore an ashen wand in [his]6375-one of the men hand . As for [their]4537-these folk bodies , [they]4537-these folk were goodly of fashion , tanned indeed by the sun â€™s burning , but all sweet of flesh were [they]4537-these folk , shapely and trim , clean - made , and light and slim . [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s heart yearned toward [them]4537-these folk , and [she]108-birdalone stepped straightway from out of the cover of the coppice , and the sun flamed from [her]108-birdalone sallet and glittered in the rings of [her]108-birdalone hauberk , so that [the folk]228-the folk might not fail to see [her]108-birdalone ; the sheep fled bundling from [her]108-birdalone past [[their]4537-these folk keepers]6378-their keepers , who stood firm , but seemed somewhat scared , and moved not toward [Birdalone]108-birdalone . [She]108-birdalone gave [them]4537-these folk the sele of the day and stood still [herself]108-birdalone ; but [the man with the ash - wand]6379-the man with the ash - wand said : Hail , [[thou]108-birdalone man]6380-thou man ; but [we]6381-we would have [thee]108-birdalone come no nearer a while , though [thy]108-birdalone voice be sweet : for [we]6381-we know what things they be which [thou]108-birdalone bearest , and that [thou]108-birdalone art [a warrior]2458-a warrior . Wilt [thou]108-birdalone hurt [us]6381-we ? [Birdalone]108-birdalone laughed as sweetly as the blackbird sings , and [she]108-birdalone did off [her]108-birdalone sallet and shook the plenteous hair down over [her]108-birdalone , and then drew forth [her]108-birdalone sword and dagger and cast them to earth , and laid [her]108-birdalone bow and quiver of arrows upon [them]4537-these folk , and said : Now will [I]1325-the black squire come to [you]6379-the man with the ash - wand , or [ye]6379-the man with the ash - wand shall come to [me]1325-the black squire , whereas [I]1325-the black squire am unweaponed , and [no warrior]6383-no warrior , but [a woman]235-a woman , and [ye]6379-the man with the ash - wand are four to one , and two of [[you]6379-the man with the ash - wand carles]6385-you carles ; wherefore now [ye]6379-the man with the ash - wand may bind [me]1325-the black squire or slay [me]1325-the black squire if [you]6379-the man with the ash - wand will ; but in any case [I]1325-the black squire pray [you]6379-the man with the ash - wand first to give [me]1325-the black squire a mouthful of meat . When [she]108-birdalone had done [her]108-birdalone speech , [she]108-birdalone went up to [the fairest of [the women]1990-the women]6386-the fairest of the women and kissed [her]6386-the fairest of the women ; but [the two carles]6388-the two carles made no more ado but came to [Birdalone]108-birdalone and kissed [her]108-birdalone one after other , and that as [men who needed nought to compel [them]6388-the two carles therein]6389-men who needed nought to compel them therein , and [each thereafter]6390-each thereafter took a hand of [her]108-birdalone and held it and caressed it . But [the other woman]6391-the other woman had run into [the house]311-the house as soon as [Birdalone]108-birdalone spoke , and came back again with a treen bowl full of milk and a little loaf , not white but brown ; and there blundered about [her]108-birdalone legs as [she]108-birdalone came [a little lad of some three winters old]6393-a little lad of some three winters old , naked and brown , who was shy of [the gleaming new - comer]6394-the gleaming new - comer , and hid [him]6393-a little lad of some three winters old behind [the woman]237-the woman one while , and [the other while]6396-the other while came forth to see the new thing . But [the woman]237-the woman said : [Dear woman]6398-dear woman , here is for [thee]6398-dear woman some of the ewes â€™[1325-the black squire] milk , and a bite of bread , and a little deal of cheese ; the said milk is yet warm , so that it is not yet clottered ; but if [thou]3432-thou wilt come with [us]3433-us [thou]3432-thou mayest speedily drink cows â€™ milk , and [we]3433-us be now at point to go milk them . [Birdalone]108-birdalone thanked [her]237-the woman with a heart full of content , and was not ill - pleased to get [her]108-birdalone hands free from [the two carles]6388-the two carles ; so [she]108-birdalone sat down and ate [her]108-birdalone breakfast while [they]6388-the two carles talked with [her]108-birdalone , and told [her]108-birdalone of diverse work of [theirs]6388-the two carles ; as to how [their]6388-the two carles trees were waxing , and new tillage [they]6388-the two carles had done the past spring , and how it befell to the kine and the goats ; of [[their]6388-the two carles children]6400-their children also [they]6388-the two carles spake , and how there were already four thereof , and [one of [the women]1990-the women]6401-one of the women , [the meat - bringer]6403-the meat - bringer , already quickened with [child]283-child once more . So that ere [we]3433-us die , quoth [the carle who was speaking]6405-the carle who was speaking , [we]3433-us look to see [many grandchildren]6406-many grandchildren , and shall have some stout carles and queans here . And by that time will some of the trees be well grown , so that [we]3433-us may fell timber and make [us]3433-us some keel that will wend [the lake]355-the lake , and help [us]3433-us a - fishing ; or [we]3433-us may go to [other lands]6408-other lands ; or [whiles folk]6409-whiles folk may come to [us]3433-us , even as [thou]6410-thou hast , [[thou]6410-thou dear - handed , [sweet - voiced woman]6412-sweet - voiced woman]6411-thou dear - handed , sweet - voiced woman . But wilt [thou]6410-thou abide here ever ? [Yea]6413-yea , said [the other]250-the other , but that is looking forward a long while , that building of [ships]6415-ships . What is nearer and well to think of is , that these apple and pear trees be so well fruited , small as they be , that this harvest [we]3433-us shall be able to make [us]3433-us cider and perry ; yea , and no little deal thereof . But art [thou]6410-thou minded to abide with [us]3433-us ever ? That were dear to [us]3433-us ; and belike [thou]6410-thou wouldest bear [us]3433-us [children]1274-children , [thou]6410-thou also . Then spake [the meat - fetching woman]6417-the meat - fetching woman and laughed withal : Nay , [thou]6410-thou also lookest aloof a pretty deal ; whereas what is now to do is to go milk the kine , and to take [this guest]6418-this guest with [us]3434-they , so that [she]6418-this guest may drink somewhat better than ewes â€™[0-i] milk though the cider be not ready to hand . But tell [me]0-i , [[our]3434-they dear guest]3435-our dear guest , art [thou]3435-our dear guest verily going to abide with [us]3434-they a long while ? that were sweet to [us]3434-they , and [we]3434-they will do all [we]3434-they may to pleasure [thee]3435-our dear guest . Nay , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , it will no better be but that [I]0-i depart on the morrow ; and all thanks do [I]0-i give [you]3435-our dear guest for [your]3435-our dear guest kindness . [The woman]237-the woman kissed [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone arose , and all [they]3434-they went together to the milking of the kine some half mile inland ; and [they]3434-they passed through much of orchard , and some deal of tillage , wherein the wheat was already growing high ; and so came [they]3434-they to [a wide meadow]3437-a wide meadow through which ran [a little stream]3438-a little stream , and therein was a goodly herd of kine . So [they]3434-they fell to the milking , and made [Birdalone]108-birdalone drink of the sweet cows â€™ milk , and then went and lay down under the shade of the little young trees , and talked and were merry together . But [the men]4811-the men were both of [them]4811-the men somewhat willing at first to kiss [Birdalone]108-birdalone and toy with [her]108-birdalone , but when [she]108-birdalone let [them]4811-the men know that [she]108-birdalone desired it not [they]4811-the men refrained [them]4811-the men without grudging . All this while of [their]3434-they talk [they]3434-they asked [Birdalone]108-birdalone nought of whence and whither , and [she]108-birdalone would not ask [them]4811-the men , lest it might stir [their]4811-the men asking , and then [she]108-birdalone would have to tell [them]4811-the men some deal of [her]108-birdalone story ; and telling it was now become unto [her]108-birdalone somewhat weary work . In a while [they]3434-they arose all , and [the men]4811-the men and [one woman]6421-one woman went [their]3434-they ways to deal with [the acre - land]454-the acre - land , but [the meat - fetcher]6423-the meat - fetcher went back with [Birdalone]108-birdalone into [the house]311-the house ; and [she]108-birdalone showed [her]108-birdalone all that was therein , which was for the more part , forsooth , [the four babes]6425-the four babes aforesaid . [The others]1287-the others came back in the eventide , bearing with [them]1287-the others foison of blue hare - bells , and telling joyously how [they]1287-the others had found [them]4811-the men anigh the coppice edge in such a place : and thereafter [they]1287-the others were merry , and sang and talked the evening away , and showed [Birdalone]108-birdalone at last to [a fair little chamber wherein was a bed of dry grass , where [she]108-birdalone lay down and slept in all content]6427-a fair little chamber wherein was a bed of dry grass , where she lay down and slept in all content . Chapter X ~ Of [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s Flitting from [the Isle of Nothing]32-the isle of nothing On the morrow [Birdalone]108-birdalone arose betimes , and would not tarry despite all the kindness of [that folk]6428-that folk and the change which had come over [the Isle of Nothing]32-the isle of nothing ; so [the friends]6429-the friends saw [her]108-birdalone down to [the boat]850-the boat all together , and bore down with [them]6429-the friends a deal of bread and cheese and late apples of the last year , for [her]108-birdalone provision on [the road]1797-the road , and a pail of milk withal ; and [men]204-men and [women]420-women [they]6429-the friends kissed [her]108-birdalone at departure , and [the meat - fetcher]6423-the meat - fetcher said : If by any means [thou]6435-thee mayst find a keel which will carry [thee]6435-thee hither , at some time , [I]108-birdalone would [thou]6435-thee wouldst come ; for even if [thou]6435-thee be old , and [we]6436-we passed away , yet here shall be [[our]6436-we children]6437-our children or [[our]6436-we grandchildren]6438-our grandchildren to welcome [thee]6435-thee ; and [we]6436-we will tell [them]6429-the friends the tale of [thee]6435-thee that [they]6429-the friends remember it and long for [thee]6435-thee . Then [Birdalone]108-birdalone kissed [her]108-birdalone again , and made much of [her]108-birdalone , and so stepped into [the boat]850-the boat , and fell to [her]108-birdalone sacrifice to the wight thereof ; and [those others]1785-those others stared at [her]108-birdalone and wondered , and spake nought unto [her]108-birdalone till [she]108-birdalone was gone gliding over the face of [the waters]624-the waters ; but as [they]1785-those others walked back to [the house]311-the house , [they]1785-those others spake amongst [themselves]1785-those others that this must be [some goddess ( for of [Holy Church]163-holy church [they]1785-those others knew nought ) who had come to visit [them]1785-those others in [her]6443-some goddess ( for of holy church they knew nought ) who had come to visit them in her loveliness loveliness]6443-some goddess ( for of holy church they knew nought ) who had come to visit them in her loveliness ; and in after times , when [this folk waxed a many]6444-this folk waxed a many , and tilled [all the isle]6445-all the isle and made [ships]6415-ships and spread to [other lands]6408-other lands and became great , [they]1785-those others yet had a memory of [Birdalone]108-birdalone as [[their]1785-those others own very lady]6448-their own very lady and goddess , who had come from [the fertile and wise lands]6449-the fertile and wise lands to bless [them]1785-those others , when first [they]1785-those others began to engender on [that isle]6450-that isle , and had broken bread with [them]1785-those others , and slept under [their]1785-those others roof , and then departed in a wonderful fashion , as might be looked for of [a goddess]6451-a goddess . But as for [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [she]108-birdalone came not back ever , nor saw [that folk]6428-that folk again , and now [she]108-birdalone sped over [the water]347-the water toward [the Isle of Kings]4853-the isle of kings . Chapter XI ~ Coming to [the Isle of Kings]4853-the isle of kings [Birdalone]108-birdalone Findeth There A Score and Two of Fair [Damsels Who Would Fain Have]116-damsels [Her]108-birdalone Company [Birdalone]108-birdalone came ashore at [the said isle]1885-the said isle at the day - dawn , and saw but little change in [the isle]631-the isle when it grew light , and still [the castle]1534-the castle stood looking down awfully on to [the meadows]1769-the meadows . But when [she]108-birdalone had set foot on [the land]198-the land , [she]108-birdalone handled [her]108-birdalone bow lest the worst might befall , and looked about [her]108-birdalone , deeming that this time [she]108-birdalone would not go [her]108-birdalone ways to the dread show that was arrayed in [the castle]1534-the castle , if forsooth [those dead folk]6462-those dead folk yet abode [there]215-there . So now as [she]108-birdalone looked across [the meadow]499-the meadow , [she]108-birdalone saw [one with light and fluttering raiment]6465-one with light and fluttering raiment come forth from the trees , and look toward [her]108-birdalone whereas [she]108-birdalone stood flashing and gleaming in the sun like an image of [the God of Love turned warrior]6466-the god of love turned warrior . Now [Birdalone]108-birdalone deemed for sure that this was [a woman]235-a woman ; [she]108-birdalone saw [her]108-birdalone come a little nigher to [her]108-birdalone , and then stand looking at [her]108-birdalone under the sharp of [her]108-birdalone hand ; then [she]108-birdalone turned about and ran back to the brake whence [she]108-birdalone came ; and presently [Birdalone]108-birdalone heard the sound of voices coming thence , and in a little while thereafter came forth from [the said brake]6468-the said brake a rout of [women]420-women ( one score and two as [they]420-women were told thereafter ) and walked over [the meadow]499-the meadow straight unto [her]108-birdalone . [She]108-birdalone stood where [she]108-birdalone was , so as to be nigh unto [her]108-birdalone ferry in case [they]420-women willed [her]108-birdalone unpeace ; for though [they]420-women were weaponless by seeming , [they]420-women were [a many]6471-a many . When [they]420-women were come near [they]420-women stood about [her]108-birdalone in a half ring , whispering and laughing each to [each]4577-each . [Birdalone]108-birdalone saw that [they]420-women were all young , and that none of [them]420-women might be called ungoodly , and [some were full fair]6473-some were full fair . [They]420-women were bright and fine of array . Most bore gold and gems on fingers and neck and arms ; [they]420-women were clad in light , or it may be said wanton raiment of diverse colours , which had only this of [their]420-women fashion in common , that [they]420-women none of [them]420-women hid over - much of [their]420-women bare bodies ; for either the silk slipped from the shoulder of [her]108-birdalone , or danced away from [her]108-birdalone flank ; and [she]108-birdalone whose feet were shod , spared not to show knee and some deal of thigh ; and [she]108-birdalone whose gown reached unsheared from neck to heel , wore it of a web so thin and fine that it hid but little betwixt heel and neck . [Birdalone]108-birdalone stood gazing on [them]420-women and wondering , and [she]108-birdalone had a mind to think that [they]420-women were some show sent by [[her]108-birdalone old mistress]4951-her old mistress [the witch]394-the witch for [her]4951-her old mistress undoing , and [she]108-birdalone loosened [her]108-birdalone sword in its sheath and nocked an arrow . But then ran forward [two of [the damsels]4538-the damsels]6476-two of the damsels and knelt before [her]108-birdalone , and [each]4577-each took an hand of [her]108-birdalone and fell to kissing it , and [she]108-birdalone felt [their]420-women hands that [they]420-women were firm and [their]420-women lips that they were soft and warm , and [they]420-women were doubtless alive and real . Then spake one of [them]420-women and said : Hail [[our]4538-the damsels lord]6479-our lord ! How can words say how [we]4538-the damsels rejoice in [thy]6479-our lord coming this happy morn ! Now do all [we]4538-the damsels give [ourselves]4538-the damsels to [thee]6479-our lord as [[thy]6479-our lord slaves]6480-thy slaves to do as [thou]6479-our lord wilt with . Yet [we]4538-the damsels pray [thee]6479-our lord be merciful to [us]4538-the damsels and [our]4538-the damsels longings . Therewith [all the sort of [them]420-women]6481-all the sort of them knelt down on the grass before [Birdalone]108-birdalone and joined [their]420-women hands as praying to [her]108-birdalone . And [Birdalone]108-birdalone was full ill at ease , and wotted not where [she]108-birdalone was . But [she]108-birdalone said : Hail ! and good days and fulfilment of wishes unto [you]420-women , [fair damsels]6482-fair damsels ! But tell [me]108-birdalone , is this [the Isle of [Kings]421-kings]54-the isle of kings , as [I]108-birdalone deemed ; for strange it is for [me]108-birdalone to see [[ye]420-women womenfolk here]6484-ye womenfolk here ? Said [she]108-birdalone who had spoken afore : [Yea]420-women verily this is [the Isle of [Kings]421-kings]4853-the isle of kings ; but long ago are [the kings]1576-the kings dead , and yet [they]1576-the kings sit dead in [the great hall of [the castle yonder]6489-the castle yonder]6488-the great hall of the castle yonder , as [thou]420-women mayst see if [thou]420-women , who art [a man]217-a man and [a valiant warrior]6491-a valiant warrior , durst follow up [yon mountain path thereto]6492-yon mountain path thereto ; but [we]6493-we , [weak women]6494-weak women and [little - hearted]6495-little - hearted , durst not go anigh it ; and [we]6493-we tremble when whiles a - nights cometh down thence the sound of clashing swords and clattering shields , and the cries of [men]204-men in battle . But , praise be to [the God of Love]6497-the god of love , nought cometh down from thence unto [us]6493-we . Therefore do [we]6493-we live peaceful lives and pleasant here , lacking nought but [thee]6498-thee , [lord]2064-lord ; and lo now [thou]420-women hast come unto [us]6493-we , and [we]6493-we are happy in [our]6493-we inmost hearts . Now was [Birdalone]108-birdalone perplexed and knew not what to do ; but at last [she]108-birdalone said : [Gentle maidens]6500-gentle maidens , [I]108-birdalone pray [you]6500-gentle maidens pardon [me]108-birdalone , but [I]108-birdalone must depart straightway ; for [I]108-birdalone have an errand , and life or death lieth on it . In all else than [my]108-birdalone abiding here may [ye]6500-gentle maidens have [your]6500-gentle maidens will . Therewith did [she]108-birdalone move a little way toward [[her]108-birdalone ferry]4501-her ferry ; but forthwith all [they]6500-gentle maidens brake out weeping and wailing and lamenting , and [some of [them]6500-gentle maidens]6502-some of them came up to [Birdalone]108-birdalone and cast [themselves]6502-some of them down before [her]108-birdalone , and clasped [her]108-birdalone knees , and took hold of [her]108-birdalone skirts , and besought [her]108-birdalone piteously to abide with [them]6502-some of them . But [she]108-birdalone put [them]6502-some of them aside as well as [she]108-birdalone might , and stepped aboard [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat , and stood amidst [it]823-the sending boat waiting on [their]6500-gentle maidens departure ; but [they]6500-gentle maidens went not , and stood along on the lip of [the land]198-the land crying out and beseeching with much clamour . Then [Birdalone]108-birdalone waxed somewhat wrath at [their]6500-gentle maidens noise and tumult , and [she]108-birdalone drew forth [her]108-birdalone knife and bared [her]108-birdalone arm and let blood from it . But when [they]6500-gentle maidens saw the whiteness and roundness of it , and how fine and sleek it was , straightway [they]6500-gentle maidens changed [their]6500-gentle maidens tune , and cried out : [A woman]235-a woman , [a woman]235-a woman , [a fool of a woman]6507-a fool of a woman ! and [they]6500-gentle maidens laughed in scorn and mockery . And [the speaker of [them]6500-gentle maidens]6508-the speaker of them said : Now there is but one thing for [thee]108-birdalone to do , and that is to come forth from [[thy]108-birdalone boat]6509-thy boat and strip off [thy]108-birdalone stolen raiment , and [we]6500-gentle maidens shall make [thee]108-birdalone as fine as [ourselves]6500-gentle maidens , and [thou]108-birdalone shalt come with [us]6500-gentle maidens , and with [us]6500-gentle maidens abide the coming of [[our]6500-gentle maidens lord]6479-our lord . Nay , [thou]108-birdalone art so fair and lovely , that [thou]108-birdalone shalt be [the Lady]1145-the lady and [Queen of [us]6500-gentle maidens]6512-queen of us , and [we]6500-gentle maidens will do after [thy]108-birdalone commands , and [thou]108-birdalone mayst chastise [us]6500-gentle maidens if [we]6500-gentle maidens fail therein . But now if [thou]108-birdalone wilt not come forth of [the boat]850-the boat uncompelled , [we]6500-gentle maidens shall pluck [thee]108-birdalone forth of it . And therewith [she]108-birdalone set [her]108-birdalone foot on the gunwale of [the boat]850-the boat , and [two or three others]6515-two or three others did the like . But now had [Birdalone]108-birdalone [her]108-birdalone sword naked in [her]108-birdalone hand , and [she]108-birdalone waxed as red as blood , and cried out : Forbear [I]108-birdalone bid [you]6516-ye ! [Yea]6516-ye verily [I]108-birdalone am [a woman]235-a woman ; but [I]108-birdalone will not take this offer either , whereas [I]108-birdalone have an errand , as [I]108-birdalone told [you]6516-ye . And so stern it is , that if [ye]6516-ye now let [my]108-birdalone departure [I]108-birdalone will not spare to smite with this sword whoso first cometh aboard [[my]108-birdalone ferry]6307-my ferry , and though [I]108-birdalone be not [a man]217-a man , yet shall [ye]6516-ye find that in this matter [I]108-birdalone shall be little worse , whereas [I]108-birdalone am armed and [ye]6516-ye be naked . Then [they]6516-ye drew back and stood gibing and jeering at [her]108-birdalone ; but [she]108-birdalone heeded it no whit , but reddened stem and stern of [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat , and sang [her]108-birdalone spell , and forth glided [the ferry]4467-the ferry , while [the damsels]4538-the damsels stood and stared astonished . As for [Birdalone]108-birdalone , as [she]108-birdalone sped on [her]108-birdalone way [she]108-birdalone might not refrain [her]108-birdalone laughter . Thus [she]108-birdalone wended [the wet highway]6523-the wet highway . Chapter XII ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone Cometh Again to [the Isle of Queens]4854-the isle of queens , and Findeth A Perilous Adventure Therein It was not yet daybreak when [Birdalone]108-birdalone came ashore again , and the moon was down , and it was dark ; wherefore [she]108-birdalone durst not go up on [the land]198-the land , but lay down in [the ferry]4467-the ferry and fell asleep there . When [she]108-birdalone woke again it was broad daylight , the sun was up , and a little ripple was running over the face of [the water]347-the water . [She]108-birdalone stepped ashore straightway , and looked up [the land]198-the land and to the right hand and the left , and saw at once that it was indeed [the Isle of [Queens]108-birdalone]53-the isle of queens , and [the house]311-the house stood trim and lovely as of old time ; then [she]108-birdalone longed somewhat to tread [the green meadow]6530-the green meadow a little , for yet young was the day , and [she]108-birdalone saw nought stirring save the throstle and a few small beasts . However , [she]108-birdalone said to [herself]108-birdalone that [she]108-birdalone would go nowhere nigh to [the goodly house wherein abode those images of death]6531-the goodly house wherein abode those images of death . Yet [her]108-birdalone body longed so sore for the springtide freshness of the grass , and was so bewooed of the flowery scent thereof , that though [she]108-birdalone durst not go unarmed , [she]108-birdalone did off [her]108-birdalone footgear and went stealing softly barefoot and with naked legs over the embroidered greensward , saying aloud to [herself]108-birdalone : If run for [the ferry]4467-the ferry [I]108-birdalone needs must , lighter shall [I]108-birdalone run so dight . Nonetheless , [she]108-birdalone had gone but a little way ere a terror took hold of [her]108-birdalone , though [she]108-birdalone saw [no child of [Adam anigh]96-adam]6533-no child of adam anigh , and [she]108-birdalone turned and ran back swiftly to [[her]108-birdalone old place]6534-her old place and sat down under a twisted oak - tree hard by the Sending Boat , and abode there panting and quaking , and scarce daring to look up from the grass for a while . Then [her]108-birdalone heart came back to [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone laughed , and said to [herself]108-birdalone : [I]108-birdalone am [a fool]482-a fool , for [I]108-birdalone need fear nought on [this Isle of [Queens]108-birdalone]6536-this isle of queens save [women like [myself]108-birdalone]6537-women like myself . Yet [she]108-birdalone sat there a little while longer without stirring ; then [she]108-birdalone stood up and looked keenly around , and , as aforesaid , exceeding far - sighted [she]108-birdalone was ; but still [she]108-birdalone saw [neither man]6538-neither man nor [maid]6539-maid nor [suckling child]6540-suckling child . Then [her]108-birdalone eyes sought the lips of [the lake]355-the lake , and rested on a little bight some stone â€™s throw ahead of [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat , where , a little back from [the water]347-the water , slim willows made a veil betwixt [the water of [the meadow]499-the meadow]6544-the water of the meadow ; and [she]108-birdalone looked , and saw how pleasant a place it were for [a one]6546-a one to stand and look on the ripple just left , while the water dripped from the clear body on to the grass . And [her]108-birdalone bare feet fell to telling [her]108-birdalone clad sides of the sweet coolness of the water , and waited for no naysay , but lightly bore [her]108-birdalone toward [the willowy bight]6547-the willowy bight . And when [she]108-birdalone was there , [she]108-birdalone did off [her]108-birdalone sallet and ungirt [her]108-birdalone , and laid [her]108-birdalone sword on the grass , and did off [her]108-birdalone surcoat and hauberk , and so was [a woman]235-a woman again in one white coat above [her]108-birdalone smock . Then [she]108-birdalone looked heedfully betwixt [the willow - boughs]6549-the willow - boughs , and saw no more than before , nought but a little whitethorn brake , now white indeed with blossom , some fifty yards landward from where [she]108-birdalone stood . So [she]108-birdalone laughed , and did off [her]108-birdalone other raiment , and slid swiftly into [the water]347-the water , that embraced [her]108-birdalone body in all its fresh kindness ; and as for [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [she]108-birdalone rewarded it well for its past toil by sporting and swimming to [her]108-birdalone full . Then [she]108-birdalone came forth from [the water]347-the water , and clad [herself]108-birdalone in no great haste , and did on [her]108-birdalone hauberk and sallet and sword , and so went back to [her]108-birdalone place , and sat down and began to do on [her]108-birdalone foot - gear . But as [she]108-birdalone looked up from [her]108-birdalone work a moment , lo ! [a tall man coming toward [her]108-birdalone]6552-a tall man coming toward her , and just about the willows whereby [she]108-birdalone had bathed . [Her]108-birdalone heart beat quick and [her]108-birdalone face changed , yet [she]108-birdalone hastened , and was shod and stood up in knightly array by then [he]6552-a tall man coming toward her stayed [his]6552-a tall man coming toward her steps some five paces from [her]108-birdalone , and gave [her]108-birdalone the sele of the day in courteous wise ; and [she]108-birdalone strove to think that [he]6552-a tall man coming toward her had not seen [her]108-birdalone , or at least noted [her]108-birdalone otherwise dight ; yet [her]108-birdalone heart misgave [her]108-birdalone . [He]6552-a tall man coming toward her was [a grizzled - haired man of over fifty summers by seeming , but goodly enough and well - knit]6553-a grizzled - haired man of over fifty summers by seeming , but goodly enough and well - knit ; [he]6552-a tall man coming toward her was clad in a green coat more than a little worn , but made after the fashion of knighthood ; [he]6552-a tall man coming toward her had nought on [his]6552-a tall man coming toward her head but an oak - chaplet , and no weapons but a short sword by [his]6552-a tall man coming toward her side and a stout staff in [his]6552-a tall man coming toward her hand . [She]108-birdalone gave back [his]6552-a tall man coming toward her greeting in a quavering voice ; and [he]6552-a tall man coming toward her said : Welcome again , [young man]6554-young man . Art [thou]108-birdalone come to dwell with [us]6555-us ? Truly [thou]108-birdalone art trim now , but ere some few months [thine]108-birdalone attire will be not so much fairer than [ours]6555-us , and thine hauberk will be rusted , for here be no joyous tiltings nor deeds of arms , and [no kind ladies to give the award of honour]6556-no kind ladies to give the award of honour , so that if [we]6555-us fight amongst [ourselves]6555-us it will be because [we]6555-us have fallen out , and spitefully . Yet ( and [he]6552-a tall man coming toward her laughed , mockingly , as [she]108-birdalone thought ) [thou]108-birdalone mayst bring [us]6555-us luck , and draw [some fair damsels]6557-some fair damsels unto [us]6555-us , for that is what [we]6555-us await in [this isle]4486-this isle , which is barren of [their]6557-some fair damsels fair bodies , despite of its deceitful name . Thereat [Birdalone]108-birdalone reddened , deeming that [he]6552-a tall man coming toward her divined [her]108-birdalone womanhood , but [she]108-birdalone enforced [her]108-birdalone to speak hardily , and as manly as [she]108-birdalone might , and said : [Yea]6559-yea , [fair sir]1675-fair sir , and if [I]108-birdalone be [the God of Love]6497-the god of love , as [thou]108-birdalone deemest , and not merely [a poor squire]6562-a poor squire ( [Louis Delahaye]187-louis delahaye , at [thy]108-birdalone service ) , how many damsels shall [I]108-birdalone send [thee]108-birdalone if there must needs be one to [each man of [you]108-birdalone]6563-each man of you ? Quoth [he]6552-a tall man coming toward her : [Thou]108-birdalone must make up the tale to a score or more , or some of [us]6564-we must lack . Sooth to say , at this time [thou]108-birdalone needest not haste overmuch for all the tale , whereas there is but one other of [the company near at hand]6565-the company near at hand , [a mere foolish young man]6566-a mere foolish young man ; the others are gone to [the leeward side of [the isle]631-the isle]6567-the leeward side of the isle , to fetch [us]6564-we venison and fish , both of which are more plenty there than here ; wherefore are [we]6564-we two somewhat lonesome in this stead , all the more as [we]6564-we be over - nigh to the sorcery in [the great house]6569-the great house , which [we]6564-we durst not enter ; for though nought cometh out thence down unto [us]6564-we , yet hear [we]6564-we a - night - tides , first songs , and then cries and shrieking , come out therefrom . Then [he]6552-a tall man coming toward her stayed [his]6552-a tall man coming toward her speech , and drew a little nigher to [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and then grinned , and said : Forsooth [we]6564-we can spare [him]6552-a tall man coming toward her , [we]6564-we twain . And [he]6552-a tall man coming toward her looked on [her]108-birdalone hard , and the colour came into [her]108-birdalone cheeks , and [she]108-birdalone laughed uneasily , as [a dainty lady]6570-a dainty lady when [she]108-birdalone heareth some unmeet tale . But again [the old carle]4662-the old carle drew nigher to [her]108-birdalone , and said : [Thou]6572-thou seemest to have a good bow and store of arrows ; if [thou]6572-thou wouldst lend them to [me]108-birdalone for a little , and come with [me]108-birdalone into the wood hard by , [I]108-birdalone might shoot [thee]108-birdalone some venison with little toil to [thee]108-birdalone ; whereas , forsooth , [thou]6572-thou lookest scarce like one who is meet for over - much toil . Again [she]108-birdalone reddened , and spake nought this time ; and [he]4662-the old carle said : Deem not there be no deer [this end of [the isle]631-the isle]6573-this end of the isle because [I]108-birdalone said that [the others]1287-the others were gone to fetch [home venison]6576-home venison ; only the deer be tamer there and more , and [we]6577-we have but evil shooting - gear , whereas [thou]6572-thou art well found therein . Wilt [thou]6572-thou not come ? [we]6577-we shall have merry feast after the hunt . Now had [Birdalone]108-birdalone come to [her]108-birdalone wits again , and [she]108-birdalone answered like [a merry youth]6578-a merry youth , with a flavour of mockery in [her]108-birdalone speech : Fair sir , [thou]6572-thou shalt not deem that [I]108-birdalone need much help in slaying the dun deer ; for [I]108-birdalone do [thee]6572-thou to wit that [I]108-birdalone shoot not ill in the bow ; neither am [I]108-birdalone heavy - footed . But [I]108-birdalone will not hunt in [[your]6572-thou park]6579-your park today , for [I]108-birdalone have an errand which calleth [me]108-birdalone away , so that [I]108-birdalone shall depart hence presently . Besides , [wise elder]6580-wise elder , there is thine errand to see to ; and if [I]108-birdalone be [the God of Love]6497-the god of love , as [thou]6572-thou sayest , [I]108-birdalone must not keep [thee]6572-thou and [[thy]6572-thou valiant fellows]6582-thy valiant fellows languishing mateless ; so with [thy]6572-thou leave [I]108-birdalone will now depart , that [I]108-birdalone may send [you]6572-thou a score of fair damsels for [your]6572-thou company . And [she]108-birdalone turned about and made a step toward [[her]108-birdalone boat]6583-her boat ; but [the carle]1429-the carle drew nearer , laughing ; and [he]1429-the carle said : Truly sayest [thou]6572-thou that [thou]6572-thou art not heavy - footed , for never saw [I]108-birdalone feet lighter or fairer than glided over [the meadow eâ€™en]6585-the meadow eâ€™en now ; nor a fairer body than came like rosy - tinted pearl fresh out of the water while [I]108-birdalone lay hidden in yonder thorn - brake that while . Wherefore trouble not [thyself]6586-thyself to bring any more damsels than [thyself]6586-thyself , [fairest Goddess of Love]6587-fairest goddess of love , for [thou]6572-thou art enough for [me]108-birdalone . And therewith [he]1429-the carle ran forward , and stretched out a hand to [her]108-birdalone ; but in that nick of time had [she]108-birdalone [her]108-birdalone sword naked in [her]108-birdalone hand , and [the carle]1429-the carle drew back before the glitter thereof , and cried out : Ho , ho ! is it to be battle , [[my]108-birdalone mistress]4401-my mistress ? Deemest [thou]6572-thou that [thou]6572-thou wilt slay [me]108-birdalone as lightly as the dun deer , and [thou]6572-thou with [thy]6572-thou bow unstrung at [thy]6572-thou back ? Now shall [I]108-birdalone show [thee]6572-thou a trick of fence ; but fear not that [I]108-birdalone shall hurt [thee]6572-thou to spoil [thee]6572-thou . [He]1429-the carle advanced on [her]108-birdalone with [his]1429-the carle staff aloft , and [her]108-birdalone heart failed [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone quaked , and lightly [he]1429-the carle beat down [her]108-birdalone guard and did the sword out of [her]108-birdalone hand ; and again [he]1429-the carle turned on [her]108-birdalone to take [her]108-birdalone , but [she]108-birdalone sprang aside and ran from [him]1429-the carle , but ran landward perforce , as [he]1429-the carle was betwixt [her]108-birdalone and [the boat]850-the boat ; and [he]1429-the carle followed heavily , and had nought to do in the race . But [she]108-birdalone had not gone a two - score yards ere [she]108-birdalone heard a great shout , and [another man]6591-another man came running over [the meadow]499-the meadow ; [a slim young man]6593-a slim young man was this , and worse of attire than [the old carle]4662-the old carle , for so tattered was [his]6593-a slim young man raiment that [he]6593-a slim young man was half naked ; but [he]6593-a slim young man was goodly of fashion , fresh - coloured and black - haired . [Birdalone]108-birdalone stayed [her]108-birdalone feet when [she]108-birdalone saw [him]6593-a slim young man , for though [she]108-birdalone doubted not to outrun [him]6593-a slim young man , yet whither should [she]108-birdalone run , since [her]108-birdalone ferry was behind [her]108-birdalone ? So [the young man]6595-the young man came up to [her]108-birdalone , and [the old carle]4662-the old carle met [him]6593-a slim young man all panting , and [the young man]6595-the young man said : How now , [Antony]188-antony ! what battle is this ? and wherefore art [thou]108-birdalone chasing [this fair knight]6598-this fair knight ? And [thou]108-birdalone , [fair sir]1675-fair sir , why fleest [thou]108-birdalone this grey dastard ? Said [Antony]188-antony : [Thou]108-birdalone art but [a young fool]1939-a young fool , [Otter]189-otter , this is [no man]534-no man , but [a woman]235-a woman , and [I]108-birdalone have taken [her]235-a woman , and [she]235-a woman is mine . Well , said [Otter]189-otter , [I]108-birdalone say [she]235-a woman is as much mine as thine ; nay , more , if [she]235-a woman will give [herself]235-a woman unto [me]108-birdalone . But if [she]235-a woman will not , [she]235-a woman shall go whither [she]235-a woman will in [thy]108-birdalone despite . Or art [thou]108-birdalone [a woman]235-a woman ? Yea , yea , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; and [I]108-birdalone pray [thee]108-birdalone , by [[thy]108-birdalone mother]323-thy mother â€™s head , suffer [me]108-birdalone to depart ; for heavy and full of need is the errand that [I]108-birdalone am about . Go [thou]108-birdalone shalt then , said [Otter]189-otter ; lead back to [[thy]108-birdalone place]6605-thy place , and [I]108-birdalone will walk with [thee]108-birdalone . So did [they]6606-they : and [Birdalone]108-birdalone went beside [the young man quaking]6607-the young man quaking ; but [he]6607-the young man quaking put out no hand unto [her]108-birdalone ; and sooth to say , [she]108-birdalone deemed that [she]108-birdalone had seldom seen so fair [a young man]6251-a young man , but it were [Arthur]119-arthur or [Hugh]118-hugh . Now [he]6607-the young man quaking , as [Antony]188-antony , was girt with a short sword , but [he]6607-the young man quaking let it be in its sheath ; and as [they]6606-they went , [Antony]188-antony drew [his]188-antony blade again , and hove it up to smite [Otter]189-otter , but as it befell [Birdalone]108-birdalone saw [him]6607-the young man quaking , and turned round sharp upon [him]6607-the young man quaking and gat hold of [his]6607-the young man quaking wrist , and therewith [Otter]189-otter turned also , and caught [the old carle]4662-the old carle by the nape as [he]6607-the young man quaking turned away , and put a foot before [his]6607-the young man quaking and shoved mightily , so that [he]6607-the young man quaking went noseling to [the earth]432-the earth . Then turned [Otter]189-otter about again , laughing , and [he]189-otter said to [Birdalone]108-birdalone : By [Saint Giles]190-saint giles ! [thou]6611-thou art well - nigh too valiant for [a woman]235-a woman , and [I]108-birdalone would that [we]6613-we two might be together ; and then between [us]6613-we [we]6613-we might achieve the adventure of [the dead ladies]6614-the dead ladies up yonder . [She]108-birdalone hung [her]108-birdalone head , and said : Fair sir , it may not anywise be ; yet [I]108-birdalone thank [thee]189-otter , [I]108-birdalone thank [thee]189-otter . So came [they]6613-we to the water - side and the Sending Boat , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone stayed [her]108-birdalone feet there , and [the young man]6595-the young man said : What is this keel , that seemeth unto [me]108-birdalone as if it were a ferry for [malefactors wending to a death of torment]6616-malefactors wending to a death of torment , so grey and bleared and water - logged and sun - bleached as it is , and smeared over with stains of [I]108-birdalone know not what ? Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : Such as it is , it is [[my]108-birdalone ferry]6307-my ferry over [the water]347-the water to where [I]108-birdalone would be . Strange ! said [Otter]189-otter ; to [my]108-birdalone mind it is like to [our]6613-we fortunes on [this isle]4486-this isle , [we]6613-we who were once [knights]5590-knights and [merry squires]6621-merry squires and are now as [gangrel men , and of ill conditions]6622-gangrel men , and of ill conditions , thinking of nought save [our]6613-we first desires , even those which [we]6613-we share with the wolf and the kite . [She]108-birdalone said : But art [thou]6623-he of evil conditions , [thou]6623-he who hast just delivered [me]108-birdalone from trouble ? [He]6623-he smiled grimly : [Damsel]127-damsel , said [he]6623-he , [I]108-birdalone have not delivered [thee]127-damsel yet from [me]108-birdalone , though [I]108-birdalone have from [him]6623-he . But tell [me]108-birdalone , art [thou]6623-he [a sorceress]6624-a sorceress ? Not a black one , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; but [I]108-birdalone will tell [thee]127-damsel at once that [I]108-birdalone have been bred by [a witch most mighty]6625-a witch most mighty , and some deal of lore have [I]108-birdalone learned . And therewith [she]108-birdalone told [him]6623-he of [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat , and how [she]108-birdalone would have to speed it on the way . [He]6623-he looked on [her]108-birdalone a little and then turned away , and saw [her]108-birdalone sword lying on the grass ; so [he]6623-he went to it and picked it up and brought it to [her]108-birdalone , and said : [Thou]127-damsel mayst yet need [this keen friend]6627-this keen friend . So [she]108-birdalone took it and thrust it back into the scabbard , quaking somewhat because of [him]6623-he ; so feeble and frail as [she]108-birdalone felt before [him]6623-he . Then [he]6623-he said : If [thou]127-damsel deemest [thou]127-damsel hast somewhat to reward [me]108-birdalone for , [I]108-birdalone have a boon to ask of [thee]108-birdalone , and granting that , [we]6628-we shall be quits again . Yea , [she]108-birdalone said faintly , and what is the boon ? [He]6623-he said : Art [thou]127-damsel pressed to depart now , this minute ? Nay , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , not for an hour if there be no peril here from [other men]6629-other men , and . . . and . . . And if [I]108-birdalone be true to [thee]108-birdalone and will let [thee]108-birdalone go ? said [he]6623-he , laughing ; hah ! is that not [thy]108-birdalone word ? fear not , [I]108-birdalone swear by thine eyes that [thou]127-damsel shalt depart whenso [thou]127-damsel wilt . Now then , the boon [I]108-birdalone crave is , that [thou]127-damsel wilt sit down here beside [me]108-birdalone and tell [me]108-birdalone the tale of [thy]127-damsel life that has been . Said [she]108-birdalone : It wearies [me]108-birdalone to think thereof ; yet hast [thou]127-damsel a right to crave somewhat of [me]108-birdalone , and this is not hard to grant . And [she]108-birdalone sat down by [him]6623-he ; but [he]6623-he said : Do this also for [me]108-birdalone , take off [thine]127-damsel headpiece , since now that [we]6630-we know [thee]127-damsel for [a woman]235-a woman it serveth [thee]127-damsel nought . So did [she]108-birdalone , and began [her]108-birdalone tale straightway , and told [him]6623-he all thereof , save as to [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife , and [he]6623-he sat hearkening and watching [her]108-birdalone face ; and when [she]108-birdalone had made an end , [he]6623-he said : Now shall [I]108-birdalone ask none other boon of [thee]108-birdalone , though [I]108-birdalone long sore for it ; but best it is that [we]6630-we sunder straightway , else maybe [I]108-birdalone might yet be for hindering [thee]108-birdalone . Therewith [he]6623-he stood up , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone also , and [he]6623-he looked on [her]108-birdalone eagerly , and said : [I]108-birdalone am now to bid [thee]108-birdalone farewell , and it is most like that [I]108-birdalone shall never see [thee]108-birdalone again , wherefore [I]108-birdalone will ask [thee]108-birdalone yet to let one thing come from [thy]108-birdalone mouth ; for [I]108-birdalone deem [thee]108-birdalone [the dearest of all women [I]108-birdalone have ever seen]6633-the dearest of all women i have ever seen . What shall [I]108-birdalone say ? said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , smiling on [him]6623-he kindly ; must [thou]108-birdalone needs put the word in [my]108-birdalone mouth ? [Thou]108-birdalone hast been friendly with [me]108-birdalone here when need was to [me]108-birdalone of friendliness ; wherefore [I]108-birdalone say , [I]108-birdalone would [I]108-birdalone might see [thee]108-birdalone again , and [thou]108-birdalone better bestead than now [thou]108-birdalone art . [The young man]6595-the young man â€™s face brightened , and [he]6595-the young man said : Spake [I]108-birdalone not that [thou]108-birdalone wert the dearest of all ? This was even the word [I]108-birdalone would have put in [thy]108-birdalone mouth . But now see [thou]108-birdalone , one goeth on from one thing to another , and [I]108-birdalone must now ask [thee]108-birdalone , is there aught which [thou]108-birdalone hast a mind to give [me]108-birdalone ere [I]108-birdalone depart , some keepsake which [I]108-birdalone durst not ask for ? [She]108-birdalone flushed red and said : [I]108-birdalone will with a good heart give [thee]6595-the young man [my]108-birdalone bow and arrows for a keepsake ; whereas [the old carle]4662-the old carle told [me]108-birdalone that [ye]6595-the young man be ill furnished of shooting - gear . And [she]108-birdalone would have taken [her]108-birdalone bow from [her]108-birdalone back , but [he]6595-the young man laughed aloud , and said : Nay , nay , [I]108-birdalone will not have that ; for there be those who gird [them]6636-them to a sword and know not how to use it , but [few]2227-few will cumber [their]2227-few shoulders with bow and quiver who can not shoot therewith ; [I]108-birdalone deem it like that [thou]108-birdalone art [a fell bowman]6638-a fell bowman . Keep [thy]108-birdalone bow therefore , and if [thou]108-birdalone wilt go without any other gift , even so be it . And [he]6595-the young man made as if [he]6595-the young man would turn away ; but [she]108-birdalone put forth both [her]108-birdalone hands and took [his]6595-the young man in them , and lifted up [her]108-birdalone face and kissed [him]6595-the young man kindly , and then turned away to [[her]108-birdalone ferry]4501-her ferry ; while [Otter]189-otter stood still and said in a merry voice : Now is it better than well , for [thou]108-birdalone art in all ways what [I]108-birdalone would have [thee]108-birdalone , and there is nought like unto [thee]108-birdalone . And therewith [he]6595-the young man turned away and departed ere [Birdalone]108-birdalone had stepped into [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat , and [she]108-birdalone blushing like a rose the while . Then [she]108-birdalone did due sacrifice to [the wight of [the witch - ferry]6642-the witch - ferry]6641-the wight of the witch - ferry , and sped on [her]108-birdalone way without any hindrance . Chapter XIII ~ Coming to [the Isle of the Young]19-the isle of the young and [the Old]172-the old carle whither , [Birdalone]108-birdalone Findeth It Peopled with [Children]1274-children Midst all this had worn some hours , but yet it was barely noon ; wherefore it was yet dark by then [Birdalone]108-birdalone made [the Isle of the Young]19-the isle of the young and [the Old]4658-the old ; so [she]108-birdalone stepped out of [the boat]850-the boat , and lay down on the grass and abode the dawn sleeping . And [she]108-birdalone awoke with the clatter of shrill voices , and [she]108-birdalone rose up and looked , and lo [a multitude of [children]1274-children all about [her]108-birdalone]6646-a multitude of children all about her , both [men]204-men and [women children]6649-women children , and , as it seemed , from five years old upward to fifteen . [They]6646-a multitude of children all about her cried and crowed merrily when [they]6646-a multitude of children all about her saw [her]108-birdalone stand up , and pressed on [her]108-birdalone to see [her]108-birdalone the nearer and to touch [her]108-birdalone hands or [her]108-birdalone raiment . [They]6646-a multitude of children all about her were but little clad , and [the younger ones not at all]6650-the younger ones not at all , but were [goodly younglings and merry]6651-goodly younglings and merry . So great was the noise [they]6646-a multitude of children all about her raised , that loud were the thunder which had not been hushed thereby ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone stood looking on [them]6646-a multitude of children all about her , smiling , and knew not what to do . Anon [she]108-birdalone turned to [a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters]6652-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters , and said unto [him]6652-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters : Wilt [thou]6646-a multitude of children all about her now take [me]108-birdalone unto [the house]311-the house , and the place where dwelleth [the old man]1380-the old man ? Quoth [he]6652-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters : [I]108-birdalone neither know of [an old man]1431-an old man , nor rightly what it means , the word . Am not [I]108-birdalone old enough for [thee]108-birdalone ? [I]108-birdalone am the oldest of these here . But belike [thou]108-birdalone art hungry ; wherefore if [thou]108-birdalone come to the place where [we]108-birdalone sleep a - nights , and where [we]108-birdalone shelter [us]108-birdalone from the storm and the rain when need is , [I]108-birdalone will give [thee]108-birdalone to eat ; for [we]108-birdalone have both bread and milk and cheese , and raisins of the sun . So [he]6652-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters took [her]108-birdalone hand and led [her]108-birdalone along , and asked [her]108-birdalone by the way concerning [her]108-birdalone armour and weapons , and of the fashion of battle , and [she]108-birdalone told [him]6652-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters thereof what [she]108-birdalone would . Thus came [they]6656-they to the place where erst had been [the cot under the ruin of [the great ancient house]6658-the great ancient house]6657-the cot under the ruin of the great ancient house ; but now was gone all that ruin and the great grey walls , though the cot was left ; and all about [it]6657-the cot under the ruin of the great ancient house were low bowers built of small wood and thatched undeftly . But [the lad]4608-the lad smiled when [he]4608-the lad saw it , as if the sight thereof made [him]4608-the lad happy ; and [he]6652-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters said : All these have [we]108-birdalone made since [I]108-birdalone have dwelt here , and [no other home]6660-no other home have [I]108-birdalone known . And [he]6652-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters led [her]108-birdalone into [the cot]6661-the cot , and set [her]108-birdalone down to eat and to drink , and through the open door [she]108-birdalone could see [the children]4637-the children swarming , and [they]4637-the children that were nighest thrusting [each other]569-each other this way and that to catch a sight of [her]108-birdalone . Now [she]108-birdalone said : [Fair child]950-fair child , how gattest [thou]950-fair child this victual if there be [no older folk]6665-no older folk to help [you]950-fair child ? Said [he]6652-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters : [We]108-birdalone dig the ground and sow it , and the wheat comes up , and [we]108-birdalone reap it in harvest , and make bread of it ; and [we]108-birdalone have goats and kine , and [we]108-birdalone milk [them]4637-the children , and turn the milk with a little blue flower , which is fair to see . And there are in [this isle little hills]6666-this isle little hills where the grapes grow plenty ; and [some]213-some [we]108-birdalone eat and some [we]108-birdalone dry for store . Lo [thou]950-fair child , such be [our]108-birdalone ways for victual . But tell [me]108-birdalone , said [he]6652-a tall thin lad of some fifteen winters , [thou]950-fair child sayest old , and [I]108-birdalone know not the word ; art [thou]950-fair child old ? [She]950-fair child laughed : Not very , said [she]950-fair child , yet older than [thou]950-fair child . Said [the lad]4608-the lad : [Thou]950-fair child art fair and dear to look on , and [thy]950-fair child voice is sweet ; wilt [thou]950-fair child not abide with [us]108-birdalone , and teach [us]108-birdalone what it is to be old ? Nay , said [she]950-fair child , [I]108-birdalone may not , for [I]108-birdalone have an errand which driveth [me]108-birdalone on ; wherefore [I]108-birdalone must be gone within this hour . Forsooth , [she]950-fair child was growing eager now to be done with [her]950-fair child journey and come to [the House under [the Wood]4-the wood]4835-the house under the wood , whatever should befall [her]950-fair child there . Moreover [she]950-fair child deemed it would not be restful to [her]950-fair child to abide among [all these restless children]6670-all these restless children , with [their]6670-all these restless children ceaseless crying and yelping : if rest [she]950-fair child might , [she]950-fair child would rest , [she]950-fair child deemed , in [the Isle of [Increase Unsought]29-increase unsought]4590-the isle of increase unsought , if there were no ill things abiding there . Wherefore now [she]950-fair child arose , when [she]950-fair child had sat hearkening the sound of [the lad]4608-the lad â€™s prattle for a while , for as to the sense thereof [she]950-fair child might not heed it over - much . [The youngling]376-the youngling would not leave [her]950-fair child , but led [her]950-fair child , holding [her]950-fair child hand , down to [[her]950-fair child ferry]4501-her ferry again ; [she]950-fair child kissed [him]376-the youngling in thanks for [his]376-the youngling meat , and [he]376-the youngling reddened thereat but said nought .
