[All the whole rout of little ones]6675-all the whole rout of little ones had followed [her]950-fair child down to [the water]347-the water , and now [they]6675-all the whole rout of little ones stood , as thick as bees on a honeycomb , on the bank , to watch [her]950-fair child departure . But if [they]6675-all the whole rout of little ones were keen to see [her]950-fair child doings before , how much keener were [they]6675-all the whole rout of little ones when it came to the baring of [her]950-fair child arm and the smearing of [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat . To be short , so keen were [they]6675-all the whole rout of little ones , and pushed and shoved [each other]569-each other so sturdily , that [more than one or two]6679-more than one or two fell into the water , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone was frighted lest [they]6675-all the whole rout of little ones should drown ; but [they]6675-all the whole rout of little ones swam like ducks , and got on to [the land]198-the land when [they]6675-all the whole rout of little ones would , which was not so very soon , for [some of [them]6675-all the whole rout of little ones]6502-some of them hung unto the gunwale of [the boat]850-the boat , and hove [their]6502-some of them faces up to look over into it , and left not hold till [the ferry]4467-the ferry was fairly under weigh and beginning to quicken [its]4467-the ferry speed . So left [Birdalone]108-birdalone [the isle]631-the isle , and nought befell [her]108-birdalone on the way to [the Isle of Increase Unsought]4590-the isle of increase unsought . Chapter XIV ~ The Sending Boat Disappeareth from [the Isle of Increase Unsought]17-the isle of increase unsought , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone Seeketh to Escape Thence by Swimming It was as before that [Birdalone]108-birdalone came to [the shore of [the isle]631-the isle]6686-the shore of the isle while it was yet night ; but the wizard keel was so loathsome to [her]108-birdalone , that [she]108-birdalone stepped out of it and laid [her]108-birdalone down on [the land]198-the land for what was left of the night ; yet hard [she]108-birdalone found [her]108-birdalone bed , and neither grassy nor flowery . For all that , [she]108-birdalone slept , for [she]108-birdalone was weary , and it was broad day and not very early when [she]108-birdalone awoke . [She]108-birdalone stood up trembling , for [she]108-birdalone foreboded evil , so near as [she]108-birdalone was to [the dwelling of [[her]108-birdalone old mistress]4951-her old mistress]6689-the dwelling of her old mistress ; and [she]108-birdalone looked up to where in time past was [the fair and wicked house]6691-the fair and wicked house , and saw that all was changed indeed ; for no longer was [the isle]631-the isle goodly with meadow and [orchard]2880-orchard and [garden]6694-garden , but was waste and bare , and nought grew on [it]631-the isle save thin and wiry grass , already seeding even ere [June]92-june was born , and here and there hard and ugly herbs , with scarce aught that might be called a flower amongst them . Trees there were yet , but the most of them stark dead , and the best dying fast . No beasts [she]108-birdalone saw , nor fowl ; nothing but lizards and beetles , and now and again a dry grey adder coiled up about a sun - burned stone . But of great carrion flies , green and blue , were there a many , and whiles they buzzed about [her]108-birdalone head till [she]108-birdalone sickened with loathing of them . All this [she]108-birdalone found on [her]108-birdalone way as [she]108-birdalone went up toward the place where erst was the great perron . But when [she]108-birdalone came to the top there was no sign either of the stairs or [the house]311-the house , or aught that ever was builded ; there was nought but the bare bent top , ungrassed , parched by wind , scorched by sun , washed by rain . [She]108-birdalone wandered about [the isle]631-the isle , to [places where [she]108-birdalone had not been [herself]108-birdalone , but which [she]108-birdalone deemed [she]108-birdalone might have known by the telling of [the Green Knight]118-hugh â€™s tale]6697-places where she had not been herself , but which she deemed she might have known by the telling of the green knight â€™s tale , had there been no change since those days ; but now was all changed , and [the whole isle]6698-the whole isle was a mere waste , and withal poisonous of aspect to [her]108-birdalone mind , as if many corpses lay underneath the wretched stones of [it]6698-the whole isle . Nevertheless , though it seemed so evil unto [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [she]108-birdalone lingered on [it]6698-the whole isle , wandering about till [she]108-birdalone was to - wearied , for [she]108-birdalone had no will to depart at such time as [she]108-birdalone would be like to come to [[her]108-birdalone old abiding - place]6699-her old abiding - place by night and cloud ; wherefore [she]108-birdalone dallied with the time , and came not back to [the haven of [[her]108-birdalone ferry]4501-her ferry]6700-the haven of her ferry till it was nigh sunset , and the westering sun was in [her]108-birdalone eyes when [she]108-birdalone came [there]215-there ; and [she]108-birdalone said to [herself]108-birdalone that this was the cause why [she]108-birdalone might not see [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat . So [she]108-birdalone cleared [her]108-birdalone eyes and looked on the thin grass awhile , and then down over [the edge of [the land]198-the land]6704-the edge of the land , and still [she]108-birdalone saw not [[her]108-birdalone boat]6583-her boat . [She]108-birdalone turned pale , and a pang of anguish went to [her]108-birdalone heart ; but [she]108-birdalone walked a little east , deeming that perchance [she]108-birdalone had erred as to [the place of [the haven]6708-the haven on [that dull and empty shore]6709-that dull and empty shore]6707-the place of the haven on that dull and empty shore ; but yet there was [no boat]410-no boat . Then [she]108-birdalone turned back wild with terror , and sought where erst [she]108-birdalone had missed it , and found [neither boat]4924-neither boat nor [the world]417-the world â€™s end . And [she]108-birdalone deemed that there might be some devilish malice of the wight of the Sending Boat , to torment [her]108-birdalone with fear , and [she]108-birdalone walked along [the land]198-the land â€™s edge up and down , and down and up , further each time , and still there was [no boat]410-no boat . Then [she]108-birdalone stood still and strove to think , and might not , nor might [she]108-birdalone do aught , but spread abroad [her]108-birdalone hands and moaned in [her]108-birdalone agony ; for now indeed [she]108-birdalone felt [herself]108-birdalone in the trap ; and [she]108-birdalone said that all [her]108-birdalone past life of hope and desire and love and honour was all for nought , and that [she]108-birdalone was but born to die miserably in [that foul ruin of [an isle]6716-an isle]6715-that foul ruin of an isle envenomed with the memories of bygone cruelty and shame . But in a little while [she]108-birdalone came somewhat to [herself]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone said : At least [this hideous land]6717-this hideous land shall not mock [my]108-birdalone dying anguish ; [I]108-birdalone will give [myself]108-birdalone to [the water]347-the water and let it do with [me]108-birdalone as it will . Therewith [she]108-birdalone cast off [her]108-birdalone helm and hauberk first , and [her]108-birdalone weapons , and [her]108-birdalone pouch with the treasure that could buy nought for [her]108-birdalone now , and thereafter all [her]108-birdalone raiment , till [she]108-birdalone was as naked as when [she]108-birdalone first came aland [there]215-there that other time . Again [she]108-birdalone moaned , and put up [her]108-birdalone hand to [her]108-birdalone bosom and felt a little gold box lying there betwixt the fragrant hills of [her]108-birdalone breasts , which hung to a thin golden thread about [her]108-birdalone neck ; and a thought came into [her]108-birdalone mind , and [she]108-birdalone stooped adown and drew from [her]108-birdalone pouch flint and fire - steel , and then opened the said golden box and drew thence the tress which [Habundia the wood - wife]6720-habundia the wood - wife had given to [her]108-birdalone those years agone , and all trembling [she]108-birdalone drew two hairs from it , as erst [she]108-birdalone did on [the Isle of Nothing]32-the isle of nothing , and struck fire and kindled tinder and burnt the said hairs , and then hung the golden box with the tress therein about [her]108-birdalone neck again ; and [she]108-birdalone said : [O wood - mother]1618-o wood - mother , if only [thou]1618-o wood - mother couldst know of [me]108-birdalone and see [me]108-birdalone , [thou]1618-o wood - mother wouldst help [me]108-birdalone ! Thereafter [she]108-birdalone sought along [the bank]1035-the bank for bread which [she]108-birdalone had taken from [[her]108-birdalone store]6723-her store that morning , and [she]108-birdalone found it , and compelled [herself]108-birdalone to eat of it for the strengthening of [her]108-birdalone body , and then [she]108-birdalone stood and abode tidings ; and by then the sun had just sunk below the rim of [the lake]355-the lake , and the stars began to twinkle , for the night was cloudless , and exceeding fair , and very warm . No visible token came to [her]108-birdalone , but [her]108-birdalone heart grew stronger , and [she]108-birdalone seemed to see [herself]108-birdalone yet alive and in hope on the other side of [the water]347-the water ; and [she]108-birdalone said : Who wotteth what Weird may do , or where [the waters]624-the waters may bear [me]108-birdalone ? and there is no swimmer stronger than [I.]108-birdalone So then without more ado [Birdalone]108-birdalone slipped into [the water]347-the water , which lay before [her]108-birdalone as calm and plain as a great sheet of glass , and fell to rowing with [her]108-birdalone arms and [her]108-birdalone legs as though [she]108-birdalone were but swimming from [Green Eyot]6-green eyot to [the mainland]1030-the mainland , as so oft [she]108-birdalone had done in the other days . Chapter XV ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone Lacketh Little of Drowning , But Cometh Latterly to [the Green Eyot]6-green eyot On swam [Birdalone]108-birdalone , not as one who had a mind to drown [her]108-birdalone for the forgetting of troubles , but both strongly and wisely ; and [she]108-birdalone turned over on to [her]108-birdalone back , and looked on the stars above [her]108-birdalone , and steered [herself]108-birdalone by them thitherward whereas [she]108-birdalone deemed was [the land under the wood]6729-the land under the wood . When [she]108-birdalone had been gone from [the evil isle]6730-the evil isle for an hour or so , there rose a fair little wind behind [her]108-birdalone , which helped [her]108-birdalone forward , but scarce raised the water more than a little ripple . Still [she]108-birdalone swam on , and it was some three hours [she]108-birdalone began to weary , and then [she]108-birdalone floated on [her]108-birdalone back and let the wind and water have its way with [her]108-birdalone ; and now the night was as dark as it would be ere dawn . Thus it went for another hour , that whiles [she]108-birdalone swam on and whiles [she]108-birdalone floated ; and now [her]108-birdalone heart began to fail [her]108-birdalone , and the great water was no longer unto [her]108-birdalone a wet highway , but a terrible gulf over which [she]108-birdalone hung fainting . Nevertheless [she]108-birdalone did not give up doing what [she]108-birdalone might : [she]108-birdalone floated supine a long while , and then , when [she]108-birdalone had gathered a little strength , turned over again and struck out , still steering [her]108-birdalone by the stars . But [she]108-birdalone had scarce made three strokes ere [her]108-birdalone arms met something hard and rough ; and at first in [her]108-birdalone forlornness [she]108-birdalone deemed [she]108-birdalone had happened on some dread water monster , and for terror of it [she]108-birdalone sank down into the deep , but came up presently blinded and breathless , and spread abroad [her]108-birdalone arms , and again [they]6731-they came on the thing aforesaid , and this time found that it was nought alive , but the bole of a tree sitting high out of [the water]347-the water . So [she]108-birdalone clomb up on to it with what might [she]108-birdalone had left , and sat [her]108-birdalone down , and saw in the dim light that it was big , and that there was a fork betwixt two limbs reaching up into the air , and [she]108-birdalone thrust [herself]108-birdalone in between these two limbs and embraced one of them , so that [she]108-birdalone might scarce tumble off ; and a great content and happiness came over [her]108-birdalone that [she]108-birdalone had thus escaped from the death of the deep ; but therewithal weariness overcame [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone slept , whether [she]108-birdalone would or not ; and the bole went on over [the waters]624-the waters no slower than might have been looked for , whether it were by the pushing on of the south wind , or by the hand of [Weird]154-weird that would not have [her]108-birdalone die . Long [she]108-birdalone slumbered , for when [she]108-birdalone awoke it was broad day and the sun was shining high in the heavens , and [she]108-birdalone cleared [her]108-birdalone eyes and looked around , and saw before [her]108-birdalone [the land]198-the land , but yet blue in the offing . And the tree - bole was yet speeding on towards [the shore]344-the shore , as if it were being drawn there by some bidding of might . Now indeed grew [Birdalone]108-birdalone happy , and [she]108-birdalone thought if any had helped [her]108-birdalone it must have been [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother once again ; and [she]108-birdalone said to [herself]108-birdalone that [she]108-birdalone should soon meet with [that helper]6737-that helper ; nor heeded [she]108-birdalone that [she]108-birdalone was naked and unfurnished of any goods , whereas [she]108-birdalone deemed indeed that it was but to ask and have of [[her]108-birdalone friend]433-her friend . For a while indeed [she]108-birdalone knew not whither [she]108-birdalone was wending , and if [her]108-birdalone face were verily turned toward [the land under the wood]6729-the land under the wood ; but as the morning wore the blue distance began to grow green , and then [she]108-birdalone saw that a great wood was indeed before [her]108-birdalone , and thereafter , as it cleared yet more , [she]108-birdalone knew [the land]198-the land [she]108-birdalone was nearing for [the meadows of [the House under the Wood]4835-the house under the wood]6741-the meadows of the house under the wood , and it was not long thence ere [she]108-birdalone saw clear and close [Green Eyot]6-green eyot and [Rocky Eyot]73-rocky eyot , though [the house]311-the house was yet hidden from [her]108-birdalone by [the green shores of the first of [those two isles]6745-those two isles]6744-the green shores of the first of those two isles . Shortly to tell it , [her]108-birdalone tree - bole floated with [her]108-birdalone past [the outer ness of [Green Eyot]6-green eyot]6746-the outer ness of green eyot , and came ashore in [that same sandy bight]6747-that same sandy bight where erst [she]108-birdalone was wonted to make [her]108-birdalone body ready for [the water]347-the water . [She]108-birdalone stepped ashore all glad to feel the firm warm sand underneath [her]108-birdalone foot - soles , and as one drunk with joy [she]108-birdalone was when the tall flowery grass of the latter May was caressing [her]108-birdalone legs as they shook the seed - dust off the bents , and smote the fragrance out of the blossoms ; and [she]108-birdalone might scarce at first lift [her]108-birdalone eyes from [their]6745-those two isles familiar loveliness . Glad [she]108-birdalone was indeed , but exceeding worn and weary with the long voyage , and all the longing and fear and hope which had encompassed [her]108-birdalone that while . [She]108-birdalone lifted up [her]108-birdalone eyes but once , and saw [[the witch]394-the witch â€™s house]6103-the witch â€™s house standing where [it]6103-the witch â€™s house was wo nt , but no shape of [man]537-man moving about [it]6103-the witch â€™s house ; then [she]108-birdalone turned aside to a little brake of thorn and eglantine in [the meadow]499-the meadow hard by , and laid [her]108-birdalone down on the grass in the shade thereof , and almost before [her]108-birdalone head touched [the ground]5349-the ground [she]108-birdalone fell asleep , and slept there long and peacefully . Chapter XVI ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone Findeth [Her]108-birdalone Witch - Mistress Dead It was some while after noon when [she]108-birdalone wakened , and the sun was shining bright and hot . Somewhat [she]108-birdalone felt the burden of fear upon [her]108-birdalone , even before [she]108-birdalone was fully come to [herself]108-birdalone , and knew not what it was that [she]108-birdalone feared ; but when [she]108-birdalone called to mind that it was even the meeting with [[her]108-birdalone old mistress]4951-her old mistress , [her]108-birdalone flesh quaked indeed with the memory of bygone anguish , but valiantly [she]108-birdalone arose and faced the dwelling of [the witch]394-the witch despite [her]108-birdalone naked helplessness . As [she]108-birdalone went [she]108-birdalone looked up unto [it]6756-it , and saw no smoke coming from the chimney , but marvelled little thereat since it was not yet cooking - time and the weather hot . [She]108-birdalone drew nigher , and saw [someone sitting on the bench without the door]6757-someone sitting on the bench without the door whereas [the witch]394-the witch was wonted ; and [her]108-birdalone heart beat quick , for [she]108-birdalone saw presently that it was [none other than [[her]108-birdalone mistress]407-her mistress]6759-none other than her mistress . Moreover , near to [her]108-birdalone stood three of [the milch - kine lowing uneasily and as in reproach , even as such beasts]6761-the milch - kine lowing uneasily and as in reproach , even as such beasts use when [their]6761-the milch - kine lowing uneasily and as in reproach , even as such beasts udders be full and [they]6761-the milch - kine lowing uneasily and as in reproach , even as such beasts desire to be milked . [Birdalone]108-birdalone stayed a minute , and [her]108-birdalone legs nigh failed [her]108-birdalone for fear , and then because of the very fear [she]108-birdalone hastened on till [she]108-birdalone came within ten paces of [the said witch]2791-the said witch ; and sore [she]108-birdalone missed [her]108-birdalone bow and arrows , and the cutting blade of [her]108-birdalone feigned squirehood , lest the carline should arise and come raging and shrieking at [her]108-birdalone . Then spake [Birdalone]108-birdalone in no feeble voice , and said : Dame , [I]108-birdalone am come back unto [thee]108-birdalone , as [thou]108-birdalone seest , in even such plight as [I]108-birdalone fled from [thee]108-birdalone ; and [I]108-birdalone have a mind to dwell in [this land]1250-this land : what sayest [thou]108-birdalone ? [The witch]394-the witch neither moved nor spake at [her]394-the witch word ; and [the kine , who had held silence]6765-the kine , who had held silence when [she]394-the witch first came up , and had turned from [her]394-the witch , fell to [their]6765-the kine , who had held silence peevish lowing again . [Birdalone]108-birdalone drew a step nigher , and said : Dost [thou]108-birdalone hear [me]108-birdalone , [dame]6766-dame , or art [thou]108-birdalone exceeding wroth with [me]108-birdalone , and art pondering what vengeance [thou]108-birdalone wilt take on [me]108-birdalone ? Still no answer came from [the carline]4438-the carline , and [the kine]6768-the kine kept on lowing now and again . Once more [Birdalone]108-birdalone drew nigher , and spake loudly and said : Tell [me]108-birdalone at least , is it peace between [us]6769-us or unpeace ? But now when [she]108-birdalone looked [she]108-birdalone saw that the eyes of [the witch]394-the witch were open and staring , and [her]394-the witch lips white , and [her]394-the witch hands hard writhen ; and [she]108-birdalone cried out and said : Is [she]394-the witch dead ? or will [she]394-the witch waken presently and beat [me]108-birdalone ? surely [she]394-the witch is dead . And [she]108-birdalone put forth [her]108-birdalone hand and touched [her]108-birdalone face , and it was stone - cold ; and [she]108-birdalone found that [she]108-birdalone was dead beyond any question . Then was a great weight lifted off [her]108-birdalone heart , and [she]108-birdalone turned about and looked on [the meadows]1769-the meadows and up to the trees of the wood and down to the rippling stream before [her]108-birdalone , and fair and sweet and joyous were [they]6772-they gotten unto [her]108-birdalone ; and [she]108-birdalone looked at [the kine who were drawing up]6773-the kine who were drawing up towards [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone laughed merrily , and went to [the out - house]6774-the out - house hard by and took forth a milking - pail and a stool and fell to milking [them]6772-they one after the other , and the beasts went off down [the meadow]499-the meadow lowing in a changed voice , for joy to wit , this time . But [Birdalone]108-birdalone knelt down and drank a long draught of the sweet warm milk , and then arose and went swiftly into [the house]311-the house , and saw nought changed or worsened so far as [she]108-birdalone could see . There was [her]108-birdalone own bed in the corner , and [the mistress]698-the mistress â€™s , greater and much fairer , over against it ; and the hutch by the door wherein the victual was kept : [she]108-birdalone opened it now , and found three loaves there on the shelf , and a meal - tub down below , and [she]108-birdalone took a loaf and broke it and fell to eating it as [she]108-birdalone walked about [the chamber]292-the chamber . There was [her]108-birdalone bow standing in a nook beside the hutch , and the quiver of arrows hanging on the wall above it . There was the settle lying athwart from the hearth ; and [she]108-birdalone smiled , and fitted [her]108-birdalone wrists to the back of the carven bear which made its elbow , whereto [the witch]394-the witch was wo nt to tie them when [she]394-the witch chastised [her]108-birdalone . Then [she]108-birdalone went to the coffers that stood against the wall behind [it]6774-the out - house , and threw up the lid of one of them , and found therein a smock or two of [her]108-birdalone own , yellowed by the lapse of time , and [her]108-birdalone old grey coat , ragged as it was when last [she]108-birdalone wore it , and now somewhat moth - eaten withal ; and [she]108-birdalone drew forth both smocks and coat and laid them on the settle . Then [she]108-birdalone opened another coffer , and therein were gay and gaudy gowns and gear of [the witch]394-the witch â€™s wear ; but lying amongst them , as if [the witch]394-the witch had worn them also , [her]394-the witch green gown and shoon which [her]394-the witch own hands had broidered . But [she]108-birdalone said : Nay , [ye]6782-ye have been in ill company , [I]108-birdalone will wear [you]6782-ye not , though [ye]6782-ye be goodly , at least not till [ye]6782-ye have been fumigated and hallowed for [me]108-birdalone . Therewith [she]108-birdalone turned back to [the settle]6783-the settle and did on [her]108-birdalone [her]108-birdalone old smock and [her]108-birdalone ragged grey coat , and said : To - day at least will these be good enough for today â€™s work . And [she]108-birdalone knit [her]108-birdalone brow withal , and walked with a firm step out - a - doors and stood a while gazing on the dead corpse of [[her]108-birdalone enemy]6784-her enemy ; and [she]108-birdalone thought how that here was that which once was so great a thing unto [her]108-birdalone for the shaping of [her]108-birdalone life - days , and which so oft came to [her]108-birdalone waking thoughts after [she]108-birdalone had escaped from [her]108-birdalone hands , ( though , as aforesaid , [she]108-birdalone seldom dreamed of [her]108-birdalone a - night - time ) , and moreover an hour ago [she]108-birdalone yet feared it so sore that [she]108-birdalone scarce might stand for the fear of it ; and now it was nought but a carven log unto [her]108-birdalone . But [she]108-birdalone told [herself]108-birdalone that the work was to be done ; so [she]108-birdalone dragged the body away thence , and across [the brook]700-the brook , and a little way into [the meadow]499-the meadow , and then [she]108-birdalone went back and fetched mattock and spade from [the outhouse]6787-the outhouse , where [she]108-birdalone knew they lay , and so fell to digging a grave for the corpse of [her]108-birdalone dead terror . But howso hard [she]108-birdalone might toil , [she]108-birdalone was not through with the work ere night began to fall on [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone had no mind to go on with [her]108-birdalone digging by night . Wherefore [she]108-birdalone went back into [the house]311-the house , and lighted candles , whereof was no lack , and made [her]108-birdalone supper of the bread and the milk ; and then sat pondering on [her]108-birdalone life that had been till the passion arose in [her]108-birdalone bosom , and the tears burst out , and long [she]108-birdalone wept for desire of [others]4825-others and pity for [herself]108-birdalone . Then [she]108-birdalone went to the bed [she]108-birdalone had been erst wo nt to , and laid [her]108-birdalone down and fell asleep . And [[her]108-birdalone mistress]407-her mistress walked not , nor meddled with [her]108-birdalone peace ; nor did [Birdalone]108-birdalone so much as dream of [her]407-her mistress , but of [[her]108-birdalone mother]318-her mother and [Master Jacobus]177-jacobus in [the fair city of the Five Crafts]6792-the fair city of the five crafts ; and in [her]108-birdalone sleep [she]108-birdalone wept for thinking of [them]6793-them . Chapter XVII ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone Layeth to Earth the Body of [the Witch]394-the witch , and Findeth the Sending Boat Broken Up When morning was , [Birdalone]108-birdalone awoke , and felt a weight upon [her]108-birdalone heart , and called to mind the task which lay before [her]108-birdalone . So [she]108-birdalone arose and clad [herself]108-birdalone , and went straight to [the grave begun]6795-the grave begun , and toiled hard till [she]108-birdalone had digged it out deep , and sithence [she]108-birdalone dragged [the witch]394-the witch thereinto and heaped the earth upon [her]108-birdalone . Then [she]108-birdalone bathed [her]108-birdalone in [the nighest pool of the brook]6797-the nighest pool of the brook , and went back into [the house]311-the house and made [her]108-birdalone breakfast on the bread and milk , and it was then about mid - morning . Thereafter [she]108-birdalone went about [the house]311-the house , and saw to the baking of bread , and so out to [the meadow]499-the meadow to see to [the kine]6768-the kine and the goats , and then stored the milk for making butter and cheese , and did in all wise as if [she]108-birdalone were to dwell long in that stead ; but thereafter [she]108-birdalone rested [her]108-birdalone body , whiles [her]108-birdalone thought went wide about . But [she]108-birdalone said to [herself]108-birdalone that [she]108-birdalone would not go up to [the Oak of [Tryst]74-tryst]767-the oak of tryst to meet [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother that day , but would abide the night , in case aught befell that [she]108-birdalone should tell [her]108-birdalone . But when the sun was getting low [she]108-birdalone roused [herself]108-birdalone and went out , and walked about [the meadow]499-the meadow , and hearkened to the birds â€™[108-birdalone] song , and watched [the kine]6768-the kine and the goats as [they]3440-they fed down [the pasture]3441-the pasture ; and now a soft content came over [her]3442-she , that all this was free unto [her]3442-she to hold in peace , and to take [her]3442-she pleasure in , as much as [one lone child of Adam]3443-one lone child of adam might do . At last [she]3442-she wandered down to [the sandy bight of [the lake]355-the lake]3444-the sandy bight of the lake and stood gazing on [Green Eyot]6-green eyot , where the osiers and willows were grown wild and long in all these years , and [she]3442-she said that [she]3442-she would swim over to [it]6-green eyot on the morrow . But now [her]3442-she feet took [her]3442-she eastward thence toward [the haven of [the Sending]75-the sending [Boat amongst]3447-boat amongst [the alders]3448-the alders]3446-the haven of the sending boat amongst the alders ; for in [her]3442-she heart [she]3442-she would fain know if there were any tidings for [her]3442-she . So [she]3442-she went softly along the path by [the water]347-the water , where [she]3442-she had sped so swiftly that last time , and came at last to [the creek - side]843-the creek - side , and looked down on to [the water]347-the water somewhat timorously . There then [she]3442-she saw what [she]3442-she deemed was [the very boat itself]3452-the very boat itself lying as [she]3442-she had known it ; but when [she]3442-she looked again [she]3442-she saw that it lay from stem to stern all loose staves with the water betwixt , and the thwarts and ribs all sundered and undone , so that never again might it float upon the waves . Then [she]3442-she said in a soft voice : Art [thou]3453-thou dead then , as [[thy]3453-thou mistress]553-thy mistress is dead ? was it not so that [thou]3453-thou wert at the point of death , and [she]553-thy mistress also , when [thou]3453-thou failedst [me]0-i at [the Isle of Increase Unsought]17-the isle of increase unsought ? No voice came to [her]3442-she as [she]3442-she spake ; and [she]3442-she said again : Must [I]0-i then bury [thee]3453-thou as [I]0-i have buried [[thy]3453-thou mistress]553-thy mistress ? Nay , that will [I]0-i not until [thou]3453-thou compellest [me]0-i ; belike in a short while little of the staves of [thee]3453-thou shall be left now that the life is out of [thee]3453-thou . Let [thy]3453-thou ghost and [hers]553-thy mistress foregather if [ye]3453-thou will . As [she]3442-she spake the last word , [she]3442-she saw a stir about the stern which lay furthest in up [the creek]675-the creek , and while [she]3442-she quaked with failing heart , lo ! a big serpent , mouldy and hairy , grey and brown - flecked , came forth from under the stern and went into [the water]347-the water and up [the bank]1035-the bank and so into the dusk of [the alder - wood]3459-the alder - wood . [Birdalone]108-birdalone stood awhile pale and heartsick for fear , and when [her]108-birdalone feet felt life in them , [she]108-birdalone turned and stole away back again into the merry green mead and the low beams of the sun , pondering whether [this evil creature]3460-this evil creature were the fetch of [the wight who drave the ferry under the blood of the sender]3461-the wight who drave the ferry under the blood of the sender . So [she]108-birdalone hastened back again to [the house]311-the house , and lit a fire on the hearth , and fell to cooking [her]108-birdalone somewhat of grout to [her]108-birdalone supper ; and [she]108-birdalone watched the fire , thinking withal : Now if [some poor soul]3463-some poor soul be abroad , [they]3463-some poor soul may see the smoke and seek hither , and [I]0-i may comfort [them]3463-some poor soul with food and shelter and converse ; or when night darkens , [they]3463-some poor soul may see the litten windows and come to [me]0-i ; wherefore shall the fire burn yet and the candles be lighted , for as warm as is the evening , even as if it were Yule - tide and the snow deep without , and the wind howling in the woodland trees . And therewith [she]108-birdalone wept for longing of [them]3463-some poor soul that [she]108-birdalone loved . But in a little [she]108-birdalone dried [her]108-birdalone tears , and reproached [herself]108-birdalone for [her]108-birdalone much softness ; and [she]108-birdalone ate [her]108-birdalone supper when [she]108-birdalone had lighted a candle ( for it was now dark ) , and again sat looking at the hearth , till [she]108-birdalone said : Now am [I]0-i getting soft again , and who knows but [my]0-i softness may tempt the ghosts to come in to [me]0-i . [I]0-i will give [my]0-i hands somewhat to do . Therewith [her]108-birdalone eye caught sight of the rents and rags of [her]108-birdalone old grey gown , and [she]108-birdalone smiled somewhat ruefully as [she]108-birdalone called to mind [[her]108-birdalone gallant knight]3464-her gallant knight â€™s array , which lay now on [the shore of the evil and ruined isle]3465-the shore of the evil and ruined isle ; and [her]108-birdalone goodly attire of the days of [the Five Crafts]6090-the five crafts ; and the rich raiment wherein [[her]108-birdalone friends of [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest]3467-her friends of the castle of the quest had clad [her]108-birdalone . Then [she]108-birdalone arose and sought needle and thread and some remnants of green cloth , and did off the ragged coat and fell to patching and mending it , and so sat at [her]108-birdalone work in smock - sewing till the night was old and [she]108-birdalone was weary and sleep overcame [her]108-birdalone , and [she]108-birdalone lay down in [her]108-birdalone bed and slept dreamlessly till the sun was high next morning . Chapter XVIII ~ [The Wood - Mother]925-the wood - mother Cometh to [Birdalone]108-birdalone and Heareth [Her]108-birdalone Story Now [Birdalone]108-birdalone arose and bathed [her]108-birdalone and broke [her]108-birdalone fast , and then went about [her]108-birdalone work with the beasts and the dairy ; but all that time seemed long to [her]108-birdalone till [she]108-birdalone had bow in hand and quiver on back , and was wending [her]108-birdalone way to [the Oak of [Tryst]74-tryst]767-the oak of tryst ; and swift were [her]108-birdalone feet and [her]108-birdalone heart beat quick with hope of pleasure . Forsooth no long tarrying had [she]108-birdalone , for scarce had [she]108-birdalone set [her]108-birdalone down beneath the oak , ere [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother came forth from the thicket even as the first time when [Birdalone]108-birdalone saw [her]108-birdalone , and presently [she]108-birdalone had [her]108-birdalone arms about [Birdalone]108-birdalone and was kissing and clipping [her]108-birdalone . Then [they]3472-they sat down together in the shade of the great tree , and [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother made much of [[her]108-birdalone friend]433-her friend with few words and those but simple , while [Birdalone]108-birdalone wept for joy . At last spake [Birdalone]108-birdalone : [Wood - mother]1619-wood - mother , [[my]0-i dear]1824-my dear , [I]0-i look in [thy]108-birdalone face , and [I]0-i see [thee]108-birdalone that [thou]108-birdalone art nowise changed , so that [thou]108-birdalone callest to [my]0-i mind the Birdalone that met [thee]108-birdalone here when [she]108-birdalone was straying from [the House of Captivity]1013-the house of captivity like to a bird with a string to its leg . [Habundia]97-habundia smiled on [her]108-birdalone and said : So it is that now [thou]108-birdalone lookest older than [I.]97-habundia Rounder and fuller is [thy]108-birdalone body , and [thy]108-birdalone limbs greater and fairer , and [thy]108-birdalone flesh sleeker ; lovelier art [thou]108-birdalone in all wise , and such as [I]0-i have thought of [thee]108-birdalone during these years , save that [thy]108-birdalone face is grown wiser and sadder than might be looked for . [Mother]191-mother , [she]108-birdalone said , [I]0-i am grown older than [I]0-i should be by the tale of the years , for [I]0-i have had joy and grief , and grief and joy , and grief again ; and now that the years have worn , the grief abideth and the joy hath departed , save this joy of [thee]108-birdalone and the day of the meeting [I]0-i have so often thought of . Said [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife : Were [I]0-i to hear the story of [thee]108-birdalone , [I]0-i deem it most like that [I]0-i would fain buy [thy]108-birdalone joy with [thy]108-birdalone grief , both that which has been and that which is to come . And now [I]0-i will ask [thee]108-birdalone right out to tell [me]0-i all [thy]108-birdalone tale , as much as [thou]108-birdalone canst ; and all [thou]108-birdalone canst tell to [me]0-i , who am thine other self : and [I]0-i wot moreover that [thou]108-birdalone hast not told of [me]0-i to [any whom [thou]108-birdalone hast met in [the world]417-the world since [we]3481-we were last together]3479-any whom thou hast met in the world since we were last together : is it not so ? In faith and in troth so it is , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone . Said [Habundia]97-habundia , after [she]97-habundia had looked hard on [Birdalone]108-birdalone a while : Now there is this [I]0-i find in [thee]108-birdalone , that though [thou]108-birdalone callest [me]0-i [wood - mother]1619-wood - mother still , [thou]108-birdalone art not [[my]0-i daughter]889-my daughter as [thou]108-birdalone wert erewhile , nor [I]0-i [[thy]108-birdalone mother]323-thy mother ; and [I]0-i know not whether to be glad or sorry thereof , since [thou]108-birdalone art even as much [[my]0-i friend]304-my friend as ever [thou]108-birdalone wert . But much do [I]0-i rejoice herein that [thou]108-birdalone hast not told any one soul of [me]0-i . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : [I]0-i must tell [thee]108-birdalone that part of the tale [I]0-i shall tell [thee]108-birdalone is how [I]0-i have found [[my]0-i mother]894-my mother in the flesh , and loved [her]894-my mother sorely ; and then [I]0-i lost [her]894-my mother again , for [she]894-my mother is dead . Quoth [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife , smiling on [her]559-the wood - wife lovingly : Then should [I]0-i be even more [[thy]108-birdalone mother]323-thy mother than erst [I]0-i was : there will be something else in [thy]108-birdalone tale , sweetling . Then [Birdalone]108-birdalone flushed very red , and [she]108-birdalone smiled piteously in [Habundia]97-habundia â€™s face ; but then [she]108-birdalone put up [her]108-birdalone hands to hide the change therein which the anguish of longing wrought , and [her]108-birdalone shoulders shook and [her]108-birdalone bosom heaved , and [she]108-birdalone wept bitterly ; but [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife still looked on [her]559-the wood - wife smiling , and said softly at last : Yea , how sweet it were to be grieved with [thy]108-birdalone pain . But in a while [Birdalone]108-birdalone grew calm again and the very smile blossomed out in [her]108-birdalone face , and [they]3490-they kissed together . Then [Habundia]97-habundia rose up and looked on [her]108-birdalone , and said at last and laughed out withal : One thing [I]0-i must needs say , that [thou]3491-i hast not fetched [thee]3491-i raiment of price from [the knighthood]6127-the knighthood and [[the kings]1576-the kings â€™ houses]6805-the kings â€™ houses ; or have [I]3491-i not seen [thy]3491-i grey coat of old time , while [thou]3491-i wert living amidst [the witch]394-the witch â€™s cruelty ? Yea forsooth , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; [thou]3491-i needest not to ask this . Verily not , said [Habundia]97-habundia , nor why [thou]3491-i art not clad in the fair green gown which [thou]3491-i didst broider ; for whiles [I]3491-i have seen [the witch]394-the witch flaunting it on the wooden ugly body of [her]394-the witch , and [thou]3491-i wouldst not wear it after [she]394-the witch had cursed it with [her]394-the witch foulness . Is it not so ? Yea , it is even so , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; dost [thou]3491-i love [me]3491-i the less therefor ? [Habundia]97-habundia laughed again : Were [I]3491-i [a man of [Adam]96-adam â€™s sons]6808-a man of adam â€™s sons , said [she]97-habundia , [I]3491-i might make [thee]3491-i many words on the seemliness of [thy]3491-i short coat , and the kindness of it , that it will be for ever slipping off one or other of [thy]3491-i shoulders . But now am [I]3491-i at least enough [[thy]3491-i mother]323-thy mother , and [thou]3491-i art dwelling even so much in [[my]3491-i house]6084-my house , that the next time [we]6811-we meet ( and that shall be tomorrow ) [I]3491-i shall fetch [thee]3491-i raiment which shall make [us]6811-we forget that [thou]3491-i camest back again to [this land]1250-this land as naked as [thou]3491-i didst depart thence . [Birdalone]108-birdalone reddened and hung down [her]108-birdalone head , but [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother sat down beside [her]108-birdalone and kissed [her]108-birdalone and said : But now forget all save [thy]3491-i tale , and tell all as closely as [thou]3491-i mayest , for [I]3491-i would lose nought thereof . [Yea]6814-yea , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; and where shall [I]3491-i begin ? Said [Habundia]97-habundia : [I]3491-i know nought thereof save the beginning , that [thou]3491-i fledst away naked and escaped [the witch]394-the witch ; and the ending , to wit , that [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat failed [thee]3491-i at the last of [the Wonder Isles]31-wonder isles , and that [thou]3491-i calledst on [me]3491-i not wholly in vain , whereas [the witch]394-the witch was dead , and therefore there was nought to stay [me]3491-i from sending [thee]3491-i one of [[my]3491-i trees]6818-my trees and the wight thereof ( whom belike [I]3491-i may show to [thee]3491-i one day ) to save [thee]3491-i from [the bottom of [the deep water]6820-the deep water]6819-the bottom of the deep water . At that word [Birdalone]108-birdalone threw [herself]108-birdalone on [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife and clipped and kissed [her]559-the wood - wife , and thanked [her]559-the wood - wife for the helping with all the dearest words [she]108-birdalone might . But [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother laughed for joy , and stroked [her]108-birdalone cheeks and said : Now [I]3491-i deem [thee]108-birdalone [[my]3491-i daughter]889-my daughter again , whereas [thou]108-birdalone thankest [me]3491-i with such sweet passion for doing to [thee]108-birdalone as [a kind mother]6824-a kind mother needs must without any thought thereof . And [I]3491-i bid [thee]108-birdalone , [[my]3491-i dear]1824-my dear , never again to go so far from [me]3491-i as that [I]3491-i may not easily help [thee]108-birdalone and comfort [thee]108-birdalone from out of [[my]3491-i realm]6826-my realm wherein [I]3491-i am mighty . And now tell [me]3491-i all in [thy]108-birdalone dear speech . Therewith [Birdalone]108-birdalone began [her]108-birdalone story without more ado , even as [ye]6827-ye have heard it afore . Yea and many more things than [we]6828-we can set down did [she]108-birdalone tell , for full filled [she]108-birdalone was with the wisdom of [the wood]335-the wood . And between whiles [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother fed [her]108-birdalone with dainty meat and drink , such as [Birdalone]108-birdalone had never erst tasted the like of . And by then [she]108-birdalone had got so far as [her]108-birdalone flight from [the Isle of [Increase Unsought]29-increase unsought]17-the isle of increase unsought , the sun was set and the twilight begun . And [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife said : Now shalt [thou]108-birdalone go [home]373-home to [thine house]261-thine house ; and have no fear of witch or evil thing , for [I]3491-i am not far from [thee]108-birdalone and will watch over [thee]108-birdalone . Sweet is [thy]3491-i tale , [[my]3491-i daughter]889-my daughter , and dear are [[thy]3491-i [she]6291-thy she - friends - friends]6291-thy she - friends ; and if ever it may be that [I]3491-i may do [them]6291-thy she - friends any pleasure , fain were [I]3491-i ; and that especially to [[thy]3491-i Viridis , who meseemeth is both sweet and wise even as [thou]3491-i thyself art]108-birdalone . Nay , dost [thou]3491-i begrudge [my]3491-i loving [her]889-my daughter ? Nay , nay , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , laughing ; but [I]3491-i rejoice in it . And hereafter when [I]3491-i tell [thee]3491-i how sorely [they]6291-thy she - friends paid for helping [me]3491-i , [I]3491-i will bid [thee]3491-i to love [them]6291-thy she - friends yet more than now [thou]3491-i dost . Therewith [they]6291-thy she - friends parted , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone came to [[her]108-birdalone house]3204-her house ; and on the way [she]108-birdalone made as it were a feigned tale in mockery of [her]108-birdalone old trouble , that there would be [the witch - mistress]5838-the witch - mistress awaiting [her]108-birdalone to whip [her]108-birdalone . So that when [she]108-birdalone came to the door [she]108-birdalone was half frighted with [her]108-birdalone own mock , lest [the witch]394-the witch might now at last have taken to walking . But all was quiet when [she]108-birdalone entered with the last of the twilight , and [she]108-birdalone rested that night in all peace , as in the best of [her]108-birdalone days in [the Five Crafts]67-the five crafts . Chapter XIX ~ Habundia Hideth [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s Nakedness with Faery Raiment Next morning [Birdalone]108-birdalone tarried about [the house]311-the house as little a while as [she]108-birdalone might , and then went hastening up to [the wood]335-the wood ; and when [she]108-birdalone came within sight of [the Trysting Tree]6841-the trysting tree , lo ! there was [Habundia]97-habundia before [her]108-birdalone , and the hands of [her]108-birdalone busy turning over goodly raiment , so that it was well - nigh as if the days had gone back to the time of the Captivity , and [the sitter under the oak]6842-the sitter under the oak was [Birdalone]108-birdalone [herself]108-birdalone dealing with [her]108-birdalone half - finished gown . Joyously [they]6843-they met and embraced [each other]569-each other , and then spake [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife : Now , [[thou]559-the wood - wife darling of [the world]417-the world]6846-thou darling of the world , [I]3491-i have been no worse than [my]3491-i word , and if [thou]559-the wood - wife durst wear web of [the Faery]77-the faery [thou]559-the wood - wife shalt presently be clad as goodly as ever [thou]559-the wood - wife wert down there amongst [the knighthood]6127-the knighthood ; and then [thy]559-the wood - wife tale , [[my]3491-i dear]1824-my dear , and , if it may be , the wisdom of [the barren wood - wife]6850-the barren wood - wife set thereto . And therewith [she]559-the wood - wife laid on [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s outstretched arms the raiment [she]559-the wood - wife had brought with [her]559-the wood - wife , and it was as if the sunbeam had thrust through the close leafage of the oak , and made its shadow nought a space about [Birdalone]108-birdalone , so gleamed and glowed in shifty brightness the broidery of the gown ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone let it fall to earth , and passed over [her]108-birdalone hands and arms the fine smock sewed in yellow and white silk , so that the web thereof seemed of mingled cream and curd ; and [she]108-birdalone looked on the shoon that lay beside the gown , that were done so nicely and finely that the work was as the feather - robe of a beauteous bird , whereof one scarce can say whether it be bright or grey , thousand - hued or all simple of colour . [Birdalone]108-birdalone quivered for joy of the fair things , and crowed in [her]108-birdalone speech as [she]108-birdalone knelt before [Habundia]97-habundia to thank [her]97-habundia : then in a twinkling had [she]108-birdalone done off [her]108-birdalone beggar â€™s raiment , and then the smock clung about [her]108-birdalone darling nakedness , and next the gown was shimmering all over [her]108-birdalone , and the golden girdle embraced [her]108-birdalone loins as though it loved them worthily ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone looked to the wood round about [her]108-birdalone and laughed , while [Habundia]97-habundia lay in [her]108-birdalone place and smiled upon [her]108-birdalone with gentle loving - kindness . But in a little while was [Birdalone]108-birdalone sobered ; for the thought of how fair [she]108-birdalone should look to the eyes of [[her]108-birdalone beloved]5802-her beloved when [she]108-birdalone was shown unto [him]5802-her beloved on the day of days , thrust [her]108-birdalone light and eager pleasure aside ; and [she]108-birdalone took up [her]108-birdalone shoes from the ground ( for [she]108-birdalone had not done them on ) , and sat down beside [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife and fell a - toying with the marvel of [them]6853-them ; and thus without more ado began [her]108-birdalone tale again , whereas [she]108-birdalone had left it last even , when [she]108-birdalone had told of how [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat was speeding [her]108-birdalone over [the waters]624-the waters toward [the Isle of [the Young and the Old]120-the young]58-the isle of the young and the old . Chapter XX ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone Telleth [Habundia]97-habundia of [Her]108-birdalone Love for [Arthur]119-arthur , and Getteth from [Her]108-birdalone Promise of Help Therein Long [they]6856-they sat there that day , and until the sun was down , and by then had [Birdalone]108-birdalone little to tell of [her]108-birdalone story , for [she]108-birdalone was gotten therein to the days of the Five Crafts . Many times had [she]108-birdalone wept and turned to [Habundia]97-habundia for solace as [she]108-birdalone told , not without shame , but without any covering up , all the tale of [her]108-birdalone love for [Arthur the Black Squire]119-arthur , and how [she]108-birdalone was surprised by the love of [him]119-arthur , and of [his]119-arthur wisdom and grace and loveliness . And [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother was ever as sweet and kind unto [her]108-birdalone as could be ; yet might another than [a lover]532-a lover have seen that much of all this was strange unto [her]108-birdalone , and [she]925-the wood - mother looked upon [Birdalone]108-birdalone as [a child who has broken [her]108-birdalone toy , and is hard to comfort for the loss of it , though there be a many more in [the world]417-the world]6859-a child who has broken her toy , and is hard to comfort for the loss of it , though there be a many more in the world . But when it grew dusk as aforesaid , and it was time to part , [she]925-the wood - mother spake to [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and said : True it is , [[my]3491-i child]907-my child , that [thou]6862-thou hast lived long in these six years time ; neither do [I]3491-i wonder at the increase of [thy]6862-thou beauty , and the majesty thereof ; for fair is the life [thou]6862-thou hast lived , although [thou]6862-thou hast been grieved and tormented by it at whiles . And now [I]3491-i know what it is for which [thou]6862-thou longest ; and herein again will [I]3491-i play [the mother]252-the mother unto [thee]6862-thou , and seek about to fetch [thee]6862-thou that [thou]6862-thou wouldst have ; so be not over - anxious or troubled ; and [thou]6862-thou mayest be good herein , as [[my]3491-i fair child]6864-my fair child should be ; for this [I]3491-i have noted in [thee]6862-thou , that Love is not so tyrannous [a master]6865-a master but that [[his]6865-a master servants]6866-his servants may whiles think of other matters , and so solace [their]6866-his servants souls , that [they]6866-his servants may live despite of all . Now was [Birdalone]108-birdalone arisen , and stood before [[her]108-birdalone friend]433-her friend confused and blushing . But [Habundia]97-habundia put [her]97-habundia two hands on [her]433-her friend shoulders and kissed [her]433-her friend , and said : Go [home]373-home now and sleep , and come again tomorrow and let [us]6869-us hear the last of [thy]108-birdalone tale ; and when that is done , maybe [I]3491-i shall be able to do something for thine avail . So [they]6869-us parted , and on the morrow [Birdalone]108-birdalone came again and told the remnant of [her]108-birdalone story , which was not so long now that [the Black Squire]119-arthur was out of it . And when [she]108-birdalone had done , [Habundia]97-habundia kept silence awhile , and then [she]97-habundia said : One thing [I]3491-i will tell [thee]433-her friend , that whereas erewhile it was but seldom indeed that [any son of [Adam]96-adam]6870-any son of adam might be seen in [the woodland]657-the woodland here , of late , that is , within the last three years , there be many such amongst [us]6869-us ; and to [our]6869-us deeming [they]6872-they be evil beasts , more pitiless and greedy than any bear ; and but that [we]6869-us have nought to do with [them]6872-they , for [they]6872-they fear [us]6869-us and flee from [us]6869-us , [we]6869-us should have destroyed [them]6872-they one and all . And now that [I]3491-i have heard all [thy]433-her friend story , it seemeth unto [me]3491-i not so unlike but these may be the remnants of the bands of the Red Hold , and that [they]6872-they have drifted hither fleeing before the might of [[thy]433-her friend friends of [the knighthood]6127-the knighthood]6873-thy friends of the knighthood . Wherefore now , trust [me]3491-i that [I]3491-i will look into this , but [I]3491-i must needs be away from [here]244-here for a little ; so hold [thy]433-her friend soul in patience though hear [thou]433-her friend nought of [me]3491-i , and dwell quietly at [home]373-home for seven days â€™[3491-i] space , and then come hither and find [me]0-i , farewell now , [[my]0-i child]907-my child ! So [they]3495-they kissed and departed ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone went [home]373-home to [the house]311-the house , and wore the days thereafter doing what was needful about the stead , and wandering through [the meadows]1769-the meadows , and swimming the waters about [Green Eyot]6-green eyot ; and the days were not unrestful unto [her]108-birdalone . Chapter XXI ~ How [the Wood - Wife]559-the wood - wife Entered [the Cot]78-the cot , and A Wonder That Befell Thereon But when it was the sixth day since [those two]4775-those two had met , [Birdalone]108-birdalone arose in the morning and stood in the door of [the house]311-the house , and [she]108-birdalone looked toward the bent which went up to the wood and saw one coming down it , and knew it for [Habundia]97-habundia clad in [her]97-habundia huntress â€™ raiment and bearing something over the left arm , for [her]97-habundia bow was in [her]97-habundia right hand . So [Birdalone]108-birdalone ran to meet [her]97-habundia , and embraced and kissed [her]97-habundia , and was merry over [her]97-habundia , and said : [Dear mother]985-dear mother , [thou]97-habundia farest far from [thy]97-habundia fastness today . Said [Habundia]97-habundia : There is nought in [the meadows]1769-the meadows now save the neat and the goats and [thou]97-habundia ; of [none of that folk]6879-none of that folk am [I]108-birdalone afraid . But mayhappen [thou]97-habundia shalt be afraid to come with [me]108-birdalone into the depths of the wildwood , for [thither]6880-thither would [I]108-birdalone lead [thee]97-habundia . [I]108-birdalone will be afraid of nought with [thee]97-habundia beside [me]108-birdalone , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone . But come now and look upon [the house that [I]108-birdalone have won for [me]108-birdalone]6881-the house that i have won for me . And [she]108-birdalone took [her]108-birdalone hand and led [her]108-birdalone along ; and [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife said no more till [they]6883-they were across [the brook]700-the brook and standing by [the porch]652-the porch . Then said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : [Thou]97-habundia hast a green gown over thine arm ; is that also for [me]108-birdalone ? Yea , certes , said [Habundia]97-habundia ; the old rag which [thou]97-habundia hast on [thee]97-habundia , and which [thou]97-habundia lovest so sore , is not fine enough for [my]108-birdalone company ; and the glitter - gown [I]108-birdalone gave [thee]97-habundia may be too fine for the thorns and the briars , and moreover [thou]97-habundia mayst be over - easily seen if [thou]97-habundia bear that broidered sunshine mid the boughs . Wherefore go in now and do on this other coat , though [the faery]4682-the faery have made it , and then come out to [me]108-birdalone with [thy]97-habundia bow and [thy]97-habundia quiver , and [I]108-birdalone shall find [thee]97-habundia sandal - shoon and girdle withal . Nay , [wood - mother]1619-wood - mother , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , hallow [[my]108-birdalone house]6084-my house by entering [it]6084-my house , and eat a morsel with [me]108-birdalone and drink the wine of [the horned folk]6889-the horned folk ere [we]6890-we go [our]6890-we ways . [Habundia]97-habundia shook [her]97-habundia head and knit [her]97-habundia brows somewhat as [she]97-habundia looked hard on [the house]311-the house ; then [she]97-habundia said : [I]108-birdalone know not , [[Adam]96-adam â€™s daughter]6892-adam â€™s daughter ; [I]108-birdalone have little to do with [houses]6346-houses , and doubt if [a house]6080-a house be safe for [me]108-birdalone . And this one that [the witch]394-the witch builded ! and belike [she]394-the witch buried [some human being]6896-some human being at one of [its]311-the house four corners . Tell [me]108-birdalone , [fair child]950-fair child , sawest [thou]6898-thou ever here at night - tide the shape of [a youngling crowned with a garland straying about the house]6899-a youngling crowned with a garland straying about the house ? Nay , never at all , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone . Said [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife : Then maybe [thou]6898-thou hast hallowed it with the wisdom and love of [thee]6898-thou , and [I]108-birdalone may venture ; and moreover [I]108-birdalone note that it is all builded of trees and the grass of [the earth]432-the earth ; and [thou]6898-thou art free to use them by [my]108-birdalone leave . But if aught befall of [my]108-birdalone coming under [thy]6898-thou roof , heed it not too much , but think , whatsoever [my]108-birdalone aspect may be , [I]108-birdalone am [thy]6898-thou wood - mother and wisdom - mother that loveth [thee]6898-thou . And [I]108-birdalone bid [thee]6898-thou also wish with all [thy]6898-thou might that [my]108-birdalone aspect may not change to [thee]6898-thou . Also , if [I]108-birdalone eat , [thou]6898-thou wert best not to sign the meat as [[Adam]96-adam â€™s sons]6902-adam â€™s sons are wo nt . Lead in then ; for now am [I]108-birdalone grown wilful , and will enter whatever betide . [Birdalone]108-birdalone marvelled at those words , but [she]108-birdalone fell to wishing strongly that [[her]108-birdalone friend]433-her friend might not lose [her]433-her friend lovely youthful shape either then or ever , and [she]108-birdalone took [her]108-birdalone hand , which trembled somewhat , and led [her]433-her friend over the threshold ; and when [they]6904-they were under the roof herseemed that [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother dwindled in a wondrous way , though [her]925-the wood - mother face was as sweet and [her]925-the wood - mother limbs as shapely as ever ; and [she]925-the wood - mother laughed shrilly yet sweetly , and spake in a thin clear voice : [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [[my]108-birdalone dear]1824-my dear , wish strongly , wish strongly ! though [thou]6898-thou shalt see nothing worse of [me]108-birdalone than this . And [she]925-the wood - mother was scarce three feet high , but as pretty as a picture . Thereat indeed was [Birdalone]108-birdalone affrighted , but [she]108-birdalone wished all [she]108-birdalone might , and stooped down to kiss [this little creature]6907-this little creature ; and therewith again [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife seemed to wax again as great and tall as ever [she]559-the wood - wife was , and [her]559-the wood - wife voice came full and strong again , as [she]559-the wood - wife laughed and said : Now is it all over for this time , and [I]108-birdalone see how well [thou]6898-thou lovest [me]108-birdalone ; and [I]108-birdalone pray [thee]6898-thou love [me]108-birdalone no less for this wonder [thou]6898-thou hast seen in [me]108-birdalone . But now it were better that [I]108-birdalone never go under a roof again . And [she]559-the wood - wife took [her]559-the wood - wife arms about [Birdalone]108-birdalone and clipped [her]108-birdalone lovingly ; and glad was [Birdalone]108-birdalone to feel [her]559-the wood - wife so strong and solid again . Then [they]6909-they sat to the board and ate a simple meal of bread and cheese and wood - berries , and drank milk withal ; and [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother was merry , and the smiles danced over [her]925-the wood - mother face as [she]925-the wood - mother looked on [Birdalone]108-birdalone with all loving - kindness , so that [Birdalone]108-birdalone wondered what was toward ; but so light - hearted and happy [she]108-birdalone grew , that [she]108-birdalone deemed it might be nought save good . But when [they]6909-they had eaten , then [Birdalone]108-birdalone did off [her]108-birdalone old coat , which [she]108-birdalone said was meet enough for [her]108-birdalone daily toil , and did on the fair green hunting - gown and the sandal - shoon , and girt [her]108-birdalone with the fair girdle which [Habundia]97-habundia had fetched [her]108-birdalone , and drew up the laps of [her]108-birdalone gown therethrough till [her]108-birdalone legs were all free of the skirts . And [Habundia]97-habundia looked on [her]108-birdalone , and laughed and said : Now are these white and smooth legs as bad as the gleam - gown for the lying hid ; but it may no better be , and [thou]6911-thou must draw [thy]6911-thou skirts down and stumble , if needs must be , when [we]6909-they come to the ambushment . [Birdalone]108-birdalone reddened as [she]108-birdalone laughed at the word , and took down [her]108-birdalone bow and hung [her]108-birdalone quiver at [her]108-birdalone back and thrust [her]108-birdalone sharp knife into [her]108-birdalone girdle , and forth [they]6909-they went both of [them]6909-they , and were presently past the bent which went up from [the meadows]1769-the meadows and in amongst [[Habundia]97-habundia â€™s trees]6913-habundia â€™s trees . Chapter XXII ~ [Birdalone]108-birdalone Wendeth [the Wildwood in [Fellowship]79-fellowship]6914-the wildwood in fellowship with [Habundia]97-habundia Now as [they]6909-they went [their]6909-they ways lightly through [the wood]335-the wood , spake [Habundia]97-habundia and said : [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [[my]108-birdalone child]907-my child , fair is the gold ring with the sapphire stone that the third finger of [thy]907-my child right hand beareth ; seldom have [I]108-birdalone seen so fair a stone as that deep blue one ; hangeth any tale thereby ? Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone : Did [I]108-birdalone not tell [thee]97-habundia thereof , [wood - mother]1619-wood - mother , how that [[my]108-birdalone beloved who is lost]6918-my beloved who is lost gave it unto [me]108-birdalone the very last time [I]108-birdalone saw [him]6918-my beloved who is lost , woe worth the while ? Nay , said [Habundia]97-habundia , [I]108-birdalone mind not the tale . But deemest [thou]97-habundia [he]6918-my beloved who is lost would know it again if [he]6918-my beloved who is lost saw it ? Yea , surely , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , hanging [her]108-birdalone head ; for when first [he]6918-my beloved who is lost gave it , the gift was not to [me]108-birdalone , but to [another woman]6919-another woman . And [she]108-birdalone held [her]108-birdalone peace , and went on with hanging head and all the glee faded out of [her]108-birdalone a while . At last [she]108-birdalone turned to [Habundia]97-habundia , and said : [I]108-birdalone have now bethought [me]108-birdalone to ask [thee]97-habundia whither [we]6920-we be going and on what errand ; for at first [I]108-birdalone was so glad at heart , [I]108-birdalone know not why , and it was so merry to be wending [the wood]335-the wood with [thee]97-habundia freely , that [I]108-birdalone had no thought in [me]108-birdalone as to whither and wherefore . But now wilt [thou]97-habundia tell [me]108-birdalone ? Said [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife : How if [I]108-birdalone were to tell [thee]97-habundia [we]6920-we were going a - hunting ? [Birdalone]108-birdalone said : Then [I]108-birdalone should ask [thee]559-the wood - wife what like [the quarry were]6923-the quarry were . And suppose it were [men]204-men ? said [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife . [Birdalone]108-birdalone turned somewhat pale . [[My]108-birdalone mother]894-my mother , [she]108-birdalone said , if [we]6920-we be going against [some of [those men of the Red Bands]6928-those men of the red bands]6927-some of those men of the red bands , [I]108-birdalone am not happy over it . [I]108-birdalone am [no warrior]6383-no warrior , and fear strokes . Said [Habundia]97-habundia , laughing : Yet art [thou]97-habundia [a fell archer]6930-a fell archer ; and [thou]97-habundia mayest shoot from an ambush of the thick leaves , since [June]92-june is in today . But neither would [I]108-birdalone slay or hurt [any man]4683-any man , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , but it were to save [me]108-birdalone from present death . [Habundia]97-habundia looked on [her]108-birdalone with a sly smile and said : Well maybe though [we]6920-we take cover and get within wind of [[our]6920-we quarry]6932-our quarry [thou]97-habundia shalt not need to speed an arrow to [him]6932-our quarry . Have patience therefore . For this is a strange beast which [I]108-birdalone have marked down ; [he]6932-our quarry is not ill to look on , and [his]6932-our quarry voice , which [we]6920-we may well hearken , for whiles [he]6932-our quarry singeth , is rather sweet than surly . What meanest [thou]97-habundia , [mother]729-mother ? said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , growing red and then paler yet ; what [man]537-man is it ? since [thy]97-habundia calling [him]6932-our quarry [a beast]6935-a beast is a jest , is it not ? Nay , said [Habundia]97-habundia , [I]108-birdalone neither name [him]6932-our quarry nor know [him]6932-our quarry ; only [I]108-birdalone deem [him]6932-our quarry by no means to be [one of [the Red Band]6937-the red band]6936-one of the red band . For the rest , [he]6932-our quarry may be [a man in a beast â€™s skin]6938-a man in a beast â€™s skin , or a beast in [a man]217-a man â€™s skin , for aught [I]108-birdalone know ; whereas [he]6932-our quarry seems , so far as [I]108-birdalone have seen [him]6932-our quarry , to be not wholly man - like or wholly beast - like . But now let [us]6940-they hold [our]6940-they peace of [him]6932-our quarry till [we]6940-they be come nigher to [[his]6932-our quarry haunt]6941-his haunt . So [they]6940-they went on [their]6940-they way , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone said but little , while [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife was of many words and gay . [They]6940-they made all diligence , for [Birdalone]108-birdalone was not soon wearied , and moreover as now [she]559-the wood - wife was anxious and eager to see what would befall , which [she]559-the wood - wife might not but deem would be something great . [They]6940-they went without stay till past noon , when [they]6940-they were come to [a little shady dale wherethrough ran a clear stream]6943-a little shady dale wherethrough ran a clear stream ; there [they]6940-they rested and bathed [them]6940-they , and thereafter sat under the boughs and ate the dainty meat which [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife provided , howsoever [she]559-the wood - wife came by it ; and when [they]6940-they had rested a while , [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife turned the talk once more unto [Arthur the Black Squire]119-arthur , and would have [Birdalone]108-birdalone tell [her]559-the wood - wife all nicely what manner of [man]537-man [he]119-arthur was ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone was nothing loth thereto ; for had [she]559-the wood - wife [her]559-the wood - wife will [she]559-the wood - wife had talked of [him]119-arthur day - long . Chapter XXIII ~ [The Wood - Wife]559-the wood - wife Bringeth [Birdalone]108-birdalone to the Sight of [Arthur]119-arthur in [the Wildwood]80-the wildwood Now [they]6940-they go on again , no less speedily than before , and rest but little , until it was hard on an hour before sunset . And now [Habundia]97-habundia began to go warily , as if [they]6940-they were come anigh to [their]6940-they journey â€™s end and the thing that [they]6940-they sought . [They]6940-they were come by now to a long bent of [the forest]6120-the forest well grown with big - boled oak - trees , not very close together , so that short fine greensward was all underneath [them]6940-they ; and [Habundia]97-habundia went heedfully from bole to bole , as if [she]97-habundia would be ready to cover [herself]97-habundia if need were ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone went after [her]97-habundia , and was now flushed of face , and [her]108-birdalone eyes glittered , and [her]108-birdalone heart beat fast , and [her]108-birdalone legs trembled under [her]108-birdalone , as [she]108-birdalone went running from tree to tree . So came [they]6940-they nigh to the crown of the bent , and before [them]6940-they were the oak - trees sparser and smaller as [they]6940-they went down the further side , which seemed by [their]6940-they sudden shortening to be steeper than the hither side ; and betwixt [them]6940-they showed the topmost of thorn and whitebeam and logwood , intertwined with eglantine and honeysuckle and the new shoots of [the traveller]6949-the traveller â€™s joy . There [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife put forth [her]559-the wood - wife hand to bid [Birdalone]108-birdalone stay , who came up to [[her]559-the wood - wife friend]433-her friend and stood before [her]559-the wood - wife eager and quivering : and anon came the sound of [a man]217-a man â€™s voice singing , though [they]6940-they could hear no words in it as yet amidst the rustle of the trees and the tumult of song which the blackbirds and throstles raised in [the dale below [them]6940-they]6953-the dale below them . Then spake [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife softly : Hearken , [we]6940-they are right and the time is good , [our]6940-they beast is giving tongue : now below [us]6940-they is [the bent - side steep]6955-the bent - side steep , and goeth down into [a very little dale]6956-a very little dale with a clear stream running amidst ; and therein is [the very lair of the thing that [we]6940-they are hunting]6957-the very lair of the thing that we are hunting . Wherefore now let [us]6940-they slip warily down between the bushes till [we]6940-they get close to the bottom , and then belike [we]6940-they shall see the very creature quite close , and [we]6940-they shall then consider and think what [we]6940-they shall do with [him]6958-him . [Birdalone]108-birdalone had no voice wherewith to answer [her]559-the wood - wife , but [she]108-birdalone stole quietly along by [her]108-birdalone side till [they]6940-they came to [the bank of [the dale]4999-the dale]6959-the bank of the dale and plunged into the thicket that flourished there , and fell to threading it , making [them]6940-they as small as might be . But ere [they]6940-they had gone but a little way the wordless song of what was below had ceased , and [they]6940-they heard the sweet tingle of the string - play , and [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife stayed [her]559-the wood - wife to hearken , and the smiles went rippling over [her]559-the wood - wife face and [she]559-the wood - wife beat time with [her]559-the wood - wife fingers ; but [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [she]108-birdalone stared wildly before [her]559-the wood - wife , and would have scrambled down [the bank]1035-the bank straightway at all hazards , for that string - play was a melody of [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]25-the castle of the quest , but [Habundia]97-habundia withheld [her]108-birdalone by the arm . And then suddenly the music died , and there came up a voice of wailing and lamenting , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone put [her]108-birdalone hands and held the palms tight against [her]108-birdalone ears , and was at point to cry out aloud [herself]108-birdalone ; but [Habundia]97-habundia drew a hand of [her]108-birdalone down and whispered into [her]108-birdalone ear : [Child]283-child , [child]283-child , make [thyself]6965-thyself strong and forbear , and then perchance joy may come to [thee]283-child ; hold [thy]283-child peace and come softly along with [me]108-birdalone ! So [Birdalone]108-birdalone forbore , and strove with [her]108-birdalone passion , though the sobs rent [her]108-birdalone bosom for a while ; and by then the loud lamenting waned and was done , and the sound of sobbing came up from below , as it had been an echo of [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s grief . Then [Habundia]97-habundia drew [her]108-birdalone on again till [they]6966-they saw the level of [the dale]4999-the dale and [its]4999-the dale stream piecemeal betwixt the leaves , and [they]6966-they had a glimpse of [a man on the hither side of]6968-a man on the hither side of [the stream]1777-the stream ; and again [they]6966-they went lower , till [they]6966-they were well - nigh on a level with [the greensward of the dale]6970-the greensward of the dale ; and as [Birdalone]108-birdalone knelt with head bent low , and [her]108-birdalone hands covering [her]108-birdalone eyes , [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife put away from before [her]559-the wood - wife the thick leaves of a hazel - bush , and whispering said : [Child]283-child , [child]283-child ! look forth now and see what is before [thee]283-child , and see if [thou]283-child knowest [him]6968-a man on the hither side of , or if [he]6968-a man on the hither side of be strange to [thee]283-child , and [[thy]283-child mother]323-thy mother hath done nought for [thee]283-child when all is said . [Birdalone]108-birdalone looked up , pale and wild - eyed , and into [the dale]4999-the dale , and saw [a man sitting on the grass by [the stream - side]6977-the stream - side]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side with [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side head bowed down on to [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side knees and [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side face covered with [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side hands ; [he]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side was clad but in two or three deerskins hung about [him]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side , with a strip of skin for a girdle , wherein was thrust a short sword ; [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side brown hair hung down long and shaggy over [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side face . Close by [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side side lay a little harp , and further off a short spear roughly hefted with an ash - staff . [He]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side was beating the earth with [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side feet and writhing [him]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side about over [them]6978-them . And [Birdalone]108-birdalone looked , and [her]108-birdalone breath well - nigh failed [her]108-birdalone . For presently [he]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side sat more quietly , and lifted up [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side head , and [she]108-birdalone saw [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side face that it was [Arthur]119-arthur , [[her]108-birdalone beloved]5802-her beloved ; and now [she]108-birdalone durst not move lest [he]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side should spring up and flee away ; and the mingled pain and longing within [her]108-birdalone was sweet indeed , but well - nigh deadly . Now [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side hand sought round to [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side harp , and [he]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side took it in [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side arms and fondled it as it were , and [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side fingers went among the strings , and anon the voice of it came forth , and it was nought changed from the last time it spake , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone hearkened breathlessly , till the melody died again and [Arthur]119-arthur looked about [him]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side and raised [his]119-arthur face as a dog when it fares to howl . Then [Birdalone]108-birdalone gave a great cry , and leapt forth out of the thicket and stood on the greensward with nought betwixt them two , and [she]108-birdalone stretched out [her]108-birdalone arms to [[her]108-birdalone beloved]5802-her beloved and cried out : O ! no , no , no ! do it not , [I]108-birdalone beseech [thee]5802-her beloved , lest [I]108-birdalone deem that [thou]5802-her beloved art all changed , and that [the man]5167-the man and [the dear heart beloved of [thee]5802-her beloved]6982-the dear heart beloved of thee has gone out of [thee]5802-her beloved and left [thee]5802-her beloved but a beast in [a man]217-a man â€™s shape ! [He]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side leapt up as [she]108-birdalone spake , and thrust forward [his]6976-a man sitting on the grass by the stream - side head and looked fierce at [her]108-birdalone , and cried out : What ! art [thou]5802-her beloved come again ? This is the second time [I]108-birdalone have seen [thee]108-birdalone , [thou]108-birdalone image of [her]108-birdalone that hath tormented [me]108-birdalone so long ; of [her]108-birdalone that left [me]108-birdalone in [my]108-birdalone most need and hid [herself]108-birdalone away from [me]108-birdalone . [Hah]6984-hah ! [a man]217-a man , sayest [thou]5802-her beloved ? Did [I]108-birdalone not strive with it , and hold [my]108-birdalone manhood so long as [I]108-birdalone might ; and at last it might no longer be , and [I]108-birdalone became a beast and [a man - slayer]6986-a man - slayer ? But what avails it to talk with [thee]108-birdalone , since [thou]108-birdalone art but the image of [her]108-birdalone that hath wasted [my]108-birdalone life . Yet perchance of the image [I]108-birdalone may make an end since [I]108-birdalone may not lay hand on the very destroyer [herself]108-birdalone ; and , woe â€™s [me]108-birdalone , how [I]108-birdalone loved [her]108-birdalone ! yea , and do still ; but not [thee]108-birdalone , [O false image]6987-o false image !
