And forthwith [he]217-a man drew the blade from [his]217-a man girdle and sprang forward at [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; and [she]108-birdalone cowered and cringed , but moved not else . But therewithal [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife came leaping through the bushes , and [she]559-the wood - wife nocked an arrow on [her]559-the wood - wife bended bow , and threatened [him]217-a man therewith , and cried out : [[Thou]108-birdalone man - beast]6989-thou man - beast , [I]108-birdalone will slay [thee]108-birdalone if [thou]108-birdalone hurt [[my]108-birdalone child]907-my child and [[my]108-birdalone dear]1824-my dear ; so forbear ! Nay , [I]108-birdalone tell [thee]108-birdalone more , unless [thou]108-birdalone make [her]108-birdalone as glad at the sight of [thee]108-birdalone as [I]108-birdalone meant [her]108-birdalone to be , [I]108-birdalone will in the long run slay [thee]108-birdalone ; so look to it . [He]217-a man laughed and said : What ! there is another image of the love that wasted [me]108-birdalone , is there ! Nay , but by [the Hallows]192-the hallows , [this new - comer]6992-this new - comer is [the first one]6993-the first one , and the one who chattered at [me]108-birdalone is the second . Or is it this , that [all women]6994-all women now have the semblance of the evil one that has undone [me]108-birdalone , and there is nought else left ? And [he]217-a man stood staring at [Birdalone]108-birdalone and moved not a while ; and [she]108-birdalone stood with [her]108-birdalone hands before [her]108-birdalone face cringing before [him]217-a man . Then [he]217-a man raised [his]217-a man arm and cast the weapon far into the bushes of [the bank - side]6995-the bank - side , and then came forward and stood before [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and drew down [her]108-birdalone hands from [her]108-birdalone face and stared in the eyes of [her]108-birdalone , holding [her]108-birdalone by the two arms ; and [he]217-a man said : [Thou]6996-thou hast forgotten now , belike , how fair a life [we]6997-we two might have lived if [thou]6996-thou hadst not fled from [me]108-birdalone and spoiled [me]108-birdalone . And [thou]6996-thou ! by the looks of [thee]6996-thou , for [thou]6996-thou art sleek and fair , though this moment [thou]6996-thou art pale for fear of [me]108-birdalone , [thou]6996-thou hast lived a happy life through all these years , with many a merry thing to think of : and dost [thou]6996-thou deem that [my]108-birdalone life was happy , or that [I]108-birdalone thought of any merry thing , or of anything save [my]108-birdalone sorrow ? Dost [thou]6996-thou doubt it ? go ask [the good spears of [Greenford]39-greenford]6998-the good spears of greenford , or the Riders of the Red Hold , and [the field of the slaughter]6999-the field of the slaughter ! If there was little joy there , less was there elsewhere . [He]217-a man left go of [her]6996-thou therewith and stood trembling before [her]6996-thou , and [she]6996-thou bowed down and put palm to palm and held them out to [him]217-a man as [one who prays]7000-one who prays ; and [she]6996-thou knew not what [she]6996-thou did . Then [he]217-a man cried out with a lamentable cry and said : O woe â€™s [me]108-birdalone ! for [I]108-birdalone have frighted [her]6996-thou and scared the wit out of [her]6996-thou , so that [she]6996-thou knows not who [I]108-birdalone am nor what [I]108-birdalone would ; and [I]108-birdalone would pray to [her]6996-thou and beseech [her]6996-thou to pity [me]108-birdalone , and not depart from [me]108-birdalone again or mock [me]108-birdalone with images of [herself]6996-thou . Then [he]217-a man went down on [his]217-a man knees to [her]6996-thou , and [he]217-a man also joined [his]217-a man hands to pray to [her]6996-thou ; but it seemed as if [she]6996-thou was stricken to stone , so wholly [she]6996-thou moved not . But for [him]217-a man , [he]217-a man sank [his]217-a man forehead to earth , and then [he]217-a man rolled over and [his]217-a man limbs stretched out , and [his]217-a man head turned aside and blood gushed out from [his]217-a man mouth . But [Birdalone]108-birdalone shrieked out and cast [herself]108-birdalone on [his]217-a man body , and cried : [I]108-birdalone have found [him]217-a man , and [he]217-a man is dead ! [he]217-a man is dead , and [I]108-birdalone have slain [him]217-a man , because [I]108-birdalone was [a timorous fool]7001-a timorous fool and feared [him]217-a man ; and [he]217-a man was coming to [his]217-a man right mind and knew [me]108-birdalone for what [I]108-birdalone was ! But [Habundia]97-habundia came and stood over [them]7002-we , and drew up [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and said : Nay , nay , be comforted ! for now [he]217-a man is thus , and the strength is gone out of [him]217-a man for a while , [we]7002-we may deal with [him]217-a man . Abide , and [I]108-birdalone will fetch the blood - staunching herb and the sleepy herb , and then [we]7002-we will heal [him]217-a man , and [he]217-a man will come to [his]217-a man right mind and be [a man]217-a man again . Therewith [she]108-birdalone hastened away and was gone but a little ; and meanwhile [Birdalone]108-birdalone knelt down by [[her]108-birdalone love]7004-her love and wiped the blood from [him]217-a man , and caressed [his]217-a man sword - hardened hands and moaned over [him]217-a man . But when [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife came back [she]559-the wood - wife put [Birdalone]108-birdalone aside once more , and knelt down by [the squire]2382-the squire and raised [his]217-a man head , and laid the blood - stauncher to [his]217-a man mouth and [his]217-a man heart , and muttered words over [him]217-a man , while [Birdalone]108-birdalone looked over [her]559-the wood - wife shoulder with [her]559-the wood - wife pale face ; then the [she]559-the wood - wife - leech fetched water from the stream in a cup which [she]559-the wood - wife drew from [her]559-the wood - wife wallet , and [she]559-the wood - wife washed [his]217-a man face , and [he]217-a man came somewhat to [himself]217-a man , so that [she]559-the wood - wife might give [him]217-a man drink of the water ; and yet more [he]217-a man came to [himself]217-a man . So then [she]559-the wood - wife took the sleepy herb and bruised it in [her]559-the wood - wife hands and put in [his]217-a man mouth and again said words over [him]217-a man , and presently [his]217-a man head fell back and [his]217-a man eyes closed and [he]217-a man slept peacefully . [She]559-the wood - wife stood up then and turned to [Birdalone]108-birdalone and said : Now , [[my]108-birdalone child]907-my child , have [we]7008-we done all that [we]7008-we may do , save that [we]7008-we shall bring [him]217-a man to a place where the dew and the sun shall not torment [him]217-a man and sicken [him]217-a man ; for [he]217-a man shall lie thus till the sun comes up tomorrow , or longer ; and fear nor , for when [he]217-a man awaketh [he]217-a man shall be in [his]217-a man right mind , and shall know [thee]108-birdalone and love [thee]108-birdalone . This [I]108-birdalone swear to [thee]108-birdalone by [the earth]432-the earth and the sun and [the woodland]657-the woodland . Said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , trembling yet : O [mother]729-mother , but may [I]108-birdalone kiss [him]217-a man and caress [him]217-a man ? [Yea]7012-yea , surely , said [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother , smiling in [her]925-the wood - mother face , but be not too long over it , for lo ! the last of the sun , and it were better that [he]217-a man be under cover ere the twilight falls . [Birdalone]108-birdalone knelt down by [[her]108-birdalone love]7004-her love quietly at that word , and fell to kissing [him]217-a man softly , and laid [her]108-birdalone cheek to [his]217-a man , and called [him]217-a man gentle names such as none can tell again without shame , till [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife laid [her]559-the wood - wife hand on [her]559-the wood - wife shoulder and said kindly and sweetly : Rise up now , for [thou]7016-thou must make it enough for this present ; [thou]7016-thou shalt have time enough hereafter for more and much more . So [Birdalone]108-birdalone arose and said : How shall [we]7017-we bear [him]217-a man to [[his]217-a man place]7018-his place ? Shall [I]108-birdalone not take [him]217-a man by the shoulders and [thou]7016-thou by the legs ? For [I]108-birdalone am stronger than [thou]7016-thou after all these years . Laughed [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife : Nay , [little one]7020-little one , said [she]559-the wood - wife ; [thou]7016-thou knowest [me]108-birdalone not utterly as yet . [Thou]7016-thou shalt not bear [him]217-a man at all , nor any part of [him]217-a man ; [I]108-birdalone am strong enough for more than that ; see [thou]7016-thou ! And [she]559-the wood - wife stooped down and took [him]217-a man up in [her]559-the wood - wife arms as if [he]217-a man were [a little child]3092-a little child , and stepped off lightly with [him]217-a man ; but looked back over [her]559-the wood - wife shoulder and said to [Birdalone]108-birdalone : But [thou]7016-thou mayest walk by [me]108-birdalone and hold a hand of [him]217-a man as [we]7022-they go , though it will hinder [me]108-birdalone somewhat ; but [I]108-birdalone know [thine]7016-thou heart and would pleasure [thee]217-a man , [[my]108-birdalone child]907-my child . [Birdalone]108-birdalone ran up to [her]559-the wood - wife and thanked [her]559-the wood - wife and kissed [her]559-the wood - wife , and took [Arthur]119-arthur â€™s left hand , while [Habundia]97-habundia bore [him]217-a man on down [the dale]4999-the dale and out of it , and still along [the stream]1777-the stream till [they]7022-they came to a place where [it]1777-the stream was narrow on either side thereof , and a sheer rock came down so near to the water that there was but a strip of greensward three yards wide betwixt [water and rock]7026-water and rock ; and in the face of [the rock]1543-the rock was a cave wide enough for [a man to enter by stooping somewhat]7028-a man to enter by stooping somewhat . Therein [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife lightly bore [Arthur]119-arthur , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone followed ; and [they]7022-they found [the cave]2843-the cave dry and roomy within ; there was a bed [therein of dry heather and bracken]7031-therein of dry heather and bracken , and thereon [Habundia]97-habundia laid [her]97-habundia burden , and said : Now , [[my]108-birdalone child]907-my child , there is nought to do but abide till [he]119-arthur comes to [himself]119-arthur again , which may be some time tomorrow ; and be of good cheer , for [he]119-arthur will come to [his]119-arthur right self , but [he]119-arthur will be weak and humble ; but [I]108-birdalone shall have meat and drink ready for [him]119-arthur . Now if [thou]119-arthur wilt be ruled by [me]108-birdalone , [thou]119-arthur wilt keep out of the way when [he]119-arthur awakens ; moreover , be [thou]119-arthur not scared if [I]108-birdalone meet [his]119-arthur awakening with another shape than that which [thou]119-arthur hast known of [me]108-birdalone ; for sure it is that it will trouble [his]119-arthur wits over - much if again [he]119-arthur seeth [the two of [us]7033-the two of us]7033-the two of us alike . But fear not ; for [thy]119-arthur sake , [[my]108-birdalone child]907-my child , [I]108-birdalone will take no ugly shape , though it may well be less beauteous than thine . [I]108-birdalone will do what [thou]119-arthur wilt , [mother]729-mother , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone , for [I]108-birdalone see that [thou]119-arthur art helping [me]108-birdalone all [thou]119-arthur mayest ; yet [I]108-birdalone beseech [thee]729-mother let [me]108-birdalone sit by [him]119-arthur till the time of [his]119-arthur awakening draweth nigh . [The wood - wife]559-the wood - wife smiled and nodded yeasay on [her]559-the wood - wife , and [they]7033-the two of us sat down , both of [them]7033-the two of us , beside [the sleeping man]7037-the sleeping man , and the day died into the night as [they]7033-the two of us sat hearkening to the ripple of [the brook]700-the brook and the song of the nightingales . Chapter XXIV ~ [The Wood - Mother]81-the wood - mother Changeth [Her]559-the wood - wife Form to That of [A Woman Stricken in Years]7039-a woman stricken in years When the morrow came , there yet lay [Arthur]119-arthur sleeping peacefully , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone awoke from the slumber which had at last fallen on [her]108-birdalone , and looked about [her]108-birdalone and saw not [Habundia]97-habundia in [the cave]2843-the cave ; so [she]108-birdalone arose and bent over [Arthur]119-arthur and kissed [him]119-arthur , and so went forth and stood in the door and looked about [her]108-birdalone . And [she]108-birdalone was still dim - eyed with [her]108-birdalone just departed slumber and the brightness of the morning sunlight , and [she]108-birdalone scarce knew whether it were a part of a dream , or a sight that was verily before [her]108-birdalone , that [she]108-birdalone seemed to see one coming across [the brook]700-the brook toward [her]108-birdalone , stepping heedfully from stone to [stone thereof]7042-stone thereof : [a woman stricken in years , but slim and trim and upright , clad in a gown of green cloth , with a tippet of some white fur]7043-a woman stricken in years , but slim and trim and upright , clad in a gown of green cloth , with a tippet of some white fur . When [she]108-birdalone was come on to [the greensward]670-the greensward [she]108-birdalone spake to [Birdalone]108-birdalone in a sweet voice , but thin with eld , and gave [her]108-birdalone the sele of the day ; and [Birdalone]108-birdalone was somewhat afraid to see [a newcomer]7045-a newcomer , but [she]108-birdalone greeted [her]108-birdalone , drawing back a little from [her]108-birdalone shyly . But [the old woman]7046-the old woman said : What maketh [thee]108-birdalone here , [[my]108-birdalone daughter]889-my daughter ? Dost [thou]108-birdalone not know that this is [[my]108-birdalone land]7048-my land and [[my]108-birdalone house]6084-my house , and that [I]108-birdalone am said not to be unmighty in [these woods]7050-these woods ? [I]108-birdalone pray [thee]108-birdalone pardon [me]108-birdalone if [I]108-birdalone have done amiss , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; but here have [I]108-birdalone [a sick friend]7051-a sick friend , [a young man]6251-a young man , and [I]108-birdalone would pray [thee]108-birdalone suffer [him]7051-a sick friend to abide here in [this cave]7053-this cave a little longer ; for there hath been also [another friend]7054-another friend , [a woman]235-a woman , but [she]235-a woman hath gone out while [I]108-birdalone slept , belike to gather simples , for [she]235-a woman is wise in leechcraft , and is tending [the sick man]7056-the sick man . [I]108-birdalone pray [thee]108-birdalone humbly to suffer [us]7057-us lest [we]7057-us lose [[our]7057-us friend]5433-our friend . As [she]108-birdalone spake , [she]108-birdalone heard [the carline]4438-the carline chuckle softly , and at last [she]108-birdalone said : Why , [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [[my]108-birdalone dear]1824-my dear , dost [thou]108-birdalone not know [me]108-birdalone after all these years ? Look on [me]108-birdalone again , look ! and [thou]108-birdalone shalt see that [I]108-birdalone am not so much changed from what [thou]108-birdalone sawest [me]108-birdalone last night . [I]108-birdalone am still thine image , [[my]108-birdalone dear]1824-my dear , only [I]108-birdalone was the image of what [thou]108-birdalone wert , and now [I]108-birdalone the image of what [thou]108-birdalone shalt be when two score years and ten of happy life have worn for [thee]108-birdalone . Tell [me]108-birdalone , am [I]108-birdalone now aught like to [[thy]108-birdalone mother]323-thy mother in the flesh ? How hast [thou]108-birdalone frighted [me]108-birdalone , [mother]729-mother , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; [I]108-birdalone thought that [[my]108-birdalone friend]304-my friend had forsaken [me]108-birdalone , and that perchance [the new - comer]510-the new - comer was another witch like unto [the old one]7066-the old one , and that [I]108-birdalone was never to be at rest and happy . But as to [[my]108-birdalone mother]894-my mother in the flesh , nay , [thou]108-birdalone art not now wholly like unto [her]894-my mother ; and sooth to say [I]108-birdalone shall be fainer when [thou]108-birdalone hast thine own shape of [me]108-birdalone young back again , for [I]108-birdalone love [thee]108-birdalone not so much as now [thou]108-birdalone art . [The wood - wife]559-the wood - wife laughed : Well , [she]559-the wood - wife said , [thou]108-birdalone shalt not see over - much of [me]108-birdalone in this shape ; and that the less because of something [I]108-birdalone shall now tell [thee]108-birdalone , to wit , that [I]108-birdalone have been thinking the matter over , and [I]108-birdalone would have [thee]108-birdalone leave [us]7069-us twain together alone before [the young man]6595-the young man awaketh . [I]108-birdalone would have [thee]108-birdalone get [thee]108-birdalone [home]373-home and abide [him]6595-the young man there ; it shall not be long [I]108-birdalone promise [thee]108-birdalone ; and this also , that [he]6595-the young man shall come home to [thee]108-birdalone sound in body and whole in limb . [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s countenance fell , and [she]108-birdalone said : Why this second mind , [mother]729-mother ? why , [I]108-birdalone pray [thee]729-mother ? Said [Habundia]97-habundia : [I]108-birdalone fear for [thy]729-mother love lest [he]6595-the young man be not strong enough to open [his]6595-the young man eyes upon [thy]729-mother face ; but after [he]6595-the young man hath been a day in [the woods]450-the woods , and [I]108-birdalone have spoken to [him]6595-the young man diversely and cheered [him]6595-the young man with the hope of meeting [thee]108-birdalone , [he]6595-the young man may well be strong enough to seek [thee]108-birdalone for a mile â€™s length , and find [thine house]261-thine house first and then [thee]108-birdalone . So now wilt [thou]729-mother obey [me]108-birdalone ? Nay , if [thou]729-mother must needs weep , [I]108-birdalone will be gone into [the thicket]5714-the thicket till [thou]729-mother hast done , [thou]729-mother wilful ! [Birdalone]108-birdalone smiled through [her]108-birdalone tears , and said : [I]108-birdalone pray [thee]108-birdalone pardon [my]108-birdalone wilfulness , [mother]729-mother , and [I]108-birdalone will depart without turning back into [the cave]2843-the cave . Nay , said [Habundia]97-habundia , there is no need for so much haste as that : [I]108-birdalone will in now , and do [my]108-birdalone leechdoms with [the sick man]7056-the sick man . But do [thou]3502-thou go across [the stream]1777-the stream , [thou]3502-thou barefoot , and [thou]3502-thou wilt find on the other side , by the foot of the quicken - tree yonder , honeycombs and white bread and a bicker of wild goats â€™[108-birdalone] milk . Bathe [thee]3502-thou then if [thou]3502-thou wilt , and bring those matters over hither ; and then shalt [thou]3502-thou go in and kiss [[thy]3502-thou mate]3503-thy mate â€™s sick face with [thy]3502-thou fresh one , and thereafter shall [we]3504-we sit here by the ripple of the water and break [our]3504-we fast ; and lastly , [thou]3502-thou shalt go in and kiss again and then take to [the road]1797-the road . But tell [me]0-i , deemest [thou]3502-thou surely that [thou]3502-thou canst find it again ? [Yea]3506-yea , surely , [mother]729-mother , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; [I]0-i am [wood - woman]3508-wood - woman enough for that ; and now [I]0-i will do all [thy]3502-thou will . And therewith [she]108-birdalone stepped out lightly on to the greensward and sought up [the stream]1777-the stream till [she]108-birdalone found [a smooth - grounded pool]3510-a smooth - grounded pool meet for [her]108-birdalone bath , and when that was done , [she]108-birdalone fetched the victual and came back to [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife ; then [they]3512-they two sat down together , and ate and drank while the water rippled at [their]3512-they feet . But when [they]3512-they were done , [Birdalone]108-birdalone gat [her]108-birdalone into [the cave]2843-the cave again , and kissed [the sleeping man]7037-the sleeping man fondly , and came forth lightly and stood a moment before [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife , and said : Tell [me]0-i this at least , [mother]729-mother , when shall [he]7037-the sleeping man be there ? To - morrow quoth [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife ; and , for [my]0-i part , [I]0-i would keep [thee]108-birdalone within doors and abide [him]7037-the sleeping man [there]215-there , lest there be trouble ; for [he]7037-the sleeping man may not yet be as strong as the strongest . [Birdalone]108-birdalone hung down [her]108-birdalone head and answered not , but said presently : Farewell , [wood - mother]1619-wood - mother , and be [thou]108-birdalone blessed . Then [she]108-birdalone took up [her]108-birdalone bow and betook [her]108-birdalone lightly to [the woodland]657-the woodland way , and [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife stood looking at [her]108-birdalone till the thicket had hidden [her]108-birdalone , and then turned back and went into [the cave]2843-the cave . Chapter XXV ~ [The Wood - Wife]559-the wood - wife Healeth and [Tendeth the Black Squire]193-tendeth the black squire [She]559-the wood - wife stood over [Arthur]119-arthur for a minute or two , and then stooped down and whispered a word in [his]119-arthur ear , and presently [he]119-arthur stirred on the bed and half opened [his]119-arthur eyes , but straightway turned on [his]119-arthur side , as if to gather sleep to [him]119-arthur , but [she]559-the wood - wife took [him]119-arthur by the shoulder and said in a clear voice : Nay , [knight]2054-knight , nay ; hast [thou]119-arthur not slept enough ? is there nought for [thee]119-arthur to do ? [He]119-arthur sat up in the bed and rubbed [his]119-arthur eyes , and [his]119-arthur face was come to its wholesome colour , and [his]119-arthur eyes looked out quietly and calmly as [he]119-arthur looked about [the cave]2843-the cave and saw [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife standing by [him]119-arthur ; and [he]119-arthur spake in a voice which was somewhat weak , but wherein was no passion of rage or woodness : Where am [I]0-i then ? and who art [thou]119-arthur , [dame]6766-dame ? [She]559-the wood - wife said : [Thou]119-arthur art in [a cave of [the woodland]657-the woodland]3528-a cave of the woodland , and [I]0-i am for one thing [thy]119-arthur leech , and meseemeth [thou]119-arthur desirest to eat and to drink . [He]119-arthur smiled and nodded [his]119-arthur head ; and [she]559-the wood - wife fetched [him]119-arthur the milk , and [he]119-arthur drank a long draught , and sighed thereafter , as one who is pleased ; and [she]559-the wood - wife smiled on [him]119-arthur , and fetched [him]119-arthur the bread and the honey , and [he]119-arthur ate and drank again , and then lay down and fell fast asleep . And [she]559-the wood - wife suffered [his]119-arthur slumber for two hours or so , and then awoke [him]119-arthur again ; and again [he]119-arthur asked where [he]119-arthur was and what was [she]559-the wood - wife , but [she]559-the wood - wife said as before . And said [she]559-the wood - wife : The next thing [thou]119-arthur hast to do is to arise , as [thou]119-arthur well mayest , and take this raiment , which is fair and clean , and go wash [thee]119-arthur in [the brook]700-the brook and come back to [me]0-i ; and then [we]3531-we will talk , and [thou]119-arthur shalt tell [me]0-i of how it was with [thee]119-arthur , and peradventure [I]0-i may tell [thee]119-arthur somewhat of how it shall be with [thee]119-arthur . As [she]559-the wood - wife spoke [she]559-the wood - wife went to a coffer which stood in [a nook of [the cave]2843-the cave]3532-a nook of the cave , and drew forth from it a shirt and hosen and shoon , and a surcoat and hood of fine black cloth , and a gilded girdle and a fair sword , red - sheathed , and said : These may serve [thy]119-arthur turn for the present , so take them and don them , and [thou]119-arthur shalt look like [a squire]3534-a squire at least , if not [a knight]1343-a knight . So [he]3536-thou arose as one in a dream and went out ; but as [he]3536-thou passed by [her]559-the wood - wife [she]559-the wood - wife saw something gleaming on [his]3536-thou breast , and noted that it was [Birdalone]108-birdalone â€™s fair sapphire ring which hung about [his]3536-thou neck ; so [she]559-the wood - wife smiled , and said under [her]559-the wood - wife breath : Crafty is [[my]0-i dear daughter]3537-my dear daughter ! But that shall save [me]0-i some words at least . And [she]559-the wood - wife abided [his]3536-thou return . [Anon]194-anon [he]3536-thou cometh back clad in the fair raiment , with the sword by [his]3536-thou side ; and [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife smote [her]559-the wood - wife palms together and cried out : Now indeed [thou]3536-thou art fair and well - liking , and [a fair lady]3539-a fair lady might well take pleasure in beholding [thee]3536-thou . But [his]3536-thou brow was knit , and [he]3536-thou looked sullen and angry , and [he]3536-thou said : What is all this play ? and where gattest [thou]3536-thou this ring which [I]0-i found eâ€™en now about [my]0-i neck ? And who art [thou]3536-thou , and why have [I]0-i been brought hither ? [His]3536-thou eyes looked fiercely on [her]559-the wood - wife as [he]3536-thou spake , holding out [his]3536-thou palm with the ring lying thereon . But [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife answered : Many questions , [fair youth]3541-fair youth ! but [I]0-i will tell [thee]3536-thou : the play is for thine healing and pleasure , whereas both sick hast [thou]3536-thou been and sorry . As to the ring , it is [thou]3536-thou hast got it and not [I.]0-i But [I]0-i will tell [thee]3536-thou this , that [I]0-i have seen it on the finger of [a fair damsel who haunteth [the woodland not far hence]3543-the woodland not far hence]3542-a fair damsel who haunteth the woodland not far hence . As to what [I]0-i am , that were a long tale to tell if [I]0-i told it all ; but believe this meanwhile , that [I]0-i am [the lady]1145-the lady and [mistress of hereabouts]3545-mistress of hereabouts , and am not without power over [[my]0-i folk]3546-my folk and [[my]0-i land]7048-my land . And as to why [thou]3536-thou wert brought hither , [I]0-i brought [thee]3536-thou because [I]0-i had [no better house handy for [a sick man]3549-a sick man to lie in]3548-no better house handy for a sick man to lie in . Then [Arthur]119-arthur stood a long while considering the ring that lay on [his]119-arthur palm , and at last [he]119-arthur put [his]119-arthur hand on [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife â€™s shoulder , and looked into [her]559-the wood - wife face beseechingly , and said : O [mother]729-mother , if [thou]3536-thou be mighty be merciful withal , and have pity on [me]0-i ! [Thou]3536-thou callest [me]0-i [a youth]2321-a youth , and so [I]0-i may be in regard to [thee]559-the wood - wife ; but [I]0-i tell [thee]559-the wood - wife it is five long years and there hath been no other thought in [my]0-i heart but what was loathsome to [me]0-i , and it hath worn and wasted [my]0-i youth , so that it waneth and withereth and is nought . O , if [thou]3536-thou be mighty , bring [me]0-i to [her]559-the wood - wife that [I]0-i may see [her]559-the wood - wife at least one time before [I]0-i die . And therewith [he]3553-him fell down on [his]3553-him knees before [her]559-the wood - wife , and kissed the hem of [her]559-the wood - wife gown , and wept . But [she]559-the wood - wife drew [him]3553-him up and looked on [him]3553-him with the merry countenance of [a kind old woman]3554-a kind old woman , and said : Nay , nay , [I]0-i am not so hard to be won to [thy]3536-thou helping that [thou]3536-thou needest pray so sore and weep : here need [we]3555-we tarry no longer , and if [thou]3536-thou wilt come with [me]0-i [we]3555-we shall go seek [the damsel who bore this ring]3556-the damsel who bore this ring , though how it should come to [thee]3536-thou why should [I]0-i know ? Neither do [I]0-i know if [the said ring - bearer]3557-the said ring - bearer be [the one woman whom [thou]3536-thou needest]3558-the one woman whom thou needest . But [I]0-i will tell [thee]3536-thou at once that [she]3556-the damsel who bore this ring is [a dear friend of [mine]0-i]3559-a dear friend of mine . Then [Arthur]119-arthur threw [his]119-arthur arms about [her]3536-thou , and kissed [her]3536-thou cheeks and blessed [her]3536-thou , while [she]3536-thou laughed on [him]119-arthur and said : Nay , [fair sir]1675-fair sir , if [thou]3536-thou wilt do so much with the withered branch , what wilt [thou]3536-thou with the blossom of the tree ? And [he]119-arthur was abashed before [her]3536-thou , but hope made [his]119-arthur heart to dance . So [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife took up [her]559-the wood - wife bow , slung [her]559-the wood - wife quiver at [her]559-the wood - wife back , and girt [her]559-the wood - wife short sword to [her]559-the wood - wife , and then led [him]119-arthur forth , and so into [the thicket out of [the dale]4999-the dale]3562-the thicket out of the dale and forth into [the oaken bent]3564-the oaken bent , and lightly [she]3536-thou led [him]119-arthur thereafter through [the woodland]657-the woodland . Chapter XXVI ~ [The Black Squire]1325-the black squire Telleth the Wood - Wife of [His]119-arthur Doings Since [Birdalone]108-birdalone Went from [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest As [they]3568-we went [Habundia]97-habundia said to [Arthur]119-arthur : Now shalt [thou]119-arthur talk and tell for the shortening of the way , and let [us]3568-we know somewhat of [thy]119-arthur story . But first [I]0-i must tell [thee]119-arthur , for [thou]119-arthur mayest not know it , so witless as then [thou]119-arthur wast , that yesterday [we]3568-we found [thee]119-arthur down in [the dale yonder]3569-the dale yonder , playing the string - play sweetly indeed , but otherwise dight like a half beast more than [a man]217-a man , so that [we]3568-we wondered at [thee]119-arthur and pitied [thee]119-arthur . [Arthur]119-arthur knit [his]119-arthur brows as if [he]119-arthur strove with some memory and might not master it ; then [he]119-arthur said : [Thou]119-arthur sayest [We]3568-we , who then was the other ? Said [Habundia]97-habundia : [I]0-i had [a dear friend with [me]0-i]3571-a dear friend with me . Quoth [he]119-arthur : And did [she]3571-a dear friend with me pity [me]0-i also ? [Yea]3572-yea , said [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife , else scarce had [she]3571-a dear friend with me been [a friend to [me]0-i]3574-a friend to me . O let [us]3568-we on swiftly , said [Arthur]119-arthur , so long as the time may be ! And [they]3568-we quickened [their]3568-we pace and ate up the way speedily . Presently spake [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife again : Now for the tale of [thee]119-arthur , [fair sir]1675-fair sir ; yet will [I]0-i shorten it somewhat by telling [thee]119-arthur that [I]0-i know [thy]119-arthur name , that [thou]119-arthur art [[Arthur]119-arthur the Black Squire of [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]25-the castle of the quest]3577-arthur the black squire of the castle of the quest . [He]119-arthur stared at that word , and said : How knewest [thou]119-arthur this ? how couldst [thou]119-arthur guess it , who hast never seen [me]0-i erst ? [A friend]509-a friend told [me]0-i , said [she]559-the wood - wife ; too long it were as now to tell [thee]119-arthur thereof . Rather do [thou]119-arthur tell [me]0-i how [thou]119-arthur didst fare when [ye]119-arthur found [[thy]119-arthur friend]4800-thy friend gone from [the castle]1534-the castle that time [ye]119-arthur came [home]373-home from the winning of the Red Hold . [Arthur]119-arthur stared astonished , and said : What is it ? Dost [thou]119-arthur verily know [my]0-i love ? or art [thou]119-arthur [a sorceress]6624-a sorceress and knowest somewhat of [me]0-i by spell - work ? [I]0-i am somewhat more than [a sorceress]6624-a sorceress , may - happen , said [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife ; but heed it not , since [I]0-i am [[thy]119-arthur friend]4800-thy friend today , but tell [me]0-i what [I]0-i ask , that [I]0-i may have all the tale of [thee]119-arthur ; it will serve for the shortening of the way . Said [Arthur]119-arthur : And who but [I]0-i needeth it as short as may be ? so stand [we]3586-we not loitering here , and [I]0-i will talk as [we]3586-we wend on speedily . On [they]3587-they sped therefore , and said [Arthur]119-arthur : How did [I]0-i fare ? as [one stunned]3588-one stunned , [mother]729-mother , and knew not what had happened ; and when [I]0-i heard [their]3587-they babble of how [she]729-mother had done wrong here and right there , [I]0-i was driven half mad by it , so that [I]0-i hastened back to [the Red Hold]2256-the red hold , and became [the captain of [Greenford]39-greenford]3591-the captain of greenford , to hunt down [[their]3587-they scattered foemen]3592-their scattered foemen ; for [I]0-i said to [myself]0-i that needs must [I]0-i rage and slay , and that were worser amongst [[my]0-i friends]1795-my friends than [mine]0-i unfriends . What then ? that business came to an end ; though [all the ill men]3594-all the ill men were not slain , but [all]881-all were driven away from [the parts of [Greenford]39-greenford]3596-the parts of greenford ; and sooth to say [they]3587-they durst not come anywhere nigh where [they]3587-they heard of [me]0-i . Then became each day like every other , and the thought of [my]0-i hope and [my]0-i despair ate [mine]0-i heart out , and [I]0-i was of no avail unto any . Now it so happened , amidst [my]0-i many battles and chases , [I]0-i had hunted the bands of [the Red Hold]42-the red hold into [the northwest marches of [the woodland]657-the woodland]3597-the northwest marches of the woodland ; and [I]0-i noted that even [they]3587-they , howsoever hard bestead , and the worst of [men to boot]3599-men to boot , would scarce at the first be driven into the thickets thereof , though at last , whether or no [they]3587-they have made covenant with the devils , there [I]0-i know not , [they]3587-they have betaken [them]3587-they to the depths of [the wood]335-the wood and have borne off [women]420-women from [the dwellings]3602-the dwellings and got [children]1274-children on [them]3602-the dwellings , and are like to breed [an evil folk]3604-an evil folk . That then [I]0-i noted that [this Evilshaw]3605-this evilshaw was a dwelling loathed and desert , and little like it was that any would meddle with [me]0-i [there]215-there . Three years had worn since [I]0-i was cast away at [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest by [her]3608-her that loved [me]0-i , who must needs sacrifice both [her]3608-her and [me]0-i to the busy devil of folly ; and [I]0-i also deemed that if [I]0-i sought for [her]3608-her [I]0-i should not find [her]3608-her ; and yet more forsooth , that if [I]0-i found [her]3608-her [she]3608-her would be as hard unto [me]0-i as when [she]3608-her fled from [me]0-i . And as for [me]0-i , [I]0-i was gotten hard and crabbed , and [no man]534-no man , if [his]534-no man heart would let [him]534-no man , would have aught to say to [me]0-i . So [I]0-i gat [me]0-i away from [the Red Hold]2256-the red hold , as [I]0-i had from [the Castle of the Quest]4707-the castle of the quest , and [I]0-i gave out that [I]0-i would enter into religion , and forbade [any man]4683-any man to follow [me]0-i . Neither did any desire it . First of all [I]0-i set [me]0-i down at [the very outskirts of [the woodland]657-the woodland]3613-the very outskirts of the woodland , and raised [me]0-i a bower there , rude and ill - shapen . [Few folk]6051-few folk came anigh [me]0-i , and yet [some few , charcoal - burners]3616-some few , charcoal - burners , and [hunters of the edges of the wood]3617-hunters of the edges of the wood , and suchlike . [These]3618-these deemed [me]0-i [a holy man]3619-a holy man , whereas [I]0-i was but surly . Somewhat also [they]3618-these feared [me]0-i , whereas in some of [their]3618-these huntings or goings and comings after prey [I]0-i had put forth all [my]0-i strength , eked out by the lore of knighthood , which was strange to [them]3618-these . [One man]1944-one man there was of [them]3618-these who was fashioned of the minstrel craft by nature , and who forgathered with [me]0-i specially , till [we]3621-we became [friends]404-friends , and [he]1944-one man was a solace to [me]0-i , with [his]1944-one man tales and [his]1944-one man songs of [a rougher people]3623-a rougher people than [I]0-i had been wo nt to deal with . But when [I]0-i had been in [that place]2386-that place for two years [he]1944-one man died of a sickness , and [I]0-i was left lonely , and [my]0-i soreness of heart fell upon [me]0-i till [I]0-i scarce knew what next [I]0-i should do . So [I]0-i fared away yet deeper into [the wildwood]512-the wildwood , taking with [me]0-i the harp which [[my]0-i friend]304-my friend had given [me]0-i before [he]1944-one man died . It was summer , and [I]0-i wandered about ever deeper into [the wood]335-the wood , until belike [I]0-i had scarce been able to win out of it if [I]0-i had tried . At last , when the autumn came , [I]0-i built [myself]0-i again some sort of a bower in [a clearing of the wood wherein was water]3628-a clearing of the wood wherein was water , and [the resort of plenteous venison]3629-the resort of plenteous venison . What befell next ? [My]0-i mind is not over - clear concerning it all , for [I]0-i was now becoming more of a beast than [a man]217-a man . But this [I]0-i know , that [some men of the bands whom [I]0-i had chased]3631-some men of the bands whom i had chased happened on [me]0-i . [They]3631-some men of the bands whom i had chased knew [me]0-i not for [[their]3631-some men of the bands whom i had chased old foeman]3632-their old foeman , but of [their]3631-some men of the bands whom i had chased kind it was to torment and slay [any man whom [they]3631-some men of the bands whom i had chased might lightly overcome]3633-any man whom they might lightly overcome . Yet was not the battle so over - light but that [I]0-i slew and hurt divers of [them]3631-some men of the bands whom i had chased ere [they]3631-some men of the bands whom i had chased got [me]0-i under and stripped [me]0-i and bound [my]0-i hands and tormented [me]0-i , after the manner that [the devils]3634-the devils shall do with [them]3631-some men of the bands whom i had chased when [they]3631-some men of the bands whom i had chased shall go to [their]3631-some men of the bands whom i had chased reward . Yet somehow [I]0-i lived , though [they]3631-some men of the bands whom i had chased deemed [me]0-i dead , and [I]0-i crawled away thence when [they]3631-some men of the bands whom i had chased were gone ; and somehow [I]0-i was healed of [my]0-i body , but [I]0-i was confused of [my]0-i wit thereafter , and now can call to mind but little of what befell [me]0-i as [I]0-i strayed from place to place , save that [I]0-i remember [I]0-i was hapless and heart - sore ever : and also [meseemeth]3635-meseemeth that [I]0-i saw visions at whiles , and [those who had been in [my]0-i life before these things]3636-those who had been in my life before these things , [their]3636-those who had been in my life before these things images would come before [me]0-i to mock [me]0-i as [I]0-i sat singing whiles and whiles playing the string - play ( for [my]0-i harp [I]0-i bore ever with [me]0-i ) ; and whiles [I]0-i bewailed [me]0-i , and called for help on [them]3636-those who had been in my life before these things that would not or might not help [me]0-i . And now [I]0-i may not even tell the years of [my]0-i abiding in [the desert]1630-the desert , how many [they]3638-they be . But [I]0-i pray [thee]3639-thou let [us]3640-us on more swiftly yet . Said [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife : [Thou]3639-thou hast told [me]0-i but little of [thy]3639-thou life , [Black Squire]119-arthur , but it is enough maybe ; and [I]0-i see that [thou]3639-thou mayst not tell [me]0-i more because [thou]3639-thou hast [thy]3639-thou mind set on what may betide [thee]3639-thou when this day is over . But [thou]3639-thou must know that [thou]3639-thou hast come into [the wood of Evilshaw]3642-the wood of evilshaw , wherein , besides [those savage men who quelled [thee]3639-thou and [their]3643-those savage men who quelled thee and their like , there be uncouth things no few , and wights that be not of the race of adam like , there be uncouth things no few , and wights that be not of the race of [Adam]96-adam]3643-those savage men who quelled thee and their like , there be uncouth things no few , and wights that be not of the race of adam ; wherefore no great marvel is it that [thou]3639-thou sawest visions , and images of them that were not by [thee]3639-thou . [Yea]3644-yea , said [he]119-arthur , but one vision had [I]0-i that confused and overcame [me]0-i more than all others , and meseemeth that came to [me]0-i not long ago . For first [I]0-i saw the shape of [her]3645-her that [my]0-i soul desireth ever , and it wept and lamented for [me]0-i ; and then for a little [I]0-i seemed as if [I]0-i were coming forth from [my]0-i confusion of wit ; when lo ! there issued from the thicket another image of [[my]0-i beloved]3646-my beloved and blamed [me]0-i and threatened [me]0-i . [God]114-god wot good cause there was of the blame . But tell [me]0-i , [mother]729-mother , since [thou]3648-thou callest thyself wise , what may this portend ? [The wood - wife]559-the wood - wife laughed : Since [I]0-i am wise , said [she]0-i , [I]0-i will foretell [thee]3650-thee good days . And now [we]3651-they will talk no more of [thee]3650-thee or [thy]3650-thee love or [thy]3650-thee sorrow , but since [thou]3648-thou wilt so fiercely devour the way , [I]0-i will tell [thee]3650-thee a tale or two of this wood and its wights to save [us]3651-they from over - much weariness . So did [she]0-i , talking and telling as [they]3651-they went ; and [she]0-i went on a pace before [him]3650-thee , and howsoever long or hardly [he]3650-thee might stride [he]3650-thee might not overgo [her]0-i . And so fast [they]3651-they went , that [they]3651-they were within a little way of [the Oak of Tryst]767-the oak of tryst a good while before the sun had set , though [they]3651-they had set out from [the cave]2843-the cave three hours after the hour when [Birdalone]108-birdalone and [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife had left [the House under [the Wood]4-the wood]4835-the house under the wood on the yesterday . [They]3651-they had come to [a steep rock that rose up from [a water â€™s side]3657-a water â€™s side]3656-a steep rock that rose up from a water â€™s side , and [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife bade stay , whether [Arthur]119-arthur would or no , and [she]559-the wood - wife made [him]3650-thee eat and drink , bringing the victual and wine from out of a cleft in [the said rock]3659-the said rock . And [she]559-the wood - wife held [him]3650-thee there till the night was come and there was a glimmer of the rising moon in the east , and [he]3650-thee was ill at ease and restless ; but still [she]559-the wood - wife held [him]3650-thee there till the moon rose high and shone upon [them]3651-they , and the shadows of the oak - boughs lay black all around . Then [she]559-the wood - wife bade [him]3650-thee arise , and led [him]3650-thee on to [the Oak of Tryst]11-the oak of tryst , yea and somewhat beyond it toward [the great water]3660-the great water . Then [she]559-the wood - wife spake to [him]3650-thee : [Black Squire]119-arthur , [I]0-i am now come [home]373-home , and will lead [thee]3650-thee no further ; [I]0-i was deeming that [we]3662-we should have slept in [the wood]335-the wood a good way from this , and then would [I]0-i have brought [thee]3650-thee on [thy]3650-thee way tomorrow morning ; but the eagerness of thine heart hath made [thy]3650-thee feet so speedy , that [we]3662-we be here somewhat rathe , and yet [I]0-i am not ill - pleased therewith . Then [she]559-the wood - wife turned [him]3650-thee about and said : Look down the bent and tell [me]0-i what [thou]3650-thee seest . [He]3650-thee said : [I]0-i see the boles of goodly trees , and betwixt them the gleaming of a great water . [She]559-the wood - wife said : Go thitherward then while the moon is yet at [her]559-the wood - wife brightest , and [thou]3650-thee shalt presently come to [wide meads lying along [the water]347-the water]3664-wide meads lying along the water , and a stream running through [them]3664-wide meads lying along the water . Enter then into [the meads]3666-the meads and look about [thee]3650-thee , and [thou]3650-thee shalt see [a little house]3667-a little house ( there is none other nigh ) standing just across [the said stream]363-the said stream ; go up thither boldly and crave guesting from whomsoever [thou]3650-thee shalt find there , and maybe things shall go after [thy]3650-thee mind . More than this [I]0-i may not do for [thee]3650-thee . Farewell then , and if [thou]3650-thee wilt [thou]3650-thee mayst meet [me]0-i again ; that is to say , that which is verily [me]0-i : but it is like that this shape which hath been striding on with [thee]3650-thee daylong [thou]3650-thee shalt not see any more . [He]3669-his looked on [her]3650-thee wondering , for [she]3650-thee seemed to grow goodly and stately before [his]3669-his eyes . But even as [he]3669-his stretched forth [his]3669-his hand to take [hers]3650-thee , [she]3650-thee turned about suddenly and fared into the wood out of [his]3669-his sight , wending full as swiftly as might have been looked for . Then [he]3669-his drew [his]3669-his sword and turned [his]3669-his face from the wood , and went down toward [the water]347-the water . Chapter XXVII ~ [Sir Arthur]150-arthur Cometh to [the House Under the Wood]4835-the house under the wood So came [Arthur]150-arthur into [the meadows]1769-the meadows , and went eagerly but warily over the dewy grass . And here and there a cow rose before [him]150-arthur and went bundling down [the mead]370-the mead a little way , and the owls cried out from behind [him]150-arthur , and a fox barked from the thicket â€™s edge . Then [he]150-arthur found [himself]150-arthur on the stream - side , and [he]150-arthur stayed and looked from side to side , and lo ! on the other side of [the stream]1777-the stream [a little house that looked familiar to [him]150-arthur as [a yeoman]3395-a yeoman â€™s dwelling in [the builded lands]3677-the builded lands]3675-a little house that looked familiar to him as a yeoman â€™s dwelling in the builded lands , and the thatch thereon shone under the moon and [its]3675-a little house that looked familiar to him as a yeoman â€™s dwelling in the builded lands windows were yellow with candle - light ; and so homely it seemed to [him]150-arthur , that [he]150-arthur thrust [his]150-arthur sword into the sheath and lightly crossed [the brook]700-the brook , and came to the door and laid [his]150-arthur hand upon the latch and lifted it and shoved the door , and all was open before [him]150-arthur . [His]150-arthur eyes , coming from the night , dazzled with the bright light of the candles , but [he]150-arthur saw [a fair woman]580-a fair woman rising up in [her]580-a fair woman place , and [he]150-arthur said : May [a traveller in [the woodland]657-the woodland]3680-a traveller in the woodland be welcome here to - night , dealing with all in all honour ? But [the woman]237-the woman came toward [him]150-arthur holding out [her]237-the woman two hands , and ere [he]150-arthur could cry out that [he]150-arthur knew [her]237-the woman , [she]237-the woman had thrown [herself]237-the woman upon [him]150-arthur , and had cast [her]237-the woman arms about [him]150-arthur and was kissing [his]150-arthur face , and murmuring : O welcome indeed ! welcome , welcome , and welcome ! And so sore did [his]150-arthur past grief and [his]150-arthur desire move [him]150-arthur , that [he]150-arthur was weak before [her]237-the woman , and held down [his]150-arthur hands and let [her]237-the woman do . And both those were breathless with wonder and joy and longing ; and [they]3683-they stood aloof a little in a while and looked on [each other]569-each other , [she]237-the woman with heaving bosom and streaming eyes , and [he]150-arthur with arms stretched forth and lips that strove with [his]150-arthur heart â€™s words and might not utter them ; but once more [she]237-the woman gave [herself]237-the woman to [him]150-arthur , and [he]150-arthur took [her]237-the woman in [his]150-arthur arms strongly now , so that [she]237-the woman was frail and weak before [him]150-arthur , and [he]150-arthur laid [his]150-arthur cheek to [her]237-the woman cheek and [his]150-arthur lips to [her]237-the woman lips , and kissed [her]237-the woman eyes and [her]237-the woman shoulders and murmured over [her]237-the woman . And then again [they]3685-they stood apart , and [she]237-the woman took [him]150-arthur by the hand and led [him]150-arthur to [the settle]6783-the settle , and set [him]150-arthur down by [her]237-the woman , and [herself]237-the woman by [him]150-arthur ; and a while [they]3685-they said nought . Then [she]237-the woman spake as one who had come to [herself]237-the woman and was calm , though [her]237-the woman heart was aflame for love : Tell [me]0-i , love , when [thine]3687-thy hand was on the latch didst [thou]3687-thy look to find [me]0-i here in [this house]2669-this house ? for thine hand it was that waked [me]0-i ; [I]0-i heard not [thy]3687-thy foot before the threshold , for [I]0-i was weary and slumbering . Alas ! that [I]0-i lost the sound of [thy]3687-thy feet ! [He]150-arthur spake , and [his]150-arthur voice sounded false unto [him]150-arthur , as if it came from another â€™s mouth : [I]0-i wot not ; [the woman that led [me]0-i nearby]3689-the woman that led me nearby seemed to bid [me]0-i hope . Then [he]150-arthur said : Nay , the sooth is that [I]0-i should have died if [I]0-i had not found [thee]3689-the woman that led me nearby here ; [I]0-i have been sick so long with hoping . Again were [they]3690-they silent till [she]3689-the woman that led me nearby said : [I]0-i would that [I]0-i had heard [thee]150-arthur crossing [the brook]700-the brook . But [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife bade [me]0-i look for [thee]150-arthur no earlier than tomorrow ; else had [I]0-i time enough ; and [I]0-i would have made [the house]311-the house trim with the new green boughs , and dighted [our]3690-they bed with rose blooms ; and [I]0-i would have done on [me]0-i [my]0-i shining gown that [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife gave [me]0-i . For indeed [she]3689-the woman that led me nearby was but clad in [her]3689-the woman that led me nearby scanty smock and nought else . But [he]150-arthur laid [his]150-arthur head on [her]3689-the woman that led me nearby bosom and kissed [her]3689-the woman that led me nearby all about , and said : Nay , [my]0-i own love , it is well , it is better . And [she]3689-the woman that led me nearby murmured over [him]150-arthur : [O friend]3695-o friend , [[my]0-i dear]1824-my dear , think not that [I]0-i had will to hide [me]0-i from [thee]150-arthur . All that is here of [me]0-i is thine , and thine , and thine . And [she]3689-the woman that led me nearby took [his]150-arthur hand and [they]3697-they arose together , and [she]3689-the woman that led me nearby said : [O friend]3695-o friend , [I]0-i fled from [thee]150-arthur once and left [thee]150-arthur lonely of [me]0-i because [I]0-i deemed need drave [me]0-i to it ; and [I]0-i feared the strife of [friends]404-friends , and confusion and tangle . Now if [thou]3700-thou wilt avenge [thee]150-arthur on [me]0-i [thou]3700-thou mayest , for [I]0-i am in [thy]150-arthur power . Yet will [I]0-i ask [thee]3689-the woman that led me nearby what need will drive [thee]3689-the woman that led me nearby to leave [me]0-i lonely ? [He]3695-o friend said : The need of death . But [she]0-i said : Mayhappen [we]3701-we shall lie together then , as here to - night [we]3701-we shall lie . Chapter XXVIII ~ Fair Days in [the House of Love]3702-the house of love On the morrow it was sweet times betwixt [those twain]5497-those twain , and what was hard and fierce of [their]5497-those twain love [they]5497-those twain seemed to have put behind [them]5497-those twain . A dear joy it was to [Birdalone]108-birdalone that day to busy [herself]108-birdalone about the housekeeping , and to provide whatsoever seemed now , or had seemed to [her]108-birdalone in [her]108-birdalone early days , to be dainties of [[their]5497-those twain meadow]3704-their meadow and woodland husbandry , as cream and junkets and wood - fruit and honey , and fine bread made for that very occasion . Withal [she]108-birdalone was careful as [a mother]3705-a mother with [a child]229-a child that [he]3695-o friend should not over - weary [himself]3695-o friend with the sun of the early summer , but rather to follow [the brook]700-the brook up into [the wood]335-the wood and lie adown in the flecked shadow and rest [him]3695-o friend wholly , as if there were nought for [him]3695-o friend to do but to take in rest all that was done for [his]3695-o friend service , both by [the earth]432-the earth and by the hands and nimble feet of [Birdalone]108-birdalone . And as [she]108-birdalone was wilful in other ways of [her]108-birdalone cherishing , so also in this , that for nought in that daylight would [she]108-birdalone go anywise disarrayed , nay not so much as to go barefoot , though [he]3695-o friend prayed [her]108-birdalone thereof sorely , and told [her]108-birdalone that fairer and sweeter [she]108-birdalone was in [her]108-birdalone smock alone than in any other raiment . For in the morning [she]108-birdalone went in [her]108-birdalone woodland green let down to [her]108-birdalone heels , and when the day wore towards evening , and the wind came cool from over [the Great Water]13-the great water , then [she]108-birdalone did on [her]108-birdalone wonder - raiment which [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife had given [her]108-birdalone , and led [Arthur]150-arthur over [the meadows]1769-the meadows here and there , and went gleaming by the side of [the black - clad man]3712-the black - clad man along [the water]347-the water â€™s lip . And [they]3714-they looked forth on to [Green Eyot]6-green eyot and [Rock Eyot]7-rock eyot , and stood by [the shallow bight]3715-the shallow bight where [she]108-birdalone had bathed those times ; and [they]3714-they went along to [the dismal creek]3716-the dismal creek where [the Sending Boat]823-the sending boat was wo nt to lie , and where yet lay the scattered staves of it ; and then along [the meadow - land]3718-the meadow - land [they]3714-they went from end to end , resting oft on the flowery grass , till the dews began to fall and the moon cast shadows on the greensward . Then [home]373-home [they]3714-they fared to [the house]311-the house ; and again on the way must [Birdalone]108-birdalone feign for [their]3714-they disport that [the witch]394-the witch was come back again , and was awaiting [her]108-birdalone to play [the tyrant]5688-the tyrant with [her]108-birdalone ; and [Arthur]150-arthur fell in with [her]108-birdalone game , and kissed [her]108-birdalone and clipped [her]108-birdalone , and then drew [his]150-arthur sword and said : By All - hallows [I]0-i shall smite off [her]108-birdalone head if [she]108-birdalone but lay a finger on [thee]3723-thee . So [they]3714-they played like [two happy children]3724-two happy children till [they]3714-they came to the door of [the house]311-the house , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone shoved it open , and [they]3714-they two looked in together and saw nought worse therein save the strange shadows that the moon cast from the settle on to the floor . Then [Birdalone]108-birdalone drew in [her]108-birdalone love , and went about lighting the candles and quickening a little cooking fire on the hearth , till the yellow light chased the moon away from the bed of [their]3714-they desire . Chapter XXIX ~ Those Twain Will Seek the Wisdom of [the Wood - Wife]559-the wood - wife Again next day was [their]3714-they life such as it had been the day before ; and as [they]3714-they lay in cool shadow of a great oak , [Birdalone]108-birdalone fell to telling [Arthur]150-arthur all the whole story of [her]108-birdalone dealings with [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife , and how that [she]108-birdalone had so loved [her]108-birdalone and holpen [her]108-birdalone , that through [her]108-birdalone love and [her]108-birdalone help [she]108-birdalone had escaped [the witch]394-the witch and [her]394-the witch snares , who would have turned [her]108-birdalone into a half - devil for the undoing of [manfolk]3729-manfolk . And how that [the said wood - wife]3730-the said wood - wife had never appeared to [her]108-birdalone but as an image and double of [herself]108-birdalone , save on the time when [she]108-birdalone played the leech to [him]150-arthur . Then [she]108-birdalone told [him]150-arthur how all had gone when [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife had sought [him]150-arthur out for the fulfilment of [their]3732-they love , and of the dreadful day when [they]3732-they had come upon [him]150-arthur out of [his]150-arthur wit and but [little manlike]3733-little manlike . Then [she]108-birdalone asked , would [he]150-arthur , within the next day or two , that [they]3732-they should go see [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife together and thank [her]108-birdalone for [her]108-birdalone help , and bring [him]150-arthur within the ring of [her]108-birdalone love and guarding ; and [he]150-arthur yeasaid it with a good will . After this [she]108-birdalone would have [him]150-arthur tell [her]108-birdalone of how things had gone with [him]150-arthur since that evil day when [he]150-arthur had come [home]373-home from [the Castle of [the Quest]26-the quest]4707-the castle of the quest and found [her]108-birdalone gone . So [he]150-arthur told [her]108-birdalone somewhat , and of [his]150-arthur dole and misery , and [his]150-arthur dealings with [the foemen of [Greenford]39-greenford]3737-the foemen of greenford ; but yet scantly , and as [one compelled]3738-one compelled ; and at last [he]150-arthur said : Dear love , since [thou]3739-thou art cossetting [me]0-i with all solace of caresses , [I]0-i pray [thee]108-birdalone remember [my]0-i trouble and grief , how sore they were , and do with [me]0-i as with [a sick man]3549-a sick man getting well , as [I]0-i wot surely [thou]3739-thou wouldest do ; and do [thou]3739-thou that which is at this present the softest and merriest to [me]0-i , and that forsooth is , that [thou]3739-thou shouldest talk and tell , and [I]0-i should hearken the sweetness of the music , and only here and there put in a word to rest [thee]108-birdalone and make [thy]3739-thou tale the sweeter . [She]108-birdalone laughed with love on [him]150-arthur , and without more ado fell to telling everything [she]108-birdalone might think of , concerning [her]108-birdalone days in [the House of Captivity]1013-the house of captivity , both when [she]108-birdalone was but a bairn , and when [she]108-birdalone was grown to be [a young woman]506-a young woman ; and long was [she]108-birdalone about the tale , nor was it all done in one day ; and a multitude of things [she]108-birdalone told [him]150-arthur which are not set down in this book . In the evening when [they]3743-we were going again to and fro the meads , it was other talk [they]3743-we fell on , to wit , of [[their]3743-we fellows of [the Quest]26-the quest]3744-their fellows of the quest , both of [Sir Hugh]118-hugh and [the three lovely ladies]3745-the three lovely ladies : and now was [Arthur]150-arthur nought but kind when [he]150-arthur spake of [Atra]109-atra , nor spake [Birdalone]108-birdalone otherwise ; but [she]108-birdalone said : [I]0-i shall now say a hard word , yet must [thou]3746-thou bear it , [[my]0-i loveling]5671-my loveling , since [we]3743-we twain are now become one , and have but one joy together and one sorrow . Deemest [thou]3746-thou that [Atra]109-atra is yet alive ? Sooth it is , said [Arthur]150-arthur , it may well be that [I]0-i have slain [her]109-atra . And what may [we]3743-we do by [her]109-atra if ever [we]3743-we fall in with [her]109-atra alive ? said [Birdalone]108-birdalone . [I]0-i wot not , said [Arthur]150-arthur ; some would say that [we]3743-we have done penance for [our]3743-we fault , both [thou]3746-thou and [I]0-i ; and what other penance may [we]3743-we do , save sundering from [each other]569-each other ? And by [God]114-god above [I]0-i will not . By thine head and thine hands [I]0-i will not , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone . So said [they]3749-they ; but therewith [their]3749-they eyes told tales of the fair eve and [the lovely meadows]3750-the lovely meadows , and [the house]311-the house , [the shrine of the dear white bed]3752-the shrine of the dear white bed no less sweet to [them]3749-they than erst ; but then presently [Birdalone]108-birdalone stayed [her]108-birdalone love , and took [her]108-birdalone arms about [him]150-arthur , and [each]4577-each felt the sweetness of the other â€™s body , and joy blossomed anew in [their]3749-they hearts . Then fell [Arthur]150-arthur to telling of the deeds and the kindness of [Baudoin]115-baudoin , whom never again [they]3749-they should see on [the earth]432-the earth ; and [they]3749-they turned back [home]373-home to [the house]311-the house , and on the way spake [Birdalone]108-birdalone : This is what [I]0-i would [we]3749-they should do : whereas [I]0-i have sought [thee]3757-thou and [thou]3757-thou [me]0-i , and [we]3749-they have found [each other]569-each other , whereas [ye]3757-thou sought [me]0-i when [I]0-i went astray in [the Black Valley of the Greywethers]37-the black valley of the greywethers , and before , when [ye]3757-thou three sought [your]3757-thou own loves , now [I]0-i would that [we]3749-they should seek [[our]3749-they fellows]1859-our fellows and have joy in [them]1859-our fellows , and thole sorrow with [them]1859-our fellows as in days gone by . Spake [Arthur]150-arthur : Dear is the rest with [thee]3757-thou in [this wilderness]3760-this wilderness ; yet were it a deed of fame , and would bring about a day of joy , might [we]3749-they find [[our]3749-they friends]1870-our friends again , and knit up the links of the fellowship once more . But [thou]3757-thou the wise and valiant ! belike [thou]3757-thou hast in thine head some device whereby this might be set about . [Birdalone]108-birdalone said : Simple is [my]0-i device , to wit , that [we]3749-they ask one who is wiser than [I.]0-i Let [us]3749-they tarry not , but go tomorrow and see [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife and talk with [her]559-the wood - wife concerning it . Then [she]108-birdalone smiled upon [him]150-arthur and said : But when [thou]3757-thou seest [her]559-the wood - wife , wilt [thou]3757-thou be aghast if [she]559-the wood - wife come before [us]3749-they in [my]0-i shape of what [I]0-i was five years agone , or six ? Nay , nay , [he]150-arthur said , [thou]3757-thou art not so terrible as that ; not very far do [I]0-i run from [thee]3757-thou now . And therewith [they]3749-they kissed and embraced , and so entered [the House of Love]3702-the house of love . Chapter XXX ~ [They]3749-they Have Speech with [Habundia]97-habundia Concerning [the Green Knight]1341-the green knight and [[His]1341-the green knight Fellows]4821-his fellows When the morrow was [they]3749-they arose and went [their]3749-they ways toward [the wood]335-the wood , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone in [[her]108-birdalone hunter]3767-her hunter â€™s coat , quiver at back and bow in hand . [They]3749-they came to [the Oak of Tryst]11-the oak of tryst , and [Birdalone]108-birdalone was at point to call on [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife by the burning of a hair of [hers]108-birdalone , when [she]108-birdalone came lightly from out the thicket , clad as [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and [her]108-birdalone very image . [She]108-birdalone stood before [them]3749-they with a glad countenance , and said : Welcome to [the seekers]3769-the seekers and [finders]3770-finders . But [Arthur]150-arthur stepped forth and knelt before [her]108-birdalone , and took [her]108-birdalone right hand and kissed it , and said : Here [I]0-i swear allegiance to [thee]108-birdalone , [O Lady of [the Woods]82-the woods]3771-o lady of the woods , to do [thy]108-birdalone will in all things , and give [thee]108-birdalone thanks from [my]0-i heart more than [my]0-i tongue can say . Quoth [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife : [I]0-i take thine allegiance , [fair young man]3773-fair young man , and [mine]0-i help shalt [thou]108-birdalone have henceforward . Then [she]108-birdalone smiled and [her]108-birdalone eyes danced for merriment , and [she]108-birdalone said : Yet [thy]108-birdalone thanks [meseemeth]3774-meseemeth for this while are more due to [the wise carline who brought [thee]108-birdalone through [the woods]450-the woods two days ago , and only left [thee]108-birdalone when the way was easy and clear to [thee]108-birdalone]3775-the wise carline who brought thee through the woods two days ago , and only left thee when the way was easy and clear to thee . [Lady]493-lady , said [Arthur]150-arthur , [I]0-i know now how great is [thy]108-birdalone might , and that [thou]108-birdalone canst take more shapes than this only ; and humbly [I]0-i thank [thee]108-birdalone that for [us]3778-us [thou]108-birdalone hast taken the shape that [I]0-i love the best of all on [the earth]432-the earth . Said [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife : Stand up , [Black Squire]119-arthur , and consider a little what [thou]108-birdalone wouldst have [me]0-i do for [thee]108-birdalone , while [I]0-i have speech with [mine]0-i image yonder . And therewith [she]559-the wood - wife came up to [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and drew [her]108-birdalone a little apart , and fell to stroking [her]108-birdalone cheeks and patting [her]108-birdalone hands and diversely caressing [her]108-birdalone , and [she]559-the wood - wife said to [her]108-birdalone : How now , [[my]0-i child]907-my child , have [I]0-i done for [thee]108-birdalone what [I]0-i promised , and art [thou]108-birdalone wholly happy now ? O yea , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; if nought else befell [us]3782-us in this life but to dwell together betwixt [the woodland]657-the woodland and [the water]347-the water , and to see [thee]108-birdalone oft , full happy should [we]3782-us be . Nevertheless , said [Habundia]97-habundia , art [thou]108-birdalone not come hither to ask somewhat of [me]0-i , that [ye]108-birdalone may be happier ? So it is , [wise mother]3785-wise mother , said [Birdalone]108-birdalone ; grudge not against [me]0-i therefor , for more than one thing drives [me]0-i thereto . [I]0-i will not grudge , said [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife ; but now [I]0-i will ask [[thy]0-i mate]3503-thy mate if [he]3503-thy mate has thought what it is that [he]3503-thy mate will have of [me]0-i . And [she]559-the wood - wife turned to [Arthur]119-arthur , who came forth and said : [Lady]493-lady , [I]0-i have heard [thee]559-the wood - wife , and herein would [we]3789-us have [thee]559-the wood - wife help [us]3789-us : There were erst [six fellows of [us]3789-us]3790-six fellows of us , [three caries and three queans , to whom was added this sweetling here]3791-three caries and three queans , to whom was added this sweetling here ; but one of [them]3790-six fellows of us , to wit [the Golden Knight]1811-the golden knight , was slain , and for the rest . . . [Yea]3793-ye , [I]0-i know , said [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife ; [[my]0-i child]907-my child here hath told [me]0-i all ; and now [ye]3793-ye wot not where [they]3790-six fellows of us are or if [they]3790-six fellows of us be yet alive , all or any of [them]3790-six fellows of us . Now is it not so that [ye]3793-ye would seek [these friends]3796-these friends , if it were but to greet [them]3796-these friends but once , and that [ye]3793-ye would ask of [the wise wood - wife]3797-the wise wood - wife help to find [them]3796-these friends ? Is there any more of the tale ? Nay , [lady]493-lady , said [Arthur]119-arthur . Said [she]559-the wood - wife : Well then , that help shall [ye]3793-ye have , were it but for the sake of that little Viridis whereof [[my]0-i child]907-my child hath told [me]0-i . Wherefore abide tidings of [me]0-i for a fourteen days , and seek not to [me]0-i ere then ; and [meantime]3800-meantime fear not , nor doubt [me]0-i , for many messengers [I]0-i have , and ever may [I]0-i do somewhat if the end of the tale is to be told in [these woodlands]3801-these woodlands : and [I]0-i deem [these friends]3796-these friends will not be hard to draw hither , for it is most like that [they]3796-these friends be thinking of [you]3793-ye and longing for [you]3793-ye , as [ye]3793-ye for [them]3796-these friends . And now [I]0-i will depart on [my]0-i business , which is [yours]3793-ye , and do [ye]3793-ye be happy today in [the woodland]657-the woodland , and tomorrow in [the meadows]1769-the meadows and by [the water]347-the water ; and let no trouble weigh down [your]3793-ye happy days . Therewith [she]0-i flitted away from [them]3796-these friends , when [she]0-i had kissed [them]3796-these friends both . But when [she]0-i was gone [they]3796-these friends fared away together deep into [the wood]335-the wood , and were exceeding merry disporting [them]3796-these friends , and on [their]3796-these friends return [they]3796-these friends gat [them]3796-these friends venison for [their]3796-these friends meat , and so came back to [the House of Love]3702-the house of love when the moon was up and shining brightly . Chapter XXXI ~ Habundia Cometh with Tidings of [Those Dear Friends]106-new friends Wore the days thenceforth merrily ; and one day it was delight in [the wide meads]3808-the wide meads , and another [they]3796-these friends went a long way west along [the water - side]351-the water - side , and so into [another meadow - plain]3810-another meadow - plain , smaller than [[their]3796-these friends home]3811-their home â€” plain , which [Birdalone]108-birdalone had never erst come into ; and [three eyots]3812-three eyots lay off [it]3810-another meadow - plain , green and tree - beset , whereto [they]3796-these friends swam out together . Then [they]3796-these friends went into [the wood]335-the wood thereby in the heat of the afternoon , and so wore the day , that [they]3796-these friends deemed [themselves]3796-these friends belated , and lay there under a thorn - bush the night through . Another day [Birdalone]108-birdalone took [[her]108-birdalone mate]3814-her mate over on to [Green Eyot]6-green eyot and [Rock Eyot]7-rock eyot , and showed [him]3814-her mate [all the places [she]108-birdalone was used to haunt]3815-all the places she was used to haunt . And [they]3796-these friends had [their]3796-these friends fishing - gear with [them]3796-these friends , and angled off [the eyots]3816-the eyots a good part of the day , and had good catch , and swam back therewith merrily . And [Birdalone]108-birdalone laughed , and said that it seemed to [her]108-birdalone as if once again [she]108-birdalone were ransoming [her]108-birdalone skin of [the witch - wife]336-the witch - wife by that noble catch . Divers times also [they]3796-these friends fared into [the wood]335-the wood , and thrice [they]3796-these friends lay out the night there in [some woodlawn where was water]3819-some woodlawn where was water ; and on one of these times it happed that [Arthur]119-arthur awoke in the grey dawn , and lay open - eyed but not moving for a little ; and therewith [he]119-arthur deemed [he]119-arthur saw the gleam of war - gear in the thicket . So [he]119-arthur kept as still as [he]119-arthur might , but gat [his]119-arthur sword out of its sheath without noise , and then leapt up suddenly , and sprang thitherward whereas [he]119-arthur had seen that token , and again saw armour gleam and heard [some man crashing through the underwood]3820-some man crashing through the underwood , for all was gone in one moment . So [he]119-arthur woke up [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and [they]3796-these friends bended [their]3796-these friends bows both of [them]3796-these friends , and searched the thicket thereabouts heedfully , arrow on string , but found nought fiercer than a great sow and [her]3821-her farrow . So came the full day , and [they]3796-these friends gat [them]3796-these friends back to [[their]3796-these friends meadows]3822-their meadows and [[their]3796-these friends house]1698-their house ; but thereafter were [they]3796-these friends warier in going about [the woodland]657-the woodland . In all joyance then wore the days till the fifteenth , and in the morning early [they]3796-these friends went [their]3796-these friends ways to [the Oak of [Tryst]74-tryst]11-the oak of tryst , and had no need to call [Habundia]97-habundia to [them]3796-these friends , for presently [she]108-birdalone came forth out of the thicket , with [her]108-birdalone gown gathered up into [her]108-birdalone girdle and bow in hand . But [she]108-birdalone cast it down and ran up to [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and kissed [her]108-birdalone and clipped [her]108-birdalone , and then [she]108-birdalone took a hand of [Arthur]119-arthur and a hand of [Birdalone]108-birdalone , and held [them]3825-them both and said : [[My]0-i child]907-my child , and [[thou]3827-thou [dear knight]3829-dear knight]3828-thou dear knight , have [ye]3829-dear knight still a longing to fall in with [those friends of yours]3830-those friends of yours , and to run all risk of whatsoever contention and strife there may be betwixt [you]3829-dear knight thereafter ? [Yea]3831-yea , certes , said [Arthur]119-arthur ; and even so said [Birdalone]108-birdalone . Well is that then , said [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife ; but now and for this time , ere [I]0-i help [you]3829-dear knight , [I]0-i shall put a price upon [my]0-i help , and this is the price , that [ye]3829-dear knight swear to [me]0-i never wholly to sunder from [me]0-i ; that once in the year at least , as long as [ye]3829-dear knight be alive and wayworthy , [ye]3829-dear knight come into [the Forest of Evilshaw]83-the forest of evilshaw , and summon [me]0-i by the burning of a hair of [mine]0-i , that [we]3833-we may meet and be merry for a while , and part with the hope of meeting once more at least . And if [ye]3829-dear knight will not pay the price , go in peace , and [ye]3829-dear knight shall yet have [my]0-i help in all other matters that may seem good unto [you]3829-dear knight , but not in this of joining [your]3829-dear knight fellowship together . How sayest [thou]3834-your , [Birdalone]108-birdalone , [[my]0-i child]907-my child ? How sayest [thou]3834-your , [Black Squire]119-arthur , whom , as [meseemeth]3836-meseemeth , [I]0-i have delivered from a fate worse than death , and have brought out of wretchedness into bliss ? [Spake Birdalone]110-birdalone : Had [I]0-i dared , [I]0-i would have bidden [thee]3834-your to swear to [me]0-i even such an oath , to wit , that [thou]3834-your wouldst never wholly sunder [thee]3834-your from [me]0-i . How then may [I]0-i not swear this that [thou]3834-your biddest [me]0-i , and that with all joy and trustiness ? [Spake Arthur]195-spake arthur : [Lady]493-lady , had [I]0-i no will to swear oath for [thy]3834-your sake , yet with a good will would [I]0-i swear it for [my]0-i true - love â€™s sake who loveth [thee]3834-your . Yet verily of [mine]0-i own will would [I]0-i swear it joyfully , were it for nought else save to pleasure [thee]3834-your , who hast done so kindly by [me]0-i , and hath given [me]0-i back [my]0-i manhood and [my]0-i love , which else [I]0-i had miserably lost . Spake [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife : It is well again . Join hands then , and swear as [I]0-i have bidden [you]3834-your by the love [ye]3834-your bear each other . Even so [they]3834-your did , and then [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife kissed [them]3834-your both and said : Now do [I]0-i deem [you]3834-your [earth â€™s very children]3840-earth â€™s very children and [mine]0-i , and this desire of [yours]3834-your is good , and it shall be done if [I]0-i may bring it about ; yet therein the valiance and wisdom of [you]3834-your both may well be tried . For this have [I]0-i found out by [[my]0-i messengers]3841-my messengers and [others]4825-others , that [[your]3834-your friends]3843-your friends are alive , [all of [them]3843-your friends]2381-all of them ; and [they]3843-your friends have thought of [you]3834-your in [their]3843-your friends inmost hearts , and have long determined that [they]3843-your friends must needs go seek [you]3834-your if [they]3843-your friends are to live lives happy and worthy . Furthermore , [their]3843-your friends quest hath drawn [them]3843-your friends hither to [Evilshaw]89-evilshaw ( nor say [I]0-i that [I]0-i have been nothing therein ) , and [they]3843-your friends are even now in [the wood]335-the wood . But [ye]3834-your shall know that peril encompasses [them]3843-your friends ; for [they]3843-your friends fare but a few , and of those few be there [two traitors who are minded to deliver [them]3843-your friends to [the men of [the Red Company]3848-the red company]3847-the men of the red company , unto whom three women as fair as [[your]3834-your she - friends]3849-your she - friends]3846-two traitors who are minded to deliver them to the men of the red company , unto whom three women as fair as your she - friends were a prize indeed . Wherefore [the Red Folk]3850-the red folk are dogging [them]3843-your friends , and will fall upon [them]3843-your friends when [they]3843-your friends find the occasion . But [I]0-i shall see to it that the occasion shall be in time and place where [they]3843-your friends shall not be unholpen . Now what [ye]3834-your have to do for [your]3834-your parts , is to waylay [the waylayers]3851-the waylayers , and keep watch and ward anigh the road [they]3843-your friends must needs take , and to fall on when need is . But this again [I]0-i shall see to , that [your]3834-your onset fail not . But now [ye]3834-your may say : Since [thou]3852-thou art mighty , why shouldst not [thou]3852-thou [thyself]3852-thou take [[our]3853-our friends]1870-our friends out of the hands of [these accursed]3855-these accursed , as [thou]3852-thou couldst well do , and [we]3853-our to take no part therein ?
