Chapter IV ~ Of the Abiding in [Utterhay]1-utterhay in Love and Contentment Now when seven days were worn , [the mayor]4255-the mayor made a great feast at [[his]4255-the mayor house]1399-his house , and thither were bidden all [the men of the porte and other worthies]4308-the men of the porte and other worthies , and [great merchants who had come into [[their]4292-our town]4310-their town]4309-great merchants who had come into their town ; and the said feast was given in honour of [these new - comers]4311-these new - comers , and that day [they]4311-these new - comers sat on the dais , and [all the guests]4312-all the guests worshipped [them]4311-these new - comers and wondered at [their]4311-these new - comers beauty ; and nought was spoken of for many days save the glory and hope that there was in [this lovely folk]4313-this lovely folk . But the next day after the feast were [they]4311-these new - comers brought to [[their]4311-these new - comers house]1698-their house in all triumph ; and it was as fair as might be thought of , and there [they]4311-these new - comers dwelt a while in rest and peace , and great recourse there was there of [Gerard]173-gerard and [[his]173-gerard sons]3034-his sons . But ere the winter was over , were [Hugh]118-hugh and [Arthur]150-arthur and [Gerard]173-gerard and [[his]173-gerard sons]3034-his sons taken to [the freedom of [Utterhay]1-utterhay]4317-the freedom of utterhay ; and thereafter spake [the chief men of the porte]4318-the chief men of the porte and [the masters of the crafts]4319-the masters of the crafts unto [the two knights]5960-the two knights by the mouth of [the mayor]4255-the mayor ; and [he]173-gerard told [them]4311-these new - comers , what already [they]4311-these new - comers partly knew , that [the good town]3003-the good town had of late gotten [many enemies]4323-many enemies , whereas [it]3003-the good town was wealthy and not very strong , and that now [two such warriors]4324-two such warriors having come amongst [them]3003-the good town , [they]4311-these new - comers were minded to strengthen [themselves]4311-these new - comers , if only [they]4311-these new - comers two would of [their]4311-these new - comers gentleness and meekness become [their]4311-these new - comers war - dukes to lead [them]4311-these new - comers against [the foemen]4325-the foemen . But [the two friends]4326-the two friends answered that it was well [their]4311-these new - comers will to dwell [there]215-there neighbourly , and do [them]4311-these new - comers all the help [they]4311-these new - comers might , and that [they]4311-these new - comers would not gainsay the worship [they]4311-these new - comers offered [them]4311-these new - comers nor the work that should go with it . With that answer were [all men]212-all men well content and more : and then [the mayor]4255-the mayor said that the mind of [the porte]4249-the porte it was to strengthen the walls and the gates , and to build [a good and fair castle]4331-a good and fair castle , meet for [any earl]4332-any earl , joining on to the wall by the face that looked west , that is to say , on to [Evilshaw]89-evilshaw ; and that liked [the war - dukes]4333-the war - dukes well . So when spring came it was set about , but it was five years adoing , and before it was all finished [the war - dukes]4333-the war - dukes entered into it , and dwelt [there]215-there with [[their]4333-the war - dukes wives]4336-their wives and [[their]4333-the war - dukes friends]2925-their friends in all honour . And a little thereafter , whether [they]4311-these new - comers would or no , [the men of [Utterhay]1-utterhay]4338-the men of utterhay had to handle weapons and fare afield to meet the foe with [the valiant men of the crafts]4339-the valiant men of the crafts , and what of waged [men]204-men [they]4311-these new - comers might get . And well and valiantly were [they]4311-these new - comers led by [[their]4311-these new - comers dukes]4341-their dukes , and [they]4311-these new - comers came to [[their]4311-these new - comers abode]4342-their abode , and gained both wealth and honour thereby ; and from that time forward began the increase of [Utterhay]1-utterhay under [those two captains]4343-those two captains , who were unto [them]4311-these new - comers as in old time [the consuls]4344-the consuls had been unto [the Roman folk]4345-the roman folk , save that [they]4343-those two captains changed [them]4345-the roman folk not year by year as [the Romans were wo nt]4346-the romans were wo nt . So wore the days , and [all those friends]4347-all those friends dwelt together in harmony and joy ; though the wearing of time wrought changes amongst [them]4347-all those friends . For [Robert Gerardson]174-robert began in no long while to look on [Aurea]107-aurea with eyes of love ; and at last [he]174-robert came to [Birdalone]108-birdalone and craved [her]108-birdalone leave to woo [the said lady]4348-the said lady , and [she]108-birdalone granted it with a good will , and was fain thereof , whereas [she]108-birdalone saw that [Aurea]107-aurea sorely lacked [a mate]4349-a mate ; and scarce might [she]108-birdalone have a better than was [Robert]174-robert ; so in process of time [they]4350-they two were wedded and dwelt together happily . [Forsooth Birdalone]108-birdalone had been fainer yet might [she]108-birdalone have seen [Giles Gerardson]175-giles gerardson and [Atra]109-atra drawn together . But though [they]4350-they were [dear friends]1316-dear friends and there was much converse betwixt [them]4350-they , this betid not , so far as [we]4352-we have heard . [The old Gerard]4353-the old gerard dwelt happily amongst [them]4350-they all for fifteen years after [they]4350-they had come to [Utterhay]1-utterhay , and then fell asleep , [a very old man]4354-a very old man . As to [the wood of]4355-the wood of [Evilshaw]89-evilshaw , it was not once a year only that [Birdalone]108-birdalone and [Arthur]150-arthur sought thither and met [the wood - mother]925-the wood - mother , but a half - score of times or more , might be , in the year â€™s circle ; and ever was [she]925-the wood - mother kind and loving with [them]4350-they , and [they]4350-they with [her]925-the wood - mother . But of [all those fellows]4357-all those fellows it was [Atra]109-atra that had longest dealings with [the wood - wife]559-the wood - wife ; for whiles would [she]109-atra leave [Utterhay]1-utterhay and [[her]109-atra friends]1305-her friends and fare lonesome up into [Evilshaw]2-evilshaw , and find [Habundia]97-habundia and abide with [her]109-atra in all kindness holden for a month or more . And ever a little before these departures betid would [she]109-atra fall moody and few - spoken , but [she]109-atra came back ever from [the wood]335-the wood calm and kind and well - liking . Amidst all these comings and goings somewhat wore off the terror of [Evilshaw]89-evilshaw ; yet never was it accounted other than a daring deed to enter [it]89-evilshaw alone without fellowship ; and [most]4361-most had liefer that [some man of religion]4362-some man of religion were of [[their]4361-most company]5025-their company therein , or [they]4361-most would bear about [them]4361-most something holy or blessed to hold the evil things . Now when all this hath been said , [we]4364-we have no more to tell about [this company of friends]4365-this company of friends , [the most of whom had once haunted [the lands about the Water of the Wondrous Isles]4367-the lands about the water of the wondrous isles]4366-the most of whom had once haunted the lands about the water of the wondrous isles , save that [their]4366-the most of whom had once haunted the lands about the water of the wondrous isles love never sundered , and that [they]4366-the most of whom had once haunted the lands about the water of the wondrous isles lived without shame and died without fear . So here is an end .
